webTitle: From: Pauline Grimshaw (19 Dec)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Pauline Grimshaw
fields.trailText: Hope you continue to enjoy India and I will look forward to reading your diaries. When you get to Nepal, look out for the numerous excellent bakeries in Kathmandu; we always enjoyed them after a period of travelling in India.
fields.body:
Hi Sue,

Have just read about your trip and in particular your arrival in India which I can certainly identify with. My first experience of India was Bombay (and it was Bombay then) and my reaction was similiar to yours; however, it didn't take me long to fall in love with India and I look forward to returning sometime. I did go on an Imaginative Traveller trip to Bhutan and Nepal that started in Calcutta, which was one of the best holidays ever (we had a wonderful tour leader who kept us in stitches most of the time). Anyway, I was going to suggest drinking lassi with meals as lots of people swear they keep tummy bugs at bay but you have already discovered them. I'm not sure if they work but I've been lucky so far! Hope you continue to enjoy India and I will look forward to reading your diaries. When you get to Nepal look out for the numerous excellent bakeries in Kathmandu; we always enjoyed them after a period of travelling in India.

Best wishes and stay healthy.

webTitle: Charities and businesses need strategic partnerships

fields.headline: Charities and businesses need strategic partnerships
fields.trailText: British business is becoming more and more professional in just about every aspect of corporate life and the way large companies deal with requests to support charities is no exception, writes Ros Luckman
fields.body:
British business is becoming more and more professional in just about every aspect of corporate life and the way large companies deal with requests to support charities is no exception.

It is no longer the case that companies will give thousands of pounds at the whim of the chairman's wife or send a cheque by return of post. Today, corporations are entering into strategic alliances with charity partners and devising cause-related marketing initiatives with the third sector.

My own organisation, The Co-operative Bank, assesses requests for donations in order to ensure that any support makes the greatest possible impact on society. That does not mean we are looking at ways in which to avoid giving to good causes, or that we never support small groups who just need a financial hand up.

However, we want to be sure that the money or other resources we give make the best possible impact. It is no use to anyone if any money given fails to achieve the purpose for which it was intended. In the past many companies saw the cheque presentation as the end of the process but that is no longer the case.

More and more businesses are also realising that a cash hand-out is not always the best answer. Many organisations have skills and expertise that a charity needs but it would be prohibitively expensive for it to buy them in. At the same time, companies appreciate that giving staff an opportunity to work in a community situation can be morale boosting and a very effective way of retaining highly trained and qualified personnel.

So what does all this mean for the professional fundraiser? Many large charities have grasped the importance of strategic partnerships and the "business plan" approach but many medium and smaller groups are still writing the "begging letter" to large companies, with decreasing success.

It is important that all those involved in soliciting funds from companies understand the new culture and respond accordingly because in the future any proposition will have to demonstrate what impact the donation will have on the work of the good cause and be able to measure the success.

It is a development that should be looked upon positively by all those involved in fundraising. It is only common sense that charities want to forge long-term relationships with corporate organisations and this can only be done if all parties feel they are fulfilling their objectives. A challenge - but one I am sure charities will rise to.

webTitle: Charities demand funding security

fields.headline: Charities demand funding security
fields.trailText: Charities have called on the government to make sure that the flow of lottery funding to good causes is not interrupted by legal wrangling over today's decision to renew the licence of national lottery operator Camelot. By Guy Campos
fields.body:
Charities have called on the government to make sure that the flow of lottery funding to good causes is not interrupted by legal wrangling over today's decision to renew the licence of national lottery operator Camelot.

Charity representatives made the appeal to safeguard a stream of lottery funding which has become increasingly important as individual giving has declined during the 1990s.

Before today's decision was announced, The People's Lottery, the rival consortium backed by businessman Richard Branson, refused to rule out a legal challenge if the decision went against it.

However, a spokesman for the National Council for Voluntary Organisations said: "It is vitally important that the delays in the appointment of Camelot will not be allowed in any way to delay the continuation of the welcome stream of income to the charitable sector that comes from the lottery."

Lottery experts have suggested that fear of disruption to the flow of income to charities may have been a significant influence on the decision to retain the existing operator Camelot.

Barbara Bloomfield, editor of the Lottery Monitor newsletter, said: "We now know we are not going to have any delays in funding as a result of the handover as Camelot will in effect be handing over to itself at the end of its current licence. The only spanner in the works could be if a judicial review decides that The People's Lottery has been badly done by."

The People's Lottery had promised to hand over a greater proportion of lottery income to good causes, while raising the same amount of money from lottery ticket sales overall. However, Bloomfield suggested that the sales forecasts of both sides were too speculative to be relied upon.

Charities in general have been reluctant to back either of the bidders for the licence to run the lottery.

A spokeswoman for the Charities Aid Foundation (CAF) said: "We never came down on one side or the other on the question of whether the operator should be for-profit or not-for-profit. The most important thing is that the lottery should be run efficiently."

A spokeswoman for the NSPCC, which has received around £1.75m in lottery funding, said: "The NSPCC believes that Camelot and the National Lottery Charities Board have exercised their responsibilities well and remain sensitive to the competing needs within the sector."

A spokeswoman for the Cancer Research Campaign, which claims that the £1m in lottery funding it has received over the first seven years of the national lottery is "a pitiful amount", said: "We hope that the second time round Camelot will listen to the great British public and dole out more money to good causes, especially medical research."

webTitle: Economic growth hampers regeneration

fields.headline: Economic growth hampers regeneration
fields.standfirst: A growing economy and buoyant labour market is often at odds with the regeneration of deprived neighbourhoods, writes David Blackman
fields.trailText: A growing economy and buoyant labour market is often at odds with the regeneration of deprived neighbourhoods, writes David Blackman.
fields.body:
It seems a simple enough equation. Bring economic growth to a rundown urban area and regeneration will follow.

But the reality can be starkly different, say those working in Britain's most deprived neighbourhoods. In such circumstances, there is often a tension between jobs and urban regeneration.

One person with first-hand experience of this surprising phenomenon is Richard Kemp, member for housing and regeneration in the cabinet at Liberal Democrat-controlled Liverpool council, one of the European Union's most deprived areas.

"I've seen examples where, after single regeneration budget programmes have finished, the socio-economic indices are as bad at the end as they were at the beginning," said Mr Kemp, who spent nearly two decades working in urban regeneration before becoming a full-time councillor last year.

The problem is that once individuals get well-paid jobs, they tend to flee the rundown areas where they have been living.

Those taking over these properties are often attempting to emulate the previous tenants' escape from unemployment. The temptation to leave is greatest in those parts of the country, such as the poorer parts of large northern cities, where people are able to pick and choose their accommodation because housing supply exceeds demand. Such problems are most acute in the very cities most desperate for regeneration.

Tom Mannion, chief executive of north-west-based Irwell Housing Association, agrees with this analysis. He said: "We would strike local labour deals and then those nine or 10 people would up sticks and we would end up with similar levels of unemployment."

This problem has worsened in recent years as the benefits of a growing economy, in terms of a more buoyant labour market, have spread to even the economically depressed parts of the UK.

Nobody argues that the answer is to keep the poor on the breadline so that deprived areas remain well populated. "Long-term regeneration is dependant on economic growth," said Peter Stott, managing director of Home housing association, one of the biggest social landlords in the north of England.

Chris Brown, head of Ician, the urban regeneration arm of Amec Developments, said the key is to create attractive neighbourhoods that people will want to live in.

"People should have the opportunity to choose where they want to live. We want to make sure that when people exercise that choice they will choose urban areas," he said.

Many were hoping that last month's urban white paper, trailed as the government's programme for arresting the decline of England's towns and cities, would offer concrete assistance to tackle the issue. But the white paper ducks the issue, according to Merron Simpson, policy officer at the Chartered Institute of Housing. "We are finding that economic growth isn't filtering down to the most rundown areas. It's a problem that the government hasn't really picked up in the white paper," she said.

In the long term, the government's drive to throttle greenfield housing development will encourage developers to invest in towns and cities, as they are already doing in places such as Manchester and Leeds city centre.

But such remedies will not arrive soon enough to rescue areas such as Langworthy in Salford, which are caught in a vicious downward spiral of decline. For the north-west branch of housing association umbrella body, the National Housing Federation, the issue is especially pressing.

It has come up with proposals for a fund to radically restructure the housing market in areas where demand has collapsed.

In a report, due to be issued early in the new year, the federation's northern branch will say that in some unpopular neighbourhoods, empty housing should be demolished. This would include certain types of housing, such as pre-First World War terraced housing, for which little demand exists in the former mill towns of the north-west .

Home's Mr Stott said his association is working on a range of initiatives to bring neighbourhoods up to scratch. These include selective demolition in places such as the former mining village of Tow Law in County Durham.

"The alternative is to allow neighbourhoods to become more run down and uncared for," he said. It is "far better", Mr Stott said, to tear down homes than allow them to remain boarded up. In the long term, such an approach will create a more viable neighbourhood, he argued.

But to carry out such radical initiatives, councils say they need stronger compulsory purchase powers, to buy and clear unpopular private housing. So far the government has moved slowly on the issue of compulsory purchase orders, failing to adopt the urban task force's recommendation for special powers to assist regeneration. But Irwell Valley's Mr Mannion is suspicious about what he sees as superficially attractive initiatives, like using public money to restructure local housing markets.

The kind of housing rated as ripe for demolition in the north-west fetches hundreds of thousands of pounds in London's more prosperous neighbourhoods, he pointed out. He instead believes it is important to manage existing properties better, such as by cracking down on anti-social tenants and rewarding those who pay their rent on time by offering them a better standard of service.

The proof of the pudding, he said, is that tenants are much less likely now to leave Irwell Valley's properties when they can afford to. The association currently only has around 40 empty properties out of a stock of more than 7,000 in the north-west, the area where social landlords find properties hardest to let.

Kemp agreed, adding that it is also important to improve overall public services, such as litter cleaning. He said: "There are two things that work, improving crime and anti-social behaviour and the environment. If you get those two right you give yourself a breathing space."

The recent announcement by the Housing Corporation that it is setting up five housing regeneration companies with powers to manage whole neighbourhoods has been welcomed as a step in the right direction.

Housing providers will be hoping that the national strategy for neighbourhood renewal, due to be published next month, will come up with some firm ideas about how economic growth can better promote urban regeneration.

webTitle: Overhaul in research grant policies needed to improve prospects for women

fields.headline: Overhaul in research grant policies needed to improve prospects for women
fields.trailText: A fundamental overhaul of the funding practices of the main bodies funding academic research projects as well as employment policies in universities is needed to improve the career prospects for women academics, a report concludes today.
fields.body:
A fundamental overhaul of the funding practices of the main bodies funding academic research projects as well as employment policies in universities is needed to improve the career prospects for women academics, a report concludes today.

The long awaited conclusions of a survey of grant applications among male and female researchers by the Wellcome Trust and research councils concludes that there is no evidence of direct gender discrimination in the allocation of research funding.

However, the 'deep-rooted nature' of some of the factors making women apply for fewer grants, such as the increased likelihood of being on short term junior positions, means that reforms are needed "to ensure a more equitable distribution of research funding".

Wellcome and the research councils commissioned the National Centre for Social Research to carry out a survey of academic staff. A total of 3090 academic staff drawn from 44 institutions took part in the survey, with a 40% response rate. The survey was commissioned after some suggestions that the mainly male academic referees deciding on research awards were biased against women academics. The survey explored whether there were gender differences in research funding applications activities and identified possible reasons behind these differences.

It found that 50% of women and 59% of men in the sample had applied for project research grants in the past five years.

And when women applied for funding, they were as successful as their male colleagues: 51% of female and 50% of male applicants had obtained half or more of the grants they had applied for.

Virtually no gender differences were found in applications for competitively awarded fellowships: 18% of women and 16% of men in the sample had applied for this type of funding.

The survey results also show that women were less likely than men to be eligible to apply for grants provided by all research councils and the Wellcome Trust, except for the Economic and Social Research Council.

Women are less likely to be eligible for grants because of their over-representation among lower grade academic staff and those with fixed-term contracts, as many of the grant schemes are not open to academic staff in these groups.

The main influences on grant application activities included: job seniority, employment status, tenure, type of institution, and professional profile of academics.

There was also a wide variation in the institutional support provided to researchers for funding applications.

A break from employment for family reasons in the previous ten years also seems to have a considerable negative influence on grant applications.

Grant applications were lower than average among women with dependent children - 50% had applied for grants compared with 62% of men with children.

webTitle: Peterborough's tales from the riverbank

fields.headline: Peterborough's tales from the riverbank
fields.standfirst: Simon Parker speaks to Peterborough council's head of economic and community development Alex Mackay about plans to regenerate the city's south bank area.
fields.trailText: Simon Parker speaks to Peterborough council's head of economic and community development Alex Mackay about plans to regenerate the city's south bank area.
fields.body:
Why did you decide to start the project? What problem was it created to solve?

The south bank is an attractive area next to the river Nene and close to the city centre. Redeveloping it ties in with our development plans for Peterborough - we're already doing a lot of work to the north of the city centre, so this project should balance that. We're hoping to create a mixed development that makes use of the city's facilities and gets people living near the centre. We want to change the way people look at the site.

How did you go about putting it together? How and by whom was it funded, and what partners did you have to get involved?

We've been trying to develop the site for around 10 years, but we've never been able to get developers interested in putting up enough money to make this kind of project feasible. We've been speaking with the Prince's Foundation - a charity that works to secure thoughtful and sustainable neighbourhood renewal - for around 18 months now. It is creating an urban framework plan - a broad statement of the vision we have for the site.

With the Prince's Foundation, we approached the East of England Development Agency (EEDA) for support. They've now been involved for around six months, and have encouraged us to look at the regional impact of what we're doing, how it will affect shopping and leisure in the eastern region. Collectively, we're called the Peterborough south bank partnership.

We're also hoping private developers will get involved - that's where the real money will probably come from. We plan to use public investment to rekindle their interest.

What did it cost?

We're putting up around £70,000, and EEDA is putting in £80,000. The money is being used to help the Prince's Foundation prepare studies on the site.

How long did it take?

We're only in the early stages of the project at present. Up till now, we've been relying too much on market forces to drive redevelopment, but it could take 10 or 20 years for that to happen. We're hoping this way will be quicker.

Is it working?

It's too early to say. We're only just about to interview consultants for the job. I could probably answer that question in six months from now.

What difficulties did you encounter?

It's a difficult site for a number of reasons. We have to put together land from five or six different owners. There are listed buildings on the site and some of the land is contaminated.

The river flooded in 1998, so we also face the challenge of making sure there's effective drainage on the site. We need to reach agreement with the environment agency about that; the agency is reviewing its policy after the recent flooding.

Would you recommend it to other authorities? Why?

I'd recommend this kind of approach, because it means we get a good deal of flexibility. With the Prince's Foundation we get access to an eclectic range of consultants, and the foundation brings a fresh view to the project.

Want to know more?
Email editor@societytheguardian.com

webTitle: Tesco smuggles in PlayStations

fields.headline: Tesco smuggles in PlayStations
fields.trailText: 3pm: Tesco has smuggled 2,500 Sony PlayStations into the country and will put them on sale tomorrow at five of its stores, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Tesco has managed to smuggle 2,500 Sony PlayStation 2 consoles into the country and will put them on sale at 2pm tomorrow at five of its stores.

The supermarket said it would sell the games for the recommended retail price of £299 at its stores in Watford, Peterborough, Cardiff, Newcastle and Inverness.

A spokesman said he expected the entire consignment to be sold "within the hour".

Sony is understood to be furious at the "grey market" imports of the console, which is its biggest launch in years. It will put out a statement at 3pm today.

The news is a massive PR coup for the UK's biggest supermarket because the consignment is the first to hit British stores since the console's launch last month.

The original UK quota of 165,000 consoles was snapped up immediately by consumers who had placed advance orders, leaving none for general sale in the run-up to Christmas.

Tesco believes it will be the only British retailer to have PS2 on the shelves before Christmas.

The store said the move was the result of a five-month operation to source the much-hyped hardware.

"We can't understand why Sony won't make such a popular toy available to consumers." said a spokesman.

"We've gone to great lengths to source these machines and our team is still working on the project in Europe. This could be the beginning of the dam breaking."

webTitle: Camelot wins lottery licence

fields.headline: Camelot wins lottery licence
fields.trailText: Camelot has won the licence to run the lottery for the next seven years.
fields.body:
Camelot has won the licence to run the lottery for the next seven years.

The verdict, released on the lottery commission's website at 4pm today, said Camelot, which has run the game since its launch in November 1994, won the licence by a 4-1 majority vote. One of the commissioners, Hilary Blume, resigned in protest at the announcement.

The commissioners will be hoping their decision will end months of wrangling, but Camelot's rival bidder, Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery, has not ruled out taking further legal action.

Shortly after the decision a disappointed Sir Richard said he was "sad and baffled" at his failure to secure the lottery. He said he considered the commissioners' reasons for their decisions "superficial".

The decision over the game's future had first been due in June but delays saw the deadline roll over through the summer until the commission announced in August that neither bid was up to scratch.

The commission, under former chairman Dame Helena Shovelton, had originally decided to exclude Camelot from playing any further part in the selection process.

Instead, it announced it would hold talks only with organisers of the People's Lottery to iron out shortcomings in their proposals.

Camelot took the matter to the high court where the commission's decision was overturned. Dame Helena resigned from her post in October to be replaced by former Treasury mandarin Lord Burns.

Sir Richard had claimed his bid would deliver "hundreds of millions of pounds" more for good causes.

"That is something I have been passionate about for many years and it is something I believe most people in the country would like to see happen," he said this morning.

fields.headline: Camelot wins lottery licence
fields.standfirst: Read the lottery commission decision
fields.trailText: Camelot has won the licence to run the lottery for the next seven years.
fields.body:
Camelot has won the licence to run the lottery for the next seven years.

The verdict, released on the lottery commission's website at 4pm today, said Camelot, which has run the game since its launch in November 1994, won the licence by a 4-1 majority vote. One of the commissioners, Hilary Blume, resigned in protest at the announcement.

In a statement the commission said that Camelot had won the licence because it was "on balance" likely to deliver more ticket sales. They were also concerned that the "accumulation of risks" involved with a change of operator was too great in the People's Lottery bid.

The commissioners will be hoping their decision will end months of wrangling, but Camelot's rival bidder, Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery, has not ruled out taking further legal action.

Shortly after the decision a disappointed Sir Richard said he was "sad and baffled" at his failure to secure the lottery. He said he considered the commissioners' reasons for their decisions "superficial".

"Four out of the five judges had voted for the People's Lottery only two and a half months ago. One new judge turns up and somehow manages to turn a number of them round," he said. He also took a swipe at the government and Lord Burns. "It was an election pledge and it's not being honoured and it's sad I think to see that one civil servant (Lord Burns) can be appointed to a commission and change things round so dramatically without speaking to us, without ever answering my phone calls."

The decision over the game's future had first been due in June but delays saw the deadline roll over through the summer until the commission announced in August that neither bid was up to scratch.

The commission, under former chairman Dame Helena Shovelton, had originally decided to exclude Camelot from playing any further part in the selection process.

Instead, it announced it would hold talks only with organisers of the People's Lottery to iron out shortcomings in their proposals.

Camelot took the matter to the high court where the commission's decision was overturned. Dame Helena resigned from her post in October to be replaced by former Treasury mandarin Lord Burns.

Sir Richard had claimed his bid would deliver "hundreds of millions of pounds" more for good causes.

"That is something I have been passionate about for many years and it is something I believe most people in the country would like to see happen," he said this morning.

webTitle: Social work on the web

fields.headline: Social work on the web
fields.standfirst: The borough of Kingston-upon-Thames has launched a new website which gives young people access to social work services via email. Linda Steele reports
fields.trailText: The borough of Kingston-upon-Thames has launched a new website which gives young people access to social work services via email. Linda Steele reports.
fields.body:
Are we ready for the web-enabled social worker? The royal borough of Kingston-upon-Thames, tucked away to the south-west of London, believes we are.

The children and families division of the borough's community services directorate has set up Young Livin', a help and advice website for youth in the area. The site gives young people access to a social work service, via site-based email.

Team manager Eion Rush, who leads the project, said: "We have been working to try and make our services more accessible to young people. Young people rarely refer themselves to social services. They come through police, school, GPs, parents - by which time the problems are likely to be fairly serious."

About a year ago, Mr Rush and administrator Linda Jackson set up a project at local Tolworth girls' school to find out what issues pupils would like advice and help about. The group also developed a poster, which has been used on the site's homepage, to inform their peers about their services.

During the course of the project, Mr Rush became aware of two things. First, that most children wouldn't dream of phoning up social services or walking into an area office for help. And second, that children were seeking help and advice via the internet - and not always with the best results.

One 12-year-old contacted a wrestling federation website for advice about how to cope with domestic violence in his family. He got an email telling him that he could join up and beat up his stepfather when he was 18.

Students at the school worked with Mr Rush and Ms Jackson to build the website, which they then piloted among their peers. The final version was launched earlier this month.

The site allows young people to email a "personal adviser" - a social worker by a less stigmatising name. "Everyone needs advice," Mr Rush pointed out.

Every one of the 19,000 young people in the borough has an email address through their school. Eight in 10 have internet access at school but they can also access the site from any linked computer, including in local libraries.

A young person wanting help can fill in a simple electronic (email) form on the site. This form is routed to one of two offices - depending on which area the young person ticks as their place of residence - where duty officers deal with it. Those staff will then follow them up as they would any other referral, although they will always reply by email to the young person - and sometimes advice is all that's needed.

Depending on the seriousness of the problem (and whether or not the person has ticked "urgent" on the email form), they can call a pupil out of school. To this end, they are planning to work closely with all schools in the borough, following the successful Tolworth pilot. A copy of every email also goes to a central account, where there are random checks to ensure that enquiries are being properly dealt with.

In the site's first week, there were 300 hundred hits. "It provides an accessible and confidential service to young people using a medium that they are entirely at ease with," said Margie Rooke, head of children and family services. There have also been three young people asking for help.

Social services are now working with 14-year-old Alice Jones (not her real name) who contacted the site because she was in fear of being physically abused by her father. "I was getting desperate and I knew there was no point in talking to my mum," she said. "I was too embarrassed to speak to anyone and felt ashamed. When I heard about the website at school assembly I thought I could tell someone without having to face them. I just sent it off."

"I hope that cases like Alice's show that we'll be able to intervene earlier," said Mr Rush.

A monitoring group of young people has been set up to review both the site and representative email from the social workers, to make sure that the responses hit the right tone. A by-product of the site is skills development for young people. Eighteen-year-old Malcolm Cannon, who, as an A-level work experience student, helped design and build the site, has been offered a web design job on the back of it.

Youth involvement is "definitely important", he said. "It's made by kids for kids. We feel that we know what information we want to find. Kids should enjoy it first. So, if me and the Tolworth girls liked it, we could assume others would. It's come from them and it's entirely what they wanted."

Malcolm and four girls from Tolworth launched the site in front of Kingston councillors. "We were being asked and the councillors could see that this was what the young people of Kingston wanted," he said. "It was definitely something a bit different for them."

webTitle: 'Leave me alone, go talk to Colin!'

fields.headline: 'Leave me alone, go talk to Colin!'
fields.standfirst:
Consensus breaks out amongst the Middle East editorials

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: You would not expect consensus on any issue in the Middle East, but there is surprising unanimity in the Israeli and Arab media on the importance of the latest diplomatic moves to rescue the ailing peace process.
fields.body:
You would not expect consensus on any issue in the Middle East, but there is surprising unanimity in the Israeli and Arab media on the importance of the latest diplomatic moves to rescue the ailing peace process.

Not all the leader-writers approve. The hawkish Jerusalem Post, for example, is scathing about the crippled government's attempt to resume a dialogue with the Palestinians: "Without knowing the exact details of the agreement being discussed, we already know three very dangerous things about it. First, it is being negotiated at a point of maximum weakness and under fire. Second, it is being negotiated by a government that can no longer claim to represent a majority of Israelis. Third, it is being negotiated by a leader with a massive conflict of interest between his political survival and the need to be able to walk away from a bad agreement."

For commentator Yoel Marcus, writing in the more liberal daily Ha'aretz, the reappearance of Binyamin Netanyahu on the nationalpolitical stage is a welcome development - though not in a sense that he will appreciate: "In weekend interviews, he offered his 'let the IDF win' solutions - restore Israel's deterrent capability, employ all the means at the IDF's disposal to hit Palestinian Authority Chairman Yasser Arafat and his supporters where it hurts, make sure they feel the blows 'personally,' even if it means the collapse of Arafat's regime. In addition, counsels Netanyahu, Israel should stop running after Arafat just to obtain his signature on a piece of paper. 'Time is working in our favor,' he assures us. Israelis have never heard such an accursed phrase since the time of prime minister Golda Meir, on the eve of the 1973 Yom Kippur War."

In the latest edition of the fortnightly news magazine Jerusalem Report, Ehud Ya'ari is less concerned with the looming election than with the one just past in America. He warns leaders that George W. Bush will be a good deal less interested than Bill Clinton in the Middle East peace process: "Bush wants to concentrate on tax reform, which would require at least six months of wrestling with Congress. One might assume that he would not be overly keen to receive Israel's prime minister, whoever that may be, in the near future. Nor would he go out of his way to meet any of the Arab leaders, including Arafat himself. There's no mistaking the signals coming out of Austin, Texas, that read: Leave me alone, go talk to Colin! [the new US secretary of state Colin Powell]."

The excellent pan-Arab site Arabia.com reports the deep scepticism among Palestinians about the ongoing diplomatic effort to revive the peace process. It also carries an indignant open letter to President Clinton from the formidable Palestinian intellectual Hanan Ashraw. She urges Mr Clinton to make a post-presidential penitential visit to the region - essentially, to apologise to the Palestinians: "These are the same people to whom you promised 'freedom,' 'dignity,' and the fulfillment of their 'political rights,' but who are now languishing in collective incarceration, in abject humiliation, and in total deprivation. These are the people, Mr. President, on whom you are now calling to 'stop the violence' while their lives, rights, lands, and very humanity are being systematically violated. These are the people whose entire security, in every aspect, was totally annihilated while you are pursuing the guaranteed security of their Israeli occupiers."

In the United Arab Emirates, the Khaleej Times also has some advice for US leaders: to abandon their role as the sole arbiters of peace moves in the region. The editorial suggests one reason for American fallibility: "It is now evident that if a genuine peace process is to succeed, the process has to have more than one referee. The Americans may have been successful in kickstarting the peace process. But it would have been good for their credibility and for the peace process itself to allow France and Russia a role in the process. By doing so, the Clinton administration could have shaken off the powerful American Jewish lobby from its back and let the logic of reason prevail over the logic of force."

The Jordan Times professes a cautious optimism over the latest diplomatic moves. It believes that Israel has signalled its willingness to make further concessions on key issues, including Jerusalem and the right of return of Palestinian refugees. The editorial goes on: "The second consideration that is making us hopeful that the currently deadly deadlock in peace negotiations might be broken within the next few weeks, is that Barak seems to finally be fully aware that he is going to be defeated in the February elections, unless he achieves serious progress with the Palestinians and has something to show for himself to his constituency."

webTitle: Stirring up trouble

fields.headline: Stirring up trouble
fields.standfirst:
Both sides stand accused of playing politics with the murderous cruelties of disaffected young men on council estates

Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Both sides stand accused of playing politics with the murderous cruelties of disaffected young men on council estates.
fields.body:
Playing the race card is a phrase we understand. It's a dangerous thing for a politician to do, risking social cohesion for the sake of political advantage. In its common meaning it is always anti-black and/or anti-Asian, and usually involves a political party finding sneaky ways to legitimise such sentiments among white voters. Though the playing of it, these days, is seldom if ever overt, the code may not be hard to crack. It assumes racist sentiments exist, knows the dangers of playing the card face-up, yet reassures the observant voter that his or her sour ethnic feelings are being heeded.

But there's another way to play the race card. This is to accuse the other side of playing it when the card is so firmly face-down that hardly anyone would otherwise notice it. That such a tactic may work politically is, in a way, a mark of Britain's social advance. A couple of decades ago, when racial tolerance was less embedded in our society than it is today, there wouldn't have been so much mileage in charging a politician with exploiting covert racism. Perhaps we should applaud the truth exposed by William Hague's inept dabbling in the tragedies of two black boys in south London: that the merest hint of card-playing is utterly unacceptable all round.

Yet accusing him of playing it has now had more impact than the words he originally spoke. By calling him "disgusting" and "disgraceful", Jack Straw did as much to play the card as he did. It was a different suit, but had a worse effect. As well as giving voice to Straw's sound anti-racist record, it was designed to have a political result, namely the portrayal of Hague as a crazed extremist who will stop at nothing to retrieve his desperate situation. The hair-trigger alertness of both prime minister and home secretary, and the hyperbole of their righteous language, was their own playing of the race card. Their purpose was benign. But that, among other things, is what they were doing: making a wild, intemperate noise about race, thereby reminding ethnic and liberal minorities which side they should be on as the election comes closer.

Hague's speech was not racist, either in text or, I would say, sub-text. For Straw to call it, on that account, disgusting matches the level of rhetorical subtlety Hague himself achieved when he said the Macpherson report stigmatised all policemen as racists. Macpherson did no such thing. But neither did Hague say anything to justify Bill Morris likening his speech to Enoch Powell talking in 1968 about the rivers of blood that would flow through English cities because of immigration. Morris's charge was grotesquely irresponsible. It was a lot more likely than Hague's words to stir up antagonisms which many good people, including Bill Morris, have spent years working to reduce. On the whole it is the left, by recklessly interpreting Hague as racist, who have raised the temperature more than he did.

The Conservative leader is no philosopher-king. He is insensitive and ill- informed about law and order. Some of the things he's prepared to say about the causes of crime, and the remedies he has to offer, are crude in the extreme. His indifference to evidence, scorn for research, and braying confidence in the simplicity of solutions that are being impeded only by the liberal elite, reveal the philistinism of a desperate man. His contention that Britain, with the highest prison population in Europe, has been soft on crime for decades is an assertion too grimly absurd for even the man himself to make any coherent sense of. He merely gesticulates and roars, eyeing opinion polls which say that this may be the one social anxiety voters think Tories are more likely to appease than Labour.

Hague is also cavalier with the Macpherson report. Though the Tories were originally supportive, they now misrepresent the report in order to attack it. The finding of institutional racism was a lesson not a threat, and didn't say that every policeman and woman was a racist. It identified an attitude, often unconscious, which police forces as institutions are prone to have, and which many, as a direct result of Macpherson's work, are now doing their best to eradicate. Police leaders have accepted Macpherson. When Hague cites the whinges of individual policemen as proof of a wholesale collapse of morale, he seems to justify their complaints rather than urging them, for the sake of society, to help reform their own social order.

Here's where a vestige of racial insinuation could be said, at a stretch, to touch his remarks. But the logical path is tortuous. Stop-and-search, in the wake of Macpherson, has come down: so street crime has gone up: most street crime in south London is done by blacks: therefore, by impeding stop-and-search, the liberal consensus is assisting in the growth of crime and refusing to acknowledge blacks' part in that: and therefore William Hague, by pointing all this out and arguing that it must stop, is pandering to white instincts and showing himself to be a racist. Add the substantial error he made in the use of statistics, and what you have is a leader who has shown himself to be the most sinister and disgraceful politician under the sun.

What you have, actually, is a silly man who, when in a hole, doesn't know when to stop digging. With his paragraphs of impeccable political correctness on racial murder and black mistrust of the police, he resembles neither Enoch Powell nor Margaret Thatcher, who played the race card in 1978 by saying it was time to stop the country being "swamped" with immigrants. He makes a valid charge about the shortage of policemen, from which people on housing estates, including ethnic minorities, suffer disproportionately much. But he's not alert to the inflammation already set off by his remarks. He ploughs on, gratuitously adding Damilola Taylor to Stephen Lawrence, appropriating their names in his own defence, guaranteeing one more twist in the cycle of outrage. His complacent defiance, in face of the trouble he provoked, is offensive to behold.

But it wouldn't have happened if the left, for their part, hadn't fallen into instinctive exaggeration. The most important quality any politician can bring to public discourse on racial issues is scrupulous care with words. That applies both to comment on reality and to the depiction of other people's good or bad faith in dealing with reality. Because, mercifully, racism has become the least acceptable of all modern prejudices, spraying such a charge around needs to be done with a little more care for society than the government propaganda machine, eager to seize its moment, has showed.

An attraction of this to ministers was, in a coarse way, political. Leaping to attack Hague as a racist, they could distract attention from their own failures as liberals. They may not have done much for civil liberties, but they're clean on this one. A feeling of virtue grips them. So, they must hope, will the constituency that deplores their reactionary record. But hyperbole, in this tinder-box, exacts a high price.

webTitle: Racism row harks back to the days of Powell, but now the language has changed

fields.headline: Racism row harks back to the days of Powell, but now the language has changed
fields.standfirst:
As senior colleagues mutter behind the scenes at party's law and order policies their leader steams confidently on
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Britain has not seen a furore over crime, law and order and racism since Enoch Powell predicted a local equivalent of the river "Tiber foaming with much blood" in a Birmingham hotel in 1968, some public figures are now saying.
fields.body:
Britain has not seen a furore over crime, law and order and racism since Enoch Powell predicted a local equivalent of the river "Tiber foaming with much blood" in a Birmingham hotel in 1968, some public figures are now saying.

One of the first to criticise William Hague was Bill Morris, Jamaican-born leader of the transport workers' union. No such speech since Powell "had done more damage to good race relations", he said on Sunday.

As a young immigrant in 1968 Mr Morris's alarm must have been heartfelt, but his memory was faulty. Whatever the merits of his text, William Hague would never have dared utter them in such crude language as Powell used. He would been ridiculed if he had. That at least is a measure of how far multicultural Britain has come in the intervening years.

With hindsight the speech which the former Tory health minister gave to a party audience in the Midlands hotel, Birmingham, on April 20 1968 was the most inflammatory piece of demagogy uttered by a senior British politician since Oswald Mosley's Hitlerite prime in the 1930s.

It was not that Powell's call for "voluntary" repatriation of immigrants, or his attack on the unfairness to white Britons of the new race relations bill, was new. Senior Tories had said as much, though they had been opposed by such staunch liberal colleagues as Iain Macleod who broke with his old friend Powell over the speech. But, though he feigned surprise at the fuss he caused, this was a calculated bid for attention, "a rocket that will go up and stay up", as he confided to a friend.

The most notorious passages are well known. Few of those who later marched in support of Enoch would have recognised the classical allusion to "the Tiber foaming with much blood", but they understood his prediction that "in 15 or 20 years' time the black man will have the whip hand over the white man".

Strictly speaking Powell did not say that. He was an intellectually sophisticated man whose defence would be that he was examining not racial superiority but numbers, loyalties and national identities. The dishonesty of the exercise lay in his attribution of the worst passages to others, "a middle aged, quite ordinary working man" in one instance, a "woman writing from Northumberland about something which is happening at this moment" in distant Wolverhampton.

That provided the peg for the story about the old woman living in a seven-bedroom house in a street full of negroes (even Dr Martin Luther King still said "negroes" in 1968) and refusing to rent rooms to them.

Powell then invoked the excrement through the letter box and "charming wide-grinning piccanninies" who followed her chanting "racialist". Having predicted an "immigrant" population of 5-7m by 2000 in huge urban concentrations, he urged their return to make possible the integration the liberals proposed.

The actual figure is around 4m, though inter-marriage and other aspects of the multicultural mix have rendered the perception archaic. The majority would be British-born, Powell conceded. At least he got that right.

The public reaction to the speech was intense. Dockers and others marched behind "Enoch is right" slogans. Most newspapers fiercely condemned him. The Times leader, entitled "An Evil Speech", called it disgraceful, racialist and shameful.

Why did he do it? Probably because he thought Edward Heath would lose the coming general election and he would emerge as Tory leader. Instead Heath sacked him, rallied his party and won in 1970. Powell never held office again.

webTitle: Hague race jibe angers ministers

fields.headline: Hague race jibe angers ministers
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday raised the stakes in the row over law and order.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday raised the stakes in the row over law and order when he ignored a plea for restraint from the parents of Damilola Taylor to issue a blunt warning that a Labour election victory will lead to more tragic murders in Britain's inner cities.

Hours after the Taylors had accused Mr Hague of using their son's death as a "political football", the Tory leader went on the offensive to declare that politicians could not bury their heads in the sand over crime levels.

In a series of interviews with the BBC and ITN, Mr Hague insisted that the government was to blame for rising crime because of the fall in police numbers.

Asked by the BBC whether he was saying that another Labour government would lead to more deaths like that of Damilola, Mr Hague said: "There will be more crime if police numbers and police morale continue to fall. That will mean, yes, that there are more tragedies which we all end up discussing."

Mr Hague's remarks were condemned by the government last night as an insensitive response to Damilola's parents who publicly criticised the Tory leader yesterday morning after he linked the death of their 10-year-old son to the shortage of police numbers. Richard and Gloria Taylor said they were distressed that he had decided to make political capital out of their family's tragedy when they were trying to grieve and keep attention focused on the murder investigation.

Neil O'May, the Taylors' solicitor, said: "Mr and Mrs Taylor did not hear anything by way of condolences from Mr Hague after Damilola's death. The first they knew of his views were the reports of his article and speeches in the media in the last few days. The use of their son's death as a political football has caused a great deal of distress."

The Taylors' angry response to Mr Hague dealt a serious blow to the Tory leader who came close to blaming Jack Straw for Damilola's death over the weekend when he asked where the home secretary had been when police patrols were scaled down in Peckham, south London, where Damilola died.

Stung by the Taylors' criticism of his remarks, Mr Hague toured the television studios last night to offer his sympathy to the murdered boy's parents.

Mr Hague opened his BBC interview by expressing his shock at the killing. Asked what his message was to the Taylors, Mr Hague said: "No one can imagine what you have been through, this awful and highly publicised tragedy."

But Mr Hague showed that he remained unmoved by the Taylors' criticisms when he denied that he was using Damilola's death as a political football. Insisting that politicians had to talk about such crimes, Mr Hague asked: "What do we do when a little boy is stabbed to death and left to die in a stairwell in an estate in London where there are insuffi cient police and where there were warnings about insufficient police? We can't just bury our heads in the sand - We have to say something has to be done about this because it is an example of what is happening to our country?"

His remarks drew a furious response last night from the government. Margaret Beckett, the leader of the Commons, said: "William Hague has blundered into something without regard to the facts, to the seriousness of the case or to the fact that the police are in the middle of a very sensitive murder inquiry. He is a desperate man who has made a terrible mistake, calling his judgment into question once again."

Officers on the Damilola murder squad are also privately concerned about the way Damilola's death has been "hijacked" by politicians. They believe the truth will only come out with help from the community, and partisan rows over policing strategies in the neighbourhood cause divisiveness when they are trying to build up trust.

Tory officials underlined their sensitivity over Mr Hague's provocative remarks by issuing a transcript of his BBC interview which watered down some of his more contentious remarks last night.

Mr Hague has been buffeted by criticism since he followed an attack last week on the Macpherson inquiry with an article in the Sunday Telegraph which linked Damilola's death to Labour's policing "failures". His article was criticised yesterday by a high profile black member of the Tory party. Derek Laud said: "The Conservative party always do this in the run-up to a general election. It makes me feel semi-detached."

However, Mr Hague was supported by Ali Balli, chairman of the local tenants' association in Peckham, south London, where Nigerian-born Damilola bled to death in a stairwell on November 27.

"I agree with Mr Hague's analysis that the number of police patrolling this area has contributed to the murder of Damilola Taylor," Mr Balli said.

Mr Straw, who visited Damilola's school for a second time yesterday, discounted Mr Balli's comments as "party political", saying he was a local Liberal Democrat activist.

webTitle: Ecstasy honeymoon 'over for Britons'

fields.headline: Ecstasy honeymoon 'over for Britons'
fields.trailText: The ecstasy honeymoon may be over for British users who have become disenchanted with the mood-changing drug that became a staple for nightclub goers and ravers, researchers will suggest today.
fields.body:
The ecstasy honeymoon may be over for British users who have become disenchanted with the mood-changing drug that became a staple for nightclub goers and ravers, researchers will suggest today.

British ecstasy users report fewer benefits and more drawbacks than their American counterparts. They are more likely to have criminal convictions, are typically older and have taken the drug for longer.

Yet they are also far less likely to take precautions, such as drinking plenty of non-alcoholic liquids, to reduce potential problems, according to researchers at Edgehill college of higher education, Ormskirk, Lancashire, and Liverpool John Moores University.

"British users appear to be more complacent," they will say in a paper to be presented at a conference of the British Psychological Society in London.

The authors, Michelle Wareing, Philip Murphy and John Fisk, suggest the fact that Britain set the pace for use of ecstasy as a mainstream drug may be an explanation for the differences with the US. "British users seem to have already gone through their honeymoon period and are now perhaps entering a period of disenchantment."

More than nine in 10 American users told researchers they liked to dance under the influence, compared with 73% of Britons. Britons were also more likely to report problems such as short term memory loss, lack of motivation and tiredness.

Other papers to the conference will reveal that psychiatric problems linked to the use of recreational drugs are more prevalent among heavy ecstasy users .

fields.trailText: POOR OLD HARRY BASSETT
fields.body:
POOR OLD HARRY BASSETT

Poor old Dave Bassett doesn't have much luck. He left Wimbledon the year before they won the FA Cup, moving instead to Watford, where he was quickly sacked. He went to Sheffield United and took them into the Premiership, but his team were relegated by a goal in injury time of the final game of the season. And that was scored by Mark Stein, for Christ's sake. He went to Crystal Palace (enough said). He went to Nottingham Forest and signed Pierre van Hooijdonk (oops). And now - will his pain never end? - he's been relieved of his duties as manager of Barnsley.

The club released a statement today which read: "Following a long discussion about the way forward for Barnsley Football Club and David Bassett, the board of directors have reluctantly agreed with David that there be a parting of the ways. The directors would like to place on record their thanks to David Bassett for all his hard blah drone blether to be perfectly honest we're surprised you've kept reading this story long enough to notice we're not actually quoting the press release any more, and can you really blame us, because these things are invariably painfully tedious and they always end with the words 'wish him and his family all the very best in the future'."

Poor old Harry - who was, along with his family, wished all the very best in the future - had only been in the job 17 months, and he was quite successful too. He took the irritatingly monickered Tykes to the only remaining exciting game in the English football calendar before losing to Ipswich, which is not bad going when you think about it. But Barnsley have been sluggish this season, hindered by the departures of Craig Hignett and John Curtis to Blackburn, and Harry has paid the price. The Fiver feels for him, but we're sure he'll bounce back. Did anybody say Wolves?

PAOLO CATCHES SEPP'S EYE

The in-no-way-Machiavellian Fifa president Sepp Blatter - or Joseph S Blatter as fifa.com prefer to call him - has written to the in-no-way-Mussolini-supporting West Ham striker Paolo Di Canio, praising him for his "exceptional act of fair play" against Everton last weekend. Which to the Fiver sounds as unlikely as the Pope high-fiving the Archbishop of Canterbury for using the C word on Songs of Praise. But what do we know?

"Gestures like this are all too rare in football, especially at the professional level," twittered Blatter this morning as he practised his Paul Alcock comedy flop. "High-profile players like yourself are in the privileged position of role models for young people, but unfortunately this opportunity is taken only too seldom," he added, while flicking the Vs at a picture of Danny Wilson. The Bristol City manager, not the Eighties pop-soul troupe.

"Your spontaneous action in the game against Everton thus deserves our special recognition and respect," Sepp continued. Which unfortunately for Paolo doesn't mean a one-to-one with Italian dictator Benito Mussolini. Nor even a copy of My Rise and Fall by Benito Mussolini. No, he'll be a "consideration" for next year's Fifa Fair Play Prize.

Not really worth it, was it? Especially when you survey the wreckage of the West Ham dressing room. "We had plenty of opportunities to score but we either missed the target or were too interested in fair play," moaned Frederic Kanoute today, arching an eyebrow. Dec 19: Click here

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"To even comment on this speculation is ridiculous, I don't want to give it credence. There's more chance of us signing Father Christmas than Robbie Fowler" - Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale makes sure the papers won't write another word about his club and a certain £10m striker.

If Arsenal fans weren't already pleased with Patrick Vieira - after he managed to put a ball past unbeatable human octopus Neil Sullivan - they're going to be mighty delighted with him now. The red-card collecting midfielder today told German magazine Kicker that he is "content" with Arsenal and he's staying put. "Arsene Wenger counts on me. We have enormous quality here," said the elbows-akimbo Frenchman, who must have reasoned that there is no guarantee of gathering medals simply by jumping ship to a club like, say, Barcelona.

However, if Vieira did move - although he's definitely not going to, well, probably not, but you can never say never - he won't be heading back to Italy. "I would not return, no, absolutely not," insisted the former AC Milan man. "Although there are large teams in Italy which are interested in me, I will not return."

Sadly, this isn't because he thinks the thin stripes sported by the big Italian clubs make him look too skinny. "There is an intolerable atmosphere of the racism which prevails and I grew up in an atmosphere of equal rights," he explained. "We were over there to play football in Rome and I found an inhuman atmosphere with incomprehensible offence because of my skin colour." Now, do you think, for example, flabby bigot Sinisa Mihajlovic could pronounce any of those big multi-syllable words Patrick has used? No, we don't either.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Brazilian striker Romario will join Internazionale on a lucrative 18-month contract when the Italian transfer window reopens in January, reports onefootball.com.

West Ham have made an astonishing £10m bid for Argentinean international striker Martin Palermo, reports Planet Football. Boca Juniors president Mauricio Macri has confirmed that West Ham's bid is the highest for the player - but says that Napoli, Valencia and Aston Villa are also interested. Palermo is best remembered for missing three penalties in an international match, but Harry Redknapp reckons he is "top drawer".

Chelsea will make an improved £13m offer for Robbie Keane, claims Teamtalk.

Aston Villa have abandoned hopes of signing Benni McCarthy from Celta Vigo. "The deal is dead as far as we are concerned," admitted Villa's financial director Mark Ansell. "Celta's demands were becoming more and more unreasonable. In the end they were making demands which were unacceptable to the player himself." The club are expected to step up their efforts to sign Colombian international Juan Pablo Angel.

Alen Boksic could return for Middlesbrough's match against Tottenham this weekend after shaking off a hamstring injury.

Newcastle defender Didier Domi's future at St James' Park looks increasingly in doubt after he failed to return from France for training.

Jaap Stam and Andy Cole should both return to action early in the new year after recovering from their Achilles injuries, the Imperial Lord Ferg admitted today.

Huddersfield are about to sign Barnsley defender Adrian Moses for £350,000. Town manager Lou Macari said: "He'll have a medical and we'll speak to him about his terms and then take it from there."

Inverness Caledonian Thistle will ballot their supporters over a name change to Inverness City, after the town was awarded city status yesterday.

webTitle: Hilary Blume: why I resigned

fields.headline: Hilary Blume: why I resigned
fields.trailText: I could not agree with the decision to award the licence to run the Lottery to Camelot. I believe the Lottery needs a relaunch to arrest declining sales. TPL's [The People's Lottery's] bid was more generous to the National Lottery Distribution Fund. Assuming that they could achieve equivalent sales to those of Camelot more would flow to Good Causes.
fields.body:
I could not agree with the decision to award the licence to run the Lottery to Camelot. I believe the Lottery needs a relaunch to arrest declining sales. TPL's [The People's Lottery's] bid was more generous to the National Lottery Distribution Fund. Assuming that they could achieve equivalent sales to those of Camelot more would flow to Good Causes.

I judged TPL's game plan and marketing preferable to Camelot's. I believe that TPL will achieve sales, over the seven year period, higher than or equivalent to Camelot's. I also approve of the TPL strategy to widen play rather than increase the amount spent by the same players and judge this offers better player protection.

The technology offered by TPL is superior to that of Camelot's and could be used to provide a range of services to the local community through small retailers. Camelot's use of outdated technology presents a risk later in the licence period through problems of maintenance and lack of adaptability.

The concerns about financial soundness in the TPL bid are, in my judgement, overstated and ancillary earnings through the terminals would mitigate against this.

I carry forward concerns over issues of propriety and Camelot's continued dependence on GTech.

I would like to say that the process of evaluation has been rigorous and I quite understand why my fellow Commissioners have decided as they have.

The change of operator is a huge risk but it is also a huge opportunity. I considered the choice of appointing Camelot and watching a steady erosion of income to the NLDF (in real terms) or taking the much higher risk of appointing a new operator, committed to giving more to the NLDF, with a proven flair for marketing. I have concluded that it would be a risk worth taking.

I believe the Camelot bid was not the best they could offer (for example, the disappointing quality of the technology) and it should be capable of improvement. Perhaps too, in Dianne Thompson, we may find the fresh approach I think necessary. I wish the National Lottery well.

webTitle: Nine out of ten students struggle financially, admits government

fields.headline: Nine out of ten students struggle financially, admits government
fields.trailText: Nearly nine out of ten students face financial difficulties, reveals a government survey of student debts.
fields.body:
Nearly nine out of ten students face financial difficulties, reveals a government survey of student debts.

The study based on personal interviews with 2500 students on degree courses in the 1998-99 academic yearbefore grants were completely phased out, also shows that student debts have trebled since 1995-96 when the survey was last carried out.

Just under two thirds of the students interviewed believed that the governments current funding policies for higher education deterred their friends from university - particularly if they were from poor backgrounds, black, or female and over 25 years old.

While the student class of 1998-99 enjoyed higher annual incomes than their predecessors three year previously, they borrowed from an increasingly wide range of sources. These included student loans, other bank loans, and credit card borrowing, found the study by Claire Callendar, professor of social policy at South Bank University.

Students in 1998-99 had 12% more income in real terms compared to those studying in 1995-96. But 87% of the latter-day students complained about financial difficulties.

The results come from the Department for Education and Employments student debt survey, carried out every three years. While the students in 1998-99 were among the first to be charged tuition fees in universities, maintenance grants for living costs were phased out the following year.

webTitle: UNIverse - reports from the academic world

fields.headline: UNIverse - reports from the academic world
fields.trailText: Armed with knowledge The US Army said last week that the consulting company PriceWaterhouseCoopers will coordinate a $453m project to deliver distance-learning courses to soldiers all over the world through a team of 10 companies and 29 colleges. It aims to be a virtual institution for 15,000 students. Participating institutions include Florida State University, Northern Virginia Community College, Pennsylvania State University and Regents College.
fields.body:
Armed with knowledge The US Army said last week that the consulting company PriceWaterhouseCoopers will coordinate a $453m project to deliver distance-learning courses to soldiers all over the world through a team of 10 companies and 29 colleges. It aims to be a virtual institution for 15,000 students. Participating institutions include Florida State University, Northern Virginia Community College, Pennsylvania State University and Regents College.

Star role Having astrology in the Indian education curriculum will drive people into superstition, academic K. Saroja told a "Save Education" seminar in Dharwad, said the Times of India. Other speakers criticised the government for attacking university autonomy.

Lettori continue their campaign Unions representing Italy's 1,500 foreign language lecturers, or lettori, are going to the European Court of Justice for a fourth time in their fight over pay and conditions. They claim they were downgraded to technicians and had their salaries cut by up to 50 per cent in 1995 for having dared to sue their rectors for open-ended contracts and won.

European heads agree to merge

A single overarching body representing university heads in Europe is set to emerge next year following discussions between the Association of European Universities and the Confederation of European Union Rectors' Conferences, the two major representative organisations for European academic institutions.

European higher education and research areas are currently being mooted by university officials. It is expected that all degrees in Europe will eventually follow the same basic structure as the UK system, based on three year bachelors, one year masters and three year doctoral degrees. A European research area could see much closer collaboration on research across the continent, with different national funding agencies concentrating on complementary research topics.

Clinton's successors chosen - 32 of them

Three Yale University students, the most from any US institution, are among this years winners of the Rhodes Scholarships, announced this weekend. Harvard which has amassed 295 winners in total over the years, failed to produce any winning students this year. The 32 US winners were selected on Saturday night by 8 regional committees from among 950 applicants. Rhodes Scholarships, created in 1902 by the will of British imperialist Cecil Rhodes, provide two or three years of study at Oxford University. One of the most famous Rhodes scholars was Bill Clinton who evidently showed leadership potential, one of the four main criteria for selection along with literary and scholastic attainments, fondness for and success in sports, and compassion for others. Scholars are also chosen from 18 other countries or regions worldwide. But the US has the largest contingent. Rhodes wanted candidates who were not "mere bookworms," according to the scholarship's website, www.rhodesscholar.org.

Women academics win equality payout

The Minnesota State Colleges and Universities System reached a tentative agreement Thursday in which it agreed to pay at least $830,000 to settle a class action brought by female faculty members of St. Cloud State University who alleged that they had been paid less and overlooked for promotions because of their gender, reports the Chronicle of Higher Education http://chronicle.com/news

It's not what you know......

The chances of getting a college education in the US depend to a large degree on which state people come from, concludes a recent report by the National Center for Public Policy and Higher Education, an independent think tank based in Washington DC. In California, 38% of 18 to 24 year-olds enrol in universities, compared with only 20% of the age group starting degrees in Nevada. One reason for the large differences is the high school courses offered to students.
