webTitle: Statement: The lottery commission outlines why it gave the licence to Camelot

fields.headline: The lottery commission's statement
fields.trailText: 1. The National Lottery Commission has decided to award Camelot Group plc the next seven-year licence to run the National Lottery. This statement discharges the duty of the Commission to give reasons for its decision under paragraph 9 of Schedule 2A of the National Lottery etc. Act 1993 as amended ("the Act").
fields.body:
1. The National Lottery Commission has decided to award Camelot Group plc the next seven-year licence to run the National Lottery. This statement discharges the duty of the Commission to give reasons for its decision under paragraph 9 of Schedule 2A of the National Lottery etc. Act 1993 as amended ("the Act").

2. The Commission has made a detailed evaluation of the bids from Camelot and The People's Lottery in the form in which the bidders have revised them to meet the Commission's concerns as set out in its statement of 23 August 2000. Statement of Reasons for the Decision of the National Lottery Commission not to Grant a Licence to Operate the National Lottery, 23 August 2000. The People's Lottery was given a month to submit its revised proposals and did so on 23 September. Camelot submitted its revised proposals on 24 October after the High Court's decision that it should have a similar opportunity to allay the Commission's concerns.

3. The Commission has considered the bids in the light of the factors that it listed in The Invitation to Apply. Invitation to Apply, November 1999, especially chapter 4. It has looked at the bids afresh and without regard to any earlier provisional conclusions that it might have reached, whether on returns to the National Lottery Distribution Fund (NLDF) or on any other issues. New Lottery Bids Go to the Next Stage, 10 November 2000. The bidders were told that the Commission would take account of changes intended to rectify the original bids as they stood on 23 August in the areas of concern that the Commission had identified. Apart from that, the Commission would only take account of such changes as were necessarily incidental or consequential to the main changes. The only changes that the Commission has identified as falling into this category are certain potential increases in costs for The People's Lottery resulting from its proposed trust fund arrangements and those for an additional financial facility. The Commission has concluded that these costs are not material to its evaluation.

4. Since the National Lottery began in November 1994, it has become a national institution. It has also become one of the largest lotteries in the world in terms of sales, with a high proportion of households playing each week. Sales during the present licence period have averaged £5.0 billion at an annual rate, with total contributions so far to the NLDF of over £9 billion. The cumulative total of sales to date is £30.4 billion. The total given for contributions excludes interest earned by the NLDF.

The qualifying statutory criteria

5. When the Commission announced on 10 November 2000 that it would evaluate both bids, it said that each now had the potential to meet the criteria in section 4(1) of the Act. These concern the running of the National Lottery with all due propriety and the protection of the interests of every participant. The Commission has concluded that as a result of the changes made since 23 August 2000 both bids now meet these criteria.


 For Camelot, the Commission reached this conclusion after considering Camelot's proposals to buy out the UK operations of GTech Corporation and noting progress made so far by Camelot and GTech on implementing commitments made to the Commission in the light of a software incident during the course of the first licence.


 For The People's Lottery, the Commission has reached this conclusion after considering The People's Lottery's trust fund proposals. The Commission is satisfied that these proposals would ensure that all outstanding prizes would be paid and that all ticket holders would be reimbursed in the event of the failure of the licensee.

Maximising proceeds for the NLDF

6. Provided that the qualifying statutory criteria are satisfied, section 4(2) of the Act requires the Commission in exercising its functions to do its best to secure that the net proceeds of the National Lottery are as great as possible. In making its assessment the Commission has taken account both of forecasts of returns to the NLDF and of the risks associated with the bids.

7. The Commission has concluded that the uncertainty relating to achievable sales is greater with The People's Lottery than with Camelot. There are also greater risks in The People's Lottery's bid as regards costs and financial soundness. These risks combine with those that would inevitably arise from a change of operator.

8. Although The People's Lottery offers higher contributions to the NLDF than Camelot at the same sales levels, this factor is outweighed by two considerations. The first is that the Commission has concluded that Camelot is on balance likely to deliver more sales over the licence period than The People's Lottery. The second is that the accumulation of risks that is inherent in The People's Lottery's bid, particularly in the early stages, is uncomfortably high by comparison with those posed by Camelot's bid.

9. The remainder of this statement sets out more fully the Commission's assessment of the main factors that it has weighed in reaching its conclusion that the prospect of maximising the likely proceeds for the NLDF is greater with Camelot's bid than it is with The People's Lottery's.

Ability to operate the National Lottery

10. The Commission has concluded that Camelot will be able to operate the National Lottery satisfactorily after it has absorbed GTech's UK operations. In reaching this conclusion, the Commission has taken account of the additional responsibilities and risks for management that will result from the change.

11. Camelot's IT systems overall have demonstrated a high level of operational reliability. The Commission notes that the proposed gaming software is not as up-to-date as the version currently being introduced in many other lottery jurisdictions and that this may involve some risk in the longer term as regards maintenance, development and adaptability.

12. The Commission considers that a largely outsourced operation, such as that proposed by The People's Lottery, is capable of providing a suitable structure for running the National Lottery. However, the Commission is concerned that The People's Lottery might not have sufficiently recognised the resources required for the management tasks involved in start-up and subsequent operation.

13. The IT systems proposed by The People's Lottery are more modern than those proposed by Camelot. The Commission considers that they would have had considerable potential to benefit the National Lottery if The People's Lottery had been chosen as the preferred bidder.

14. The Commission does not regard the risks associated with a change of operator and systems as in themselves preventing it from awarding the licence to a new operator. It considers that a change of both operator and systems must be accepted as a possible consequence of the legislation. It believes that such a change can in principle be managed successfully, even though clear precedents on the scale of the National Lottery are lacking. However, the Commission has concluded that the risks presented in this area by The People's Lottery are considerable when combined with other risks involved in the bid. By comparison, the risks in terms of systems in Camelot's bid are likely to be more important in the later stages of the licence and the Commission considers them to be less critical.

Game plans

15. Camelot intends to continue with the 6/49 matrix for the main online game and to conduct a phased introduction of new games. The Commission notes that the portfolio of online games has proved popular in its present form. In contrast, Camelot's record on Instants has, after an initial successful period, been disappointing and the Commission has reservations about Camelot's plans for them. The Commission is also uncertain whether the Euro Bloc game proposed by Camelot would be capable of introduction within the proposed licence period, given the practical difficulties involved.

16. The People's Lottery proposes to increase the size of the matrix for the main online game from 6/49 to 6/53. The Commission accepts that there is an argument for doing this, given the large number of National Lottery players and the small number of rollovers that the present matrix generates. The proposed change should result in a larger number of rollovers, which in itself might well increase player appeal. However, the longer odds might equally cause some players to defer purchases until rollovers occur. The experience of other lotteries with regard to a matrix change is mixed and, because of the difficulty of isolating the impact of a matrix change from other variables, inconclusive. On the evidence available, including that provided by The People's Lottery, the Commission is not convinced that a change would have a positive net effect on sales, having regard to the risks involved.

17. The Commission also has some concerns about the ability of The People's Lottery to manage delivery of the considerable number of new games that it proposes to introduce at the start of the licence, particularly given all the other elements of start-up that need to be delivered. The Commission considers that The People's Lottery may have assumed too much in terms of players' willingness to adapt to changes in the current games and to take part in new ones. The Commission is also unconvinced that the Regional game as proposed by the People's Lottery would be workable.

18. The Commission has concluded that The People's Lottery offers some advantages over Camelot in its game plan proposals, notably with regard to Instants. However, there are considerable risks in combining a matrix change with the early introduction of many new games. The Commission also notes that The People's Lottery's plans for new media are comparatively undeveloped. The Commission is not persuaded that The People's Lottery's game plan is superior to that of Camelot and considers that it involves greater risks.

Expected sales

19. The bidders' principal forecasts show average annual sales over the licence period of £7.3 billion in the case of Camelot and £7.4 billion in the case of The People's Lottery. However, actual sales have varied between £4.5 and £5.6 billion over the first licence period. Based on a 52 week moving average. They are currently running at some £5 billion a year.

20. The Commission considers that both bidders are over-optimistic about the level of sales that they would achieve. Neither bidder has in the Commission's view satisfactorily addressed the question of how far sales of new games would displace sales of existing games. Nor have they satisfactorily addressed the issue of competition from outside the National Lottery. Having considered the evidence, including that in the bidders' proposals, the Commission is not persuaded that there is likely to be a step-change in sales over the next licence period. It has concluded that sales are more likely to be within the range achieved during the first licence period.

21. The Commission regards the level of potential sales by The People's Lottery as more uncertain than is the case with Camelot. The People's Lottery has the potential to increase sales by relaunching the National Lottery but its game plan relies heavily on the success of the matrix change and the early introduction of new games. The Commission found The People's Lottery's market research and overall marketing plan to be less convincing than Camelot's. The research provided by The People's Lottery does not in the Commission's view support its claim that by not itself taking profit it would produce a significant increase in sales. The Commission has concluded that Camelot is, on balance, likely to deliver more sales over the licence period than The People's Lottery.

Contributions to the NLDF

22. At the same sales levels the commitments offered by The People's Lottery would lead to larger contributions to the NLDF than would Camelot's. At the bidders' principal forecasts, in which The People's Lottery's sales figures are higher than Camelot's, The People's Lottery would contribute some £160 million more a year than Camelot. At sales of £5 billion a year The People's Lottery would contribute some £110 million more a year than Camelot. These figures are based on the bidders' own cost assumptions. They would be affected by The People's Lottery's cost performance, as they take account of a secondary contribution to the NLDF that consists of any surplus that The People's Lottery generates. Camelot proposes to pay a secondary contribution equivalent to one half of any excess of after-tax profits over the level in its principal forecast.

23. Although the differences given above are substantial in themselves, they are small in relation to the range of uncertainties surrounding the projections and the total amounts at stake. Relatively small movements in sales by either Camelot or The People's Lottery would lead to a reversal of the ranking.

Costs

24. The costs that The People's Lottery has included in its bid are significantly lower than those included by Camelot. In absolute terms, the biggest difference is for IT systems. The Commission accepts that this difference is explicable.

25. However, having examined the cost proposals of both bidders, the Commission considers that there is a risk that The People's Lottery may have underestimated other costs, particularly at lower levels of sales. In addition, The People's Lottery's proposed provision for expenditure on new media appears to be low. The Commission's concerns are increased because The People's Lottery has not made express provision for contingencies, which would be usual in such circumstances.

26. If the Commission's concerns proved well founded, the effect would be to reduce the extent to which Camelot needs to generate higher sales than The People's Lottery to produce the same amount of contributions for the NLDF. It would also increase the prospect of The People's Lottery going into financial deficit.

Financial soundness

27. The Commission considers that Camelot would be profitable on all the sales scenarios that the Commission has examined and that the risk of it becoming loss making is low.

28. Once The People's Lottery has repaid its initial term loan, it intends to pass all accounting profits to the NLDF year by year. There is no provision to build up reserves as a cushion against any future deficits.

29. The additional £50 million facility obtained by The People's Lottery since August provides it with increased headroom to deal with short-term cashflow requirements and could help The People's Lottery in lower revenue scenarios. However, the repayment conditions have led the Commission to conclude that the facility would only give limited assistance if there were continuing losses.

30. Given The People's Lottery's commitments to the NLDF, there is a much greater risk than with Camelot that its financial position would become vulnerable at low levels of sales or if there were unplanned costs, such as those that might arise from unexpected problems in start-up. The full extent of the risk cannot be evaluated with precision. The Commission considers, however, that at levels of sales not far below £5 billion a year there is a real risk that The People's Lottery could incur losses which would not be sustainable within its proposed financial structure. The critical point would be reached at a higher level of sales if there were unexpected costs.

Conclusion

31. In the light of the considerations set out above, the Commission has concluded that the prospects of maximising the likely proceeds for the NLDF are greater with Camelot's bid than with that of The People's Lottery.

webTitle: December 18 ratings

fields.headline: BBC casts away viewers
fields.trailText: TV overnights: The return of Castaway 2000 to BBC1 last night for a best-of programme only managed to attract 5.3m although the show averaged 7-8m earlier this year, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Documentary series Castaway 2000 returned to BBC1 last night, providing further evidence that the show's ratings momentum from earlier in the year has been squandered through stop-start scheduling.

Castaway 2000: Heaven and Hell, which looked back over the year the BBC's volunteer community has spent living on the Scottish island of Taransay, averaged 5.3m and a 22% share in an admittedly tough slot against ITV's Millionaire, according to unofficial overnights. Millionaire took 10.1m.

Earlier this year Castaway 2000 was averaging 7-8m in weekday peak-time slots. Later in the evening BBC1's BBC and Bafta Tribute to Michael Caine pulled in 4m and a third of viewing, from 10.35pm.

On Channel 4, there was little sign of viewers getting into the festive spirit, with two Christmas-related documentaries recording disappointing ratings.

Christmas Unwrapped, a documentary about how Hamley's toy store has been turned around under new chief executive Simon Burke, averaged 1.5m and a 6% share, while Cutting Edge: A Very British Christmas, which looked at the modern day significance of the event, had 1.2m and a 5% share.

webTitle: Granada renews Anglia TV licence at bargain price

fields.headline: Granada renews Anglia TV licence at bargain price
fields.trailText: 4pm: Granada Media is to renew its Anglia Television licence at a vastly reduced price, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Granada Media is to renew its Anglia Television licence at a vastly reduced price.

The Independent Television Commission has asked ITV's most powerful company to pay £3.42m annually for the 10-year licence, a massive drop from last year's £21.2m.

The ITC said it was revising the price because revenues from analogue services are expected to fall in the face of competition from digital television.

However, the level of payments through percentage of qualifying revenue has been raised from 7% to 17%. PQR is based on a proportion of advertising income.

Sir Robin Biggam, ITC chairman, said: "In setting the financial terms the ITC looks to ensure that licences can continue to provide an excellent range and quality of national and regional services whilst providing a fair return to the Treasury for the right to broadcast."

Anglia Television, which covers the east of England, said it accepted the terms for renewal.

The new financial model will also be applied to the renewal of the Central TV licence, which is held by Carlton Communications.

webTitle: JWT loses out as Camelot wins lottery licence

fields.headline: JWT loses out as Camelot wins lottery licence
fields.trailText: 4.30pm: J Walter Thompson has lost up to £40m-worth of business after Camelot won the licence to run the National Lottery, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
J Walter Thompson has said goodbye to up to £40m-worth of business after Camelot won the licence to run the National Lottery.

The advertising agency, which was part of Richard Branson's People's Lottery consortium, would have won the lucrative contract to advertise the lottery if Mr Branson's bid had been successful.

Simon Burridge, JWT senior executive, had been earmarked as chief executive of the People's Lottery.

The Lottery Commission today awarded the seven-year licence to rival Camelot after voting four to one in favour of the incumbent.

The People's Lottery's bid document had argued that advertising was crucial to the success of the lottery and earmarked a £40m annual marketing budget - twice the £20m Camelot spends on advertising.

Mr Branson's consortium included JWT, Kellogg, Compaq and AWI, the US lottery company. It also had the backing of Microsoft chairman Bill Gates.

Camelot launched in 1994, with Saatchi & Saatchi's "It could be you" campaign slogan.

The account was put up for pitch in 1998, when Camelot said it wanted a "fresh" approach. The account went to WCRS, which came up with the more cautious slogan, "Maybe, just maybe".

The BBC is expected to retain the rights to broadcast the National Lottery.

webTitle: Singer Kirsty MacColl dies

fields.headline: Singer Kirsty MacColl dies
fields.trailText: Singer and songwriter Kirsty MacColl has died in an accident in Mexico, her management company said today.
fields.body:
Singer and songwriter Kirsty MacColl has died in an accident in Mexico, her management company said today.

The 41-year-old star, whose biggest hit Fairytale of New York was with The Pogues in 1987, is believed to have died in a boating accident.

MacColl - daughter of folk singer Ewan MacColl - also scored hits with The Wonder Stuff and is known for her top 20 single There's A Guy Works Down The Chipshop Swears He's Elvis.

A spokeswoman for her management company, Major Minor, confirmed the singer had died and said they would be releasing further details later.

webTitle: Health: The online diary of a cancer patient

fields.headline: Last testament
fields.standfirst: Lu Youqing, who died last week, broke with centuries of Chinese tradition to write frankly about his cancer. His online diary touched thousands, reports  John Gittings
fields.trailText: Lu Youqing, who died last week, broke with centuries of Chinese tradition to write frankly about his cancer. His online diary touched thousands, reports John Gittings.
fields.body:
Lu Youqing had made a date with death, publicly on a Shanghai website and then repeatedly over the last months of his life in open letters to his "web friends". When he died from cancer on December 11 - the notice appeared first on the site - hundreds of readers posted messages, mostly in sorrow but some in hope. "It is you who have cured us of diseases ..." wrote one. "In today's world, your diary is like a breath of refreshing wind."

Lu's self-revealing letters, which were published in book form shortly before he died, have established a new standard for honesty in a society where reticence and considerations of face inhibit frank discussion of illness and death.

Lu, 37, was a former journalist with a degree in Chinese literature who, like many young intellectuals in the new era of "economic reform", went into business. He leaves behind his wife and 10-year-old daughter. His story, which was reported on China's main television stations and newspapers, and discussed on many other websites, has also focused attention on the rising incidence of cancer in China and the paucity of adequate treatment.

Most of Lu's last thoughts were gentle memories of happier times and wry reflections about the attention he was attracting. But he had harsh comments to make about overcrowded wards in which a bribe is often the only way to get quick treatment. He described the grim plight of "the cancer patient from outside the city, living in a small hotel beside the Shanghai tumour hospital, taking all the family savings with him and waiting for a sick bed and operation".

He also noted how Chinese society still ostracises those who are marked by misfortune. "From the moment you pick up a lab report stating that the doctor has diagnosed cancerous cells," Lu wrote, "life starts to get tough. If you're an official your career will stop dead, the personnel department will start looking for your successor and people will start positioning themselves to replace you ... If you're a business man, your credit will suddenly be devalued ... If you're a student you may give up your studies."

The medical authorities say that cancerous tumour cases are rising sharply. Not surprisingly in a country with high tobacco consumption, lung cancer remains the commonest form: the death rate from it is the highest of any developing country.

This year a national conference on tumour prevention was told that cancer now causes one out of every five deaths in China. Annual cancer-related deaths now total 1.3m a year. Advocates of healthy eating in the west have held out China as a model society with a high consumption of naturally unrefined plant food and a low consumption of animal protein. Both were thought to explain the country's low rates of cancer and cardiovascular disease. But Chinese specialists say that changes towards a less healthy diet and a less active lifestyle - the consequence of economic improvements in the past 20 years - have raised rates of the two degenerative illnesses dramatically.

Stomach cancer has always been an exception with far higher rates recorded in China than in the West. This has often been blamed upon the widespread reliance on fermented and salted preserved vegetables in rural areas.

Lu decided to keep and publish a diary both as a way of confronting death and to leave behind a memorial for his wife and daughter. After five years of cancer treatment, including two operations, a malignant tumour appeared on Lu's neck which grew rapidly. In February he was told he had only three months left to live: he decided to give up taking medicine and start writing instead. "People should choose their own way ..." he wrote. "This is my way of defying death and keeping my dignity."

He neither dwelt on his illness nor avoided it, but wove it naturally into the narrative. When the tumour on his neck bled, he recorded the event calmly, noting that it seemed to cause him difficulty in breathing. "Blood and oxygen which healthy people take for granted," he noted, "are matters of life and death for the sick.

"But enough of that, I don't want to send my spirits down like the falling Shanghai stock exchange. That is why I prefer to write in my diary about tranquil scenes."

Hundreds wrote on the bulletin board of rongshu.com where extracts from Lu's diary were published for three months until he was too ill to continue. Most applauded his courage and some came from fellow sufferers. Several appealed for help on behalf of other incurable patients. He was delighted to see a copy of the book several weeks before he died, commenting that he had "snatched it from death". It was instantly pirated although his wife, Shi Muyan, did not tell him in case it would "break his heart".

Messages flooded in when his death was announced on the site; they showed that Lu had touched many people's lives. "Mr Lu, you will always be in our hearts," wrote one, "but we should remember how many unfortunate people without names are still alive."

"Those who do not honour death cannot understand the meaning of existence," wrote another.

A small number of critical voices also wrote to the site while Lu was alive. Some accused him of seeking fame, others of dramatising his illness. "One day your child would like to read a unpublished diary by you, rather than this book published so neatly - if it can be called a book," wrote one of the most wounding. After he died, a message appeared criticising Lu's literary style and advising him to "go peacefully without making such a stupid noise". Infuriated supporters quickly rallied to denounce the anonymous carper - who had not even seen the notice of Lu's death.

Lu and Shi impressed all who came to know them with their dignity and humour. As the tumours grew, he would dictate his diary entries which she then transcribed. Later she posted her own bulletins. "This morning he could hardly swallow so we fed him some congee," she reported. "After lying on the sofa he went back to bed but I could tell he really didn't want to."

She continued to record her husband's thoughts on life and death when he became to ill to compose. "Human existence is splendid because it has an end," he told a visitor not long before he died. His website obituary began with this quotation and concluded with another remark he had made at the start of the diary. "Others may think that death is an important affair, but for me it has already lost its meaning."

webTitle: Health: Overeaters Anonymous

fields.headline: When you just can't stop eating
fields.standfirst: Geri Halliwell has been spotted at a meeting of Overeaters Anonymous - a 12-step programme for people obsessed by food. So what does God have to do with it?  Lucy Atkins  investigates
fields.trailText: Geri Halliwell has been spotted at a meeting of Overeaters Anonymous - a 12-step programme for people obsessed by food. So what does God have to do with it? Lucy Atkins investigates.
fields.body:
"I surrender my food to God by weighing and measuring, counting calories and fat grams. Without abstinence, food becomes my god again." This is a contribution to Lifeline, the online magazine of the organisation Overeaters Anonymous, among whose ranks former spice girl Geri Halliwell has just been spotted in LA.

Now Geri is not someone you'd think did much over-eating. Like her one time colleague, Posh, not to mention a host of spectral Hollywood leading ladies, ex-Ginger is tiny and seems to shrink more each day. Are we really to believe, then, that this greyhound-flanked ghost eats too much? "I'll never be naturally thin," she has lamented. "I really have to work hard at it."

Sounds scarily like anorexia, surely?

Fortunately, Overeaters Anonymous (OA) is not about starvation (though it isn't clear whether someone who is obviously very underweight would actually be excluded from a meeting). An international movement, it evolved from Alcoholics Anonymous and, like its counterpart, involves local groups whose members follow a "12-step programme". This is based on the notion that food can be as addictive as booze or drugs. If you want to conquer your addiction you have to first admit you are addicted, then change yourself and abstain.

For the rest of your life.

Which would - surely - be rather short. I mean: food? Abstinence? If you don't eat, you die, right? "Like alcoholism," says a worker for OA, which has 160 groups in Britain, "an eating disorder is something you never really recover from."

Most OA members consider themselves "compulsive eaters". They may have what is a known by psychologists as "binge eating disorder". At its simplest this is, says Dr Sarah Beglin, a clinical psychologist, "when you feel you can't stop once you've started eating." More than the inability to resist the whole packet of Pringles, this disorder, Beglin says, is characterised by "a complete loss of control: you eat the contents of the fridge".

Sandy, a 31-year-old lawyer, had struggled with her weight for years when she went to OA. "The meeting was all about abstinence," she recalls, "about saying to yourself, 'Every day I renew my gratitude for another day in which to be abstinent.'" This is not necessarily what eating disorder specialists would recommend. "We would encourage people to eat the full range of food," says Beglin. "Having 'forbidden foods' makes you more vulnerable to bingeing."

Sandy was surprised by how radical the members' approach to eating was: "Only one person in the meeting allowed themselves to include sugar in their diet. Almost everyone there was skinny and many were 'cross addicted' - to alcohol, or drugs, or both." Sandy never went back - "There were too many religious overtones" (she remembers a lot of talk of "God as I see him") - and while her eating was problematic, she didn't want a new life.

Overeaters Anonymous is not a diet. It's more a support group for "addicts". "Support groups," Beglin agrees, "can certainly be helpful. Most people who binge eat do it in private. They feel disgusted with themselves. A big part of group therapy is being with others who share your secret." But the real key to OA seems to be a desperation to change. "Success in OA," writes one member in Lifeline, "requires a willingness to change. That is what the 12 steps of OA are all about - a systematic way of changing the way we think and live, so we don't have to act like practicing compulsive over-eaters."

It would be all too easy to knock Geri for showing up at an OA meeting. Self-help groups always sound barmy and this one's got a silly name too. But what can we really know about someone's internal battle with food? If a person feels so out of control that they want to turn to God (as they know him) and remodel their life forever then why shouldn't they?

"I can honestly say," writes one OA member, "that I love myself today. Thank you, OA and my Higher Power." Such people may not be much of a laugh at parties, but going to an OA meeting is probably - at the very least - preferable to vomiting, starving or bingeing alone at home.

webTitle: Health: The diary of a junior doctor

fields.headline: A failure to care
fields.trailText: Prepare yourself for an orgy of unbridled self-pity and loathing. I'm not proud of the person I've become: because I'm everything you predicted I would be. Callous? Maybe I'm just over familiar with misery, panic and pain.
fields.body:
Prepare yourself for an orgy of unbridled self-pity and loathing. I'm not proud of the person I've become: because I'm everything you predicted I would be. Callous? Maybe I'm just over familiar with misery, panic and pain. People don't die every day (although the manager in the mortuary thinks he's being pretty funny when he calls me Dr Shiplake), but if they're not ill and in intractable pain, then they've been abandoned by their families, or they're desperate to be discharged, and there's never much I can do apart from smile, which I am doing less and less.

I am gradually, regrettably, ceasing to care. I bet the man who runs the roller-coaster at Alton Towers doesn't get scared when he goes on it for the 100th time. But I feel like I should be involved in my patients' pain, and the relatives do too: if I'm not concerned, if I'm not astonished and aghast at the sheer scale of their appalling ill-health, to the point of devoting myself to 24-hour bedside supervision, then they take no trouble to share their disappointment.

Part of the problem is, of course, that I am just so busy. "What was the result of that test my father had yesterday, doctor?" people ask, quite reasonably. And the responses that spring into my head are, in order of shamefulness: "What test?", "How should I know?", and "What's it got to do with you?". And when I'm not cursing families for pestering me, I'm cursing them for dumping their grannies on the doorstep.

Which brings me onto Christmas, and my own special appeal. Don't dump your granny on me this Christmas. In fact, please could you try especially hard not to dump them on either Christmas Eve or December 27: the days when I'm working in A&E. The 27th, it might amuse you to know, has been statistically demonstrated as the worst day in the year for granny-dumping, and will be particularly horrific coming after a long weekend with no GP surgeries.

And all that anyone ever wants to talk about is medicine: my friends, my mum, even my patients. I wandered into a patient's room for a quick chat the other night, during a quiet moment on ward cover, and all I was seeking was a bit of solace and a quiet moment. I even offered him some lemon cordial: he's a nice guy, we get on well, and he has a rather good collection of old films on video. But as soon as I get in there, all he can talk about is his endless afflictions.

The thing I'm not telling you is that I just want to get out. I don't have the nerve, the commitment, the staying power, the moral reserve, the social skills, the competitiveness, the caring nature, the backbone - I just don't have any of that stuff you need to be a doctor. I feel awful at least 10 times a day, I cry at least once a week (and I'm a boy). I tell my senior house officer and all she can do is smile and say, "You'll feel like that more than you can ever possibly imagine, for years and years."

What do they think they're all playing at? They're all either heavy drinkers, or compulsively unfaithful, or addicted to the gym, or in one case masturbation (a drunken confession). Doctors talk about the poor lifestyle of hospital medics as if a good lifestyle was something slightly camp, or incidental, or disposable. But junior doctors have no lifestyle, outside of being doctors, and most of our patients are geriatric nightmares with nothing more than social problems, getting more and more unwell the longer they spend in hospital.

So think of me and my inexcusable self-pity when you're having fun this year around the Christmas tree, and remember our special appeal (Terry Wogan children-in-need voice, stirring music, soft focus footage of old ladies gamboling gaily in the garden): "Keep them at home this Christmas."

webTitle: Airbus formally launches superjumbo

fields.headline: Airbus formally launches superjumbo
fields.trailText: European plane manufacturers Airbus today formally launched its new 555-seater superjumbo, which will create 22,000 new jobs in the UK.
fields.body:
European plane manufacturers Airbus today formally launched its new 555-seater superjumbo, which will create 22,000 new jobs in the UK.

Previously codenamed the A3XX, the plane, whose wings are built by UK company BAE Systems, is to be called the A380.

The new aircraft will go into service in 2006, and is to be partly built at BAE facilities in Filton near Bristol and also at Broughton in north Wales,.

In anticipation of the Airbus announcement, BAE had already taken on around 300 engineers at Filton and a further 1,700 engineers are being recruited at Broughton.

Thousands of other jobs in the UK will be created and it is thought that the superjumbo will bring in £20bn worth of exports for the UK over the next 20 years.

BAE Systems' chief operating officer Mike Turner said: "Today marks the real beginning for the most important civil aircraft project the world has witnessed for several decades." The company added that the double-decker plane, which has a range of more than 8,000 miles, would bring economic benefits to the UK for around 40 years.

Sir Richard Branson's airline Virgin Atlantic announced last week that it would take six of the new superjumbos, whose creation, Airbus claims will "forever change how people think about travel".

Virgin plan to put a host of new facilities in the roomy new planes including beds, gyms, bars, showers, and play areas.

The Virgin £2.6bn order took the number of firm orders for the A380 to 50 - a figure that prompted today's formal go-ahead for the aircraft's production. Other airlines that have committed themselves to the A3XX are Australian carrier Qantas, Middle East carrier Emirates, Air France, Singapore Airlines and US aircraft leasing company ILFC.

Shortly before today's announcement, the US president, Bill Clinton, said that the USA believed that the launch loans for the new plane made to Airbus by the British and German governments had violated World Trade Organisation rules. The British government has given a £530m repayable loan for the £7.3bn project.

However, the European Commission said today that the loans were in line with both a 1992 UK-US trade agreement as well as a 1994 WTO agreement.

Airbus had originally joined forces with American rival Boeing in attempting to develop a superjumbo. But Boeing dropped out and decided not to press ahead with a new large aircraft of its own, its bosses disputing Airbus' claims that there will be big demand for such planes in the future.

Airbus reckons that as many as 1,550 ultra-large aircraft, worth around £2.3bn, will be needed over the next two decades. The company has listed the cost of an A380 at around £150m - not much more than a traditional Boeing 747 jumbo jet, which can only seat about 413 people.

Airbus said today: "This decision heralds a new era in the history of flight, with the introduction into service of the world's 21st century jetliner in early 2006."

Manfred Bischoff, the chairman of the Airbus supervisory board, said the A380 represented a "great day" for the company.

"We cannot be more proud of the product we developed. We intend to once more set a standard for quality and efficient," he added.

But Boeing dropped out and decided not to press ahead with a new large aircraft of its own, its bosses disputing Airbus' claims that there will be big demand for such planes in the future. Airbus reckons that as many as 1,550 ultra-large aircraft, worth around £2.3bn, will be needed over the next two decades. The company has listed the cost of an A380 at around £150m - not much more than a traditional Boeing 747 jumbo jet, which can only seat about 413 people. Airbus said today: "This decision heralds a new era in the history of flight, with the introduction into service of the world's 21st century jetliner in early 2006." Manfred Bischoff, the chairman of the Airbus supervisory board, said the A380 represented a "great day" for the company. "We cannot be more proud of the product we developed. We intend to once more set a standard for quality and efficient," he added. webTitle: Cost cutter takes helm

fields.headline: Cost cutter takes helm
fields.trailText: Shell threw down the gauntlet to its rivals yesterday with the appointment of a new chairman and an aggressive set of targets for growth and returns to shareholders.
fields.body:
Shell threw down the gauntlet to its rivals yesterday with the appointment of a new chairman and an aggressive set of targets for growth and returns to shareholders.

Mark Moody-Stuart steps down from the chairmanship in June 2001 after a rollercoaster four years for the industry and its second largest listed company.

Phil Watts, a west Africa veteran and Shell lifer, takes his place in a break with tradition at the Anglo-Dutch group, which has tended to alternate Dutch and British executives at the helm. The news pleased in vestors. "He's a cost cutter," said one fund manager. Mr Watts, 55, who joined Shell in 1969, is seen as the steely edge of a firm that has not always reacted as quickly as investors wished.

"Last year the staff had capital discipline written on their shaving and make-up mirrors. I think they're now dreaming of capital discipline," Mr Watts told the company's annual annual strategy presentation.

Shell said instead long-term growth would be underpinned by a "disciplined" rise in yearly capital investments. Its cost improvement targets are expected to rise by $1bn (£680m) to $5bn a year.

webTitle: Eurosport to launch six websites

fields.headline: Eurosport to launch six websites
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: Sports TV channel Eurosport is to launch six new websites, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Pan-European sports TV channel Eurosport has launched a number of country-specific websites, including its first sports site dedicated to the UK market.

Six new websites have been launched in all, adding to the pan-European Eurosport.com, launched for Euro 2000.

Eurosport.co.uk is in talks with sports rights holders about using the site as a live broadcast medium in future.

In the interim, it has to make do with covering live games by typing out the minute-by-minute action and some archive audio and video clips. The website will be heavily trailed on British Eurosport.

Laurent-Eric Le Lay, Eurosport Enterprises director, said the local sites were intended to allow fans to get behind-the-scenes of sports.

"Our pan-European site in English, eurosport.com, will continue to give broad coverage of all major European sporting events, but now with the creation of eurosport.co.uk, we will let fans get behind-the-scenes of the sports they love most, with their own local heroes," he said.

Eurosport.com was launched in January 1999 and claims to pull in 30m page impressions per month from some 1.8m unique users.

webTitle: BBC unveils plans for 'media village'

fields.headline: BBC unveils plans for 'media village'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BBC
fields.trailText:
1.45pm: The BBC today unveiled an extraordinary plan for a £200m media, shopping and leisure centre at White City, writes Jason Deans.
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
The BBC has today revealed an extraordinary plan for a £200m media, shopping and leisure centre in its White City base in west London.

The corporation has submitted proposals for a new broadcasting, presentation and transmission centre, a new home for the BBC Symphony Orchestra, BBC Singers and BBC Symphony Chorus.

The centre will also house a shopping and leisure centre and accommodation for other media organisations in a development that has echoes of the recently aborted plans for a new national stadium.

Today the BBC was stressing that it would not be using licence payers money for the eight-building development.

And it said it would farm out the running of the leisure centre to a private firm.

More than £200m of private investment is expected to go into the media village development on Wood Lane.

John Smith, BBC director of finance and business affairs, said: "With the proposed new shopping centre at Shepherds Bush, Wood Lane is undergoing a transformation.

"We want to help that process by giving people reasons to visit us, to feel the thrill of a lively broadcasting centre and enjoy the facilities of a thriving neighbourhood."

The 131,000 square metre site around the BBC's existing White City complex, which will house up to 6,000 staff, is to be developed by the property joint venture for which the corporation is in the process of finding a commercial partner.

Two consortia, Insight and Foresite, have been shortlisted to become the BBC's property partner.

Insight is backed by Trillium and Land Securities, while Foresite has been formed by Amey Ventures, Barclays Private Equity and Arrowcroft Group.

The BBC spokeswoman said one of the two was expected to be selected as a preferred bidder by February, with final contract details finalised by spring 2001.

The first BBC staff are expected to move into the media village in 2003 and the complex is scheduled for completion in 2007.

Three-quarters of the accommodation will be for BBC staff, but the corporation is also planning to offer premises to other media companies.

In addition, the BBC is proposing to build a leisure centre and shops that will be open to local residents as part of moves to develop closer links with the local community.

The BBC has submitted a planning application to Hammersmith and Fulham Council.

webTitle: Global petition puts pressure on US to abolish death penalty

fields.headline: Global petition puts pressure on US to abolish death penalty
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Opponents of the death penalty opened a political front against the next US president, George W Bush, yesterday by presenting the United Nations with a petition of 3.2m signatures from 146 countries.
fields.body:
Opponents of the death penalty opened a political front against the next US president, George W Bush, yesterday by presenting the United Nations with a petition of 3.2m signatures from 146 countries.

A coalition of intellectuals, entertainers and religious and human rights groups said the petition marked a stepping-up in the campaign for moratoriums on capital punishment.

The petition was handed to the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, in New York, but its focus was on Mr Bush, who has approved more executions than any other US governor in modern times during his tenure in Texas. The objective is to exploit America's growing fear that innocent people are ending up on death row.

The Rome-based Community of Sant'Egidio, an independent Roman Catholic group which promotes peace in Africa and the Balkans, organised the petition.

It said the death penalty dehumanised the world by putting vengeance first.

The signatories include the Dalai Lama; the Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid; the Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey; the writer Umberto Eco; the film director Roberto Benigni; and the World Methodist Council president, Frances Alguire.

Sister Helen Prejean, author of the book Dead Man Walking, told Mr Annan that the petition was aimed at the estimated 90 countries where capital punishment remains legal.

Executions are common in China, Iraq, India, Iran, Pakistan, the Palestinian Authority territories, Saudi Arabia and Nigeria.

More than 660 people have been executed in the US since the death penalty was reintroduced in 1976. It is supported by two out of three Americans.

As Texas governor, Mr Bush backed a law to shorten delays between convictions and executions, blocked a bill to ban the execution of people with learning disabilities, and presided over the first execu tion of a woman since the civil war. Overseeing more than 150 deaths did his popularity no harm.

Sant'Egidio senses that this campaign against the death penalty may succeed where others failed because of revelations about incompetent defence lawyers and dishonest prosecutors and police officers, and the fact that a disproportionate number of black and Hispanic convicts have been condemned.

In January the Illinois governor, George Ryan, imposed a moratorium after 13 death-row inmates were shown to have been wrongly convicted. Such scandals have rattled confidence in the system.

The Pope is expected to use his new year message to the world to once again condemn capital punishment.

Italy's opposition was highlighted this year when the Colosseum in Rome was bathed in light for 48 hours every time a death penalty was suspended or commuted or a country abolished capital punishment. The ceremony ends this month.

webTitle: Tories give BBC 'media village' cautious thumbs-up

fields.headline: Tories give BBC 'media village' cautious thumbs-up
fields.standfirst:
1.45pm: BBC unveils 'media village'
Special report: the BBC
fields.trailText:
4pm update" The Tories have given the BBC's £200m White City "media village" plan a cautious welcome, writes Jason Deans.
1.45pm: BBC unveils 'media village'
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
The Tories have given the BBC's £200m White City "media village" plan a cautious welcome.

But Peter Ainsworth, the shadow culture secretary, said: "Developments like this serve to highlight the growing tensions between the BBC's commercial activities and its public service remit."

He added that last week's communications white paper had "really ducked this issue completely".

Mr Ainsworth said he was "not, in principle, hostile" to the public/private partnership the BBC is putting together to develop the Wood Lane site, "provided the deal is structured to ensure there is no risk to licence-fee funded core services".

But he added that the "media village" proposal, which includes the development of a leisure centre and shops, was "part and parcel of a tendency we've noticed at the BBC recently to go for growth".

webTitle: Opinion: Impunity rules in Chile

fields.headline: Impunity rules in Chile
fields.standfirst: Tito Tricot, who was tortured under the Pinochet regime, reacts to the charges against the former dictator being dropped As charges against Pinochet are dropped, Tito Tricot, who was tortured under the general's regime, writes on the state of Chile's judicial system
fields.trailText: Opinion: Tito Tricot, who was tortured under the Pinochet regime, reacts to the charges against the former dictator being dropped.
fields.body:
My mouth fills with purple butterflies ready to paint the sky with their fragile wings and a century-old rage when I hear the term "impunity".

That's exactly what is happening in Chile at the moment, because General Pinochet remains untouchable. Every time somebody or something approaches, however timidly, his military, political and judicial fortress, obscure forces go into action to protect the dictator's golden retirement.

Well, not that obscure anymore. To its disgrace, the civilian government protects Pinochet and the military. In an unprecedented and baffling move, President Ricardo Lagos recently invited, of his own volition, army general Hernán Ramirez to the presidential palace. Baffling because the general is being tried as an accomplice to the murder of trade union leader Tucapel Jimenez in 1982.

Sickening too, for the Association of Relatives of the Disappeared have been asking for over a month to meet with the president to no avail. What kind of country are we living in when murderers, torturers and rapists are more important and treated with more respect than the victims of the dictatorship's repression?

What kind of democracy are we living under when the government bows down to military pressure every time the latter show their discontent for judicial resolutions? This is what happened when the government gave in to the armed forces' demand to convoke a special meeting of the national security council. The military's anger arose from a judge's decision to prosecute Pinochet on charges of kidnapping and murdering 76 Chileans in October 1973.

The council was created by the dictatorship so that the armed forces would have a formal voice in the country's internal affairs in times of crisis. However, Pinochet's indictment does not constitute a crisis; it's just a legal proceeding in a criminal case. To call for a meeting of the council is simply unconstitutional. But who cares? Chile is a strange country with a peculiar type of democracy where everyone rules except the people. A strange country where the military lost their power, but none of the cowardly politicians had the courage to tell them.

So they just keep ruling the country as in the good old times. Not that they need it, because the supreme court also protects Pinochet. The magistrates had no problem in overruling a brave judge's decision to indict the general. So, it's back to square one again: Pinochet is still a free man, the military are happy and the government is relieved, because they fear the military.

The Catholic church also protects the military, for in a recent liturgical ceremony the bishops asked for forgiveness for all sins committed in the last three decades. As if we were all guilty of what happened in Chile before and after the military coup in 1973.

Whenever I see the dictator's smile, whenever I see his bodyguards act in the same arrogant way as they did for nearly two decades, I think of Mauricio's beautiful dreamy eyes, for he took part in the ambush to kill the dictator back in 1986.

They failed and Pinochet escaped. Mauricio did not give up the struggle for democracy and freedom, he went underground and was finally arrested after a shootout with hundreds of secret police agents. He was shot seven times, his legs were nearly destroyed by machine-gun fire and a bullet went right through his forehead.

"When I was dying," he told me,"I could only think of my little boy and how I would never see him again". But Mauricio did not die, amazingly he survived. We spent about three months in a prison hospital together before being moved to the prison itself. We shared a room in hospital, learnt to walk again and never gave up our dignified attitude.

I was eventually released and Mauricio escaped from prison along with 40 other political prisoners. Sadly he died of cancer shortly afterwards. He was only 32 years old, courageous, firm, but sweet. His only regret in life was that the ambush against Pinochet did not succeed. He remembered with sadness how the dictator got away in his armoured vehicle: "We just ran after him firing our guns, his bodyguards presented no resistance, they ran away like rats," he used to say proudly.

Today, where impunity rules in Chile, the Chile you fought for Mauricio, there are many that refuse to erase your memory from their memory. The dictatorship invented an amnesty law to protect human rights violators; the civilian government is now talking about "justice with clemency" to protect murderers and torturers.

You either have justice or you don't, anything else is just a euphemism for immunity and impunity. The government and the military want to find a way out of the human rights issue, they want to put an end to this problem. But this is not a problem for the thousands of victims of the repression, it is simply the desire for justice to be done; it is not a problem, but a moral obligation.

What they cannot understand, Mauricio, is that we will never forget your simple smile, sweet as a pink cloud. We will never cease to repair broken dreams, no matter how long it takes. Only when our right to justice is respected can we laugh at the purple butterflies painting the sky with their sparrow's jump.

webTitle: How Britain hit the bottle

fields.headline: How Britain hit the bottle
fields.standfirst: In the past 35 years our alcohol intake has shot up. More than 9m of us are now drinking at dangerous levels and our European neighbours regard us as drunks. In fact the only people who don't think Britain has a drink problem are the British.  Gary Younge  on a nation in denial
fields.trailText: In the past 35 years our alcohol intake has shot up. More than 9m of us are now drinking at dangerous levels and our European neighbours regard us as drunks. In fact the only people who don't think Britain has a drink problem are the British. Gary Younge on a nation in denial
fields.body:
From the Tannoy of Finsbury Park station comes a familiar message. The 8.33pm to Hertford North has been cancelled. The three middle-aged men, accompanied by one young boy, have an hour to kill and there is only one thing for it. "Let's go to the pub," says one. "These bloody trains will drive you to drink." They will also drive you with drink.

The majority of those who board the next train are carrying bottles of beer. About a quarter of the carriage is drunk. When we arrive at Stevenage the walkway between the town centre and the leisure park, a thoroughfare between town and clubland, teenage boys clutch pints of lager as though they were tickets to manhood.

It's Saturday night and you can almost hear the drum beats of a primal British ritual pounding. It's time for the smallest market town and the largest urban centre to bury their differences in a sea of beer and Bacardi Breezers. By the end of the night, young women with glazed eyes will link arms and sing anything from Frank Sinatra to The Wizard of Oz; young men will support themselves against the nearest immovable object and then urinate on it. It's Saturday night: time to "get hammered", "blasted" and "go mad for it". It's time, in short, for alcohol to take over.

"British social culture is built around drink," says Eric Appleby of Alcohol Concern. "If you're going to meet people after work you meet them in a pub. If you're going out for a chat you'll go to a pub and in the pub there is a macho thing about how many drinks you've had. Drinking alcohol then becomes the primary social activity."

So while the social scenes of most American sitcoms, such as Seinfeld, Friends or Frasier, take place in coffee bars and diners, all English soap characters like to mull over their problems at the Woolpack, the Rovers Return or the Queen Vic. If Jim Davidson, the comedian and Tory MC, wants to impress his colleague and co-star, the TV presenter Suzi Perry, he falls off the wagon and drinks himself silly. "As soon as I saw her I fell in love with her," he said. "I decided I'd try everything I could to pull her. I started cracking open the champagne, fell into a bottle and stayed there. I was absolutely smashed. I woke up the next morning with my first hangover since 1994."

And, being a dominant factor in our social culture, alcohol is increasingly becoming a major issue in our political culture. When the leader of the opposition wants to look like a man of the people, he recalls his days drinking 14 pints as a teenager and the 32 rum and blacks he claims he downed on his 18th birthday.

When the prime minister is looking for the central theme of what will almost certainly be the final parliamentary session, he reaches for the bottle and declares war on "yob culture". When his son, Euan, was found inebriated in Leicester Square it was not just a blow to him as a father but a political embarrassment to the head of a government that had just proposed spot fines for those found drunk in public.

Back in Stevenage a young woman, in a short skirt despite the bitter cold, stands outside the Pulse nightclub with her head in a bin. While one friend puts a coat over her back so that no one can see her knickers, the other holds her hair out of her face as she retches. A sight so common that no one is watching.

Inside the Vogue nightclub next door, Peter and Dave have been drinking since lunchtime. Peter, 35, has custody of his two children every other weekend. On his weekends off he "goes out and gets smashed". Dave runs out of fingers and moves on to his toes as he counts how many drinks he has had that day and then laughs a cheery, leery, glazed laugh, while expressing amazement that they're still standing.

By the time the night is over the car park will be spattered with vomit. A young man staggers dangerously and aimlessly down a main road shouting: "I'm a he man." Another, perched precariously against a burger van, yells: "You're a cunt."

Britain has a drink problem. We drink almost two-thirds more alcohol per person today than we did in 1965. More than 9m adults drink at levels that endanger their long-term health, and more than one in 25 of us is alcohol-dependent. While it is an issue affecting the whole country, some places and people are in more trouble than others. The proportion of women drinking over the limit rose by 55% between 1984 to 1996. Glasgow is facing the worst incidence of alcohol abuse for 80 years. Most vulnerable are the young - a third of young men live on "beer and fast food"; a quarter of 16- to 19-year-olds in greater Glasgow get drunk at least once a week.

It has cast a serious pall over the way other countries see us. According to a British Council report recently, those aged between 24 and 40 around the world regard Britons as "violent, xenophobic and frequently drunk".

And it is costing us dearly. Not just in human terms - 28,000 deaths a year are alcohol-related - but economically. Every year alcohol costs the NHS around £150m, industry an estimated £2bn and the government roughly £150m, according to Alcohol Concern.

But, curiously, it is not the amount we drink that marks us out as a nation. Even though we drink considerably more than we used to, we still drink a lot less than most other European Union countries. That is particularly true of France and Germany, where Chancellor Gerhard Schröder recently made it to number two in the music charts when a DJ put music to a recording of him saying: "Get me a bottle of beer or I'm going to go on strike here." With the exception of Finland and Sweden - where, like here, they binge drink - no other EU country drinks less than Britain.

This is borne out in other areas. Britons are far less likely to die from cirrhosis of the liver than citizens of any other EU country with the exception of the Irish and the Dutch. The incidence of road traffic accidents involving alcohol is also substantially lower than the EU average.

Our drinking habits have also changed quite radically. Europe has traditionally been split up into drinking cultures determined principally by climate. Colder, northern countries (the UK, Germany, Austria) are beer-drinking cultures, while warmer, southern nations (Italy, France, Spain) drink wine. Now those habits are converging. The proportion of beer in our national alcohol intake has dropped by a quarter, while wine has more than doubled.

So if we drink less than most other European countries and are increasingly drinking the same kind of things, why does a Saturday night out in Lisbon, Barcelona or Lyon never have quite the same chaotic, threatening feel as London, Birmingham or Liverpool?

The problem, say experts, is the way that we drink. "In most other countries they drink with food or as part of some other social activity," says Mr Appleby. "Here we mainly drink to drink and quite often to get drunk. The particular thing about British drinking culture is that it is associated with aggression."

"The problems in Europe relating to alcohol are largely medical whereas in Britain they are about disorder," says professor Nick Heather, who is the director of the centre of alcohol and drug studies in Newcastle. "They may drink more on the continent but they drink consistently and regularly whereas we drink in short bursts."

The reason for this cannot be found in the British psyche but in the history of our licensing laws and cultural make-up, argues Dr Paul Davis, a consultant clinical psychologist who specialises in addictive behaviour. "Until the very end of the 20th century, the law squashed the hours when we could drink into a relatively small space of time so we learned to drink quickly and in quite a focused way," says Dr Davis, who believes bingeing has been a key element in British drinking culture since before the Victorian era.

"And because we drink as a separate activity, away not just from food but from children, our drinking habits are not regulated by other social norms, which makes deviant behaviour far more likely." The situation in Scotland, which has enjoyed more relaxed laws for far longer but has more acute problems than the rest of the UK, is underpinned by different historical and cultural factors, he says.

Whatever the reasons, the consequences are there for all to see every weekend on almost every high street in Britain. As such, it marks an ideal point for Blairite intervention - a place where individual rights meet societal responsibilities without the encumbrance of ideology. A populist issue where the boundaries between private and public are necessarily blurred. A problem that appears to demand New Labour's increasingly familiar strain of social authoritarianism in the name of common sense and decency.

By maintaining the distinction between the nation's most popular drug and other drugs, from cannabis to heroin and crack, the government has left alcohol out of the broader picture. It does not feature in the high-profile, cross-cabinet assault on drugs; there is no alcohol tsar. By concentrating on "yob culture", says Prof Heather, "They are responding to a real and growing problem in this country. But the sheer quantity and severity of problems created by alcohol abuse are many times greater than all those caused by illicit drugs put together."

And even though alcohol abuse has a serious effect in every area that the government has made a priority, from homelessness to health, from crime to education (one in four school exclusions is related to alcohol) there has been no coordinated approach to the issue. The response has emanated from Downing Street and the Home Office and has been framed strictly in terms of crime and punishment.

Launching its action plan to tackle alcohol-related crime in August, the Home Office called for greater use of existing laws to confiscate alcohol from young people and to prevent the sale of alcohol to them as well as new powers for the police to close premises associated with violent and disorderly behaviour.

The approach is useful as far as it goes, say alcohol experts. The problem is that it doesn't nearly go far enough. "It's a start," says Mr Appleby. "But we need a national alcohol strategy that deals with issues across the board rather than just the behavioural end of it. They are relatively safe while they're just dealing with yob culture. webTitle: Sixty-two journalists killed in 2000

fields.headline: Sixty-two journalists killed in 2000
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Sixty-two journalists have been killed this year according to new figures, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Sixty-two journalists have been killed in 2000 in the course of their work, according to new figures from the International Federation of Journalists.

Although the number of journalists and media workers killed has fallen by 25 from the 1999 figure of 87, the International Federation of Journalists says the statistics are worrying.

More journalists are being killed while in the course of reporting on corruption or exposing political dissent than ever before, say the IFJ.

It welcomes a recent agreement by a number of media organisations to sign up for a code of conduct to protect their staff in hostile conditions.

The report highlights a number of cases of high-profile journalists killed in the course of their work.

It pays tribute to Jose Luis Lopez de la Calle, a Spanish journalists who was shot dead after criticism of the Basque separatist group ETA, Russian radio station owner Sergei Novikov, and Kurt Schork of Reuters and Miguel Gil Moreno of AP, who were both killed in an ambush in Sierra Leone earlier this year.

webTitle: Glasgow threatens to pull out of Cosla

fields.headline: Glasgow threatens to pull out of Cosla
fields.trailText: Glasgow city council has threatened to pull out of the Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) in protest at this year's local government finance settlement.
fields.body:
Glasgow city council has threatened to pull out of the Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) in protest at this year's local government finance settlement.

Council leader Charles Gordon said he felt that Cosla did not stand up for the city's interests in this year's finance negotiations with the Scottish Executive.

The council is to consider withdrawing from the organisation at a meeting in February. If it does carry out its threat, it will spend its £300,000-a-year affiliation fee on services for children with special needs.

Glasgow is the largest contributor to Cosla's budget.

Cosla president Norman Murray said the organisation would continue to represent Scotland's 31 other local councils.

"While their decision to withdraw is disappointing, it has to be remembered that Glasgow is but one of 32 councils in Scotland," he said.

webTitle: BT slated by telecom rivals

fields.headline: BT slated by telecom rivals
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: BT has been accused of dragging its heels over high-speed internet access, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Disgruntled telephone operators have lashed out at BT over the next generation of internet services.

Speaking at an influential trade and industry select committee, representatives from Thus, Energis, Cable & Wireless and Kingston Communications criticised BT for dragging its feet over building high-speed internet networks.

"What we do know is BT are doing very little to facilitate this process," said Emma Gilthorpe, head of policy for Cable & Wireless in Europe.

BT says 380 of its telephone exchanges will be equipped to provide lucrative broadband internet services by May or June, which has provoked uproar from competitors.

But rivals say that not enough exchanges are being included in the upgrade programme and that the programme is too slow.

"Access is possible, but when will we get it? It will probably by May or June and that is unacceptable," said Huw Saunders, Kingston Communications technology development director.

The now notorious "unbundling" process involves connecting customers' homes to telephone exchnages through disused copper lines which can provide high-speed internet services.

BT is furious with the concerted attack by its rivals. One insider said: "We are a business. What else do you expect?"

BT's competitors also criticised telecoms watchdog Oftel for allowing the company to set up its own broadband services without giving a pricing structure to operators wanting to use the same network.

"The economic viability of unbundling is still unclear, " said Bill Allan, Thus chief executive.

webTitle: Hague to let councils decide on housebuilding

fields.headline: Hague to let councils decide on housebuilding
fields.trailText: Every town in Britain would be allowed to create its own "green belt" to protect farmland and open spaces from development, under proposals unveiled by Tory leader William Hague today.
fields.body:
Every town in Britain would be allowed to create its own "green belt" to protect farmland and open spaces from development, under proposals unveiled by Tory leader William Hague today.

In a radical initiative to halt excessive development in the countryside, Mr Hague promised to scrap national housebuilding guidelines and let each local council decide for itself on its requirements for new homes.

The move came a day after planning minister Nick Raynsford announced that the government was cutting back the housebuilding target for south-east England from 43,000 to 39,000 homes.

The cut followed Tory accusations that Labour was "concreting over the countryside", but the new target remains well above the 33,000 homes a year - a number the regional planning body Serplan believes the region can cope with.

Visiting threatened green belt in Hemel Hempstead, Herts, today, Mr Hague said: "Instead of protecting our countryside, John Prescott is issuing Soviet-style diktats to local councils, forcing them to ensure the construction of millions of buildings over the next 20 years.

"In an act of supreme environmental vandalism, Whitehall bureaucrats, with their central planning targets, intend to cover England's green fields with unwanted housing estates and executive homes."

Under the Tories, communities would be given the right to appeal against unpopular large-scale developments in their area, ending the current anomaly under which only developers have the right to appeal if proposals are turned down, said Mr Hague.

Councils would also be given powers to enforce the use of local architectural styles and materials in new developments, to prevent the creation of 'identikit' estates all over the country, he added.

However, the Chartered Institute of Housing has criticised Mr Hague's call for housebuilding targets to be abolished.

A spokesperson said: "There must be some way of assessing housing needs, monitoring building levels, and reviewing these in the context of demand and supply.

"Without building targets, we risk insufficient housing to meet demand and this would have implications in high demand areas for both prospective owner-occupiers through increased house prices and the opportunity to obtain rented homes for those unable to afford house purchase.

"There are, however, some real questions about how housing needs can be assessed reliably. These problems need to be tackled, rather than rejecting the whole idea of trying to plan at a more strategic level at all. The importance of targets for affordable housing also needs to be recognised."

webTitle: France bans blood from visitors to UK

fields.headline: France bans blood from visitors to UK
fields.standfirst: Special report: BSE
fields.trailText: The French government today announced it was banning blood donations of people who spent more than a year in Britain from 1980 to 1996, a precautionary measure against health risks related to BSE.
fields.body:
The French government today announced it was banning blood donations of people who spent more than a year in Britain from 1980 to 1996, a precautionary measure against health risks related to BSE.

The move aimed to screen out donors with a higher risk of exposure to meat tainted with BSE. The brain-wasting ailment originated in Britain in the late 70s, probably as a mutation of a sheep disease. By the mid-90s, Britain was seeing tens of thousands of cases a year.

Fears about BSE and its health risks to humans have surged in France since October, when potentially infected beef was discovered on the country's supermarket shelves. Since then, the government has taken stringent measures to prevent the disease's spread, even banning some cuts as popular as the T-bone steak.

Today's measure was purely precautionary, the government insisted. It said there was no proof that variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease, believed to be the human form of BSE, can be transmitted through the blood.

"This decision will be reevaluated in light of any new scientific information that would put in question the risk analysis on which [the decision] is founded," the communique said.

France's move follows a decision last month by the Swiss Red Cross to implement a ban on blood donations from people who lived in Britain between 1980 and 1996.

People are thought to contract vCJD by eating beef infected with BSE. Two people are known to have died in France from the ailment, compared to 81 people in Britain. The disease eats holes in the brain, and no cure has been discovered.

In 1996, the European Union banned imports of beef from Britain, and millions of British cows were incinerated.

The safety of donated blood has been a key concern in France since the "tainted blood" affair of 1985, in which more than 4,000 people contracted the HIV virus from blood transfusions. Many have since died, and several government officials stood trial over the affair.

webTitle: Johnston Press bullish about profits

fields.headline: Johnston Press upbeat about profits
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: Regional newspaper group Johnston Press has predicted higher than expected profits, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Regional Newspaper Group Johnston Press has bucked predictions for a downturn in advertising sales revenue with an upbeat trading statement.

Johnston said its year-end profits would be ahead of City estimates, and its shares rose 2.5% to 357.5 in early trading.

The statement comes as some newspaper publishers are becoming jittery about a projected downturn in advertising revenues that led to a Dow Jones profit warning and a freeze on hiring at News International.

Johnston is one of several newspaper groups bidding for Regional Independent Media, who own the Yorkshire Post and Lancashire Post.
