fields.body:
Yves St Laurent will almost certainly be forced to seek approval for all its ads for the next two years after it broke advertising regulations with its raunchy Sophie Dahl Opium posters.

Advertising watchdogs said they were now considering whether to subject Yves St Laurent to the sanction, which would cause the company serious inconvenience.

The Advertising Standards Authority introduced the the pre-vetting procedures two years ago as a deterrent to companies such as Benetton, which repeatedly offended the public with controversial adverts.

"It is now up to the industry to decide whether Yves St Laurent will be subject to pre-vetting. They will consider this over Christmas and the New Year," said Christopher Graham, director general of the ASA.

The decision will be taken by the Committee of Advertising Practice, a self-regulatory body made up of representatives from advertising and the media.

Watchdogs ordered the removal of around 500 posters carrying the image after it received 730 complaints from the public.

A spokesman for the ASA said the campaign with the most complained about for five years.

The authority ruled that the positioning of the posters beside schools and mosques contravened its rule that all advertising must be "legal, decent, honest and truthful".

"You have to look at these things in context. We first saw this as a magazine ad and that attracted only three complaints. But when it appeared on the high street next to schools, churches and mosques we felt that was clearly not decent," said Mr Graham.

The controversial ad for Opium perfume showed Ms Dahl posing naked on a fur rug cupping one breast in her hand and wearing nothing but gold stiletto-heeled shoes.

Yves Saint Laurent today defended the image. In a statement the company said it was "never the intention to cause any offence".

The advertiser has got into hot water with the ASA before, over an ad for its Absolus Contours skin cream.

The ASA found claims that the cream would lead to "a slimmer, firmer-looking body" could not be substantiated and ordered Yves Saint Laurent to pull the ads.

Yves St Laurent is one of the biggest advertisers in its sector, spending around £4m a year.

The first advertiser to be subjected to pre-vetting was the Commission for Racial Equality, which got into hot water over a campaign that used deliberately racist images to test people's reaction.

webTitle: Ribena goes to court over 'Tooth Kind' claims

fields.headline: Ribena goes to court over 'Tooth Kind' claims
fields.trailText: 1pm: Ribena maker SmithKline Beecham is to challenge the Advertising Standards Authority in court over ad claims, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The maker of Ribena Tooth Kind will today go to the high court to challenge an Advertising Standards Authority ruling that it made misleading claims about the product.

Drugs giant SmithKline Beecham has taken the authority's ruling to a judicial review because it believes it should be able to carry on claiming that the product does not cause tooth decay.

The ASA ruled in July that the company could not use the claim, "Ribena Tooth Kind does not encourage tooth decay", in its advertising.

The court case is being seen as a landmark case that could have widespread repercussions for all food and drink manufacturers.

Parental concern over claims about sugar, vitamin and additives in food and drink has intensified in the past decade and consumer groups will be keenly awaiting the Ribena verdict.

The ASA said it understood from expert advice that the sugar content of Ribena Tooth Kind had been lowered but not eliminated.

It concluded that meant the product was less likely to encourage tooth decay, but only if compared with sugary drinks.

SmithKline Beecham is claiming the watchdog was not equipped to evaluate its claims.

The ASA was not the first to take issue with Ribena's claims. A Which? magazine investigation last March criticised Ribena Tooth Kind, saying that it fell short of the healthy image that helped to sell it.

The court is expected to defer its decision until the new year.

webTitle: Knesset keeps Bibi out in the cold

fields.headline: Knesset keeps Bibi out in the cold
fields.standfirst:
Netanyahu's comeback bid thwarted by decision not to hold general elections

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: An audacious comeback bid by former prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu has been foiled by Israeli parliamentarians.
fields.body:
An audacious comeback bid by former prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu has been foiled by Israeli parliamentarians.

After the knesset voted against holding general elections, Netanyahu announced that he was withdrawing from the separate prime ministerial poll, due on February 6.

The way is now open for a two-horse race between Netanyahu's successor as prime minister, Ehud Barak, and his successor as leader of the rightwing Likud faction, Ariel Sharon.

The early-morning manoeuvrings of the knesset were extraordinary, even by Israel's rancorous parliamentary standards.

Members first voted to allow non-knesset members to stand for prime minister - which would allow Netanyahu in. Then they voted against new parliamentary elections - which, in effect, froze him out again.

Netanyahu had declared before the vote that he would not run for office unless the knesset simultaneously sought a fresh public mandate.

That was not at all to the taste of the knesset members (MKs), who were elected last year at the same time as Barak, for a four-year term. Many know that in the current turbulent climate, the voters would consign them to political oblivion.

Under Israel's peculiar electoral system, MKs are chosen from national party lists, with voters allowed to indicate their preferences among the slates of candidates. That, along with the separate prime ministerial election, encourages a cult of personality in which charisma (or the lack of it) counts a great deal more than subtlety, wit, or even ideology. It also practically ensures a knesset of perpetually squabbling factions, in which no prime minister can ever be sure of a viable majority.

Netanyahu, universally known as Bibi, is the living embodiment of the system. He clawed his way to the top of the notoriously fractious Likud movement with a combination of dazzling PR skills and ruthless behind-the-scenes power-plays.

In 1996 he snatched the prime ministerial election from Shimon Peres - the successor to the assassinated Yitzhak Rabin - with a campaign dominated by security fears. But after three years of Bibi's bluster and procrastination with the peace process that Rabin had begun, the voters again opted for renewed dialogue with the Palestinians. The man they chose, Barak, had exactly the blend of qualities Israelis crave in their leaders: a bluff former army chief, he promised peace with security; a settlement without too many concessions.

That proved a chimera. Barak moved as far as he dared to offer the Palestinians what they in turn craved: a state of their own. He even offered Yasser Arafat a limited role in Jerusalem. The offer infuriated the Israeli right - and the limits on it also enraged Arafat.

The result was the renewed intifada, sparked at the end of September when the Likud leader, Sharon, made an appallingly ill-judged visit to the Muslim sacred site in Jerusalem.

Since then more than 330 lives have been lost, the overwhelmingly majority of them Palestinian. The fragile economy of the Palestinian territories is wrecked, Israelis are living in constant fear of retaliatory attacks, and the peace process is little more than a memory.

Even now, however, frantic diplomatic efforts are under way to revive some kind of dialogue, with Bill Clinton hoping to use the dying moments of his US presidency to somehow rescue the peace process.

But amid the rising clamour of the Israeli prime ministerial election, it will be hard for any candidate to stray beyond ritual pledges to deal firmly with the unrest.

Barak's chances of retaining power have been increased markedly by the sidelining of Netanyahu. Since he went into self-imposed exile after his defeat, the former prime minister has enjoyed a remarkable return to public esteem.

Opinion polls indicate that in a straight contest, Netanyahu would comfortably beat Barak. The old warhorse Sharon, by contrast, is running no more than neck-and-neck with the present prime minister.

There could yet be another runner in the race: Shimon Peres, four times prime minister and the wiliest politician in the land, is said to be considering yet another tilt at the job. He belongs to Barak's One Nation faction - but party unity and loyalty have never been exactly the most outstanding features of Israeli politics.

webTitle: NTL meets subscriptions target

fields.headline: NTL meets subscriptions target
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Cable operator NTL has broken through the 500,000 barrier for its subscriptions to digital TV services, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Cable operator NTL has broken through the 500,000 barrier for its digital TV services.

NTL announced today that it had met its target number of subscribers for this year.

The US-owned outfit has also reached the 1/2m mark in terms of registered users for its ntlworld free internet service provider offering.

NTL is predicting that the majority of its digital subscribers will also have a cable modem, offering high-speed broadband access to a range of interactive TV, enhanced TV and internet via the TV services, by the end of next year.

Barclay Knapp, NTL president and chief executive, said: "NTL's future is rooted squarely in the exciting new world of broadband services, and although we still have a long way to go, the accelerating take-up of these services means we're starting to get there fast."

Digitalplus, NTL's digital TV, phone, interactive and internet service, offers 120 channels, an electronic programme guide and email.

webTitle: Body Shop backs out of internet venture

fields.headline: Body Shop backs out of internet venture
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: The Body Shop is backing out of an internet deal with Softbank Technology Ventures in a bid to cut costs, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The Body Shop has parted company with internet developer Softbank Technology Ventures in a bid to cut costs.

It is combining its online shopping operations with its existing retail and mail order businesses and aiming primarily at the US online market.

The joint venture with Softbank was set up seven months ago to develop a separate internet business and capitalise on the expected boom in e-commerce.

However, the deal was signed at the height of dot.com fever and the e-commerce market has since bottomed out with internet stocks falling by up to 90% of their May value.

Buying itself out of the pact is a costly decision for the Body Shop. Covering the development work and technology for the jointly owned company called the Body Shop Digital will set it back £4.2m.

The Body Shop's first foray into e-commerce has now been put back to the second half of 2001.

webTitle: Netanyahu rules himself out of election

fields.headline: Netanyahu rules himself out of election
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel & the Middle East
fields.trailText: The former Israeli prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, declared today that he would not run for his old post in the February elections if the current deadlocked parliament remains in place.
fields.body:
The former Israeli prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, declared today that he would not run for his old post in the February elections if the current deadlocked parliament remains in place.

His announcement comes despite his commanding lead in opinion polls and his ardent supporters urging his return to political life.

The declaration all but eliminates Mr Netanyahu as a candidate from the February 6 election and greatly enhances the prospects for the re-election of the current prime minister, Ehud Barak, who has seen his political fortunes wane due to the ongoing Israeli-Palestinian violence.

Provided Mr Netanyahu stays on the sidelines - and he could still change his mind - the election will be a battle between two ex-generals: Mr Barak, who's pushing hard for a peace deal with the Palestinians, and Ariel Sharon.

Mr Sharon, leader of the Likud party, is a veteran right-wing politician who says Israel needs tougher security measures and should make fewer concessions in peace negotiations.

While Mr Netanyahu is far ahead in the polls, Mr Barak and Mr Sharon have been running roughly even against each other.

Until the early hours of today, Mr Netanyahu was ineligible to run for prime minister in the special election because he was not a sitting member of parliament, as required by law.

The Israeli parliament, knesset, changed the law in a late-night session to allow any citizen to run.

The measure was called the "Bibi bill", in reference to Mr Netanyahu's nickname. But moments later, the legislature voted not to disband itself - something that Mr Netanyahu had insisted on as a prerequisite for his running.

Mr Netanyahu, said in a statement today: "Because the knesset didn't have the courage to answer the will of the public and put itself up for new elections, I decided to fulfil my promise.

"I will consider running once the knesset disperses itself."

Mr Barak, meanwhile, told reporters he was pleased that parliament would not disband, thereby saving Israel from what he called "unnecessary elections."

There's little likelihood that parliament will change its mind in coming days.

However, in the complicated machinations of Israeli politics, the potential candidates still had some room for manoeuvre.

As Mr Netanyahu's supporters were calling on him to reconsider, another former prime minister, Shimon Peres, was meeting with lawmakers in efforts to make a decision about running himself.

Mr Peres, 77, is the most liberal of the potential candidates, and recent polls suggest that he could beat Mr Barak in a first round of voting and go on to face Mr Sharon in a second round. The surveys show Mr Sharon leads Mr Peres slightly.

Meanwhile, negotiators from Israel and Palestine were expected in Washington today for meetings with US peace mediators.

There was speculation in the Israeli media about the possibility of a summit with Mr Barak, the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat and the US president, Bill Clinton.

However, the Palestinian information minister, Yasser Abed Rabbo said such a summit could be held only to sign an agreement, not to negotiate, and he doubted that there was enough time to finish a pact.

Mr Sharon declared that since Mr Barak announced his resignation on December 10, he has no right to negotiate an accord. and added that if he became prime minister he would not honour any agreement Mr Barak signs now.

Mr Sharon is reviled by Palestinians and is a polarising figure among Israelis. The current round of violence erupted after his controversial September 28 visit to Jerusalem's Al Aqsa Mosque compound.

Likud leaders have harshly criticised Mr Barak's compromise offers to the Palestinians. Most of Mr Barak's coalition partners walked out over the concessions last July, though no peace agreement was reached.

Mr Barak has lost more support because of the violence, which has taken more than 330 lives, most of them Palestinians.

webTitle: Demon founder laughs off newspaper reports

fields.headline: Demon founder laughs off 'stripper' reports in Sunday newspaper
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Demon Internet founder Cliff Stanford has laughed off a newspaper report about his alleged antics with two 'strippers', writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Cliff Stanford, the millionaire behind Demon Internet and investment firm Redbus, has laughed off a report in last weekend's News of the World about his alleged antics with two "strippers".

The "tycoon with the Midas touch" was flabbergasted by the piece that appeared in Sunday's paper, which suggested he had "no inhibitions" and "breathtaking hidden assets".

Mr Stanford, who according to the NoW does a neat trick with two strippers, a punnet of strawberries and a bottle of champagne, said he wishes it were true - or at least his girlfriend Sylvia did.

"Sylvia has been asking where the hell she can get some strawberries at this time of the year," he said, taking it on the chin.

Mr Stanford said that he had been set up but that he didn't give a damn and was not going to waste time suing the paper.

However, he said that he thought the NoW treatment of a good friend, Colombian Nancy Watson, was out of order.

In the article she was portrayed as a "stripper" with whom he was involved in a threesome. "That is not the case," he said, "She is over here studying English and has been very hurt by the piece."

Mr Stanford said he hoped that the kiss'n' tell stripper, Natalie Turner, who sold the piece to NoW for a rumoured £20,000, earned enough money out of it to have a good holiday.

He said he had met her at the opening night of the Spearmint Rhino club in London where she works as a dancer and she had latched onto him. He said he hadn't thought she had an ulterior motive, not even when the photographer jumped out on him.

People close to Mr Stanford, who netted £33m from the sale of Demon to Scottish Telecom last year, reacted with disbelief at the report.

webTitle: Livingstone appoints adviser on gay issues

fields.headline: Livingstone appoints adviser on gay issues
fields.trailText: London mayor Ken Livingstone today announced his latest cabinet appointment - an adviser on lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender issues.
fields.body:
London mayor Ken Livingstone today announced his latest cabinet appointment - an adviser on lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender issues.

Angela Mason, executive director of Stonewall, will advise him on ways to tackle discrimination and hate crimes against gays and lesbians.

In his election manifesto, Mr Livingstone outlined plans for a same-sex partnership register that would act as a forerunner for civil unions between gay couples, granting them the same legal rights as heterosexual couples. He also announced plans to promote a gay Mardi Gras as a major national and international event.

Ms Mason said she was pleased to accept the post as the mayor's adviser as London had the largest lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community in the country.

She said: "I know that much still needs to be done to make sure that all Londoners, whatever their sexuality, are fully represented in the public life of London, but this is a unique opportunity to help create a modern city where every individual is treated equally and with respect.

"I am looking forward to working with everyone in the very diverse lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community in London. Together we can go a long way to promote, if I can use that word, the interests and needs of our communities and take our part, as equal citizens, in the life of London."
fields.bodyText: London mayor Ken Livingstone today announced his latest cabinet appointment - an adviser on lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender issues. Angela Mason, executive director of Stonewall, will advise him on ways to tackle discrimination and hate crimes against gays and lesbians. In his election manifesto, Mr Livingstone outlined plans for a same-sex partnership register that would act as a forerunner for civil unions between gay couples, granting them the same legal rights as heterosexual couples. He also announced plans to promote a gay Mardi Gras as a major national and international event. Ms Mason said she was pleased to accept the post as the mayor's adviser as London had the largest lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community in the country. She said: "I know that much still needs to be done to make sure that all Londoners, whatever their sexuality, are fully represented in the public life of London, but this is a unique opportunity to help create a modern city where every individual is treated equally and with respect. "I am looking forward to working with everyone in the very diverse lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community in London. Together we can go a long way to promote, if I can use that word, the interests and needs of our communities and take our part, as equal citizens, in the life of London."

webTitle: Schools inspector should be accountable to independent board

fields.headline: Schools inspector should be accountable to independent board
fields.trailText: The chief inspector of schools in England should be accountable to an independent board, MPs recommended today.
fields.body:
The chief inspector of schools in England should be accountable to an independent board, MPs recommended today.

In a clear attack on the outspoken style of the former chief inspector, Chris Woodhead, the House of Commons education select committee says that public comments by the inspector should be based on "scientific evidence".

The MPs also criticise Woodhead's refusal to see researchers who had been asked by the Commission for Racial Equality to examine the role of inspectors in preventing racism in schools.

The committee's report refers to the heated exchanges last month between the MPs and Woodhead, who resigned the next day.

The report argues that an independent board, not the Commons select committee, should hold the chief inspector to account.

webTitle: Newspaper heir Randolph Hearst dies

fields.headline: Newspaper heir Randolph Hearst dies
fields.trailText: Randolph Hearst, the son of newspaper magnate William Hearst, has died aged 85.
fields.body:
Randolph Hearst, the newspaper heir whose daughter Patricia was kidnapped by the revolutionary Symbionese Liberation Army in 1974, died yesterday in a New York hospital after suffering a stroke. He was 85.

Hearst - the last surviving son of the newspaper magnate William Randolph Hearst - was chairman of the family's media empire from 1973 to 1996.

Throughout the kidnap ordeal he left his mansion regularly to face the media and discuss the latest SLA demands.

"Randy was the centre of calm in a very turbulent period," said his nephew, William Randolph Hearst III.

Patricia later denounced her family, took the nom de guerre Tania, and joined in a bank robbery.

She was eventually captured and convicted, and served 21 months in prison.

webTitle: Obituary: Gérard Blain

fields.headline: Gérard Blain
fields.standfirst: Actor whose face launched the New Wave of French cinema
fields.trailText: Actor whose face launched the New Wave of French cinema.
fields.body:
For those who believe that the French New Wave was as seismic an event in cinema as the coming of sound, Gérard Blain, who has died of cancer aged 70, was a key figure. In fact, one could say that he was the first face of the New Wave.

The face was young, handsome and sensitive. The short-statured Blain resembled James Dean in looks and persona, and became the favourite of young critics on the influential magazine Cahiers du Cinéma, who decided, in their battle against the "cinéma du papa", to make films themselves.

François Truffaut chose Blain and his wife, Bernadette Lafont, to play young lovers in the director's first professional film, Les Mistons (The Mischief Makers, 1957). In this charming short, shot rapidly in Nmes one summer, Blain and Lafont obsess a group of pubescent boys, who spy on their lovemaking in the fields.

Blain was also in one of Jean-Luc Godard's first shorts, Charlotte et Son Jules (1958), and was picked to play the title role in arguably the very first New Wave feature, Claude Chabrol's Le Beau Serge (1959). In it, theology student Jean-Claude Brialy (another iconic actor of the period) returns to his native village to find that his talented childhood friend, Blain, has become a hopeless drunk and is estranged from his pregnant wife (Lafont). Blain, in his first leading role, brilliantly expressed the pain of the disappointed character.

Chabrol cast the same two male leads in his second feature, Les Cousins (1959), a riveting and perverse study of decadent Parisian student life. Blain was perfect as the simple, good-hearted country cousin who comes to study at the Sorbonne, while staying at the luxury apartment of his cynical cousin (Brialy).

Blain, who was abandoned as a child by his stable-lad father, was born in Paris. He had been an extra in a few films before director Julien Duvivier discovered the 25-year-old standing at the bar of a cafe in the Champs-Elysées, and gave him a role in Voici Les Temps Des Assassins (1955), starring the great Jean Gabin.

After the two Chabrol features, Blain starred in a number of Italian films, de rigueur for many actors of the 1960s, notably Carlo Lizzani's The Hunchback Of Rome (1960). He also appeared in the gossip columns because of his stormy marriage and divorce from Bernadette Lafont.

When making Les Mistons, Truffaut noted: "Gérard is, I think, very unhappy. He bellyaches because I prefer Bernadette in high heels; he has a Toulouse-Lautrec complex. And then he's come to realise that Bernadette is completely at home in front of the camera, and he makes a scene every day."

Actually, Blain never felt completely at ease as an actor, and hankered to direct, although he had to wait some years before he could do so. In the meanwhile, he was part of the international cast of Howard Hawks's Hatari! (1962), about a group of African hunters, led by John Wayne, who catch animals for zoos. Blain was one of a number of leading French actors in the boulevard comedy La Bonne Soupe (1963), and played a resistance fighter who refuses to execute a traitor in Costa-Gavras's Shock Troops (1968).

Blain, whose idols were the ascetic Carl Dreyer and Robert Bresson, directed the first of eight films, Les Amis, in 1970. Labelled Bressonian, his pictures were uncompromising studies of domestic crises, often seen from the child's point of view, which led critics to suspect they were autobiographical. Generally, critics were favourable to him, but the films seldom made money and had distribution problems.

The fact that Blain was a difficult man to work with, and refused to compromise his principles, did not help matters. There was also his ambiguous friendship with members of the National Front, which cast a shadow over Pierre et Djemila (1987), a film which seemed anti-Arab, although the screenplay was written by Mohamed Bouchibi, formerly of the FLN.

Blain, who remarried and had two sons, found his last years particularly difficult. Faced with illness and debt, he still managed to work, and his final film, Ainsi-soit-il (So Be It, 1999), could be seen as a chronicle of his death foretold.

 Gérard Blain, actor and director, born October 23 1930; died December 17 2000

webTitle: Desmond axes Express journalists' newspaper subs

fields.headline: Desmond axes Express journalists' newspaper subs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Express takeover
fields.trailText:
11.45am: Richard Desmond has axed newspaper and magazine subscriptions for all Express journalists, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
Express owner Richard Desmond has axed newspaper and magazine subscriptions for all journalists in his latest cost-cutting exercise.

From today, all journalists including editor Rosie Boycott and other senior editorial staff, will have to pay for all their own newspapers and magazines.

Richard Desmond believes he can save up to £30,000 by forcing journalists to pay for their own newspapers and magazines.

The move has enraged staff who say it is yet another sign that Mr Desmond does not understand how newspapers work.

And they fear it could lead to more cost-cutting.

The company has categorically denied that it plans to axe up to 100 journalists in the new year.

However, rumours of a fierce blood-letting persist and some believe up to 200 jobs could ultimately go. The papers currently employ 450 editorial staff.

"Comparisons are being made with the Daily Mirror, not the Mail. The figure Desmond has mentioned is 170. He says 'how come the Mirror operates on this level and we can't?'," said one source.

But Ms Boycott is believed to have repeatedly asked Mr Desmond for a figure for planned redundancies and has not been given one by him or other Northern & Shell executives.

Ms Boycott was horrified by the way Mr Desmond handled recent redundancies in the sales, marketing and IT departments, accusing him of "heavy-handed" management.

She is opposed to any editorial redundancies, believing that the paper is already under-resourced.

Meanwhile, insiders have staunchly denied reports circulating among Express journalists that Ms Boycott plans to resign at a high-profile charity event tomorrow.

"Rosie simply wouldn't do something like that.She would not hijack a charity event," said one insider.

A spokesman for the Express said Ms Boycott was in discussions with Mr Desmond about adding a new financial section to the Sunday Express, as well as planning to "upgrade" the Sunday Express magazine.

webTitle: In brief: Brosnan goes back in time to hunt dinosaurs

fields.headline: Brosnan goes back in time to hunt dinosaurs
fields.standfirst: Plus: Julia Stiles joins cast of Robert Ludlum thriller; Sundance Festival launces new online resource centre; Gladiator and Traffic top the nominees at the Golden Satellite Awards; Almost Famous continues to pick up prizes
fields.trailText: Plus: Julia Stiles joins cast of Robert Ludlum thriller; Sundance Festival launces new online resource centre; Gladiator and Traffic top the nominees at the Golden Satellite Awards; Almost Famous continues to pick up prizes
fields.body:
 According to the Hollywood Reporter, Pierce Brosnan and director Renny Harlin are teaming for a big screen adaptation of Ray Bradbury's short story, A Sound of Thunder. The pair are said to be in final negotiations to work on the time-travel project. Harlin, who most recently directed the forthcoming Sylvester Stallone drama, Driven, will helm the drama about a game hunter who goes back in time to track dinosaurs in the prehistoric era. But when confronted by a tyrannosaurus, the hunter loses his nerve, stumbles off the path and inadvertently changes history.

 Julia Stiles has signed up to join the Doug Liman-directed spy thriller, The Bourne Identity, alongside Matt Damon. Variety reports that the 19-year-old actress, currently to be seen in cinemas playing Ophelia to Ethan Hawke's Hamlet, will play a Paris-based officer for a US national security agency. The film, based on a novel by Robert Ludlum, tells the story of a fishing crew who rescue an amnesia victim (Damon), only to discover that he is being hunted by assassins.

 The Sundance Institute has created the Sundance Online Resource Centre on the internet to coincide with the 2001 Film Festival which begins on January 18. The site will showcase websites for every film in the festival and provide information on film-makers, panel participants and official activities.

 Ridley Scott's Gladiator and Steven Soderbergh's Traffic continue to do well in the numerous pre-Oscar award ceremonies. The Russell Crowe epic received 10 nominations at the fifth annual Golden Satellite Awards, while Traffic is up for nine gongs. In the Best Motion Picture category, the two films will battle it out with Billy Elliot, Erin Brockovich, Quills and Dancer in the Dark. Variety has the complete list of nominees.

 Meanwhile, ananova reports that Cameron Crowe's Almost Famous has been named the Best Picture of 2000 by the Boston Society of Film Critics. The film also won Best Screenplay and Best Director for Crowe, as well as Best Supporting Actress for Frances McDormand. Former Ballykissangel actor Colin Farrell was named Best Actor for his role in Vietnam drama, Tigerland, and Ellen Burstyn won the Best Actress prize for her role in Requiem For A Dream. Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, which has already won a number of high profile prizes, was named Best Foreign Film.

webTitle: Distinct towns win city status

fields.headline: Distinct towns win city status
fields.trailText: Three towns quite distinct in character and geography were expecting an economic boom yesterday after beating 36 others to become millennium cities reports David Ward
fields.body:
Three towns quite distinct in character and geography were expecting an economic boom yesterday after beating 36 others to become millennium cities.

In a long-overdue announcement, the Home Office said the Queen had decided to honour Brighton and Hove, Wolverhampton and Inverness at the end of a bitter contest which began two years ago and which brings the number of cities in Britain to 49.

In Wolverhampton, the council leader, Norman Davies, said it was the "best Christmas present ever". He said: "Our New Year's Eve celebrations will be even more special now that we are one of the cities of the millennium."

The director of the Inverness chamber of commerce, Simon Cole-Hamilton, said: "City status will bring a lot of kudos and further strengthen Inverness's profile."

Simon Fanshawe, the writer and broadcaster who spearheaded Brighton and Hove's campaign, said: "We're fantastically excited, not just about being a city but about what we've done. We got it because we put in a different kind of bid, reflecting the fact we're a different kind of city."

All three new cities are hoping for the kind of economic benefits experienced by Sunderland, given city status in 1992. The bookies' favourite, Luton, missed out, and other losers included Reading, Milton Keynes, Warrington, and Bolton and Stockport, two towns within Greater Manchester.

The tipsters had appeared to have little confidence in the bids from both Wolverhampton, power house of the Black Country, and Inverness, capital of the Highlands.

No Welsh town has been honoured although six originally applied. Bids by Newport and Wrexham were endorsed by the Welsh secretary, Paul Murphy, who was said to be very unhappy that none had been successful.

The Plaid Cymru president, Ieuan Wyn Jones, called it "very disappointing news". Nick Bourne, the Conservative leader on the Welsh assembly, said: "This is a giant snub to Wales."

Home Office minister Mike O'Brien announced that Wales would be given another chance in 2002, when four towns - one each in England, Northern Ireland, Scotland and the principality - will be chosen in honour of the Queen's golden jubilee.

webTitle: The three Millennium cities

fields.headline: The three Millennium cities
fields.trailText: But what a silly way to choose.
fields.body:
Inverness will have no complaints. Nor will Wolverhampton; nor Brighton and Hove - though those two may chafe against each other even more than usual, now that they have been formally conjoined. All three (or is it four?) will be celebrating this morning, since they have just been "officially" declared cities. The complaints will be left to those denied: Luton, Newport and Wrexham among the 36 places that will have to soldier on as mere towns. What is more, the rejection of all six Welsh aspirants and both of Northern Ireland's has aggravated national sensibilities as well as local ones.

But there is a greater cause for ambivalence about yesterday's news than the disappointment of those left out. Archie Norman, for the Tories, got close to it when he objected to the whole process which arrived at yesterday's decision. He suspected political calculation, noting that all three of the winners include constituencies narrowly held by Labour. With an election near, a dose of civic PR certainly will not hurt. (Still, if that was the criterion, Luton, reeling from Vauxhall, would surely have won.)

What Mr Norman complained about was the process by which city status is granted by personal command of the Queen, on ministerial advice. In other words, our old friend crown prerogative. That is why parliament had no role in yesterday's choice and why the candidate cities could do no more than wait to hear the whim of Her Majesty's ministers.

The same point was neatly highlighted by yesterday's claim that Tony Blair had pencilled March 29 2001 as the date of the general election. Such stories will proliferate between now and the spring. Why? Because dissolving parliament is one more power that rests exclusively in the hands of the executive, in the form of the prime minister. Whether it is naming cities or naming dates, the PM has too much power. It is not just a few of our towns which need to become cities; our constitution needs to grow up.

The same point was neatly highlighted by yesterday's claim that Tony Blair had pencilled March 29 2001 as the date of the general election. Such stories will proliferate between now and the spring. Why? Because dissolving parliament is one more power that rests exclusively in the hands of the executive, in the form of the prime minister. Whether it is naming cities or naming dates, the PM has too much power. It is not just a few of our towns which need to become cities; our constitution needs to grow up.

webTitle: Team work more important than money for future teachers

fields.headline: Team work more important than money for future teachers
fields.trailText: People cite the friendliness of colleagues and intellectual stimulation as bigger factors than a good starting salary when considering teaching as a career, new research reveals today.
fields.body:
People cite the friendliness of colleagues and intellectual stimulation as bigger factors than a good starting salary when considering teaching as a career, new research reveals today.

Research by Terry Haydn and colleagues of the University of East Anglia was reported today at the British Psychological Society's London Conference, held at the Institute of Education.

The team surveyed more than 2,000 young people from nine universities and 25 secondary schools. Teaching was viewed by many of the respondents as being 'about team work', and was thought to be difficult, interesting, poorly paid, and to have low status.

The work raises fresh questions over the government's attempts to improve the recruitment of new teachers, which have focused on improving student grants and starting salaries.

Haydn said: "As there is considerable concern over teacher recruitment this survey attempted to locate the ideas young people have about teaching and what factors influence those ideas. The survey provides information which should be of interest to graduate employers and policy makers concerned with teacher recruitment."

The questionnaire covered the factors young people considered desirable in a job, and what aspects of teaching they felt were either attractive or off-putting. They were also asked whether they agreed or disagreed with a number of descriptive statements about teachers and teaching and whether they had considered or rejected teaching as a possible career. Follow-up interviews were conducted with a small number of respondents after the questionnaires had been analysed.

webTitle: Racing TV rights decision put back

fields.headline: Racecourse owners put back TV rights finish line
fields.standfirst: Dec 12: stewards' inquiry into horseracing deal
fields.trailText:
11.30am: Racecourse owners have warned that TV rights negotiations will continue into next year, reports Jason Deans.
Dec 12: stewards' inquiry into horseracing deal
fields.body:
Fears that the already protracted negotiations for TV rights to UK horseracing will continue into the new year have effectively been confirmed by the Racecourse Association.

The RCA has extended the exclusive negotiating period with the Go Racing consortium, which includes Channel 4, BSkyB and racecourse owner Arena Leisure, from December 15 until January 17.

This follows the launch of an RCA inquiry into aspects of the bidding process for media rights last week.

The investigation was triggered by allegations that one racecourse owner had approached one or both of the two rival bidders - Go Racing and Carlton Communications - about entering a consultancy agreement in return for backing their media rights bid.

The RCA entered into exclusive negotiations with Go Racing in late November after its members voted on the two competing bids.

webTitle: Wolverhampton raises a ragged cheer as recognition helps keep Birmingham at bay

fields.headline: Wolverhampton raises a ragged cheer as recognition helps keep Birmingham at bay
fields.trailText: The good news was proclaimed yesterday by the town (now city) crier near the statue of Prince Albert which Queen Victoria unveiled in 1866. "Wolverhampton now holds itself in city status!" reports David Ward
fields.body:
The good news was proclaimed yesterday by the town (now city) crier near the statue of Prince Albert which Queen Victoria unveiled in 1866.

"O yea, O yea," bellowed the gent in the scarlet cloak, tricorn hat, white socks and pigtail. "Wolverhampton now holds itself in city status!"

Bookies groaned when they made sense of this bizarre syntax (they had given Wolverhampton derisory odds of 33-1) but the locals raised a ragged cheer when they got the crier's drift.

It was 11.35am; within seconds a nearby news vendor was pasting up Express and Star bills proclaiming "Yes, we're a city". To celebrate the great day, he handed out with his paper stickers ("I'm a city slicker") and packets of sticky sweets (made in Germany).

Wolverhampton based its campaign on its 1,000 years of history - Ethelred the Unready granted a charter to Lady Wulfruna in 985 - and its reputation as a vibrant multi-racial community. "City status would be a recognition of the civic pride, harmony, ambition and loyalty [of Wolverhampton's people]," said the bid document published in August.

The real question now is what benefits city status will bring. They are not sure yet whether the mayor will become a lord mayor but they are hoping for a big economic spin-off: only last week Chubb, the long-established safe maker, announced that its factory is to close with the loss of 170 jobs.

"This is a great opportunity for us to squeeze all the value we can out of the new status to bring jobs to Wolverhampton and prosperity to its people," said Ken Purchase, MP for Wolverhampton North-east. "It will cheer us up a bit and give us new opportunities. But it's not going to turn the world upside down."

Back in the council offices, one of the security staff pronounced himself "chuffed to bits" before preparing to hoist the union and civic flags from nearby poles. He explained that the civic flag carried an image of a bale of wool to mark the trade that brought the city wealth long before the first blast furnace arrived down the road in Bilston.

It is said that the lord chancellor sits on some of that wool in the House of Lords, which suggests that Wolverhampton had influence in high places denied to the 36 losers.

The new city has had two previous goes at boosting its status and lost to Sunderland in 1992, the last time a city name was up for grabs. Its motive was to secure a clear identity, to keep Birmingham at bay and fend off the inexorable advances of Telford up the M54.

"Third time lucky," said council leader Norman Davies, first elected in 1973. "We kept our cool and had confidence that we would win through at the end of the day.

"We are now citizens rather than townsfolk. It's a coming of age. We have moved from hamlet to village, from village to town, and now from town to city. People have a different feeling about cities and this will be a boost to local confidence, business confidence in particular."

Not everyone was as excited as Councillor Davies. In the Mander shopping centre, two teenage girls were literally speechless with apathy but Kirtee Patel, 24, was unstoppable.

"I'd like to know what makes a city for a start," she said. "Wolverhampton isn't a city - it's a town. It's too small to be a city. This won't make any difference."

David Bridgewater, examining Hornby trains in a shop window, thought it would but was not quite sure how. "It will make all-round improvements," he said vaguely.

Were he still with us, one of Wolverhampton's more famous sons might have raised a hearty cheer. But Button Gwinnett left town/city for the new world more than 200 years ago, became governor of Georgia and signed the American Declaration of Independence.

webTitle: France gives way on DVD

fields.headline: France gives way on DVD
fields.trailText: France yesterday gave ground in its long running and often fractious battle to protect its own culture and agreed to ease draconian restrictions on the sale of Hollywood films released on DVD.
fields.body:
France yesterday gave ground in its long running and often fractious battle to protect its own culture and agreed to ease draconian restrictions on the sale of Hollywood films released on DVD.

In a move that will bring Paris more into line with other European countries, France's culture ministry signalled that it was prepared to water down a controversial government edict which prevents popular American films being released on DVD for at least nine months after their first cinema showing in the country.

The ban will instead be reduced to only six months, despite frantic lobbying on the part of the French cinema industry, which derives the bulk of its revenues - at least 55% - from the screening of American feature films.

US-made films continue to provide French cinemas with their largest single source of revenue despite the fact that many of the country's cultural guardians see Hollywood as a serious threat to their own film industry.

Six of last year's top earning films in France were American, two were British and only two were French.

The financial stakes are high: France is forecast to be the European country with the largest number of sales of DVD players and DVDs next year.

There is also growing evidence that DVD sales are outstripping VHS video sales in France by a margin of about six to one.

France's decision to relax its ban on DVD sales is, in a sense, a recognition that it is fighting a losing battle.

French national daily newspaper Liberation yesterday predicted that whatever the authorities do, film enthusiasts in France can bypass the restrictions by ordering their DVDs over the internet from the US.

However, DVD has a long way to go before it surpasses the popularity of cinema-going in France. Up to 13m DVDs were sold in the country last year compared to some 155m cinema tickets.

The new decree will become law from January 1. But it is expected to have only a minimal impact upon France's homegrown film industry - experts believe it will not be viable to produce DVD versions of most French films because of their narrower appeal.

webTitle: Novelist Ahdaf Soueif on Israel

fields.headline: 'Our world is upside down'
fields.standfirst:
Earlier this month Egyptian-born novelist Ahdaf Soueif travelled to Israel and the occupied territories for the first time. Here she concludes her remarkable account of the journey

Read the first part: Under the gun

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Earlier this month Egyptian-born novelist Ahdaf Soueif travelled to Israel and the occupied territories for the first time. Here she concludes her remarkable account of the journey.
fields.body:
Thursday

For three nights now I have stayed up writing past 2am and yet I have not recorded all I have heard and seen. I have not even really thought about all I have heard and seen - that will come later. For now the present facts are all I can manage.

We start early for Ramallah and a couple of minutes from my hotel I see two Israeli flags fixed to the flat roof of a house. Next to them four boys in civilian clothes nurse machine guns. My driver, Abu Karim, says these are four houses that have recently been taken from their Arab residents.

Out of Jerusalem, major roads are being built to connect up with the settlements. The roadworks are guarded by Israeli Army trucks.

The road north to Ramallah - the road that the Palestinians may use - will lead us through the town of Bira and the news is that Bira was shelled last night. Soon we see the concrete blocks, the waiting cars, the soldiers and we swerve off to the right and drive through dirt roads. Abu Karim points to a rectangular crater in the middle of the road the size of a grave. The army, he says, do this just to make life more difficult. A bone-jolting 20 minutes later we rejoin the main road about one kilometre up from where we had left it.

An hour and a half later (and a distance equivalent to, say, Chelsea to Kingston) we are sitting in Rita Haniyya's living-room listening to her and her friend Layla Qasim. The women, one Christian, the other Muslim, are founders of the National Union of Palestinian Women (NUPW) and worked hard to establish the Centre for the Support of the Family in Ramallah, a day-centre where children were taught music and encouraged to draw: "The children are not allowed to see maps of Palestine or learn their own history," they tell me. Eighteen months ago the Israelis closed the centre down for "inspiring sedition".

"Sedition!" snorts Layla Qasim. "We were trying to help the mothers give their children a 'normal' childhood. You know what the children sing? They sing: 'Papa bought me a trifle/A machine-gun and a rifle'.

"We were struggling to get them to sing normal children's songs. But normal children's songs have nothing to do with the reality of their lives.

"When the children said 'The Jews came and took my cousin/Mixed our rice with the flour and the sugar', we would say don't say the Jews, it's the Israelis, the Zionists. We were battling with the ethics of language."

"The media in Britain," I say, "ask why mothers allow their children to go out and throw stones at the army."

"Allow?" says Rita Haniyya, "You should see the quantities of Valium we've dispensed to women in the camps simply to help them cope with their lives: when their children go out to play they're playing under the guns of the army observation post above them - these people have been living under 'temporary emergency' conditions for 33 years, and some since 1948. They don't go looking for the army, the army is right on their doorstep."

"There isn't a child," says Layla, "who doesn't have a father or a brother banished or jailed or killed. When the soldiers come in and beat up a father - the kids see it - all they've got is one room. They see their father being beaten. What do you think it does to them? They ask us if people in the whole world live like this. What can we tell them? A three year old comes in and tells me: 'The Jews came and beat my father and his tummy fell out onto the floor but we got him to hospital and they're going to mend him.'"

The names come thick and fast, Jihad Badr who was bringing up his kid sisters and brothers after their mother died of cancer, who survived an operation for a brain tumour but was killed in the al-Aqsa demonstrations; Hania, 13, who was shot in the leg, bundled into an army car and hit repeatedly on the same leg: "I didn't scream," they tell me she said, "not because I was feeling brave, just because I was afraid they'd kill me." The Hammouri twins, 19, shot on the same day. And on and on.

The NUPW now trains women in first aid and civil defence, it organises vaccinations, it gives counselling and advises on home economics (this includes boycotting Israeli and American products). It is funded entirely by donations from its more well-off members - many of them abroad. There are 2m Palestinians in Israel and the occupied territories, 5m in the diaspora.

"We've compromised," Rita Haniyya says, "they have West Jerusalem, the Carmel, Yafa and Haifa and so on. They have Israel. But they want everything, it's their nature. They attack us - physically - in three ways: through the army, the settlers, and the Mustaribs (agents who pretend to be Arab)."

The Mustaribs, she says, mingle with the people during demonstrations: "They choose a child, grab him, throw their keffiyehs over their faces (so they can mingle again without being identified) whip out their yarmulkes and a gun and rush with the child over to an army car."

"You know the worst of it is," they say, "that they keep you guessing. You never know if a road is to be open or closed. When they're going to shut off your water or turn off your electricity. Whether they're going to permit a burial. Whether they're going to give you a permit to travel. You can never ever plan. They create conditions to keep you spinning."

At Oslo, Israel agreed to hand over some major Arab towns to the Palestinian Authority. Israel, however, retained all the areas surrounding the towns, so that to get from one to another the Palestinians had to carry permits which were checked at Israeli checkpoints. With the intifada the Israeli army simply encircled the towns, preventing the residents from leaving or entering. Critics of Oslo at the time said this was a blueprint for disaster. No one understands why the Palestinian Authority agreed to it. Some say they simply didn't have maps. It is at the soldiers encircling their towns that the youths and children of the intifada throw stones.

There are some good Israelis, Rita says, people of conscience. "Look at what Amira Hass writes in Ha'aretz. And Uri Avnery. But they're marginalised."

Are you in touch with them?

"Not any more. We realised they would go so far and no further. The best of them balks at the right of return for the refugees. Even Leah Rabin wanted East Jerusalem. At the beginning of the intifadah when they got in touch we said you've been talking to us for years, now it's time for you to talk to your government."

Back in Jerusalem I break my fast at a small cafe outside al-Zahra Gate. On the street outside is the army car and the soldiers. At the table behind me three elderly men are extolling the days of Gamal Abdul Naser and the idea of pan-Arabism. They end up singing popular Egyptian songs of the 60s: "Ya Gamal/Beloved of millions" and "We said we'd build and now we've built/the Hi-i-gh Dam".

The owner, recognising my Egyptian dialect, gives me a tamarind juice and pudding on the house. He asks if I'm OK at my hotel. His family would have been glad to take me in but they're in al-Khalil (Hebron). He used to commute, it's only half an hour, but now with the closures he can only manage to sneak in to see them once a week.

A silent candle-lit demonstration outside the New Gate of the old city. Sixty candles flickered in the hands of 60 Palestinian women just outside the Gate. Opposite them, on the other side of the road 15 Israeli women dressed in black held 15 candles.

Friday

This is the first Friday of Ramadan and Barak, in a move designed to "achieve quiet during the month of Ramadan", has repealed the ban on men under 45 praying at the al-Aqsa mosque.

Israeli mounted police, armed and dressed in riot gear, guard the gates of the old city as though we were armed and dangerous football hooligans. We pass through al-Zahra Gate in single file between two rows of soldiers with machine guns. Each man has to stop and show his identity papers. The women, if they keep their heads bowed and their eyes on the ground, are left alone. At Bab Hutta, the actual gate to al-Haram al-Sharif, there are more soldiers with guns. Inside, the men head for al-Aqsa, the women for that choice jewel, the Dome of the Rock. Because the Israeli amnesty does not extend to the people of the West Bank, there are maybe 20,000-25,000 people here today instead of the 500,000 you would normally expect.

At the Dome I squeeze in through Bab al-Janna (the Gate of Paradise). In straight lines, shoulder-to-shoulder, we pray then sit to listen to the sermon. The Imam preaches patience, steadfastness and opposition. He reminds us of the Prophet's saying that there are those who fast and gain nothing except hunger; to fast is to renounce falsehood, hypocrisy and all bad deeds. He lists the crimes of the Israeli military occupation against the people.

He lists the demands of the people: an end to the occupation, the implementation of UN resolution 242 and the return to the borders of June 4 1967, an independent and sovereign Palestinian state in the West Bank, Gaza and east Jerusalem, the release of Palestinian prisoners from Israeli jails, the right of return to the homeland of all Palestinian refugees. He repeats God's promise that the righteous shall prevail, then he prays for al-Aqsa itself. Again and again he implores God to protect it from the plots being woven against it, again and again the women's voices from the Dome and the men's voices from al-Aqsa rise: Amen.

The al-Aqsa, where the men pray, is close to Bab el-Magharba (the Gate of the Moroccans) which is close to the Wailing Wall. As prayers end, groups of young men and boys start gathering there. But there the army and police are solidly waiting and everyone knows that if one stone hits that wall someone will be shot. But the shabab [youth] are in the grip of fervour and a man who some say is a "Fatah element" starts yelling Hamas slogans and, playing Pied Piper, leads them away from the certain danger of Bab el-Magharba and through the terraces of al-Haram to the relative safety of Bab el-Sabbat. There they stop.

Outside the gateway is a police station that they had set fire to a while back. The administrators of the mosque rush to place wooden barriers between the shabab and the small army of soldiers and police taking up positions outside with guns aimed. The shabab chant of the Prophet's victory against the Jews at Khaybar in the 7th century, some of them rush back into the Haram and try to break down the iron door leading to the stairs of the minaret. It will not break. One young man climbs a wall and tries to open a higher door into the minaret.

On the walls of the terraces hundreds of women and older men stand and watch. The atmosphere is almost one of carnival. Maybe a thousand shabab are facing the soldiers, but the gate is narrow so it's not too hard for the elders to hold them back. On the steps just opposite the gate, the steps leading up to the top of the city wall, the photographers stand with their cameras, helmets and bullet-proof vests. Something happens outside and the shabab scatter for a moment then regroup. A woman in an embroidered bedouin dress pushes forward into their midst, yelling along with them and a man tries to hold her back: "They might shoot you!"

"Let them shoot me. Am I worth more than any of these youngsters?"

A woman in horn-rimmed spectacles waves her arms at the soldiers from the wall where she's standing: "Get out!" she shouts, "Get out! You've strangled us, may God strangle you."

One young man is ordering his little brother to go home. "Let me stay," the kid begs. "Just for a few minutes. Let me stay." It takes a cuff on the side of the head to send him home. A couple of smallish stones are pitched across the wall. "Bet that landed on our car," a very well-dressed, slim young man says to his companion.

A well-built youth picks up a large rock and throws it to the ground to smash it. It doesn't smash and he picks it up again. As he raises it a mosque caretaker runs up and takes it from him, quietly, without a word. He places it carefully under a tree and the young man walks away. An argument is breaking out on the side: "They shouldn't make trouble," a tall, fair man shouts. "The Israelis will close it down. Let people pray."

A bystander laughs: "You've been praying for 50 years. What good has it done you?"

A dimunitive sheikh in a very trim costume and brand-new red cleric's hat is marching measuredly up and down beside the yelling demonstrators with a megaphone: "Your presence here incites them. Disperse. Disperse."

No one pays any attention to him except one man who says to his neighbour: "He does this every Friday."

There are women and girls sitting chatting under the trees. Eventually the shabab start to drift away. It has taken two hours but this time, here, the Palestinians have no martyrs.

Saturday Noon, Ramallah

The great hall of Our Lady of the Gospels independent school in Ramallah is filling up with students. Hundreds of girls and boys crowd into the seats talking and laughing. On the stage the principal, Mrs Samira, and the guest speaker, Dr Mustafa Barghouti are setting up the overhead projector. Dr Barghouti is one of the triumvirate heading the People's Party of Palestine, and - more importantly - he has been organising all the medical aid work for the intifada.

This talk is part of the independent schools of Ramallah's joint initiative to "document the truth and demand our legitimate rights before the world". This group of kids is in economic band A, their parents can afford to educate them privately, can stop them going to the barricades. Their hair is glossy, their teeth are good. As Mrs Samira lists the names of the participating schools they cheer and stamp and she outlaws whistling.

They all want to know how they can contribute. They ask why the Authority has not declared Oslo dead? Why it arrests members of Hamas? What is the Authority doing to protect civilians from the attacks of the settlers? Why does the Authority continue to try to coordinate security with the Israelis? They want a programme to support the thousands of workers who've lost their jobs inside Israel. They want the leadership to pull together and an end to the factions. They want to talk to the world. They want independence and they want to know what they can do.

Dr Barghouti tells them they can join the NGO across the road. They can be trained in first aid and primary care, in crisis management. They can do media work, monitor the net, respond to articles ... They crowd around to put their names down before they rush off to be picked up by parents at 2.30pm sharp.

3pm, Ramallah

Another Barghouti (it's a massive family), Marwan Barghouti, is mostly on the move. He is 41, the chief executive officer of Fatah. Since the intifada he's been on the streets with the shabab and he has formed the People's Watch, groups in each village that try to defend the villagers against the settlers. Everybody says he is targeted by the Israelis (Ma'ariv called him one of the "triangle of terror: Arafat, Barghouti and Raggoub, head of Palestinian intelligence"). Some say he's targeted by the Palestinian Authority - for being too popular.

In his office, against a huge poster of al-Aqsa, he repeats that the intifada and negotiations do not preclude each other; that the intifada is the only way the people have of projecting their own voice, their own will into the negotiations. He points at a poster of Muhammad al-Durra and says: "We need to get away from the image of the Palestinian as a victim. This is a better poster," pointing at a poster of a child confronting a tank.

I say: "That kid was killed two days later."

He says: "Yes."

I wonder whether there is space to get out of the "victim" frying-pan without falling into the "fanatical Islamic terrorist" fire. The margin is terribly narrow. Then a man sitting with us - clearly an old friend - says: "But I hear Qassam [Barghouti's 16-year-old son] is down at the barricades. Why don't you stop him?" Barghouti waves the question away. The man insists: "You have to stop him." And for a moment the militia leader looks helpless: "I can't," he says. "How can I?"

3.45pm

Abu Karim is getting restless. He wants to be home in Jerusalem before sunset, but I have asked to see the barricades and now we examine them. An area of desolation at the edge of the town - which means 10 minutes from the center. After sunset this will turn into a battleground. Concrete blocks, stones, burn marks, some shattered glass. Two Israeli army cars on the other side of the concrete.

A woman appears from nowhere. Fortyish, poor, dressed in black, she is an Egyptian who has married a Palestinian and lived here for 25 years. Umm Basim, I have heard of her, heard that she lost her eldest son in the previous intifada and that she is in the thick of the action at the barricades every night.

Is it because of your son, I ask, that you come here?

"No. I have four more, and they are with me here. I come because this situation has to end. We can't live like this."

I ask if I may take her photo. She hesitates: "It won't appear in any Egyptian newspapers? I wouldn't want my mother to know what I'm doing. She'd worry." As I take the photo she turns to the man who brought us here: "I've seen Qassam here. Tell his father to keep him away."

Sunday 10.30am

Psagot. ("Bascot," the students at Bir Zeit University had said, "biscuits. Think American cookies.")

Psagot is a settlement built 10 years ago on a hilltop just outside Ramallah and Birah. The Palestinians say it was built by the government (like other settlements) on land expropriated from Birah. They say it was positioned strategically to halt the natural expansion of the town and to control the Arab population. They say the settlers are armed and the army itself can move into the settlement at very short notice. For the past two months Birah and Ramallah have been shelled every night from Psagot.

My calls to the Yesha council have paid off and they have sent me here to meet Chaim Bloch.

A western journalist connects me to a taxi driver who will go to a settlement (but charges triple), and from the start the journey is unlike any other I've made here. Smooth, wide roads, speeding cars, no roadblocks. And Psagot, like almost every settlement, on the top of a hill like a look-out, like the spooky small town of Edward Scissorhands. Barak's proposed budget for the coming year would spend $300m on settlements.

Chaim Bloch is courteously waiting for us outside his house. He is dressed in a suit with a buttoned-up shirt and no tie. He has a longish light-brown beard and speaks softly and carefully. His father, a textile engineer, was offered a job in Israel 31 years ago and within two weeks the family had moved over from Baltimore. I work out that Mr Bloch is 39. I had thought him older.

In Israel, if you choose to do religious studies you are exempt from military service. For the young men who want to do both special yeshivas exist. There are 30 of them round the country. Bloch is a graduate of one and, until recently, he had always taught at another. Now he teaches Jewish law as it relates to monetary management as a kind of "continuing education" course. He has been in Psagot nine years.

Why Psagot?

"Because this is the land of Judea and Samaria. It is here that the Israeli destiny is to be decided."

The people across the valley, in Ramallah and Birah say this land was expropriated from them. How do you feel about that?

"The government of Israel never takes land without paying for it. The Arabs tried to bring a court case against us and in the end they begged us to allow them to drop it because they were going to be ruined."

There are UN resolutions stating that the West Bank and Gaza are illegally occupied.

"Israel is a law-abiding nation but there can be differences in the interpretation of the law. What we are doing here is not against international law." Then, without pause: "Even if I was 100% sure that international law was against me it would not change my views. Just because international law says something does not make it so."

But if not the law, what is your reference?

"God promised us this land. The state of Israel was here 2,000 years ago and God promised this land to our forefathers 37,000 years ago. There was never a state of Palestine here."

The one thought that I have is that I am not afraid any more, not even uneasy. I feel nothing. I am conducting an interview.

Well, I say, there was never Syria or Lebanon or Jordan or Iraq. As states. It was all part of the Ottoman empire and was carved up by the British and the French.

"This is the land promised to us by God."

OK. You say this land is yours because you were here 2,000 years ago. Across the valley there is a man who says this land is his because he has been here for 2,000 years. If - just for a moment - you put yourself in his position ...

"I do not put myself in his position. You do that for a friend, on a personal matter. This is a question of nations. And my business is to look after the interests of the Jewish nation."

So you have no individual moral responsibility in this matter?

"No."

Well, from your point of view, what should the Palestinians do?

"They can go on living here. No-one will throw them out. But they have to understand that they are living in a Jewish state. If they do not like that there are many places where they can go."

But if they live here, in a Jewish state, they don't have the same rights as the Jews.

"Yes. It is a Jewish state and they live as a minority." Believe me, 90% of Palestinians admire us and want to live in the state of Israel."

I know that a poll among young Palestinians found that they admired Israeli democracy as it was applied to the Jews. But it is not applied to the Arabs.

"Ninety per cent of Palestinians would be happy to live in the state of Israel. I know this."

You know that 90% of Palestinians would be happy to live as second-class citizens forever?

"This is what my Palestinian friends tell me."

You have Palestinian friends?

"Yes."

Forgive me but - who are they?

Silence.

I don't want to know their names, just - where did you meet them, for example?

"One is a mechanic. He had to fix something for my car. And the other - he knows him.

"Could I just ask you how life on the settlement works - economically?

"How do you mean?"

Well, I've heard that settlements get government help.

"Barak's government has cut back on most of what we got from Netanyahu. We get hardly anything."

(My companion Judy Blanc ascertains that the house he lives in was bought for a fifth of the market value. For a settler to travel to and from his or her settlement the government provides an armoured bus and two army car escorts. Water, the main resource under government control, is divided between the Arab population and the Israeli settler: each settler is allocated 1,450 cubic meters of water per year. Each Palestinian is allowed to use 83 cubic meters. Electricity is regularly shut down in the Palestinian towns while the settlements are lit up.)

Mr Bloch, you have Israel. If you do not allow the Palestinians their own state in the West Bank this conflict will never end.

"Not everything has to be solved now."

You are happy that your children should inherit this conflict?

"Happy?" His voice rises, but only slightly. "My sister was on the bus that they blew up. The woman sitting next to her was killed. Children had to have their limbs amputated. I am not happy."

But you believe your children should inherit this situation?

"Those children on the bus - I pray that God will never ask me to pay such a terrible price. But if He does, I shall pay it."

As we drive away from Psagot I feel empty. I look at my notes and realise that I have no impression of what the living room we had been in looked like - except that it was bare and functional and sunny - and looked out on Ramallah. The taxi driver (even with $100 in his pocket) is speeding and angry and has an argument with a speeding young Israeli. Through the window I hear: "Kess ikhtak!" (Your sister's c***)

Is that the same in Hebrew? I ask.

No, that was Arabic, Judy says.

"I see a terrible fire," Mme Haniyya had said to me, "a terrible fire coming to swallow us all, Israelis and Palestinians - unless the Palestinian people are freed from their bondage."

1.30pm

On the way back to the bridge I see that the army has dug a brand-new trench between the road and the town of Ariha (Jericho).

After

Exhaustion hits me the minute I get to London. This conflict has been part of my life all my life. But seeing it there, on the ground, is different.

What can I do except bear witness?

I am angrier than before I went. And more incredulous that what is happening in Palestine - every day - to men, women and children, should be allowed by the world to continue.

The choices are in the hands of Israel. They can hand over the West Bank, Gaza and east Jerusalem and live within their borders as a nation among nations. There are no choices for the people of Palestine.

Ilan Halevi, a Jew who fought with the PLO, says it's a question of macho image: "Israel does not want to be seen as 'the fat boy of the Middle East'."

Others say Israel does not want to be a "nation among nations". It wants the beleaguered, plucky image - and the moral indulgence and trillions of dollars worth of aid that goes with it. If that is so then the Israeli government has joined others of the region who are not working in the interests of their own people.

Awad Awad [two of whose photos were in the Guardian on Saturday] says the Israelis have declared they will not renew the licences of any Palestinian photographers working with the international media.

What will you do?

"Just carry on taking photograhs. I'm a photographer."

I have seen women pushing their sons behind them, shoving them to run away, screaming at the soldiers: "Get out of our faces. Stop baiting the kids."

I have heard a man say: "I have four sons and no work. I cannot feed them. Let them go out and die if it will help our country; if it will end this state of things."

I have seen children calmly watch yet another shooting, another funeral. And when I have wept they've said: "She's new to this."

I have listened to everybody predict that the leadership would do a deal. "But if they don't bring us independence and the right of return the streets will catch fire."

Palestinian weddings are celebrated over coffee, but when a young man is killed his mother is held up over his grave. "Trill out your zaghrouda [ululation], mother," his friends say, the shabab who might die tomorrow. A mother says to me: "Our joy-cries now only ring out in the face of death. Our world is upside down."
