fields.bodyText: Thursday For three nights now I have stayed up writing past 2am and yet I have not recorded all I have heard and seen. I have not even really thought about all I have heard and seen - that will come later. For now the present facts are all I can manage. We start early for Ramallah and a couple of minutes from my hotel I see two Israeli flags fixed to the flat roof of a house. Next to them four boys in civilian clothes nurse machine guns. My driver, Abu Karim, says these are four houses that have recently been taken from their Arab residents. Out of Jerusalem, major roads are being built to connect up with the settlements. The roadworks are guarded by Israeli Army trucks. The road north to Ramallah - the road that the Palestinians may use - will lead us through the town of Bira and the news is that Bira was shelled last night. Soon we see the concrete blocks, the waiting cars, the soldiers and we swerve off to the right and drive through dirt roads. Abu Karim points to a rectangular crater in the middle of the road the size of a grave. The army, he says, do this just to make life more difficult. A bone-jolting 20 minutes later we rejoin the main road about one kilometre up from where we had left it. An hour and a half later (and a distance equivalent to, say, Chelsea to Kingston) we are sitting in Rita Haniyya's living-room listening to her and her friend Layla Qasim. The women, one Christian, the other Muslim, are founders of the National Union of Palestinian Women (NUPW) and worked hard to establish the Centre for the Support of the Family in Ramallah, a day-centre where children were taught music and encouraged to draw: "The children are not allowed to see maps of Palestine or learn their own history," they tell me. Eighteen months ago the Israelis closed the centre down for "inspiring sedition". "Sedition!" snorts Layla Qasim. "We were trying to help the mothers give their children a 'normal' childhood. You know what the children sing? They sing: 'Papa bought me a trifle/A machine-gun and a rifle'. "We were struggling to get them to sing normal children's songs. But normal children's songs have nothing to do with the reality of their lives. "When the children said 'The Jews came and took my cousin/Mixed our rice with the flour and the sugar', we would say don't say the Jews, it's the Israelis, the Zionists. We were battling with the ethics of language." "The media in Britain," I say, "ask why mothers allow their children to go out and throw stones at the army." "Allow?" says Rita Haniyya, "You should see the quantities of Valium we've dispensed to women in the camps simply to help them cope with their lives: when their children go out to play they're playing under the guns of the army observation post above them - these people have been living under 'temporary emergency' conditions for 33 years, and some since 1948. They don't go looking for the army, the army is right on their doorstep." "There isn't a child," says Layla, "who doesn't have a father or a brother banished or jailed or killed. When the soldiers come in and beat up a father - the kids see it - all they've got is one room. They see their father being beaten. What do you think it does to them? They ask us if people in the whole world live like this. What can we tell them? A three year old comes in and tells me: 'The Jews came and beat my father and his tummy fell out onto the floor but we got him to hospital and they're going to mend him.'" The names come thick and fast, Jihad Badr who was bringing up his kid sisters and brothers after their mother died of cancer, who survived an operation for a brain tumour but was killed in the al-Aqsa demonstrations; Hania, 13, who was shot in the leg, bundled into an army car and hit repeatedly on the same leg: "I didn't scream," they tell me she said, "not because I was feeling brave, just because I was afraid they'd kill me." The Hammouri twins, 19, shot on the same day. And on and on. The NUPW now trains women in first aid and civil defence, it organises vaccinations, it gives counselling and advises on home economics (this includes boycotting Israeli and American products). It is funded entirely by donations from its more well-off members - many of them abroad. There are 2m Palestinians in Israel and the occupied territories, 5m in the diaspora. "We've compromised," Rita Haniyya says, "they have West Jerusalem, the Carmel, Yafa and Haifa and so on. They have Israel. But they want everything, it's their nature. They attack us - physically - in three ways: through the army, the settlers, and the Mustaribs (agents who pretend to be Arab)." The Mustaribs, she says, mingle with the people during demonstrations: "They choose a child, grab him, throw their keffiyehs over their faces (so they can mingle again without being identified) whip out their yarmulkes and a gun and rush with the child over to an army car." "You know the worst of it is," they say, "that they keep you guessing. You never know if a road is to be open or closed. When they're going to shut off your water or turn off your electricity. Whether they're going to permit a burial. Whether they're going to give you a permit to travel. You can never ever plan. They create conditions to keep you spinning." At Oslo, Israel agreed to hand over some major Arab towns to the Palestinian Authority. Israel, however, retained all the areas surrounding the towns, so that to get from one to another the Palestinians had to carry permits which were checked at Israeli checkpoints. With the intifada the Israeli army simply encircled the towns, preventing the residents from leaving or entering. Critics of Oslo at the time said this was a blueprint for disaster. No one understands why the Palestinian Authority agreed to it. Some say they simply didn't have maps. It is at the soldiers encircling their towns that the youths and children of the intifada throw stones. There are some good Israelis, Rita says, people of conscience. "Look at what Amira Hass writes in Ha'aretz. And Uri Avnery. But they're marginalised." Are you in touch with them? "Not any more. We realised they would go so far and no further. The best of them balks at the right of return for the refugees. Even Leah Rabin wanted East Jerusalem. At the beginning of the intifadah when they got in touch we said you've been talking to us for years, now it's time for you to talk to your government." At the table behind me three elderly men are extolling the days of Gamal Abdul Naser and the idea of pan-Arabism. They end up singing popular Egyptian songs of the 60s: "Ya Gamal/Beloved of millions" and "We said we'd build and now we've built/the Hi-i-gh Dam". The owner, recognising my Egyptian dialect, gives me a tamarind juice and pudding on the house. He asks if I'm OK at my hotel. His family would have been glad to take me in but they're in al-Khalil (Hebron). He used to commute, it's only half an hour, but now with the closures he can only manage to sneak in to see them once a week. A silent candle-lit demonstration outside the New Gate of the old city. Sixty candles flickered in the hands of 60 Palestinian women just outside the Gate. Opposite them, on the other side of the road 15 Israeli women dressed in black held 15 candles. Friday This is the first Friday of Ramadan and Barak, in a move designed to "achieve quiet during the month of Ramadan", has repealed the ban on men under 45 praying at the al-Aqsa mosque. Israeli mounted police, armed and dressed in riot gear, guard the gates of the old city as though we were armed and dangerous football hooligans. The Imam preaches patience, steadfastness and opposition. He reminds us of the Prophet's saying that there are those who fast and gain nothing except hunger; to fast is to renounce falsehood, hypocrisy and all bad deeds. And my business is to look after the interests of the Jewish nation." So you have no individual moral responsibility in this matter? "No." Well, from your point of view, what should the Palestinians do? "They can go on living here. No-one will throw them out. But they have to understand that they are living in a Jewish state. If they do not like that there are many places where they can go." But if they live here, in a Jewish state, they don't have the same rights as the Jews. "Yes. It is a Jewish state and they live as a minority." Believe me, 90% of Palestinians admire us and want to live in the state of Israel." I know that a poll among young Palestinians found that they admired Israeli democracy as it was applied to the Jews. But it is not applied to the Arabs. "Ninety per cent of Palestinians would be happy to live in the state of Israel. I know this." You know that 90% of Palestinians would be happy to live as second-class citizens forever? "This is what my Palestinian friends tell me." You have Palestinian friends? "Yes." Forgive me but - who are they? Silence. I don't want to know their names, just - where did you meet them, for example? "One is a mechanic. He had to fix something for my car. And the other - he knows him. "Could I just ask you how life on the settlement works - economically? "How do you mean?" Well, I've heard that settlements get government help. "Barak's government has cut back on most of what we got from Netanyahu. We get hardly anything." (My companion Judy Blanc ascertains that the house he lives in was bought for a fifth of the market value. For a settler to travel to and from his or her settlement the government provides an armoured bus and two army car escorts. Water, the main resource under government control, is divided between the Arab population and the Israeli settler: each settler is allocated 1,450 cubic meters of water per year. Each Palestinian is allowed to use 83 cubic meters. Electricity is regularly shut down in the Palestinian towns while the settlements are lit up.) Mr Bloch, you have Israel. If you do not allow the Palestinians their own state in the West Bank this conflict will never end. "Not everything has to be solved now." You are happy that your children should inherit this conflict? "Happy?" His voice rises, but only slightly. "My sister was on the bus that they blew up. The woman sitting next to her was killed. Children had to have their limbs amputated. I am not happy." But you believe your children should inherit this situation? "Those children on the bus - I pray that God will never ask me to pay such a terrible price. But if He does, I shall pay it." As we drive away from Psagot I feel empty. I look at my notes and realise that I have no impression of what the living room we had been in looked like - except that it was bare and functional and sunny - and looked out on Ramallah. The taxi driver (even with $100 in his pocket) is speeding and angry and has an argument with a speeding young Israeli. Through the window I hear: "Kess ikhtak!" (Your sister's c***) Is that the same in Hebrew? I ask. No, that was Arabic, Judy says. "I see a terrible fire," Mme Haniyya had said to me, "a terrible fire coming to swallow us all, Israelis and Palestinians - unless the Palestinian people are freed from their bondage." 1.30pm On the way back to the bridge I see that the army has dug a brand-new trench between the road and the town of Ariha (Jericho). After Exhaustion hits me the minute I get to London. This conflict has been part of my life all my life. But seeing it there, on the ground, is different. What can I do except bear witness? I am angrier than before I went. And more incredulous that what is happening in Palestine - every day - to men, women and children, should be allowed by the world to continue. The choices are in the hands of Israel. They can hand over the West Bank, Gaza and east Jerusalem and live within their borders as a nation among nations. There are no choices for the people of Palestine. Ilan Halevi, a Jew who fought with the PLO, says it's a question of macho image: "Israel does not want to be seen as 'the fat boy of the Middle East'." Others say Israel does not want to be a "nation among nations". It wants the beleaguered, plucky image - and the moral indulgence and trillions of dollars worth of aid that goes with it. If that is so then the Israeli government has joined others of the region who are not working in the interests of their own people. Awad Awad [two of whose photos were in the Guardian on Saturday] says the Israelis have declared they will not renew the licences of any Palestinian photographers working with the international media. What will you do? "Just carry on taking photograhs. I'm a photographer." I have seen women pushing their sons behind them, shoving them to run away, screaming at the soldiers: "Get out of our faces. Stop baiting the kids." I have heard a man say: "I have four sons and no work. I cannot feed them. Let them go out and die if it will help our country; if it will end this state of things." I have seen children calmly watch yet another shooting, another funeral. And when I have wept they've said: "She's new to this." I have listened to everybody predict that the leadership would do a deal. "But if they don't bring us independence and the right of return the streets will catch fire." Palestinian weddings are celebrated over coffee, but when a young man is killed his mother is held up over his grave. "Trill out your zaghrouda [ululation], mother," his friends say, the shabab who might die tomorrow. A mother says to me: "Our joy-cries now only ring out in the face of death. Our world is upside down." © Ahdaf Soueif  Some names in this piece have been changed. Ahdaf Soueif will be reading at Visions of Palestine at the Royal Geographic Society at 7pm on February 14. webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are more exciting than a full-throttle clinch with Billie Piper
fields.trailText: Former Southampton manager Dave Jones could be handed a return to football with Wolves following the dismissal of Colin Lee, reports Teamtalk.
fields.body:
Former Southampton manager Dave Jones could be handed a return to football with Wolves following the dismissal of Colin Lee, reports Teamtalk.

Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale has denied reports in the Sun which claim that David O'Leary is preparing a £10m bid for Robbie Fowler. "To even comment on this speculation is ridiculous, I don't want to give it credence," he said. "There's more chance of us signing Father Christmas than Robbie Fowler."

Chelsea will make an improved £13m offer for Robbie Keane today, claims Teamtalk.

West Ham have made an astonishing £10m bid for Argentinean international striker Martin Palermo, reports Planet Football. Boca Juniors president Mauricio Macri has confirmed that West Ham's bid is the highest for the player - but says that Napoli, Valencia and Aston Villa are also interested. Palermo is best remembered for missing three penalties in an international match, but Harry Redknapp reckons he is "top drawer".

Spurs are hoping to buy 18-year-old East Fife striker Steven Ferguson. East Fife are reported to want £500,000 for the player - but George Graham has only offered £250,000 up front with the rest to follow in instalments.

Blackburn manager Graeme Souness is interested in signing Turkish international Tugay from Rangers, according to the Daily Record. ''I have had a conversation with David Murray about Tugay but there is no bid at this stage,'' Souness told the paper. ''I have still to speak to my own people at Blackburn before anything can be done."

Preston are lining up a £2.5m bid for Millwall striker Neil Harris, according to reports.

webTitle: The A3XX

fields.headline: The A3XX
fields.standfirst: Airbus is to announce it is to begin production of its twindeck super jumbo  jet, the A3XX. Here's our guide to the best sites on the skies' new behemoth
fields.trailText:
NetNotes: Airbus is to announce it is to begin production of its twindeck super jumbo jet, the A3XX. Here's our guide to the best sites on the skies' new behemoth.
More NetNotes
fields.body:
1. Airbus Industrie is expected to formally announce today that it is to begin building the world's biggest passenger jet, the A3XX.

2. The A3XX will be colossal. It will carry between 480 and 650 passengers on two decks and in a no-frills all-economy version it could cram in 850. It could be in service by 2005.

3. The US maker Boeing affects a studied indifference to the prospect of losing the monopoly it has enjoyed since 1970, when its 747 jumbo jet first took to the air. It says it is making its own study of the market for extra-large aircraft, but will go ahead only when there is proven demand.

4. Boeing is, however, furious about the prospect of more state-subsidised competition. It has frequently leaned on the US government to back its complaint of unfair competition. Airbus pooh-poohs the Boeing claim. It says the American company also scoops in buckets of taxpayers' cash in lucrative contracts for its military planes, its space projects, its missiles and other death-dealing products.

5. The world has been strapping Boeing jets to its collective backside since the late 1950s. The total order book amounts to a whopping 14,600 aircraft, nearly 1100 of which are 747s. Its range of aircraft covers every segment in the market, and, since 1968, it has also made the most successful commercial jet ever, the twinjet 737.

6. Airbus is by comparison a tiddler, with annual sales of around US$25bn and a total order book to date of around 3000 aircraft, of all types. Still, for an outfit that was derided when it launched in 1969, it has grown into the world's second biggest plane-builder. (There are, alas, only two of any significance.)

7. Airbus has a family of small and medium sized airliners, and is now trying to break into the military market, with its A400M transport aircraft. The RAF has ordered 25.

8. Airbus knows how to build big. It produces and operates a fleet of supertransporters, with stupendous fuselages to accommodate extra-large loads - such as the main body-parts of its own airliners.

9. There has been a flurry of recent interest in the A3XX. At least six airlines have expressed an interest in becoming launch passengers, including Singapore, Emirates and, most recently, Air France.

10. To Boeing's possible embarrassment, at least one US operator is now paying close attention.

webTitle: 'And the winner is... Steve Martin!'

fields.headline: 'And the winner is... Steve Martin!'
fields.standfirst: It was announced yesterday that comedian Steve Martin is to take over the mantle of Oscar night host from Billy Crystal, who has hosted the awards seven times in the last 10 years
fields.trailText: It was announced yesterday that comedian Steve Martin is to take over the mantle of Oscar night host from Billy Crystal, who has hosted the awards seven times in the last 10 years.
fields.body:
Comedian Steve Martin can add Oscar night host to his increasingly varied resume - it was announced yesterday that he is to take over the mantle from Billy Crystal who has hosted the awards seven times in the last 10 years.

Gil Cates, producer of the Oscar night broadcast, made the surprise announcement, saying Martin's many talents make him a perfect fit for the high-profile event "He's everything!" Cates gushed in a statement. "He's a movie star, he's funny, he's classy, he's literate - he'll be a wonderful host."

Martin, who has never been nominated for an Oscar, saw it another way, quipping, "If you can't win 'em, join 'em."

The 55-year-old star of Bowfinger and Dirty Rotten Scoundrels is, however, no stranger to the protocol of Oscar night. He has appeared at the awards ceremony eight times in total, but never as host.

The decision puts an end to much media speculation over who was to inherit the crown from Crystal, who pulled out due to work commitments on his forthcoming film, American Sweetheart.

Crystal himself had said he would have liked Jim Carrey to host the evening, but it is believed Carrey still holds a grudge against the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences for snubbing him for his serious roles in The Truman Show and Man on the Moon.

Martin, who's just completed filming the black comedy, Novocaine, with Helena Bonham Carter and Laura Dern, has recently found success as a novelist. His first book, Shopgirl has proved to be a huge bestseller and is already on its seventh print run in the States.

Martin will host the star-studded awards from the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles on March 25.

webTitle: Pickles' dogged deed shows true spirit of '66

fields.headline: Pickles' dogged deed shows true spirit of '66
fields.trailText: During the marketing and partying madness of the past few weeks I'm sure I haven't been alone in wondering whether we've actually lost sight of the real importance of history's most celebrated and singular event. I know it is easy to get carried away by the fanfare and hoop-la, but in the commercial frenzy that increasingly surrounds it, I can't help feeling we have forgotten the true meaning of the 1966 World Cup.
fields.body:
During the marketing and partying madness of the past few weeks I'm sure I haven't been alone in wondering whether we've actually lost sight of the real importance of history's most celebrated and singular event. I know it is easy to get carried away by the fanfare and hoop-la, but in the commercial frenzy that increasingly surrounds it, I can't help feeling we have forgotten the true meaning of the 1966 World Cup.

Like the Nativity, the further that famous afternoon in north London has receded into history the more its importance has grown and its message been diluted. Christmas began with minimal fuss on a silent night in Bethlehem. Two thousand years later it is the root cause of Charlotte Church, ill- advised cream-based liqueurs and middle-class women slugging it out like Dempsey and Firpo over the last Tracy Island in the toyshop.

July 30 1966 was, likewise, a relatively low-key affair compared with what it has become today. The merchandising operation was entrusted to a few blokes who had bought a job lot of army surplus rattles and painted them red white and blue; the England players' victory celebrations culminated with Jack Charlton kipping on a stranger's sofa in Chigwell.

Thirty-four years later 1966 is a major industry. New books, re-interpreting events and profiling everyone from Sir Stanley Rous to the people who ran on the pitch, appear almost daily. The evidence surrounding England's third goal is subjected to more analysis than the Kennedy assassination. A couple of weeks ago Alan Ball launched the 1966 World Cup winners sporting club with its 1,966 members paying £1,966 a year for the privilege. Even one of the linesmen has a sports stadium named after him.

If things continue like this by the time the 1966 centenary comes around the last week in July will have become a time of annual celebration. Businesses will close, gifts will be exchanged, clerks will be sick in rubber plants. People will be employed to re-tell the key moments in language to which modern kids can really relate ("You know in many ways Nobby Stiles was a lot like Pikachu from Pokemon. He might have looked cuddly, but he was one bad-ass dude"), and in May the newspapers will be full of letters from retired colonels in the shires complaining that the 1966 season seems to start earlier every year.

Both the Nativity and 1966 trade on their uniqueness. If God were to add to his family or England win another major trophy both would be devalued. Though admittedly neither of these two events seems particularly likely at the moment. This, of course, is not to denigrate 1966 or the achievements of England's players in any way. It's just that I feel that at some point we should pause from exploiting the event and reflect on its spiritual significance instead.

Sacrifice, loyalty, decency and dignity were all part of the story. And, to my mind, nobody embodied these virtues more than a shaggy-haired lad from south London named Pickles. When the Jules Rimet Trophy was stolen from a stamp exhibition in Westminster a few months before the World Cup began it was this black-and-white mongrel that recov ered it from under a bush in Upper Norwood.

Without Pickles's brilliant intervention things would have been very different. Fifa would have been forced to hastily cobble together another trophy or hand Bobby Moore an IOU.

"As a nation I do not think we salute our heroes sufficiently," Jimmy Tarbuck remarked at the launch of the 1966 World Cup winners sporting club. Too true. Pickles did his job with a minimum of fuss and then got out. In a celebrity-obsessed world his reticence was commendable. Regrettably, though, it allowed more peripheral figures in the 1966 story such as Sir Bobby Charlton to elbow him out of the way and steal the limelight. Today his story is largely forgotten. Though, naturally, all that could be about to change thanks to my recently launched Pickles The 1966 World Cup Mutt range of interactive cuddly toys. Hurry, hurry, hurry while stocks last.

webTitle: Microsoft risks overreaching itself

fields.headline: Gates looks up from his desktop
fields.standfirst:
Microsoft risks overreaching itself by placing stakes across the whole computer industry

Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: Microsoft risks overreaching itself by placing stakes across the whole computer industry
fields.body:
This will be remembered as the year Microsoft abandoned its PC-centric view of the world. Having successfully turned to confront the threat of the internet in December 1995, the surprisingly agile software maker pirouetted again last summer, proclaiming it would build a computer operating system directly into the fabric of the internet.

Creating a network operating system - an idea Microsoft once opposed - is a particularly daring shift in strategy because it goes to the heart of the bitterly contested federal antitrust lawsuit that Microsoft is now appealing. Success in this venture would mean Microsoft completing the internet-centered vision of the shift from the PC desktop first articulated by the Netscape half a decade ago. Over the next five years, the strategy, known as .Net, will transform Microsoft from a purveyor of packaged software increasingly into a supplier of information-age services such as digital wallets, software subscriptions and e-commerce portals.

Still, .Net today is merely a statement of direction and a piece of a much bigger picture. Behind the hoopla that has surrounded the .Net proclamation is a more remarkable transformation of Microsoft.

The new millennium story for the company that once had a laser focus on the personal computer desktop is that it has decided to place ambitious bets across the whole computer industry. It is a strategy that has not been seen in the computer industry since IBM's domination in the late 1970s to the early 1980s, when it explored technologies ranging through laser videodiscs, satellite communications and home computers. It also puts Microsoft at great risk of overreaching. The question is whether the company will end up on the course charted some years ago by Robert Allen at AT&T, when he tried to create a synergy among many moving parts and failed, or whether it will succeed as John F Welch did with his conglomerate strategy at General Electric.

"They're practically building the casino and setting the odds at each table," said Richard Doherty, president of Envisioneering, a computer industry consulting firm in Seaford, New York.

Consider just these recently announced initiatives:

 The Xbox video game player will become the company's first big foray into computer hardware and consumer electronics next autumn.

 Ultimate TV is Microsoft's effort to push into the cable set-top box and satellite television market, building on WebTV, its Internet TV service.

 At the high end of the computer industry, the Windows 2000 server edition, introduced during the summer, gave Microsoft an entry into the big-systems software market dominated by IBM., Sun Microsystems, Hewlett-Packard and Compaq. The database initiative, the SQL Server 2000, introduced last summer, competes against Oracle and IBM.

 At the annual Comdex computer show last month, Bill Gates, Microsoft's chairman and co-founder, showed off the company's version of the tablet computer, an effort to recharge the personal computer industry with a new package for mobile office and home computing.

 A move into cellular phones is emerging, and Microsoft has publicly outlined its strategy for a cell phone based on Windows CE, a consumer operating system intended for hand-held devices, that will place the software maker in a head-to-head confrontation with the Symbian joint venture backed by Ericsson, Motorola and Nokia. Microsoft this year embarked on its third- generation challenge to Palm with the Pocket PC, operated by a specially tailored version of Windows CE.

 In October, the company refocused on MSN, the Microsoft Internet service provider, in its continuing effort to catch up with America Online.

 This summer, the company brought out a revamped Windows Media Player version to take on RealNetworks players and Apple's Quicktime Media Player.

 Finally, the company's Reader publishing software is an attempt to take on Adobe's Acrobat electronic publishing software and to redefine the publishing market around electronic books.

There is a widely held industry view that Microsoft has no choice but to gamble on renewing its growth by entering a wide array of new businesses. The Microsoft stock market miracle clearly ended this year, with the company's stock falling more than 50%, largely - on the surface at least - because of the blow dealt to the software publisher by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who ruled in the federal antitrust lawsuit that Microsoft be broken into two companies. The ruling has been stayed pending an appeal scheduled for February.

Microsoft has doggedly resisted giving any ground in the case, arguing that its software integration approach serves its customers well. Indeed, for almost 15 years, the company's stock has reflected its success, creating in the process a flock of new millionaires. This year, with the stock price down, there has been an exodus of managerial and technical talent - something Microsoft cannot afford if it is to continue to match its internet-era competitors. Moreover, there is concern that there is a saturation point in the growth of the personal computer market that has fuelled Microsoft's growth for 25 years. Microsoft underscored that concern when it said last week that it was facing profit and sales erosion in the quarter that will end on December 31.

That point is driven home most clearly by a close look at the company's performance in its last two quarters. While revenue and net income grew and Microsoft was generally given positive marks on Wall Street, operating income in the first quarter, ended September 30, actually fell to $2.78bn (£1.88bn), from $2.79bn a year earlier. And that decline followed an even bigger drop in the fourth quarter, to $2.55bn from $2.93bn in the previous year. Those represent the first quarterly declines in operating income in Microsoft's history as a public company.

Even given its strong product cycle dependence and its huge cash reserves, it is clear that the company must quickly find new markets to grow in - hence the decision to attack markets in which it has little experience.

It is tempting to acknowledge that the company's most effective tactic - software integration - will give it the same edge in these other industries that it has acquired against its PC industry competitors. The tactic is indeed being employed in other areas, as witnessed by the company's demonstration of the next version of Office, code-named Office 10, at Comdex.

The program integrates such previously independent features as the company's Messenger program directly into its Office program. Although the integration strategy was one that led directly to the antitrust verdict against the company this year, Microsoft has continued to insist that integration is pro-customer, if not pro-competitive. At the same time, the new strategy raises challenges that the software publisher has not faced.

One is suggested by a technical analysis buried deep in the October issue of the industry journal Microprocessor Report that presents serious implications for the world's most powerful software company.

A group of engineers performed a "teardown analysis" on Sony's consumer hit PlayStation 2, the video game player with sales of nearly 5m since its introduction in March.

It estimates the manufacturing cost of each PlayStation at $441 - or $41 more than the machine's retail price in Japan and $142 more than its $299 retail price in the United States. The numbers could be sobering for the team that is completing the design of Xbox, Microsoft's first entry into the computer hardware business and a frontal assault on the competitive video game world.

While Sony is reportedly losing money on each machine it sold this year - money it hopes to recapture with software sales - Microsoft is planning a computer so powerful that it will dwarf not only the power of the PlayStation 2, but also many of the most powerful desktop computers selling for many times the price. The Xbox will have a faster Intel processing chip, a faster graphics chip from Nvidia, more memory and the addition of a hard disk capable of storing eight gigabytes or more.

Some analysts believe Microsoft would run less of a risk than Sony because the software maker has apparently struck sweetheart deals with its main suppliers.

There is no escaping the fact that Microsoft has finally crossed the Rubicon. Its plans for the Xbox, as well as other moves put it decisively in the consumer electronics business with its low margins and notoriously fickle consumers.

Although Microsoft has enjoyed a relatively warm reception from the mass market, it does not have a great record of producing hit consumer hardware.

One has only to remember its most embarrassing venture into consumer computing when, in 1995, it introduced "Bob," a family software agent intended to help users but ending up the object of ridicule. In consumer electronics, Microsoft is definitely in a world where it no longer has any guarantee of success.
fields.bodyText: This will be remembered as the year Microsoft abandoned its PC-centric view of the world. Having successfully turned to confront the threat of the internet in December 1995, the surprisingly agile software maker pirouetted again last summer, proclaiming it would build a computer operating system directly into the fabric of the internet. Creating a network operating system - an idea Microsoft once opposed - is a particularly daring shift in strategy because it goes to the heart of the bitterly contested federal antitrust lawsuit that Microsoft is now appealing. Success in this venture would mean Microsoft completing the internet-centered vision of the shift from the PC desktop first articulated by the Netscape half a decade ago. Over the next five years, the strategy, known as .Net, will transform Microsoft from a purveyor of packaged software increasingly into a supplier of information-age services such as digital wallets, software subscriptions and e-commerce portals. Still, .Net today is merely a statement of direction and a piece of a much bigger picture. Behind the hoopla that has surrounded the .Net proclamation is a more remarkable transformation of Microsoft. The new millennium story for the company that once had a laser focus on the personal computer desktop is that it has decided to place ambitious bets across the whole computer industry. It is a strategy that has not been seen in the computer industry since IBM's domination in the late 1970s to the early 1980s, when it explored technologies ranging through laser videodiscs, satellite communications and home computers. It also puts Microsoft at great risk of overreaching. The question is whether the company will end up on the course charted some years ago by Robert Allen at AT&T, when he tried to create a synergy among many moving parts and failed, or whether it will succeed as John F Welch did with his conglomerate strategy at General Electric. Microsoft has doggedly resisted giving any ground in the case, arguing that its software integration approach serves its customers well. Indeed, for almost 15 years, the company's stock has reflected its success, creating in the process a flock of new millionaires. This year, with the stock price down, there has been an exodus of managerial and technical talent - something Microsoft cannot afford if it is to continue to match its internet-era competitors. webTitle: Vieira fires Gunners' retort

fields.headline: Vieira fires Gunners' retort
fields.trailText: Arsenal continue to sound a distant warning to Manchester United at the top of the Premiership rather than pose an immediate threat. Last night they missed a chance to halve the champions' six-point lead, being content instead to avoid defeat by Tottenham with another of Patrick Vieira's late face-saving headers and reduce United's advantage by one.
fields.byline: David Lacey at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Arsenal continue to sound a distant warning to Manchester United at the top of the Premiership rather than pose an immediate threat. Last night they missed a chance to halve the champions' six-point lead, being content instead to avoid defeat by Tottenham with another of Patrick Vieira's late face-saving headers and reduce United's advantage by one.

The strength and purpose of Arsenal's second-half recovery after they had fallen behind to a goal from Sergei Rebrov just past the half-hour said much for the indefatigable spirit that has brought league titles to Highbury in the past.

Yet the fact remains Arsenal have still won only twice away in the Premiership and as their manager Arsène Wenger admitted later: "A draw is not too bad in the circumstances but in terms of chasing United this is still two points lost."

Certainly that would have been a view shared by Spurs, who with Neil Sullivan pulling off a series of outstanding saves came so close to winning a North London derby that rapidly improved as a spectacle once a goal had untangled a frantic and scrappy start. Had Tottenham held on to win even the more discontented of their fans might have wished Sir Alan Sugar a happy Christmas.

Until Vieira scored Spurs' fans shared an unusual lightness of heart for two reasons. Not only was there the prospect of their team denying Arsenal the chance to capitalise on United's defeat by Liverpool the previous day, there was also the thought that the chairman was selling up.

This game was just mutual perspiration in the pouring rain, although Wenger's introduction of Dennis Bergkamp and Vieira, initially on the bench through a mixture of choice and injury, for the last half-hour added quality.

Arsenal are still not right and cannot rely on United suffering a repetition of Sunday's slump in form too often. On Saturday, while Ipswich are at Old Trafford, Wenger's team will be at Liverpool, where Vieira will surely be on from the start if his hamstring can stand the strain.

Last night Vieira's unflurried presence was missed in the first half as Ray Parlour and Gilles Grimandi struggled with the five-man midfield George Graham pitted against his old club. Yet Arsenal might have led just before the quarter-hour when Nwankwo Kanu held off two defenders near the byline and supplied Thierry Henry, who had a clear view of goal but dragged his shot wide.

If anything Arsenal infiltrated Tottenham's cover with greater ease and economy of effort. Nevertheless Spurs scored after 31 minutes with excellent improvisation tinged with controversy.

After Stephen Carr crossed dangerously from the byline on the right Martin Keown appeared to have headed the ball to safety. But Stephen Clemence glanced it back to Darren Anderton, whose 25-yard drive was blocked by Alex Manninger, Rebrov meeting the bouncing rebound with a sharp header into the net.

When Anderton shot, Les Ferdinand and Tim Sherwood were standing offside in front of Arsenal's goalkeeper yet neither the referee Jeff Winter nor his linesman considered he was interfering with play. "It is difficult to understand why the linesman did not flag when the first shot went in," said a puzzled Wenger.

Yet Arsenal began the second half two gears higher than they had ended the first and if one of two opportunities that came their way in a minute been accepted United might even now be hearing a louder clatter of pursuing feet.

First Grimandi met a pass from Henry with a shot that was well struck but of negotiable height. Then Henry, set up by Parlour from the byline, delayed his shot by a fraction, allowing Sullivan to push it away from the far post when he would surely have been beaten had the ball been struck first time.

As Sherwood toe-ended the ball wide and Silvinho cleared from Clemence off the line Tottenham appeared to have survived the crisis. But after Chris Perry had performed a similar service for Spurs, Sullivan became the crucial figure, saving from Henry and Bergkamp in quick succession with Sol Campbell's vital interception stopping Fredrik Ljungberg breaking through.

In the 89th minute Sullivan kept out Tony Adams at the far post, but from Silvinho's corner Vieira outjumped everyone to nod the scores level. Graham complained with some justification, that Ferdinand, deputed to mark the Frenchman, had been held back but that did not refute the justice of the result.

webTitle: Walker to take over Wembley

fields.headline: Walker to take over Wembley
fields.trailText: Sir Rodney Walker, the UK Sport chairman, is set to take over this week from Ken Bates as overlord of the troubled new Wembley stadium project.
fields.body:
Sir Rodney Walker, the UK Sport chairman, is set to take over this week from Ken Bates as overlord of the troubled new Wembley stadium project.

Bates's departure as chairman of Wembley National Stadium Ltd and the arrival of Walker is almost certain to see the original plan restored with both football and athletics being housed in the stadium.

This would mean abandoning the government's plans for a purpose-built athletics stadium for the 2005 World Championships at Picketts Lock in north London.

The departure of the Chelsea chairman and the installation of Walker, who is also chairman of Leicester City plc, as troubleshooter is expected to be formalised at the latest by Thursday, when a top-level meeting of the Football Association is scheduled.

webTitle: Prize money increased on US Millionaire show

fields.headline: Double dollar Millionaire
fields.trailText: 10.30am: American TV bosses are upping prize money on Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? to halt a ratings slide, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ABC is upping the prize money on the US version of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? to almost $2m in an attempt to halt a ratings slide.

From January a rollover jackpot will boost the top prize by $10,000 for every edition of the show broadcast since the last $1m winner.

There hasn't been a $1m winner since July 11, 71 editions ago.

The grand prize will now stand at $1,710,000 and will increase by a further $10,000 for every subsequent instalment of the quiz show.

Millionaire, which is co-produced for the US by UK format owner Celador Productions, is still a big hit for ABC.

However, ratings for the show, presented by Regis Philbin, have fallen from 24m to 20.6m viewers over the past year.

Advertisers are also said to be worried about Millionaire's ageing demographic profile - research shows that the average age of viewers is 54, compared with 48 for the previous series.

webTitle: Lee pays price for Wolves slide

fields.headline: Lee pays price for Wolves slide
fields.trailText: Wolves last night sacked their manager Colin Lee following a series of poor results that have left the First Division club one point above the relegation zone.
fields.body:
Wolves last night sacked their manager Colin Lee following a series of poor results that have left the First Division club one point above the relegation zone.

Lee, who took over from Mark McGhee as manager in November 1998, had his contract terminated following a meeting with the Wolves chief executive Jez Moxey. "The entire board felt that decisive action needed to be taken," Moxey said.

The decision follows Wolves' 1-0 defeat by Birmingham on Sunday. The assistant manager John Ward has been put in temporary charge of team affairs but the vacancy could provide an opportunity for the former Southampton manager Dave Jones to resume his managerial career after being cleared of sex offences in the High Court last week.

"We appreciate that Colin has faced problems this season with injuries but our current league position - averaging just one point a game - is not acceptable," Moxey added. "This is dangerously close to relegation form."

Huddersfield Town's manager Lou Macari faces a 12-match suspension and a fine of one month's wages after the Football Association charged him with violent behaviour towards the fourth official at Portsmouth on Saturday.

Macari insists that he did not realise he had touched the official, Barry Wade, although he was ordered from the dug-out.

The Aston Villa midfielder Lee Hendrie is to appeal to the FA over his sending-off by Andy d'Urso in Saturday's Premiership game with Manchester City at Villa Park.

Hendrie was given a red card, his second this season, for foul and abusive language after protesting when he had a penalty appeal turned down; he faces a three-match suspension.

"I am absolutely gutted with the decision," Hendrie said. "What I did was a yellow-card offence at most." Villa's manager John Gregory has nevertheless insisted that he would fine Hendrie the maximum two weeks' wages.

Hendrie's team-mate David James has withdrawn the transfer request he handed in to Villa last week. But the goalkeeper will not sign the new 3-year contract offer on the table in the foreseeable future.

James said: "I believe it is in the best interests of Aston Villa that I should withdraw the transfer request." But added: "I was disappointed my request was leaked from within the club the day before a game."

The Real Madrid and Portugal forward Luis Figo has been named European footballer of the year in the annual France Football poll.

webTitle: 'Sad end' for Sugar as shares take off

fields.headline: 'Sad end' for Sugar as shares take off
fields.trailText: Tottenham's chairman Sir Alan Sugar last night admitted regret that he would always be tarnished with the label of "money man and not a football man" as he repeated his determination to sell his controlling stake in the club.
fields.body:
Tottenham's chairman Sir Alan Sugar last night admitted regret that he would always be tarnished with the label of "money man and not a football man" as he repeated his determination to sell his controlling stake in the club.

"This is a sad end to 10 years," he said. "It is unfortunate that you can often get stuck with a label in life." Sugar confirmed he was selling up and revealed there were "a lot of people hot to trot" - or at least to hold talks over buying out all or part of his 40% stake.

And he will give any interested parties prepared to invest in the club his advice. "My wife will probably kill me for saying this, but I'm prepared to offer my assistance to them. I will carry on coming to watch Tottenham."

And after a statement to the Stock Exchange yesterday morning officially confirming that he was "actively seeking a buyer", Sugar said: "That's it. I'm off. No tricks and no jokes."

Tottenham shares climbed sharply yesterday. They were in heavy demand in early trading after Sugar said he was in discussions with "a number of parties" about offloading his stake. They closed up 10% at 57p, valuing the club at £58m.

Enic, the sports and leisure group that owns shares in a string of European clubs, remains favourite to take over Sugar's holding but significant differences remain over the value attached to the club.

The chairman thinks his shares are worth more than £1 each but many in the City believe he would be lucky to get 80p. Sugar will fly to the United States this morning and a deal is unlikely to go through before he returns next month.

webTitle: DMGT to launch Manchester evening paper

fields.headline: DMGT to launch Manchester evening paper
fields.trailText: 10am: The Daily Mail & General Trust is to launch a new evening paper in Manchester, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Daily Mail & General Trust has confirmed plans that it will spark a fresh circulation war next year with the launch of an evening paper in Manchester.

The company behind the Daily Mail and the successful Metro regional free newspapers believes there is a gap in the market for a successful evening paper targeted at young, upwardly mobile commuters in the Manchester region.

DMGT believes that 84% of the Manchester population does not read the Manchester Evening News, published by the Guardian.

Earlier this month, the company announced plans to launch new versions of Metro in Leeds and Sheffield.

webTitle: PeopleNews.com raises £1m extra funding

fields.headline: PeopleNews.com raises £1m extra funding
fields.trailText: 10am: Showbiz website PeopleNews.com has raised £1m to see it through next year, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Showbiz gossip website PeopleNews.com has sought to allay doubts about its short-term future by raising £1m in new financing.

The cash comes at a crucial time for the site, which has been plagued by rumours of financial difficulties over the past two months.

The fresh investment from existing shareholder GoldenEgg Ventures takes the total raised by PeopleNews to £5m, a figure that chief executive Simon Walker said will see the business though into the latter part of next year.

"We're talking to a number of players in the radio and TV areas and expect to announce something in the first couple of months of next year," he said.

"Fundraising is not a concern for us now and revenues are starting to come in."

PeopleNews, which launched in September, is backed by GoldenEgg and Antfactory. GoldenEgg is currently merging with another venture capital firm, E-Street, to form Syntek Capital Group.

webTitle: Profile: Janine Gibson

fields.headline: Profile: Janine Gibson
fields.trailText: Janine Gibson is editor of the Guardian
fields.body:
Janine Gibson is editor of theguardian.com, the UK's most popular newspaper website.

Formerly she was G3 editor of the Guardian, responsible for the weekly Media, Education, Society and Technology sections.

Other positions she has held at the Guardian include media editor, during which time she launch-edited mediatheguardian.com, and media correspondent.

She was also media correspondent of the Independent. Her career began in trade magazines.

webTitle: Technospeak not understood

fields.headline: Technospeak used but not understood
fields.trailText: 9.30am:Acronyms and abbreviations are increasingly used on the web, but most people don't know what they mean, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
When it comes to technology acronyms and abbreviations, the majority of the British public can't tell their ISPs from their WWWs, according to a survey from Gallup for CompuServe UK.

While acronyms are becoming more commonplace in everyday language, it seems that most people who use them have no idea what they actually mean.

More than 54% of those surveyed in the poll said they had used the acronyms but hadn't got a clue what their correct meaning was.

The acronym DVD (Digital Versatile Disk) is the most misunderstood with 47% using the term liberally but only a quarter of those knowing what it stood for.

Wap (Wireless Application Protocol) is another term that caused confusion. Only 18% of respondents had used it, and only 26% of those knew what it stood for.

In contrast, 88% of the 1,016 people interviewed knew that the acronym ISP stood for internet service provider.

Mike Hales, CompuServe UK editorial director, said: "People need to be able to understand the true meaning behind each abbreviation so that they do not feel alienated if someone uses one in a conversation."

webTitle: Reebok to make belly toys

fields.headline: Reebok to make TV ad belly toys
fields.standfirst:
Dec 6: interest swells in Reebok belly
See the ad
fields.trailText:
8.15am: The Reebok beer belly is set to be the must-have present at Christmas after the sportswear company decided to sell toy versions.
Dec 6: interest swells in Reebok belly
See the ad
fields.body:
The Reebok beer belly, made famous by its latest TV ad, is set to become the must-have present this Christmas as the sportswear company has decided to put miniature toy versions on general sale.

Reebok decided today to initially auction off 200 five-inch foam bellies via its website. It said all proceeds would go to charity.

It believes they could prove the perfect Christmas gift for portly friends and family in the season of excess.

The beer belly icon first appeared in a 40-second Reebok running shoes commercial, created by Lowe Lintas. A runner is seen trying to escape an eight-foot high stomach chasing him down the road.

Reebok then made 2,500 miniature toys to celebrate the ad and send out as gifts to a select few. But they have proved so popular that there have been calls in the press for them to be mass-produced.

"They could be the perfect Christmas warning to friends while they are stuffing themselves," said a Reebok spokesman.

He said that the toys were not yet available but that the company would try to sell them on its website, Reebok.co.uk within the next week or so.

The amazingly lifelike belly in Reebok's £4m TV ad was created by Asylum, the model agency whose credits include the Millennium Dome's central Body Zone.

webTitle: Small cut in air noise ordered

fields.headline: Small cut in air noise ordered
fields.trailText: Residents near Britain's booming airports are to be given limited relief from intrusive engine noise after ministers last night agreed modest reductions in sound levels reports Patrick Wintour
fields.body:
Residents near Britain's booming airports are to be given limited relief from intrusive engine noise after ministers last night agreed modest reductions in sound levels.

The announcement ends four years of consultation and a court challenge from the aircraft industry.

The restrictions covering Britain's three major airports will see enforced falls in aircraft noise for all planes leaving the airports during specific night and day time periods.

Noise limits will be reduced by three decibels by day to 94 decibels and by two decibels by night to 87 decibels. The airline industry has warned that older 747s and A340s, which are yet to take to the skies, will be unable to meet the new limits.

The Labour MP for Slough, Fiona MacTaggart, last night said the changes struck a balance between the need to create jobs at Heathrow and allowing residents to sleep.

The lower night noise limits will only apply between 11.30pm and 6am. Higher night time limits will apply between 11pm and 11.30 pm and again between six and seven in the morning. Airlines will also be required to reach 1,000ft at 6.5km from the start of their take-off. The new day noise limits will apply from February next year, a year later than the government originally indicated.

Chris Mullin, the environment minister, defended the modest reductions saying only small numbers now live close to runways. The new restrictions will cover Gatwick, Heathrow and Stansted. Concorde, if it returns to public use, will not be subjectto the limits

The airlines lobbied against the reforms on the grounds that aircraft cannot cut back power until they reach 1,000ft. In addition, largely for safety reasons, airlines usually use the same operating procedures for all routes from a particular airport.

However, Mr Mullin rejected their arguments on the grounds that airlines were overestimating the likely weights of aircraft.

webTitle: United in talks over internet pay-per-view

fields.headline: United in talks over internet pay-per-view
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Manchester United is talking with "potential partners" about new media ventures that could lead to pay-per-view matches on the web. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Manchester United says it is in touch with "potential partners" for new media ventures, which could lead to pay-per-view matches on the web.

A spokesman said the club was looking to "exploit opportunities" in new media, as soon as the club gets the rights to screen its own matches.

"We are always talking to people to try to improve the way we offer our services. As more Manchester United content becomes available, we will find more ways of putting it out to fans," he said.

From next season, Manchester United and other Premiership clubs will be able to show delayed highlights of their matches in a deal with massive money-spinning potential. The time delay is 72 hours for weekend matches and 48 hours for weekday games.

The Old Trafford club has already established its own TV channel, MUTV, to take advantage of the deal.

"That is an important step for all clubs. There are many fans who have not seen Manchester United on Sky, so it is a question of how we distribute the pictures to fans," the spokeman added.

He also played down reports that Manchester United was set to team up with Microsoft in a new media venture.

There is no shortage of suitors for a club which is the world's best-known football brand and has a massive, untapped fan base in areas such as south-east Asia.

He said the club did not have any definite plans regarding a joint venture partner.

webTitle: Ding-dong on high at choir school

fields.headline: Ding-dong on high at choir school
fields.standfirst:
Concerned parents of Westminster Abbey choristers accuse headmaster of bullying and verbal abuse
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: At a time when choirs across the country are preparing for their busiest week of the year, proclaiming glad tidings of peace and goodwill, there is discord at Westminster Abbey's choir school, where pupils and parents have accused the headmaster of bullying and verbal abuse.
fields.body:
At a time when choirs across the country are preparing for their busiest week of the year, proclaiming glad tidings of peace and goodwill, there is discord at Westminster Abbey's choir school, where pupils and parents have accused the headmaster of bullying and verbal abuse.

The centuries-old school - the only one in the country exclusively devoted to the education of boy choristers - nurtures the choir which sings at state occasions, such as coronations and the funeral service for Princess Diana.

It nestles in the shadow of the abbey, next to Church House, headquarters of the Church of England. From their offices opposite, staff at the Department for Education can look down on the school.

The choir's records sell in tens of thousands. It conducts concert tours all over the world, most recently this autumn to the United States. A live concert of sacred and traditional choral works will be broadcast tomorrow night on Classic FM.

Yet one parent told the Guardian: "The school is becoming a bit like Dotheboys Hall. It is becoming a place where some parents are seriously concerned about their sons' welfare."

One parent told the Guardian of an 11-year-old cowering under a 20-minute tirade of abuse from the headmaster, Roger Overend, after being called from his dormitory for a minor infraction.

There are no complaints of physical or sexual abuse against the headmaster. Concerns arise over his conduct of the school and whether he is too stressed to cope. The abbey maintains that many parents are happy with him and that accusations have not been proved.

But another parent said: "What has been going on at the school is absolutely appalling. It would make your hair stand on end. There is a culture of paranoia at the abbey which is preventing the authorities dealing with the problem.

"If you do not treat pupils with fairness and respect, you should not be surprised if there are problems with discipline."

One said that the headmaster had taken notes of everything said to him by a pupil during the recent American trip, culminating in the boy being told that the head would be "consulting his lawyer."

One parent said his son had been told by the head during an outburst: "I can ruin your career."

The boy and his brother have subsequently been withdrawn from the school and have won places at one of the country's leading independent schools.

Another parent said: "I have concerns about the behaviour of the headmaster. It is a tiny school with the sort of pupil/teacher ratio that would be the envy of an Oxford college but people are seriously worried."

The number of parents threatening to remove their children means that the choir could soon be severely depleted. In a school of 37 pupils, aged between eight and 13, up to eight of the 20 families which send children to the school are thought to be contemplating withdrawal. Six separate parents spoke to the Guardian under conditions of anonymity.

An independent seven-week inspection into parental complaints by the abbey's receiver general, Major General David Burden, has been held. Westminster council, the local education authority, is completing a routine inspection believed to focus on problems at the school.

At issue are complaints from several parents about the behaviour of Mr Overend towards their sons and accusations that the dean of the abbey, the Very Rev. Dr Wesley Carr, 59, has refused to take them seriously. He has declined to disclose the details of General Burden's report even to the school's governing body.

Two years ago Dr Carr sacked organist Dr Martin Neary amid accusations of a poisonous and secretive atmosphere. Although the sacking was upheld by an inquiry, it found the way the abbey had handled the affair "must score a gamma-minus on the scale of natural justice."

The abbey is a so-called royal peculiar, notionally under the direct jurisdiction of the Queen, which in practice means that it is administered by the dean. A commission ordered by the Queen in May 1999 to examine the "organisation, management and accountability" of the abbey after the Neary dispute is due to report early next year. Westminster council con firmed yesterday that it was conducting a routine inspection, though the school will not be obliged to publish it.

All inquiries yesterday were referred to the abbey's deputy receiver general in charge of communications. In a two-page statement, the abbey said: "As a matter of good practice, the governors do not comment on individual personnel cases or boys ...We have abided by this principle in all of our dealings as this is the best way to protect the welfare of the boys.

"We question whether any parent truly interested in the welfare of the boys and the school would wish to approach a newspaper with such allegations.

"I can confirm that a complaint has been made against the headmaster connected with his criticism of a pupil ... Dr Carr appointed the head of administration of the abbey, who is not directly connected with the school, to carry out a full investigation... The chairman of governors has taken the appropriate action and it would be wrong to comment further."

Pride in history and wealth of musical talent

The Westminster Abbey choir school's prospectus says: "A boy joining...becomes an heir to a tradition of musical excellence many centuries old. Singing daily in the abbey is the central part of life for the choristers.

"The choir takes part in numerous state and national occasions, gives concert performances in Britain and abroad and makes frequent TV and radio broadcasts and recordings."

The abbey's website says the origins of its choir are lost in obscurity but it is probable that boys joined with novices in the singing of masses and daily services as far back as 1170.

Both Henry VIII and Elizabeth I provided funds to educate the choirboys along with the 40 scholars of Westminster school but the first chorister school was opened in 1848. The current buildings date from 1915 and among distinguished old boys is the organist and conductor Sir David Willcocks.

The average class size is seven. Parents pay (heavily subsidised) boarding fees of £1,168 a term.

The prospectus adds: "We are very conscious that ... choir singing and music should not stand in the way of the boys' development as normal, healthy children.

"They play soccer and cricket ... run in St James' Park and swim regularly ... The boys can play table tennis, table football, snooker and, at the end of a busy day, sit and watch a little television or a video.

"Although the school and abbey routines inevitably impose some restrictions, we encourage parents to see their sons as often as possible. On most weekends boys can be taken out after Evensong at about 4.15pm until their bedtime."

The prospectus adds: "Apart from the younger ones, the boys are required to sing for the Christmas and Easter periods. They have a tremendous amount of fun and families become involved in some of the celebrations.

"The boys of Westminster Abbey choir come from various parts of the country, their families from all walks of life. What they have in common is musical talent; previous experience in a choir is less important. Selection is through a series of musical and academic tests."

The abbey says voice trials are held twice a year, with musical tests including the singing of a prepared song, aural tests and playing an instrument, together with academic tests in English and maths.

The prospectus adds: "If your son is musical and will be about 8 years old in September 2001, then this is a wonderful opportunity to fulfil his potential ... The dean and chapter give generous choristerships worth about 80% of the annual fees."

webTitle: Fair and affordable

fields.headline: Fair and affordable
fields.trailText: But a key NHS group needs more pay.
fields.body:
After Saturday's splash headline on the Times front page - "Nurses win 8% pay rise ahead of election" - there was bound to be disappointment yesterday. Some senior nurses, sisters and charge nurses, in the top four grades will (with the new cost of living supplement and inner-London weighting) get increases of 8% or more starting in April.

At the bottom end of the pay scale, yesterday's report from the pay review body expresses "particular concern" for nurse auxiliaries, calling for the new pay system currently under negotiation to take on board their problems as "a matter or urgency". But the main nursing army - some 430,000 or more - will only receive a 3.7% pay rise.

The special rises for senior nurses - outside London they are getting 5% - is needed. As yesterday's report notes, the structure of the profession has historically been too flat, with differentials that are much too small and which fail to recognise the real differences in skills and responsibility that exist. Under the government's 10-year modernisation plan, the 70,000 nurses in senior grades will have a crucial role in breaking down current demarcation boundaries between the medical professions. They will be expected to assume more responsibility, such as drug prescribing, in Labour's more responsive and flexible health service. It was crucial these more experienced nurses were retained.

But clearly this award is not going to generate "a winter of contentment" among the main army. Health department spin doctors have shot themselves in their own feet. By building up expectations in Saturday's papers, they guaranteed yesterday's disenchantment. Yet one year's award cannot be looked at in isolation. Two years ago, newly qualified nurses had a 12% pay rise and last year staff nurses received 8%. There are limits to such big rises.

To its credit, the Royal College of Nursing acknowledged the good news in this year's award and its complexity. For the third year in a row, the pay review body's recommendations are being being implemented in full.

The NHS will face a serious challenge in meeting its target of 20,000 extra nurses by 2004, but the current 22,000 vacancies is only a 5% shortfall. The professions allied to medicine - occupational therapists, physiotherapists, chiropodists - have a far larger hole to fill. Their salary scale starts a few hundred pounds above nursing, but has a ceiling way below senior nurses. Yet, ironically, it is these professionals who are the key players in ensuring the NHS gets through the winter without a trolley scandal. These are the professionals - along with social workers - who can ensure elderly patients do not block hospital beds, by providing care packages and home adaptations that allow them to be discharged.

The health service is facing a much more competitive market. Gone are the days when women only had two main professions to choose from: teaching or nursing. The life of a nurse has become more stressful in a hospital system which discharges patients much more quickly. Patients are sicker and need more intensive nursing. Pay is going to have to reflect these extra strains, but employment conditions are almost as important.

The NHS has been notoriously slow in introducing more flexible working hours and childcare facilities. That is a major reason why 70,000 former nurses declined to return and why thousands more joined nursing agencies, where they could demand more flexible arrangements. That cost the NHS £340m last year. Time for change is long overdue.

webTitle: Can't get no satisfaction

fields.headline: Can't get no satisfaction
fields.trailText: "Labour gambles on modest rise for nurses", said the Guardian yesterday - and so it turned out when the pay review recommendations were published. But was it a gamble, asks Jo-Ann Mulligan and John Appleby
fields.body:
"Labour gambles on modest rise for nurses", said the Guardian yesterday - and so it turned out when the pay review recommendations were published. But was it a gamble? What if people's satisfaction, or lack of it, with the NHS has little to do with how much money is spent on doctors, nurses and hospitals but is much more a "political" judgment related to feelings about the party in power?

Apart from questions about voting intentions, the most commonly asked opinion poll question is about (dis)satisfaction with the NHS. Both, of course, are about politics. The entanglement goes further: politics is about the NHS and vice-versa.

A typical "satisfaction" question was posed in a survey carried out by Mori on behalf of the British Medical Association at the end of November. Of those asked the question "Overall, how satisfied or dissatisfied are you with the NHS?", 28% said fairly or very dissatisfied. The BMA made much of the fact that these figures were 11 percentage points higher than in a poll carried out in 1998.

Naturally, the Department of Health chose to emphasise the 58% who expressed satisfaction. However, other polls carried out this year have suggested that two-thirds of the population believe that the NHS had not improved since Tony Blair became prime minister.

The BMA poll also revealed something about the link between politics and the NHS. Unprompted, three-quarters of those polled thought either the current or the last government was responsible for the current state of the NHS. The BMA's interpretation of their opinion poll results was, unsurprisingly, that the NHS needs more doctors and more money (and also by implication that doctors need more money).

But we know that opinion poll results are very sensitive to the exact wording of questions, the order in which they are posed and whether interviews are carried out face to face or over the telephone. We know it is important to be able to tie in respondents' personal characteristics (age, party allegiance) in order to interpret satisfaction results. It is also necessary to track trends in opinions over time rather than to construct over-elaborate interpretations of one-off polls.

The best trend data on NHS satisfaction is produced by the British Social Attitudes survey, with data going back to 1983. The graph displays the results - the survey was not done every year, which explains the gaps. Latest results - for 1999 - show that dissatisfaction with the way the NHS is run fell from an all time high of 50% in 1996 to 33% in 1999, its lowest level for more than a decade. But this happened after the notorious 1998-99 winter of NHS discontent. What is going on?

One interpretation is that these results reflected a honeymoon period for the Labour government. When the figures are broken down by political allegiance, it is Labour supporters who account for the greatest decrease in dissatisfaction - from 60% in 1996 to 31% in 1999. The fall in dissatisfaction among Tory supporters over the same period was just two percentage points.

So, as the BMA poll showed, asking people how they feel about the running of the NHS turns out to be as much a question about the performance of the government of the day as it is about the performance of the health service. So the chart does mirror the changing economic and political fortunes of both the NHS and those charged with its stewardship.

Dissatisfaction rose sub stantially during the 1980s, coinciding with historically very low real-terms increases in NHS funding between 1983 and 1989. Then, following the unusually large injection of cash for three years in succession from 1990, dissatisfaction fell. The cycle shifts during the mid 1990s, when the Major government entered the 1997 general elec tion following one of the lowest real increases in NHS funding for many years. Dissatisfaction with the NHS had rocketed and Labour was subsequently elected.

However, the fall in dissatisfaction last year does not fit easily with this interpretation based on NHS funding. NHS spending in 1998 and 1999 effectively continued the previous government's parsimony, and yet dissatisfaction fell in both years.

Whatever the reason for the ebbs and flows in dissatisfaction, it is by no means certain that the mere knowledge of money being spent on the health service - without visible signs of improvement - will be enough to convince the public that the service is being turned around. The BMA poll certainly suggests otherwise. And, significantly, British Social Attitudes shows that dissatisfaction towards specific components of the NHS (GPs, inpatient, outpatient care, and so on) has remained more or less the same throughout the past few years.

More generally, questions about satisfaction are easy to ask; perhaps too easy. The media and the prevailing political climate play a role in shaping and influencing overall perceptions. If we really want to get close to what people feel about the health service, it is much better to ask questions about their personal experience of it: "how long did you wait to see your GP?", rather than "are you satisfied with your GP?"

In the meantime, if you are stopped on the street by pollsters and asked to rate your satisfaction with the health service, try cutting through to the heart of the matter by telling them how you plan to vote in the general election.

 Jo-Ann Mulligan and John Appleby are at the King's Fund.

webTitle: 'When I quit, it was 60% to do with low pay'

fields.headline: 'When I quit, it was 60% to do with low pay'
fields.trailText: Phillip Huston says he was very idealistic about nursing and the NHS when he began a three-year degree course in 1995. But within 18 months of qualifying, he had quit his job because of poor pay and lack of job satisfaction.
fields.body:
Phillip Huston says he was very idealistic about nursing and the NHS when he began a three-year degree course in 1995. But within 18 months of qualifying, he had quit his job because of poor pay and lack of job satisfaction.

"I was not as badly off as other people on the course, because at least I owned my own house," he said. "When I first qualified at the beginning of 1998, I was earning £12,500 and it eventually was increased to £14,000 after a pay review. It is ridiculous if you think what trainee police officers get."

He said that the 3.7% pay increase for nurses was terrible. "I would have thought it would have been a lot more generous; between 7.5% and 8% would have been a reasonable figure. People will be completely disillusioned by this pay award and this is not the way to retain nurses in the NHS."

Mr Huston, 34, from Hyde, Greater Manchester, decided to go into nursing after he was made redundant in 1994 after 10 years as an army officer. His aunt, two cousins and mother had all been nurses.

"I went from having a very healthy salary to earning £4,000 a year in a bursary. Even though I had some money to fall back on, I did incur some debts while training," he said.

"As soon as I qualified I started work in anaesthetics and recovery at the Countess of Chester hospital in Chester.

"After six months I started to wonder why I had gone into nursing. I found it incredibly frustrating. When I decided to quit, 60% of the reason was because of the pay and the rest was the lack of job satisfaction."

He now works as development manager for Thornbury nursing services, which provides agency nurses and offers professional training.

Alison Brierley had always wanted to be a nurse, but has only been able to realise her ambition in the last few years. She spent the previous 14 years working as a health care assistant in NHS hospitals. Now, with her four children at school, she has been able to realise her ambition.

Alison, 37, who lives in Oldham, Greater Manchester, qualified in October 1999 and now works as a D grade at the Royal Oldham hospital on an acute medical ward.

The 3.7% pay increase will be worth £554.81 a year to her. "At the end of the day, the police do a few months' training and then start off on £19,000 a year," she said. "We do three years at university and then start off on £14,995. It is no wonder that we get despondent.

"We were expecting a little bit more than a 3.7% pay rise. Although we got an increase earlier this year, it is not ideal. It would have been better if we had something nearer 5%.

"Nursing is a very difficult job. Morale is very low and has been for quite some time - it is not just about pay.

"The staff shortages are also having an effect on the wards. It is quite demanding working on an acute medical ward. I didn't realise how much of a strain nursing would be.

"It is not easy when you come home because you can't just switch off from work. When I was training, I didn't realise how demanding a job it would be.

"If I am working a late shift, I don't get home until 10pm and then I can be starting work again the next day at 7.30am. By the time I wind down, it's 12 o'clock before I get to bed and then you are up again and ready to start work."

"At this time of year there are extra pressures with the demands for beds which makes things difficult.

"The people I trained with feel the same way - we are all despondent. I didn't come into nursing because of the pay, it was because I love the job of nursing.
