webTitle: NHS pay deal 'will fuel staff crisis'

fields.headline: NHS pay deal 'will fuel staff crisis'
fields.trailText: Nurses' and doctors' leaders warned ministers last night that "disappointing" pay increases promised for next year would not be enough to attract the staff needed to implement the government's ambitious NHS reform plan.
fields.body:
Nurses' and doctors' leaders warned ministers last night that "disappointing" pay increases promised for next year would not be enough to attract the staff needed to implement the government's ambitious NHS reform plan.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said he accepted the pay review body's recommendation of a 3.7% rise for nurses and therapists and 3.9% for doctors and dentists.

The extra will be paid in full from April 1, coinciding with what is widely expected to be the start of the general election campaign.

The settlement included higher increases for about 70,000 senior nurses, giving 5.5% to sisters at the top of the main scale and taking their maximum to £25,420.

There will also be cost of living supplements worth £600 to £1,000 for some nursing staff in London and £400 to £600 in other high-cost areas. That would contribute towards raising their pay by up to 9%.

But most NHS staff will be limited to an increase of less than 1% above the rate of inflation, currently running at 3.2%.

The deal will add 4% to the NHS pay bill in England, costing £673m in a full year. So it will consume less than a quarter of the £2.9bn increase in health authority budgets, already announced for the coming year.

The Department of Health said this should leave room for 5.9% real growth in NHS spending - to recruit more staff, expand facilities and meet the ever-increasing drugs bill.

Mr Milburn said: "We are determined to do right by frontline NHS staff. Year on year we are making steady progress on increasing their numbers and improving pay rates.

"These fair and affordable pay rises will help increase still further the numbers of trained, qualified staff working in the NHS. For the third year in a row, the awards will be paid in full, without staging."

But leaders of the medical professions cast doubt on whether the increases would be enough for the government to make progress towards targets to recruit an extra 20,000 nurses, 2,000 GPs and 7,500 consultants by 2004.

Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, said the pay settlement "is hardly the winter tonic that doctors had been hoping for".

He added: "While it is an above-inflation award, it will do little to motivate frontline staff and even less to tackle the major shortfall of doctors in the UK."

John Chisholm, chairman of the BMA's general practitioners committee, said: "We are disappointed. In our view it fails to address the serious shortfall in current GP numbers. Nor does it recognise the huge workload pressures faced by those in the profession."

Peter Hawker, chairman of the consultants committee, said: "We know there is a crisis of under-capacity and this announcement will do little to resolve that."

John Renshaw, chairman of the British Dental Association executive board, said: "It appears unlikely it will help overcome the shortage of dentists working for the NHS."

Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, said it was a "complex pay award" that would be good news for ward sisters, specialist clinical nurses and community nurses. "Many staff nurses will be disappointed by a basic uplift of 3.7% as alone it won't bring fast progress in encouraging nurses back to the health service."

Karen Jennings, head of nursing at the public sector union, Unison, said: "This is a missed opportunity by the pay review body who should have had the vision to solve tomorrow's problems and not just look at today's."

But Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS Confederation representing health authority managers and trusts, said the deal "could well take us to the edges of affordability".

Health ministers were confident last night that the increases would be enough to continue the trend to recruit and retain more nurses. A spokesman said the workforce grew by 6,000 over the last year and four more years at that rate would achieve the target of 20,000 extra.

The awards range from £335 a year at the bottom of the scale for a nursing assistant aged 18, to £4,835 for a top consultant doctor with maximum distinction awards. According to Department of Health figures, a newly qualified nurse's pay will rise from a minimum of £14,890 to £15,445.

An experienced staff nurse at the top of the scale will rise from £19,220 to £19,935 and a sister at the top of the main scale from £24,090 to £25,420

A hospital consultant's starting salary will go from between £48,905 and £63,640 to between £50,810 and £66,120, with top specialists able to earn up to a maximum £128,935.

Family doctors should see their income rise from £54,220 to £56,335 from next year.

There will also be cost of living supplements worth £600 to £1,000 for some nursing staff in London and £400 to £600 in other high-cost areas. That would contribute towards raising their pay by up to 9%. But most NHS staff will be limited to an increase of less than 1% above the rate of inflation, currently running at 3.2%. The deal will add 4% to the NHS pay bill in England, costing £673m in a full year. So it will consume less than a quarter of the £2.9bn increase in health authority budgets, already announced for the coming year. The Department of Health said this should leave room for 5.9% real growth in NHS spending - to recruit more staff, expand facilities and meet the ever-increasing drugs bill. Mr Milburn said: "We are determined to do right by frontline NHS staff. Year on year we are making steady progress on increasing their numbers and improving pay rates. "These fair and affordable pay rises will help increase still further the numbers of trained, qualified staff working in the NHS. For the third year in a row, the awards will be paid in full, without staging." But leaders of the medical professions cast doubt on whether the increases would be enough for the government to make progress towards targets to recruit an extra 20,000 nurses, 2,000 GPs and 7,500 consultants by 2004. Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, said the pay settlement "is hardly the winter tonic that doctors had been hoping for". He added: "While it is an above-inflation award, it will do little to motivate frontline staff and even less to tackle the major shortfall of doctors in the UK." John Chisholm, chairman of the BMA's general practitioners committee, said: "We are disappointed. In our view it fails to address the serious shortfall in current GP numbers. Nor does it recognise the huge workload pressures faced by those in the profession." Peter Hawker, chairman of the consultants committee, said: "We know there is a crisis of under-capacity and this announcement will do little to resolve that." John Renshaw, chairman of the British Dental Association executive board, said: "It appears unlikely it will help overcome the shortage of dentists working for the NHS." Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, said it was a "complex pay award" that would be good news for ward sisters, specialist clinical nurses and community nurses. "Many staff nurses will be disappointed by a basic uplift of 3.7% as alone it won't bring fast progress in encouraging nurses back to the health service." Karen Jennings, head of nursing at the public sector union, Unison, said: "This is a missed opportunity by the pay review body who should have had the vision to solve tomorrow's problems and not just look at today's." But Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS Confederation representing health authority managers and trusts, said the deal "could well take us to the edges of affordability". Health ministers were confident last night that the increases would be enough to continue the trend to recruit and retain more nurses. A spokesman said the workforce grew by 6,000 over the last year and four more years at that rate would achieve the target of 20,000 extra. The awards range from £335 a year at the bottom of the scale for a nursing assistant aged 18, to £4,835 for a top consultant doctor with maximum distinction awards. According to Department of Health figures, a newly qualified nurse's pay will rise from a minimum of £14,890 to £15,445. An experienced staff nurse at the top of the scale will rise from £19,220 to £19,935 and a sister at the top of the main scale from £24,090 to £25,420 A hospital consultant's starting salary will go from between £48,905 and £63,640 to between £50,810 and £66,120, with top specialists able to earn up to a maximum £128,935. Family doctors should see their income rise from £54,220 to £56,335 from next year.

webTitle: Cut in home-building plans for south-east fails to satisfy critics

fields.headline: Cut in home-building plans for south-east fails to satisfy critics
fields.trailText: The government has scaled back plans for construction of thousands of homes in the south-east, following claims that the planned pace of development would eat into acres of valuable countryside reports Rebecca Allison
fields.body:
The government has scaled back plans for construction of thousands of homes in the south-east, following claims that the planned pace of development would eat into acres of valuable countryside.

The planning minister, Nick Raynsford, yesterday confirmed the decision to cut the number of new homes to be built each year from the original plan of 43,000 to 39,000 for the next five years.

But he admitted that ministers had been unable to accept proposal by the South East Regional Planning Authority (Serplan) for a further reduction of 6,000, as this failed to take proper account of the region's future housing needs.

He said that by concentrating on high-density housing developments, it would be possible to meet the new target without using any more land than Serplan had envisaged would be needed for 33,000 new homes per year.

The announcement was given a cool reception by environmental groups and the opposition, who argued that the new target figure was an inadequate response to the threat development poses to the region's green spaces.

The shadow environment secretary, Archie Norman, accused ministers of arrogantly assuming that they knew better than Serplan what the region needed.

"This is a slap in the face for local people. This will inevitably mean the loss of more of our precious green fields. This shows how the centralised national planning system is flawed with Whitehall diktats overriding local wishes," he said.

"The rise in the number of single-person households is the factor fuelling household growth, but single people mainly want to live in towns and cities. Labour are building the wrong houses in the wrong places."

Tory leader William Hague is also expected to criticise the move today, accusing the government of putting the green belt in jeopardy.

Tony Burton, assistant director of the Council for the Protection of Rural England, urged the government to do more to ease building pressures on the already overcrowded south-east by encouraging the regeneration of other regions.

"This is an inadequate response to building pressures on the south-east's countryside, which leaves 100 square kilometres of rural land under threat from the bulldozer," he said.

"The south-east's environment is at breaking point. The harm caused by excessive housebuilding cannot be masked by commitments to improve the density and design of new development.

"Policies to focus on urban regeneration will be undermined by the vast area of rural land already earmarked for development."

webTitle: MP calls for Mental Health Act reforms

fields.headline: MP calls for Mental Health Act reforms
fields.trailText: A Tory MP has called for a reform of the Mental Health Act to force potentially dangerous patients to be detained against their will if necessary after a drunk, mentally ill intruder forced her way into his home.
fields.body:
A Tory MP has called for a reform of the Mental Health Act to force potentially dangerous patients to be detained against their will if necessary after a drunk, mentally ill intruder forced her way into his home.

Andrew Mackay, the shadow Northern Ireland secretary, grappled with the screaming woman, who had fled the nearby Gordon psychiatric hospital, and knocked her to the floor of the Westminster town house he shares with his wife, Julie Kirkbride, the Tory MP for Bromsgove, and two-month-old baby.

The white paper on mental health, published tomorrow, will include this proposal but patients such as the one who entered the Mackay home would not be included. A spokesman for the Gordon hospital, where she had been a voluntary residential patient for a few years, stressed she had not been sectioned.

The altercation came at around 9pm on Sunday after the doorbell rang. Because of the security threat of Mr Mackay's job, Ms Kirkbride opened the door and was struck by the force of a stocky woman.

"The door was thrown back on me and I tried to push her but she was on her front foot and I was on my back so she pushed her way in. She screamed that she needed help and ran into the house," Ms Kirkbride recalled yesterday.

Mr Mackay, the MP for Bracknell, alerted by his wife's screams, rushed to stop the woman, who was in her 30s. "I just caught her and brought her to the ground. I just pushed her and then held her wrists," he said.

The nanny rang the police who arrived within five minutes. The woman, a voluntary psychiatric patient, was not charged but returned to the hospital on the same square in which the MPs live. It emerged she had been involved in a fracas after drinking in Victoria and had fled to the Mackays after being detained by a nurse.

Last night, Ms Kirkbride, 40, who was confronted by a burglar wielding a knife in the house earlier this summer, said: "This was less terrifying than the last time, but only because I wasn't alone: my have-a-go hero husband was there."

"These things are so split second," Mr Mackay said. "My reaction was that this was an unwelcome intruder, who had barged past my wife while my baby and young nanny were downstairs. She was clearly a danger to us - and my first and immediate thought was that I had to control her."

Ms Kirkbride added that the latest incident highlighted the problem of falling numbers in the Metropolitan police force. This month, the commissioner Sir John Stevens warned the Met was 3,000 officers short.

webTitle: Recruitment: Marsh tipped to leave BBC for BSkyB

fields.headline: Marsh tipped to leave BBC for BSkyB
fields.trailText: 8.15am: BSkyB is on the verge of appointing Kate Marsh, BBC Birmingham head of lifestyle and features, to its pay-TV networks operation, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BSkyB is on the verge of announcing the appointment of Kate Marsh, BBC Birmingham head of lifestyle and features, to its pay-TV networks operation.

Ms Marsh is quitting in the wake of the closure of Pebble Mill studios and the reorganisation of her department.

She is expected to report to Mark Sharman, BSkyB director of broadcasting.

It is not yet clear whether Ms Marsh will take over any of the responsibilities of David Bergg, Sky One general manager.

Mr Bergg is currently understood to be negotiating severance terms with BSkyB.

In Birmingham Ms Marsh oversaw programmes including Top Gear, Gardener's World and Delia's How To Cook.

webTitle: Mirror to name Brady source

fields.headline: Mirror to name Brady source
fields.trailText: The Mirror must name the source who leaked a confidential diary on the Moors murderer Ian Brady, judges ruled yesterday. By Clare Dyer.
fields.body:
The Mirror newspaper must name the source who leaked the contents of a confidential diary on the Moors murderer Ian Brady kept by medical staff at Ashworth high security hospital, three appeal court judges ruled yesterday.

The judges, headed by the master of the rolls, Lord Phillips, upheld a high court judge's order last April forcing the paper to name the source of a series of extracts logging the killer's moods, actions and words at the hospital in Maghull, Merseyside.

The case is one of the first since the Human Rights Act came into force last October in which judges have had to balance two opposing rights - in this case, privacy and freedom of information.

Last April, the appeal court overturned a high court judge's ruling that Express Newspapers must name the source of a draft opinion leaked from the chambers of lawyers representing the singer Elton John. In that case, said Lord Woolf, then master of the rolls, there was a "prime need" to protect the source "in the interest of ensuring a free press in a democratic society".

But in the Brady case, Lord Phillips, dismissing the appeal, said: "The disclosure of confidential medical records to the press is misconduct which is not merely of concern to the individual establishment in which it occurs.

"It is an attack on an area of confidentiality which should be safeguarded in democratic societies. The protection of patient information is of vital concern to the NHS and to health services in Europe."

The Mirror, which published the extracts, for which it paid a contact £1,500, in December 1999, is to seek a ruling from the House of Lords. If it loses there, it could take the case to the European court of human rights in Strasbourg.

In a recent case on journalists' sources, the European court ruled that an order requiring a reporter to reveal his sources so a company could trace a disloyal employee breached his right to freedom of expression.

webTitle: 'Offensive' Opium posters to be removed

fields.headline: 'Offensive' Opium posters to be removed
fields.trailText: A perfume ad featuring model Sophie Dahl posing naked is to be withdrawn because it is deemed degrading to women, writes Rebecca Allison.
fields.body:
A poster of the model Sophie Dahl posing naked on a fur rug in an advertising campaign for Opium perfume is to be withdrawn because it is deemed to be too sexually suggestive and degrading to women.

The removal of the billboard adverts, which show the 23-year-old granddaughter of the author Roald Dahl lying on her back cupping one breast in her hand and wearing nothing but gold stiletto-heeled shoes, was ordered by the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) last night.

The Yves Saint Laurent perfume campaign, which has caused widespread controversy since it appeared in more than 500 locations over the past three weeks, has become one of the most complained about adverts in the ASA's history.

Plaid Cymru backbencher Brian Hancock was among those who complained to the ASA this month after one of the Opium posters was put up near the Welsh assembly's doors.

The authority's ruling council yesterday asked for an assurance that every poster would be removed and that the picture would not be used in such a way again.

Christopher Graham, ASA director general, said: "This was the most complained about advertisement in the last five years. As a poster it clearly caused serious and widespread offence." He said it was sexually suggestive and likely to cause "serious or widespread offence" thereby breaking the British codes of advertising and sales promotion.

The ASA received 730 complaints about the picture from members of the public who had found it too sexually suggestive and unsuitable for display on the streets.

The image, from a photograph by Stephen Meisel, was deemed as acceptable when it appeared in print media in October and November because it was targeted at a specific group of consumers and only elicited three complaints, according to the ASA.

"We ruled that it was acceptable in that case because it mainly appeared in women's magazines and was seen by a target audience.

"This was unlikely to cause serious or widespread offence, whereas when the posters went up nationwide the complaints flooded in," Gary Ward, the authority's head of communications, said.

The Opium advert was the most controversial since 1995 when the ASA received 1,100 complaints about the British Safety Council's leaflet promoting safe sex with a picture of the Pope wearing a crash helmet, he added.

As a consequence of the ASA decision, Yves Saint Laurent may now be forced to have their posters pre-vetted for up to two years if requested by the Committee of Advertising Practice.

webTitle: BBC to launch kids' music label

fields.headline: BBC to launch kids' music label
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BBC
fields.trailText:
11.30am: BBC Worldwide is to capitalise on the chart success of Bob the Builder and the Tweenies by launching a children's music label, writes Claire Cozens.
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
BBC Worldwide is to capitalise on the surprise chart success of its Bob the Builder and Tweenies characters by launching a children's music label.

It will take on the giants of the music world with its own "record division" for younger audiences.

Bob the Builder has become a chart phenomenon after beating off competition from Eminem and Robbie Williams with his hit single, "Can We Fix It?". The track is number one in the charts and is already certified platinum.

The BBC plans to build on this success by releasing more records early next year.

"The new BBC children's record label will continue to make quality pop music for children," said Graham Samuels, BBC Music marketing director.

"The Tweenies and Bob the Builder will develop on this early success by releasing more records in the UK and around the world next year."

Previous successes from the BBC's children's portfolio include the Teletubbies single released in 1997, which reached number one in the charts and sold 1.5m copies in the UK.

The Tweenies' single, released seven weeks ago, has sold 300,000 copies and is still in the top 10.

webTitle: Saatchis wins top ad prize

fields.headline: Saatchis strikes gold with army ads
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Saatchi & Saatchi won the top prize at the Direct Marketing Association/Royal Mail awards last night for its army recruitment ads, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Saatchi & Saatchi walked away with the top accolade at the Direct Marketing Association/Royal Mail awards last night, scooping the Grand Prix for its army recruitment campaign.

Saatchis also took home a gold in the Best use of copy category and two highly commended awards, all for its army work. The campaign was based around a scratchcard inserted into magazines and newspapers.

Marc Nohr, chairman of the judges, said: "The army scratchcard won because of its simplicity and efficacy. The simplest of all ideas executed perfectly.

"It showed audience insight in terms of the way it used the media and targeted its audience. It pushed the boundaries and worked."

The awards are run every year by the DMA in conjunction with the Royal Mail.

Other winning agencies were Craik Jones, which took home 12 golds for its work on brands including Virgin Trains and Land Rover; Oneagency, which received accolades for campaigns for Glenmorangie and the Northern Ireland Tourism Board; and Rapier, which picked up awards for its work on Cable & Wireless.

KLP Euro RSCG also picked up a gold for its work on the Guardian.

webTitle: Solvency queries Equitable didn't raise

fields.headline: Solvency queries Equitable didn't raise
fields.standfirst:
Treasury knew risks in 1998

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Until this year's court case, Equitable Life was safe as houses. To borrow a phrase current in the 1960s relating to IBM, nobody ever got fired for recommending Equitable Life. Yet more than two years ago, the Treasury knew otherwise.
fields.body:
Until this year's court case, Equitable Life was safe as houses. To borrow a phrase current in the 1960s relating to IBM, nobody ever got fired for recommending Equitable Life. Yet more than two years ago, the Treasury knew otherwise.

In a leaked memo, dated November 1998, it emerges that a senior Treasury official in charge of the supervision of pension companies had - and it's in black and white - "serious questions about the company's solvency".

Equitable has sold many, many policies since November 1998. Who would have bought one if they knew that the Treasury was deeply concerned that Equitable was not putting aside enough cash to cover its guarantees?

Or that senior civil servants found the information supplied by the company to be "unconvincing"?

The individuals who bought since then - some of them refugees from the £13bn pensions mis-selling scandal of the 1980s and early 1990s - were entirely unaware of the alarm bells ringing in the corridors of Whitehall. It will be difficult to deny them a formal inquiry into the Equitable affair.

The Treasury will argue that it took steps to remedy the situation. Why else did the liability figure of £1.5bn suddenly appear in Equitable's accounts the next time they were posted to the Treasury?

But somebody forgot to tell the punters. The accounts insurance companies send to their regulator are thicker than the London phone book, and usually even less interesting.

When it did emerge that Equitable had pencilled in the £1.5bn figure, the company hurriedly set about denying that it had any relevance.

It argued that £1.5bn was a highly unlikely, worst case scenario, and that a figure of between £50m and £200m was much more likely.

The regulatory failure with Equitable was not in identifying the scale of the problem, but in having the confidence to tackle it.

Did Equitable arrogantly rebuff the attempts by civil servants to make it reserve more prudently? Were civil servants too timid when faced with one of the most powerful insurance groups in Britain?

Or was the problem the government's own rulebook? Year in, year out, Equitable ran on a tight solvency margin and yet was well within the minimum solvency requirements set out by the DTI. In such a situation, civil servants could scarcely demand that Equitable put aside more cash for future liabilities.

The tiny band of people who understand pension companies' opaque accounts have known for years that the financial strength figures - such as the free assets ratio - can be bent every which way.

Some companies even throw in a figure for future profits that have not been made and almost certainly will not.

In the hall of mirrors that is pension company accounts, a company with a high financial strength figure can be weaker than a competitor with a lower financial strength figure.

The blame for allowing such a daft situation to develop must lie at the government's door. But it also calls into question the standards of the - until now - scandal-free actuarial profession.

Out of order

A decade or so ago a rather silly young man stood up in a north London magistrates court. His crime was to have typed up a takeover offer for a small software firm on his PC; he then faxed it to the Stock Exchange. The offer was written on a single page, rather than the 50 or so usually associated with bona fide bids. It was also full of errors.

Some sharp wit at the LSE spotted the hoax. The "news" did not become public; nobody suffered. Yet the young man had the book thrown at him - and it was a thick book at that: the Financial Services Act, section 47. He'd tried to create a "false market"!

His solicitor pointed out that the case amounted to "using a mallet to squash a marshmallow", and the matter did not proceed much beyond that.

A decade on, the market regulators are still playing out the same old farce. Another trial has collapsed - this one ruining the career of rather older man who, as it happens, has never showed any sign of silliness.

Johnny Townsend will now seek financial retribution from his former employer, Hoare Govett, which must now be scratching its collective head in bewilderment at the judge's criticisms of its corporate behaviour. Hoare is under a statutory duty to report possible misdemeanours and yet ...

The fact is that nobody in investment bank management, regulation or the law is sure what is right or wrong in financial markets any more. New legislation is coming through, but creating case law will be a long and painful task.

Meanwhile every takeover bid, every significant news release, leaks somewhere to somebody who trades - for profit. Judging by the authorities' record, maybe they are just incompetent.
fields.bodyText: Until this year's court case, Equitable Life was safe as houses. To borrow a phrase current in the 1960s relating to IBM, nobody ever got fired for recommending Equitable Life. Yet more than two years ago, the Treasury knew otherwise. In a leaked memo, dated November 1998, it emerges that a senior Treasury official in charge of the supervision of pension companies had - and it's in black and white - "serious questions about the company's solvency". Equitable has sold many, many policies since November 1998. Who would have bought one if they knew that the Treasury was deeply concerned that Equitable was not putting aside enough cash to cover its guarantees? Or that senior civil servants found the information supplied by the company to be "unconvincing"? The individuals who bought since then - some of them refugees from the £13bn pensions mis-selling scandal of the 1980s and early 1990s - were entirely unaware of the alarm bells ringing in the corridors of Whitehall. It will be difficult to deny them a formal inquiry into the Equitable affair. The Treasury will argue that it took steps to remedy the situation. Why else did the liability figure of £1.5bn suddenly appear in Equitable's accounts the next time they were posted to the Treasury? But somebody forgot to tell the punters. The accounts insurance companies send to their regulator are thicker than the London phone book, and usually even less interesting. When it did emerge that Equitable had pencilled in the £1.5bn figure, the company hurriedly set about denying that it had any relevance. It argued that £1.5bn was a highly unlikely, worst case scenario, and that a figure of between £50m and £200m was much more likely. The regulatory failure with Equitable was not in identifying the scale of the problem, but in having the confidence to tackle it. Did Equitable arrogantly rebuff the attempts by civil servants to make it reserve more prudently? Were civil servants too timid when faced with one of the most powerful insurance groups in Britain? Or was the problem the government's own rulebook? Year in, year out, Equitable ran on a tight solvency margin and yet was well within the minimum solvency requirements set out by the DTI. In such a situation, civil servants could scarcely demand that Equitable put aside more cash for future liabilities. The tiny band of people who understand pension companies' opaque accounts have known for years that the financial strength figures - such as the free assets ratio - can be bent every which way. Some companies even throw in a figure for future profits that have not been made and almost certainly will not. In the hall of mirrors that is pension company accounts, a company with a high financial strength figure can be weaker than a competitor with a lower financial strength figure. The blame for allowing such a daft situation to develop must lie at the government's door. But it also calls into question the standards of the - until now - scandal-free actuarial profession. Out of order A decade or so ago a rather silly young man stood up in a north London magistrates court. His crime was to have typed up a takeover offer for a small software firm on his PC; he then faxed it to the Stock Exchange. The offer was written on a single page, rather than the 50 or so usually associated with bona fide bids. It was also full of errors. Some sharp wit at the LSE spotted the hoax. The "news" did not become public; nobody suffered. Yet the young man had the book thrown at him - and it was a thick book at that: the Financial Services Act, section 47. He'd tried to create a "false market"! His solicitor pointed out that the case amounted to "using a mallet to squash a marshmallow", and the matter did not proceed much beyond that. A decade on, the market regulators are still playing out the same old farce. Another trial has collapsed - this one ruining the career of rather older man who, as it happens, has never showed any sign of silliness. Johnny Townsend will now seek financial retribution from his former employer, Hoare Govett, which must now be scratching its collective head in bewilderment at the judge's criticisms of its corporate behaviour. Hoare is under a statutory duty to report possible misdemeanours and yet ... The fact is that nobody in investment bank management, regulation or the law is sure what is right or wrong in financial markets any more. New legislation is coming through, but creating case law will be a long and painful task. Meanwhile every takeover bid, every significant news release, leaks somewhere to somebody who trades - for profit. Judging by the authorities' record, maybe they are just incompetent.

webTitle: Secret warning on Equitable

fields.headline: Secret warning on Equitable
fields.trailText: The Treasury knew more than two years ago about financial difficulties at the world's oldest mutual life insurer, Equitable Life, according to a leaked government memo obtained by the Guardian.
fields.body:
The Treasury knew more than two years ago about financial difficulties at the world's oldest mutual life insurer, Equitable Life, according to a leaked government memo obtained by the Guardian.

In a damning assessment of Equitable's financial health the Treasury told the City's watchdog, the Financial Services Authority, in November 1998 that it had "serious questions about the company's solvency", adding that information obtained from the company was "unconvincing".

The memo raises new questions about government's role in the Equitable Life crisis - which some commentators have dubbed the biggest financial disaster since the collapse of Barings Bank in 1995. It will also strengthen calls for compensation for its 1m-plus policyholders.

The 238-year-old insurer sparked panic among many of its investors 11 days ago when it closed its doors to new customers and warned existing policyholders they will see their investment returns slashed after it lost a multibillion-pound legal battle involving pension promises made to some customers.

The 1m policyholders - mainly people with personal pensions or company top-up plans provided by Equitable - will be hit with a 10% penalty if they switch their investments to another provider, and have also lost seven months' worth of bonuses.

As worried customers deluged the company and their MPs with calls, some politicians have claimed the FSA failed to protect the public by allowing it to carry on selling new policies until a fortnight ago.

Now the memo leaked to the Liberal Democrats shows the FSA was aware of problems long before the court case in July which landed Equitable with a £1.5bn bill.

It states that the Treasury was concerned about Equitable's ability to set aside sufficient cash to meet promises it had made to 90,000 customers who had bought pension policies with "guaranteed annuities" - the promise of a minimum level of income in retirement.

When the guarantees became very costly in the mid-nineties, Equitable Life tried to renege, resulting in a legal battle which culminated in a House of Lords ruling in July that the company must honour the promises.

Senior Treasury official Roger Allen states in the memo to FSA managing director Michael Foot that "our pri mary concern is over the company's ability to reserve adequately for these guarantees.

"The information received to date is unconvincing and raises serious questions about the company's solvency. We shall be meeting the company again next week to discuss what further steps we may require the company to take."

Vincent Cable, the Liberal Democrat trade and industry spokesman, said the memo provides "clear evidence" that 18 months before the ruling the FSA had ample opportunity to demand Equitable increase its cash reserves to cover the potential costs of its promises. "It apparently did nothing and large numbers of investors signed up for new policies in good faith, totally unaware of the risks that were well-known to the regulator."

Dr Cable has said that if it were established that the FSA failed to act, there would be a "very strong moral obligation" on the government to pay compensation to those who have lost out. He is writing to Gordon Brown, the chancellor, demanding an inquiry.

MPs are due to discuss the crisis during a Commons debate today called by Richard Ottaway, the shadow paymaster general, who said he had been "swamped" by letters from policyholders. "The regulators have got important questions to answer," he said. "If it was obvious to the House of Lords that Equitable Life's position on guarantees was wrong, why was it not obvious to the DTI or to the regulators?"

The FSA defended its handling of the crisis, saying that after receiving the warning memo, "we were subsequently satisfied that the Equitable was solvent and it remains solvent today". A spokesman said the FSA did not officially take over responsibility for regulating insurers until January 1999, two months after the memo was sent by the Treasury, and until then it was the Treasury's responsibility.

webTitle: FSA to investigate Equitable

fields.headline: FSA to investigate Equitable
fields.trailText: City watchdog, the Financial Services Authority, is to launch an investigation into the events which caused troubled life insurer Equitable Life to close its doors to new business, the government announced today.
fields.body:
City watchdog, the Financial Services Authority, is to launch an investigation into the events which caused troubled life insurer Equitable Life to close its doors to new business, the government announced today.

The decision came after the Guardian obtained a leaked memo that showed the FSA had serious question marks over Equitable's solvency as early as November 1998.

The memo, sent from a member of the government's Insurance Directorate, read: "Our primary concern is over the company's ability to reserve adequately for these (annuity rate) guarantees. The information received to date is unconvincing, and raises serious questions about the company's solvency."

Equitable, which has 450,000 with-profits policyholders, sparked panic 11 days ago when it closed its doors to new clients after losing a legal battle over pension promises made to some customers.

This was the culmination of a process begun in July when the House of Lords ruled Equitable was not entitled to cut final bonuses on its guaranteed annuity rate policies, in a decision that cost the mutual £1.5bn and triggered a forced sale.

After the ruling, Equitable was forced to seek a buyer to plug the gap in its finances so policyholders would not suffer. Talks were held with Prudential, but no decision was reached and the insurer was forced to close to new business nearly two weeks ago.

The FSA, which oversees the British financial services industry, has been criticised for allowing Equitable's situation to deteriorate to a point where it was unable to find a buyer.

However, economics secretary Melanie Johnson said today: "The government very much appreciates the concerns that the closure of new business brings to the 650,000 policyholders. The FSA's advice is that policyholders will now have to reflect very carefully on their options before taking action."

She added that the company was not insolvent, no fraud had taken place and all policies with Equitable were still valid.

webTitle: Photography student snapped up to work as a model for Vogue

fields.headline: Now you see me
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston talks to Nina Hauki, a photography student who found herself snapped up to work as a model for Vogue
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston talks to Nina Hauki, a photography student who found herself snapped up to work as a model for Vogue
fields.body:
It started with one of the oldest lines in the lecher's lexicon. A diner sidled up to a beautiful waitress in a restaurant with a cliche along the lines of: "I'm a photographer. Have you ever thought of doing some modelling?"

On this occasion, however, the inquiry did not slither to any of the more dodgy conclusions.

The questioner really was a photographer, and no, she wasn't talent scouting for any of the Daily Express's new top shelf stablemates. "She told me she was doing a shoot for Vogue," Nina Hauki recalls.

The photographer - who, Hauki says, was actually very bashful about making the approach - was a fashion specialist called Vanina Sorrenti, and she proved as good as her word.

Within a matter of weeks, the 24-year-old Finnish student was indeed in Vogue, albeit minus clothes.

"She did tell me she was doing pictures for an article about how people see their own bodies, and did warn me that I would be nude."

If anybody can pull that line off with a stranger they've watched walking past their table with plates of bangers and mash it is your haut-couture snapper.

"I was prepared to do it for Vogue," Hauki says. "Obviously I wouldn't do nude photographs for anybody." Hauki was less defensive about the approach than she might have been because she recognised Sorrenti's name and admired her work. She had examples of it in her own sketchbook.

This is because Hauki is herself a photography student in the second year of a Btec course and she wants to specialise in fashion work. But now she finds herself in the rare and interesting position of working professionally on the other side of the lens first.

Not long after the Vogue appearance, Hauki found herself whisked to Cuba for a fashion shoot. "Autumn wear, underwear and sparkly Christmas party stuff."

The biggest break so far came a month or so ago when she became the new Special K girl. Apparently you won't be able to flick through the titles at the dentist's next year without seeing her standing in front of a mirror holding a dress in front of herself while her "boyfriend" looks admiringly on.

The healthy start to the day could mark the start of a very healthy career as a model, were she to want it. But Hauki insists that it is simply a useful cash prop for her studies.

"I really wouldn't want to be a model for longer than I have to," she says. "When I can support myself from photography I won't think twice about stopping modelling."

She is now thinking of getting herself an agent, but that is as seriously as it will go. She's not taking up the gym nor the fabled supermodel diet of Marlboroughs and champagne to keep in trim.

Photography is her real buzz. Why else would anybody forsake rural Finland for the bleak gulag charms of the Barking College campus, admittedly not seen to best advantage in December drizzle, were they not serious about pursuing their art on a course with an obviously high reputation?

Her dedication is plain, which is why the real benefit of her modelling, even more than the cash it brings, is the insight it gives her into what it is like to be photographed.

She senses the experience will make her a better photographer.

"The relationship between photographer and model is important.

"I know now how it feels to be on the other side. It's given me the whole picture."

Some photographers can be high-handed and autocratic, heedless of the feelings of the person in front of them.

Professional models will move as instructed.

"If you just want a pretty face and you order them to smile, they'll do it."

But the results will be better if there is a proper rapport with someone sympathetic and taking them seriously, Hauki says.

"I think this experience will make me a lot more sensitive to the subjects I shoot."

Even in her brief modelling career to date she has glimpsed good and bad.

"Vanina is really into pictures where there is this interraction with the model.

"It's very important to her that the model is happy and I think that you see it. Her pictures are so natural."

At the other end of the spectrum she has experienced rudeness, not from photographers but from studio assistants, who are often aspiring photographers on the first rungs of their careers.

"That experience will help me be more considerate when I'm an assistant," she says.

Her comparatively late start in modelling - she is 24 - has also been a boon in coping with the somtimes callous modes of rejection.

"If you start at 16 you could be too insecure and take it personally.

"I've met models who even if they are really lovely, have been scarred because of the way they have been rejected for jobs."

Perhaps her knowledge of photography protects her too. "I'm constantly listening to the technical stuff during the shoots - you know, apertures, stops, lighting - and I'm thinking: Is that right? Is this going to work?"

She subtly lets photographers know that she's one of them. To date she hasn't chipped in to give a snapper the benefit of her advice. But there's always a first time.

webTitle: Acting up, falling down

fields.headline: Acting up, falling down
fields.standfirst: Bruised shins and fierce dogs are the stuff of Xmas parties. Or so says  Donald Hiscock
fields.trailText: Bruised shins and fierce dogs are the stuff of Xmas parties. Or so says Donald Hiscock
fields.body:
Acting, organising excitable young children and maintaining calm in the presence of a large, salivating animal are not what I consider to be my strengths. I could add to this list trying to reason with Roxanne, trying to teach Roxanne or probably even just trying to teach.

Once again I have been persuaded to take part in the annual children's Christmas party organised by the student union. Roxanne told me that as her personal tutor I owed it to her to repeat the wonderful performance I gave last year. I should have known better.

The hours are running out. By 6pm tonight I will be picking jelly out of my cotton-wool beard and nursing bruised shins after a frenzied kicking from a five-year-old upset with my offering. Santa will be limping away from his grotto in search of a stiff drink.

Roxanne brought the Father Christmas costume to class yesterday. She kept me in at the end of the lesson to try it on. In fact, the whole class detained themselves from the Yuletide menu in the cafeteria. Santa Claus uncovered was more of an attraction than tree-shaped pizza slices and sausage rolls with holly piercings.

Bemused by why the suit appeared to have Velcro running up each leg and what looked like a padded sporran hanging from a rhinestone studded belt, I asked Roxanne if she had picked up the right costume.

"They only had the stripping Santa suit left," she said fluffing up my beard. "I know the pouch might be a bit too big, but never mind." Apparently, I am in Roxanne's theatre-studies assessment. I have even got a script. You would be amazed how hard it is to deliver a string of "ho ho ho's" in a Brechtian manner. I have been to two rehearsals now, only to be shouted at by a despairing Roxanne demanding more feeling in my "Merry Christmas everybody" set speech.

And then there is the reindeer problem. I thought last year's inflatable ones were fine until some of the children made off with them. This year Roxanne is bringing her dog, Iago.

With foam antlers and a red-plastic nose a doberman looks ridiculous. It also growls when I bend down to get a present out of my sack. I fear an anxious-looking bloke in red PVC will bring out any latent savagery lurking within Iago's canine brain.

The only good thing about this evening's party is that Roxanne has got other staff involved. Colin from maths has been elevated from last year's part as Santa's little helper to a star role as The Grinch. I pointed out to Roxanne at the final rehearsal that this might be an unnecessary Americanisation of our usual tableau.

"I haven't got time to listen to this crap," she said. "Just sit still in your grotto with Iago while I sort out the frigging fairy chorus." At least I don't have to be a fairy like my colleagues from leisure and tourism. And perhaps the media production students will fail to capture the event on video. Well, things could be worse. But I can't imagine how. All together now: "Ho. Ho, Ho. Merry Christmas everybody."

webTitle: Student speak

fields.headline: Hardcore nation
fields.standfirst: Increasingly, students have a language all of their own, which parents - and lecturers - find incomprehensible.  Abul Taher breaks the code
fields.trailText: Increasingly, students have a language all of their own, which parents - and lecturers - find incomprehensible. Abul Taher breaks the code
fields.body:
If you are a hapless parent whose sons and daughters are returning from university for the Christmas break, the chances are you won't have a "Scoobie-Doo" when they tell you that they were "kettled" at the "radio rental" end-of-term party, where they managed to get off with a right "swamp donkey".

According to new research conducted by leading linguist Tony McEnery at Lancaster University, students are using a huge corpus of words that are "currently exclusively in use at campuses around the country". Increasingly, students are developing a language all of their own, which parents will find almost incomprehensible.

Dr McEnery's research, based on his tour of 80 different UK campuses during this year's freshers' week, was commissioned by a student website - Student-World.co.uk - which is carrying a dictionary of student slang for parents and students trying to communicate with each other this Christmas.

McEnery, whose findings are part of his wider research on swearing and abuse in modern English, says: "Student slang is deeply obsessed with sex, drink, etc, as well as other aspects of student life (staying up all night working, degree classifications, etc)."

He has found that there are no fewer than 18 different words for getting drunk - among them "kettled", "trollied", "mullered" and "klangered".

A good night out drinking is absolute "carnage", which is only second to a "complete bender", after which you would be "coming in with the milk bottles" (which means you stayed out getting drunk all night).

Second to drink comes sex, a serious preoccupation among students. Terms like "lancing/jousting", "boning", "get some poot", "park your bus", and "to go Russell" are trendy code words.

Next to sex, and closely linked with it, are terms that describe ugly people, especially women. There are the usual terms like "minger" or "Jerry Springer" (rhyming slang), "munter" and "mutt".

There are several different ways to describe different types of ugliness in women. A "moose" is a large ugly person; a "five pinter" is someone you would only chat up after five pints. There is also the "mucky duck", who is an ageing slapper, and the "swamp donkey", a large and exceptionally ugly individual, notes McEnery, who is an expert in computational linguistics.

There also are numerous slang terms to describe degree classifications.

Some of McEnery's own students in Lancaster's linguistics and modern languages department will be getting a "Geoff Hurst" (first), while most will receive a Trevor Nunn (2:1). Some will also get a Desmond (Tutu - a 2:2), and a few "hardcore" (party-animals) may even get a "Dan Quayle" (fail).

McEnery says student slang is no different from other types of slang. "Just as with slang throughout the ages, it is a mix of old and new forms, student-specific and borrowed forms," he says.

He says student slang isn't a recent phenomenon, but has existed from at least the 18th century.

In the mid-18th century, Captain Francis Grose compiled his Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue, which was an early dictionary of British slang. "When this dictionary was made available to the wider public in 1811," he says, "it had been extended to include the language of the University Wits, as students had already become notable sources of slang words. Although student slang has been around for so long, as an integral part of the language, it has been frowned upon - and still is - "as a vulgarisation of the language".

As the author of the 1811 dictionary notes: "Our young men of fashion [students] are as distinguished for the vulgarity of their jargon as the inhabitants of Newgate [prison]."

"Some words/phrases which appeared in the 1811 dictionary are now so commonplace that people would think it strange that they were ever viewed as slang - 'hoax', 'elbow grease', 'frosty face' and 'fuss' spring to mind. These words have become respectable. So while one generation may view its slang terms as 'vulgar' and 'improper', some of the words may become accepted after a time, so that they cease to be viewed that way."

Similarly, Tony Thorne, who has been studying student slang for the past three years, says that it is a highly creative form that has made valid contributions to the English language. He says that respectable terms such as "omnibus", "mob" and "spondulicks" all began their life as student slang terms.

Thorne, who lectures in lexicology and cultural studies at King's College, London, says that the only reason student slang is frowned upon and not studied seriously is because linguists in Britain have always had a traditional conservative view of language.

Both McEnery and Thorne believe student slang needs to be given serious academic attention. "Student slang remains an evergreen subject for linguists to explore," says McEnery.

Thorne, whose dictionary of adolescent/student slang, Youthspeak, is due out by the end of next year, says his own study has revealed that "adolescents are the most creative users of language". The sources of student slang are very rich and part of the dynamics of a living language at any time.

In the past students played with Latin and Greek to coin new slang terms, when these two languages were prevalent in academia.

Hence "spondulicks", which means money, is ultimately derived from the Greek for sea-shells, which were once used for financial transactions, and "mob" is derived from the Latin mobile vulgus, meaning excitable crowd.

He says the only difference now is that students tend to draw more on English, Afro-Caribbean creole or black African speech in coining new words.

At King's and other cosmopolitan campuses, he has observed that a whole new corpus of slang terms is arising from British-Asian students, where the chief sources are the Indian languages.

Terms such as "gora" (white) and "desi" (Indian native) are gaining a wide currency, as well as terms like "coconut", which refers to an individual who is black-Asian on the outside but thinks like a white person inside.

Whereas it was the white student groups that produced the slangs in the past, followed by Afro-Caribbeans, now increasingly it is Asian students who are becoming increasingly confident about themselves in British campuses, argues Thorne. And student slang is reflecting the "multi-ethnic, multicultural and multi-regional" make-up of the British student population.

Both McEnery and Thorne agree that an overwhelming amount of student slang is based around leisure activities such as drinking and romancing and very little on books and study.

But to them it does not indicate that British students are neglecting their study, and concentrating too much on social activities.

Rather, argues McEnery, students use slang to talk about "taboo" matters such as sex and drinking, which need a certain "codedness". "Studying, mercifully, is not taboo amongst students, so the need to code discussions is reduced," he says.

Thorne adds that in formal contexts such as seminars and lectures standard English is used so there is no need to create slang terms.

But Thorne admits that British students have an overwhelmingly large vocabulary to describe "pleasure activities" - much better than that of their counterparts in other countries, such as America.

"We've found that 75% of student slang in Britain is about drinking and getting drunk," says Thorne.

This is in stark contrast to a representative US campus such as North Carolina University, where only 10% of their slang terms are about drinking. Similarly, around 10% of British student slang term is about sex, compared with only 5% in US campuses.

"This doesn't mean that British students are drunk all the time and oversexed - it means they just like talking about it," says Thorne. But it indicates a change in lifestyle and attitudes amongst students. "It seems that British students are actually pioneering a new kind of lifestyle which is hedonistic."

He adds that this lifestyle and the accompanying slang are not an act of defiance against authority. There are very few slang terms for authority figures, suggesting very little interest or concern with that. Student lifestyle is apolitical and purely pleasure-based, says Thorne.

He think the hedonism may be part of "self-experimentation" and self-discovery, which is increasingly what, for most students, the three or four years of university life are all about.

webTitle: Higher browsing

fields.headline: Higher browsing
fields.trailText: University and research news
fields.body:
The third degree

 As Warwick University revelled in the glow of the world's attention, the main event at its arts centre was clearly billed as "The Twits". While Bill Clinton and Tony Blair gave their vision of world events, Roald Dahl's scabrous creations were entertaining an audience of children a few yards away. The president and White House officials had said the children should not miss their Christmas treat.

 After three years of agonising, Anglia Polytechnic University has finally settled for a new name: APU. The last poly to retain the title, it found "Anglia University" was ruled out by objections from the nearby University of East Anglia, and someone else in Cambridge had bagged the town name. Now the governors have rejected "Anglia Prior University", so denying its former chancellor Lord (Jim) Prior immortality. Officially it's because "prior" suggested pre-university, but one wonders how well it would have gone down with his less-than-devoted fan Lady Thatcher and admirers - such as Tory treasurer Lord Ashcroft, a big APU benefactor.

 Nottingham's decision to accept £3.8m from British American Tobacco continues to provoke strong reactions. The influential environmental activist Jonathan Porritt told a local Nottingham meeting that he is threatening to give back his honorary degree. A Nottingham MBA student of the year last week refused to accept a prize in response to the BAT deal. Rumours are now rife around Nottingham that the university recently turned down funding from Imperial Tobacco.

 Are you a polymath? Try our special Xmas quiz next week - designed to test knowledge on subjects across the academic spectrum. Questions concern key developments and findings in the arts, social sciences, humanities and sciences during the last year.

 Stories? Gossip? Contact us: donald.macleod@Guardian.co.uk or lee.elliotmajor@Guardian.co.uk

Money news

Block research funds for English academic institutions will stay level in real terms over the next year, totalling just under £890m, funding council officials have confirmed.

The Higher Education Funding Council for England will this week consult universities and colleges on plans to allocate an extra £330m over three years to improve pay among academic and non-academic staff. Institutions will have to submit strategies describing how they are managing staff in order to qualify for the funds announced by the government last month.

The money for pay increases will be allocated as a separate stream from core teaching funds. The council will allocate just over £5.5bn to English universities and colleges in 2001-02. The council is also allocating an extra £300m for capital projects over the next three years.

Hero, the new web gateway for higher education in the UK, launched yesterday. Besides links to all HE institutions, it informs on research and business - and has daily higher education news from Guardian Unlimited.

Research news

Driving force An extra £15.6m for research equipment was announced yesterday by the Higher Education Funding Council for England. The "golden triangle" of Oxbridge and London does well among the 32 awards, but relative newcomer Sunderland gets a £200,000 "holistic driver assessment facility".

Joint relief December has been dope month in the research world, with dangers and benefits of cannabis both highlighted. In New Zealand researchers found serious lung damage in 21-year-olds; in the US effects on fertility were uncovered. But at a Norfolk hospital 10 out of 13 MS sufferers reported pain relief.

Universe

Armed with knowledge The US Army said last week that the consulting company PriceWaterhouseCoopers will coordinate a $453m project to deliver distance-learning courses to soldiers all over the world through a team of 10 companies and 29 colleges. It aims to be a virtual institution for 15,000 students. Participating institutions include Florida State University, Northern Virginia Community College, Pennsylvania State University and Regents College.

Star role Having astrology in the Indian education curriculum will drive people into superstition, academic K. Saroja told a "Save Education" seminar in Dharwad, said the Times of India. Other speakers criticised the government for attacking university autonomy.

webTitle: What software to get your child for Christmas

fields.headline: Switched on
fields.standfirst: Hundreds of children will get computers for Christmas.  John Davitt suggests what to give with them
fields.trailText: Hundreds of children will get computers for Christmas. John Davitt suggests what to give with them
fields.body:
This Christmas, parents are set to spend £1bn on computers for their children. How can you make sure they enjoy it - and learn something?

One key approach to breathing life into the use of the home computer is to make children active in its use. Instead of passive screen viewing, consider an investment that will offer them the opportunity to be creative - to plan, draw, compose or perhaps even film, away from the computer, before they switch it on to take their ideas further. Here we look at the most active technology offerings.

Age 4-8

Young digital artists will enjoy the Art Attack CD gift pack for children aged five-plus at WH Smith and all big suppliers, £24.99. It comes with pencil case, paper and specialist stationery as well as the graphics software. It even features a cartoon-creator section where young children can design and make their own animations.

For young, emergent readers, Spot the dog's busy day gift pack (Europress) includes the book, a CD-Rom with four richly animated stories, a colouring book and soft toy. £24.99 for children four and over - this bundle makes a much more sensible present than a sole CD.

If you already have a computer with the newer USB connections, the ideal artistic attachment for all ages is a Wacom Digitiser tablet. This flat, A5 device comes with a stylus pen and whatever you draw or trace on it appears on screen. Better still, it comes with software known as Painter where you can draw with oils, chalks, felt-tip and several other media. Each one behaves exactly as it would on paper."It provides an authentic oil paint experience," says digital artist Fiona Hawthorne, who used the tablet and software with children as young as six this year at Fox primary school in London to make their own float designs for the Notting Hill Carnival. Expect to pay around £70 (Mac/PC) from all big suppliers for the complete system.

Age 9-12

There are two activity games that will require real thoughtful input from this age group. First comes the latest Age of Empire II The Conquerors (Microsoft, £24.99, PC). Here you build your own civilisations and plan wars and epic constructions. Now in its fifth expansion, this game provides a real sense of chronology and teaches historical terminology almost without the players realising.

Next is the Sims (Electronic Arts, £29.99), a number one worldwide bestseller where you get to build and populate your own community. It leads to great engagement and the opportunity to swap ideas and developments is provided via a website at thesims.ea.com/us/. Both these titles are available in the shops or online from www.game.uk.com .

For home reference investments look no further than the Encarta Reference Suite. Available for £24.99 in many centres, it provides a one-stop shop for homework and general knowledge questions.

Lego have made a dramatic move into the area of interactive technology with their Mindstorms range of robots. Star Wars robots can be programmed by children from nine onwards and 12-year-olds will be ready for the Robotics Invention System built around an RCX microcomputer, which resembles a large Lego brick. Building and programming their own machines is a tremendous learning experience. A digital camera (Vision Command) can also be added to give the robot "sight" and then it can be "taught" to play music. The Mindstorms range starts at £49.99 for the Star Wars druids and goes up to £149 for the Robotics Invention system. Vision command costs £74.99 (available from Toys R Us and all big suppliers).

Age 13-16

Access to sound files in MP3 file format is an important cultural badge for most teenagers, and software to convert your own CDs into MP3 files can be downloaded free from www.realplayer.com/ - choose the free player option at the bottom of the screen. The MP3 format preserves most of the sound quality of CD but makes a file of a much smaller size, so that it can be sent over computer connections to the internet. Get teenagers thinking about how they can use the format to record their own sound files and share them, with a microphone and audio conversion software from www.shoutcast.com. They can then make their own radio show and have it played live over the inter net for free at www.live365.com You just go to the site and register and they host your own radio station, where whatever sounds you send up are played and replayed for others to tune into via the web. Just the thing for Granny in Australia to tune into on Christmas day.

Serious music youths will want their own portable MP3 player, and by far the best value comes in the hybrid models that combine a standard portable CD player with the ability to read MP3 files on CD-R discs - the discs you can produce yourself if you have your own CD writer. The Goodmans CDMP 350 from CPC provides a low-cost hybrid for £69.95 - while not as svelte as the dinky players, it packs a lot more capacity and at a much cheaper storage cost.

Maybe a CD writer is the most useful upgrade you can get for a home PC as it also gives you a foolproof way of backing up important files. Subject to copyright considerations you can write a disc for a media cost of only 80 pence that can hold over 200 MP3 songs. Expect to pay around £110 for a CD-Writer, available from all big suppliers.

For those wanting to render a complete collection into MP3 and keep it portable, Creative Labs have a sophisticated solution in the form of the DAP MP3 Jukebox, a CD-sized portable player with a massive six-gigabyte hard disc capacity. You can download enough music from your computer to the player to keep you going for around 100 hours. It connects via the ubiquitous USB port. Sound quality is excellent and the DAP retails at around £379 including VAT.

For all budding film directors, the Canon MV30i digital camera (around £999) and the Apple iMac DV (£680+VAT) go together to give you a complete digital movie edit suite and powerful home computer to boot. I watched 12-year-olds make stunning movies using this set-up and it provides an ideal way to tap into the visual literacy of the whole family. The iMovie software, which comes free, allows split-second editing, special effects and voiceovers to be added with ease and the movies can be sent back to video tape for shipping or saved on the computer as digital movie clips in the QuickTime format. Have a creative Christmas!

Age 13-16 Access to sound files in MP3 file format is an important cultural badge for most teenagers, and software to convert your own CDs into MP3 files can be downloaded free from www.realplayer.com/ - choose the free player option at the bottom of the screen. The MP3 format preserves most of the sound quality of CD but makes a file of a much smaller size, so that it can be sent over computer connections to the internet. Get teenagers thinking about how they can use the format to record their own sound files and share them, with a microphone and audio conversion software from www.shoutcast.com. They can then make their own radio show and have it played live over the inter net for free at www.live365.com You just go to the site and register and they host your own radio station, where whatever sounds you send up are played and replayed for others to tune into via the web. Just the thing for Granny in Australia to tune into on Christmas day. Serious music youths will want their own portable MP3 player, and by far the best value comes in the hybrid models that combine a standard portable CD player with the ability to read MP3 files on CD-R discs - the discs you can produce yourself if you have your own CD writer. The Goodmans CDMP 350 from CPC provides a low-cost hybrid for £69.95 - while not as svelte as the dinky players, it packs a lot more capacity and at a much cheaper storage cost. Maybe a CD writer is the most useful upgrade you can get for a home PC as it also gives you a foolproof way of backing up important files. Subject to copyright considerations you can write a disc for a media cost of only 80 pence that can hold over 200 MP3 songs. Expect to pay around £110 for a CD-Writer, available from all big suppliers. For those wanting to render a complete collection into MP3 and keep it portable, Creative Labs have a sophisticated solution in the form of the DAP MP3 Jukebox, a CD-sized portable player with a massive six-gigabyte hard disc capacity. You can download enough music from your computer to the player to keep you going for around 100 hours. It connects via the ubiquitous USB port. Sound quality is excellent and the DAP retails at around £379 including VAT. For all budding film directors, the Canon MV30i digital camera (around £999) and the Apple iMac DV (£680+VAT) go together to give you a complete digital movie edit suite and powerful home computer to boot. I watched 12-year-olds make stunning movies using this set-up and it provides an ideal way to tap into the visual literacy of the whole family. The iMovie software, which comes free, allows split-second editing, special effects and voiceovers to be added with ease and the movies can be sent back to video tape for shipping or saved on the computer as digital movie clips in the QuickTime format. Have a creative Christmas!

webTitle: Watching your child's nativity play - again

fields.headline: Play it again, Robbie
fields.standfirst: John Crace sees his children's nativity (one more time) and finds it moves him to tears, of the wrong kind
fields.trailText: John Crace sees his children's nativity (one more time) and finds it moves him to tears, of the wrong kind
fields.body:
"No way am I dressing up as a star," said Robbie, my five-year-old son. "It's girlie."

We were running through the list of possible characters for the school nativity play that he had been sent home with, and we were one down already. Which left either the first world war soldier - it was clearly to be a pioneering, post-modern production - or Joseph. He was dead set on the soldier as it gave him carte blanche to take a gun into school. My wife and I weren't so keen. Not because we're peaceniks, but because it was so clearly going to be a hassle trying to knock up a soldier costume. Joseph was easy. He's a sheet.

"I think you should be Joseph," I said.

"Why?"

"Because he's a central character in the nativity play."

Which is true, though not as it happened in this nativity play, where Robbie would be destined to be just one of 27 Josephs.

"OK, then," he muttered.

So last week we wrapped him up in a sheet and packed him off to school - without the hastily improvised halo that had been attached to his sister's hairband and had been predictably rejected for being cissy. Two hours later, my wife and I trooped into the school hall to witness the miracle of the nativity. There was no danger of Jesus's birth going unrecorded here, as almost every member of the audience was wielding a video recorder or a digicam. Except us, which was perhaps just as well, as Robbie thought it was hysterically amusing to spend virtually the entire performance hiding behind a few other Josephs and assorted livestock. Just occasionally he bobbed into view, only to disappear grinning inanely as soon as he had caught our eye.

But then maybe Robbie had a point. This nativity play felt as if it was being acted out in real time, as the school was anxious to give every class its moment in the spotlight, and in the hour or so it took for the Good News to be well and truly spread, I'm sure I was not the only member of the audience on the brink of coma.

Forgive me for sounding jaded. I know you're supposed to fill with tears at the very thought of the little treasures giving it their all for Jesus, and to be fair that's the way I felt for the first couple of nativity plays that I went to. But my daughter, Anna, is now nearly nine and with Robbie having already appeared in a couple of shows at nursery, I'm almost into double figures. You name it, I've seen it. Traditional, multicultural and just plain bizarre: they're all as dreary as each other.

It would be different, I suspect, if my children had ever been asked to play a starring role in proceedings. Or a co-starring role. Or a supporting role. Anything other than a walk-on part as an extra, in fact. The catalogue of obscurity began when Anna was at nursery school.

"Who are you going to be, darling?" I asked eagerly.

"I'm the third narrator," she replied proudly. "It's very important."

May her teacher rot in hell for that lie.

"Of course it is. Well done," I added doubtfully.

Come the big day, we sat dutifully while the chosen few recited most of the New Testament, waiting for Anna's big moment. Eventually she wandered on from stage left. "Lo, a star appeared," she annunciated, before herself disappearing stage right. And that was that. It was almost the same story the following year: she had graduated to second angel but it was still a case of blink and you've missed it. It's been much the same ever since and, as Robbie appears to have inherited a similar theatrical insignificance - his first role was as fourth donkey - it's hard not to take it personally.

You see, over the years I've noticed that it's pretty much the same group of people who get the leading roles every year. They're bright, socially accomplished, squeaky clean. And, in my opinion, hideously precocious. It's as if they've been born with a social identifier that marks them out as future prefects and general all-round high-fliers, to which their teachers unconsciously defer. That Anna and Robbie have been mysteriously omitted from this elite I find bewildering. What's more, whenever I see the überkinder poncing around on stage, I start wishing teenage pregnancies and drug addiction on them.

In their more honest moments, other parents have told me they feel exactly the same way. So far from being a bonding, uplifting experience, the nativity play is quite likely to be one of the most divisive events on the school calendar. Still, it's not all bad news. A friend was telling me that the parents at her child's school were in uproar because the school had banned videocams so that they could charge parents £14.99 for their own recording. Quite right. Make the three sets of parents who want the thing pay for it.
