webTitle: Thousands of lecturers have not had the national pay rise

fields.headline: Prime suspects
fields.standfirst: Thousands of lecturers have not had the national pay rise, says  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: Thousands of lecturers have not had the national pay rise, says Peter Kingston
fields.body:
The lecturers' union Natfhe announced yesterday that nearly a half of colleges have failed to honour this year's nationally agreed 3.3% salary rise, four months after it should have been paid. It demanded that colleges should now pay up or open their finances to public scrutiny.

Employers dispute Natfhe's figures as out of date, and say 70% of colleges have now paid the national figure, which was due to apply from August 1. The rest are waiting for a clearer picture on how many students they have recruited this year.

Meanwhile Malcolm Wicks, the lifelong learning minister, has warned colleges that he is seriously concerned that many lecturers are still waiting to receive the inflation-linked increases. He said he failed to understand this after the government had put "record levels of investment" into further education.

The non-payers include Warrington Collegiate Institution, whose chair of governors, Colin Daniels, also chaired the employers' committee which agreed the national increase.

A separate survey of principals' pay commissioned by the Association of Colleges (AoC) shows that their average salary increase this year is 3.47%, which has been paid to them. The survey shows that the median principals' basic salary is £64,150. According to Natfhe, only 55% of colleges have paid the rise, four months after the settlement date.

Its general secretary Paul Mackney said there were only three possible explanations. Non-paying colleges might have genuine financial problems. Otherwise their managements were either wilfully refusing to honour the agreement or incompetent.

He said that where colleges could show government underfunding to be the cause, Natfhe would make special joint representation to ministers for extra funds to pay the award. He called on colleges to pay up by January 14, adding: "We are tired of the humbug. Too many colleges are still treating their staff with contempt. Even on the AoC's figures, it's outrageous that 30% of colleges have not paid increases four months after they should have. If non-payers refuse to open their books we will be calling for a full investigation into their handling of public money, by the National Audit Office if necessary."

Sue Dutton, the AoC's deputy chief executive, said the union's figures were out of date: "Our survey has just been carried out. So far 70% of colleges have paid the 3.3% and 10% of these have paid more. All of the remaining colleges are still to have their meetings to determine pay awards because they are waiting for the results of their enrolments this year. Obviously governing bodies have got to be quite cautious."

Malcolm Wicks made plain his disquiet about non-paying colleges when he met the national joint forum led by Natfhe and the AoC.

"We have given extra money and made record levels of investment recently in further education," he said after the meeting. Colleges ought to be able to pay staff proper inflationary increases, he added: "When I hear that some colleges have not felt able to do that, I am troubled."

Colin Daniels admitted that Warrington Collegiate Institute had not yet honoured the 3.3% and would be taking a decision on it in February on the basis of clearer enrolment figures. Enrolments are up and the college is classed as in good financial health by the Further Education Funding Council. "The management are simply being prudent," he said. "I've no doubt that a pay award will be backdated to August."

The AoC annual report on principals' pay surveyed about a quarter of colleges. A small cluster of the highest earners fall in the £85-£90,000 bracket. These highest salaries are earned by principals who have been in post for 10 years or more and are running the biggest colleges, a spokesperson said.

Basic pay of principals in further education colleges

Number of posts 96

10% earn less than £53,575

25% earn less than £58,880

Median basic salary £64,150

25% earn more than £69,610

10% earn more than £75,152

Peripheral benefits at median £1,782

Posts at less than £50,000 4

Posts at more than £100,000 0

Median size of colleges £8.2m

Increase in median 3.47%

Median size of college last year £8.2m

Source: Association of Colleges

webTitle: Freeserve insists Christmas will narrow losses

fields.headline: Freeserve insists Christmas will narrow losses
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Freeserve announced widening losses yesterday but predicted that it would sign off in style as an independent company thanks to buoyant Christmas PC sales.
fields.body:
Freeserve announced widening losses yesterday but predicted that it would sign off in style as an independent company thanks to buoyant Christmas PC sales.

The UK's largest internet service provider, which yesterday sent shareholders details of its £1.6bn all-share takeover offer from French rival Wanadoo, said its quarterly losses had increased from £13.4m to £18.4m in the three months to November 11.

Revenues for the reporting period - which was four weeks shorter than the previous period to allow the company to update shareholders on trading conditions prior to the impending takeover - grew from £14.6m to £15.5m.

Finance director Nick Backhouse said the losses were exaggerated by a £9.4m write-off Freeserve was forced to take on some of its internet-related investments. The sale of its stake in online retailer Streets Online to Kingfisher was particularly painful, costing the company £2m.

Without the write-off, Freeserve would have been £6m in the red.

"The operating loss was significantly below analysts' expectations, and we are well set on our path to profitability," Mr Backhouse said.

Concerns that Freeserve may be hit by the downturn in online advertising were quelled by a 51% rise in weekly advertising and e-commerce revenues. Around 40,000 people are signing up to Freeserve every week and fewer customers are leaving for rival internet providers, Mr Backhouse added.

Freeserve hopes that Christmas PC sales will cheer up its next set of results. This year's festive season is likely to see record sales of PCs, net enabled televisions and web enabled handheld devices, and Freeserve believes that as the market leader it is well positioned to win the custom of first-time internet users.

Extra capacity has been booked with telecoms partner Energis in anticipation of a surge in demand. Last year usage time quadrupled during the Christmas period.

A £12.99 per month unmetered internet access package will go on sale next month, competing with similar offerings from BT and AOL.

Freeserve's position, once it has merged with cash-rich Wanadoo, is in stark contrast to the fortunes of rival ISP Breathe.com, which collapsed last week with debts of £50m. Freeserve is thought to have spoken to Breathe's administrators at Pricewaterhouse-Coopers and is running the rule over Breathe's technology.

Several overseas ISPs such T-Online, Terra-Lycos and Tiscali which are seeking to build a presence in the UK are thought to have been contacted by PwC. They are also understood to be interested in LineOne, the ISP being auctioned by BT and United News & Media.

Wanadoo said yesterday it would pay €360m for Spain's second-largest telephone directory publisher, Indice Multimedia, in a move that will increase its subscriber base and increase directories revenue.

webTitle: Business: Market forces

fields.headline: Glimmer of a 'Santa rally'
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: A bit of Christmas cheer swept across the City yesterday.
fields.body:
A bit of Christmas cheer swept across the City yesterday.

With dealers encouraged by hopes on Wall Street that the Federal Reserve chairman might be minded to cut American interest rates sooner rather than later, the FTSE 100 managed a 70.7-point rally to 6246.5.

As the heavyweight banking and telecoms sectors led the way, there was even talk of a so-called "Santa rally" - a reaction to the squeeze on share prices often seen towards the end of the year when dealing conditions are thin.

For most market participants, the past year has been so painful no one dare forecast such a move until yesterday.

But the real moving influence came from New York. The US president-elect met Alan Greenspan and the Dow Jones Industrial Average leapt more than 200 points (2%) during London trading time.

In the banking sector, still gripped by bid speculation, Barclays climbed 68p to £20.93, while HSBC added 34p to 972p and Royal Bank of Scotland put on 44p to £15.38. Trading among those directly involved in the phoney bid war was relatively quiet, with Abbey National easing 4p to £11.71 as potential hostile suitor Lloyds TSB clawed back 15p to 715p. But Bank of Scotland, which would like to merge with Abbey, surged 37p to 744p.

Vodafone led the way in the telecoms sector, with a 4p move to 257p adding the equivalent of 10 Footsie points, while Colt Telecom, which is rolling out high-quality networks across the world's leading financial centres, did better in percentage terms, the shares adding 64p to £15.50.

The bargain hunters were out in force in the wider tech sector, chasing the likes of CMG, the IT services group, which was up 55p to 900p. Similarly, Misys, which specialises in financial software, added 37p to 673p.

Bookham Technology stood out, running 106p higher to £11.66 after news that one of its main products is being integrated into optical systems being produced by America's Lucent Technologies. But not all tech-related issues were in vogue.

Intelligent software group Autonomy dropped from £26 to £24.30 on its Footsie debut, while online auctioneer QXL, which was trading at 800p at the height of the internet madness, dipped another 2.5p to 10p. If it drops another 2p, the company will be a member of the "99% club".

In the drugs sector, the "high" over Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham getting the final regulatory nod to merge was short-lived. Deutsche Bank stepped in with a downgrade of the proforma GlaxoSmithKline from "buy" to "market perform" - which means the investment bank reckons the price is simply going sideways.

So, in their current form, shares in Glaxo shed 51p to £18.92 and SmithKline dropped 21p to 857p. The new-form stock commences trad ing on the day after Boxing Day.

Elsewhere, Bass fell 23.5p to 701.5p as the stock moved ex-dividend and sentiment was soured by weekend reports that that the refocused hotels group might have to cut the £750m asking price for the 900-strong chain of pubs it has up for sale.

Nomura's private finance arm run by financier Guy Hands and Legal & General Ventures are believed to be the two remaining bidders for the business.

TBI, the airports group, slumped 10p to 61.5p after news that potential takeover talks had come an end, "despite lengthy discussions". It first revealed it had had an approach in early August, taking the shares above 100p at one stage.

TeleCity, the so-called "internet hotel", handling facilities management and the like, added 10p to 590p.

After a spectacular flotation by Goldman Sachs in June, which took the price to a high of £23.45, the stock slumped recently when its maiden set of figures disappointed. Yesterday, a few whispers suggested trading might have enjoyed a sudden and unexpected recovery.

Deutsche Bank stepped in with a downgrade of the proforma GlaxoSmithKline from "buy" to "market perform" - which means the investment bank reckons the price is simply going sideways. Yesterday, a few whispers suggested trading might have enjoyed a sudden and unexpected recovery.

webTitle: Pearson puts more into the net

fields.headline: Pearson puts more into the net
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Pearson, publisher of the Financial Times, yesterday gave the internet an increasingly rare vote of confidence when it said its online ventures would hit profitability sooner than expected.
fields.body:
Pearson, publisher of the Financial Times, yesterday gave the internet an increasingly rare vote of confidence when it said its online ventures would hit profitability sooner than expected.

In a trading statement, the group said it has accelerated investment in online businesses including FT.com and now expects a "faster path to profitability". Shares in the company initially flew on the back of the statement before settling 60p lower at £16.22.

The number of individual users of FT.com had swollen from 1.1m in July to 1.7m by November, Pearson said. It was now expected to reach break even in 2002, some two years ahead of forecast. The company admitted that the number of users dipped in the summer after hitting 1.2m in January.

Pearson is developing additional premium online and wireless services for FT.com. It says revenues for the website are running at £20m a year.

Under chief executive Marjorie Scardino, Pearson had been in the vanguard of traditional media companies which announced plans to throw money at the internet at the start of the year.

It said yesterday that costs would peak in the second half of this financial year and then fall away significantly in 2001. It is expected to invest between £180m-£200m this year and around £130m next year.

The company also said its US schools business was performing well, offsetting slower growth in the professional publishing markets.

Pearson underscored its presence in online education this year with the £1.7bn pur chase in August of National Computer Systems of America and payment of £85m in June for control of Family Education Network.

The online Learning Network, aimed at the kindergarten to grade 12 market in the US, was attracting up to 100m monthly page views.

Pearson also defied the gloom with upbeat comments about the Financial Times newspaper. Recent cautioun from Dow Jones, owner of the Wall Street Journal, had raised concerns that the advertising market might be softening.

The FT had enjoyed "vigorous advertising revenue growth" throughout the year and an 11% increase in circulation worldwide to 483,000. The group is developing the FT as a global brand to meet the Wall Street Journal head-on and said its latest launch, FT Deutschland, was beating expectations.

Pearson also said its business newspapers in France and Spain, Les Echos and Expansion, had avoided any slowdown in advertising.

 Dutch publisher VNU yesterday agreed a $2.3bn deal to buy AC Nielsen, the US marketing information company, and is expected to sell its consumer and educational units to refocus on business-to-business information.

"The purchase hits the bull's eye. We become the world leader in marketing information with a 19% share," said Frans Cremers, the chief financial officer.

webTitle: Business: Time Warner hit by media malaise

fields.headline: Time Warner hit by media malaise
fields.trailText: Time Warner become the latest media group to disappoint investors yesterday when it warned that this year's profits would be worse than expected because of declining advertising revenues and weaker sales of music and film.
fields.body:
Time Warner become the latest media group to disappoint investors yesterday when it warned that this year's profits would be worse than expected because of declining advertising revenues and weaker sales of music and film.

Shares in the company, which is expected to close its merger with America Online early in the new year, were down 12% at lunchtime as traders expressed their disappointment. Earlier this month, senior executives at Time Warner and AOL suggested that the company had largely escaped the downturn in the US advertising market.

Jessica Reif Cohen, analyst at Merrill Lynch, was one of many to warn they would be revising profits estimates based on the new guidance. "I think everyone was surprised by it," she said yesterday.

The company's statement blamed the disappointing box office performance of Little Nicky, the latest film starring Adam Sandler, for some of its pre-Christmas malaise, as well as lower-than-expected cable advertising revenue and music sales.

The disappointing December quarter is expected to cut one or two percentage points from an expected earnings increase of 12% to 13% this year.

Time Warner also announced the restructuring of its Road Runner broadband subsidiary yesterday. As part of the deal, Time Warner is to pay Compaq and Microsoft, the computer groups which own a combined 20% of Road Runner, $570m in cash for their stake.

The media company was forced to restructure Road Runner, which offers high-speed internet access over cable lines, as a result of two separate agreements reached with anti-trust regulators at the department of justice.

webTitle: Business: At this price? Blue Circle

fields.headline: At this price?  Blue Circle
fields.trailText: Blue Circle Industries is keen to show that it is more than living up to the promises the cement group made when it saw off a hostile £3.65bn bid from French rival Lafarge this year.
fields.body:
Blue Circle Industries is keen to show that it is more than living up to the promises the cement group made when it saw off a hostile £3.65bn bid from French rival Lafarge this year.

The group's trading statement yesterday, two months ahead of full-year results, said operational savings would be way ahead of the £29m target. The extra saving would more than offset the £9m increase in energy costs stemming from the rise in the oil price.

Operating profits from Malayan Cement and from the Philippines were expected to achieve the target of £45m before goodwill amortisation.

The group, which has spent £400m on a share buyback, yesterday confirmed that it is on course to return a further £400m to shareholders through a special dividend.

All of which is good news for Lafarge. The French group and its financial advisers still own a third of Blue Circle and have not relinquished hopes of obtaining full control.

Lafarge's presence on the share register is a constant encouragement to Blue Circle's management to wring the best out of the business.

It might also encourage directors to go on the takeover trail themselves in an attempt to become too large even for Lafarge's pockets. It is looking at possible purchases in Asia and Latin America, but not before the second half of 2001.

There are limits to the extent Blue Circle can boost its bottom line through operational efficiencies. Its results are influenced by events outside its control, such as the vagaries of the construction market and the oil price.

Looking to next year, the group is expecting higher prices and higher demand in Britain and Greece. It is anticipating increased demand in Chile and a modest increase in the United States.

A decision by Lafarge to make a renewed assault or sell its stake could boost or weaken Blue Circle's share price. The shares, up 7p to 461.5p yesterday, look fully priced and a bit of a gamble.

webTitle: Business: Galen's rude health

fields.headline: Galen's rude health
fields.trailText: Northern Ireland's richest business duo, Allen McClay and John King of health care firm Galen Holdings, can afford to dine out in greater style than usual after making £13.1m apiece by selling 1.5m shares each.
fields.body:
Northern Ireland's richest business duo, Allen McClay and John King of health care firm Galen Holdings, can afford to dine out in greater style than usual after making £13.1m apiece by selling 1.5m shares each.

They said they were releasing stock to satisfy a surge in demand from tracker funds following Galen's re-entry to the FTSE-250 index.

Galen recently became the province's first £1bn company on the back of excitement over its new intra-vaginal rings: these could be a convenient way for women to take hormone therapy and contraceptives.

Mr McClay still has a 23% stake worth £330m; Mr King has 12% worth £170m.

Yesterday's placing was at 875p, a shade below the market price, which slipped 17.5p to 852.5p.

Mr King said he would not be splashing out: "The money will go in the bank, as far as I'm concerned."

webTitle: Business: Struggling Post Office loses £80m

fields.headline: Struggling Post Office loses £80m
fields.standfirst: Rail chaos will take further bite, admits chairman
fields.trailText: The Post Office yesterday blamed increased competition in the industry and unexpectedly high costs for an £80m first half loss and warned of tougher times to come.
fields.body:
The Post Office yesterday blamed increased competition in the industry and unexpectedly high costs for an £80m first half loss and warned of tougher times to come.

The organisation - which is struggling to get the government's universal bank plan off the ground - said figures for the second half of the year would be hit by additional costs arising from the disruption to rail services.

The rail problems are costing the Post Office an extra £500,000 a week.

It has been forced to increase mail flights from 40 to 67 a day and put an extra 2,000 vehicles on the road. Neville Bain, the chairman of the organisation, said the rail delays - which affected about 25% of mail - were predicted to last for another three months.

He said it seemed inevitable that the Post Office would have to wait until the next financial year before it could recoup the additional costs.

Mr Bain said he was still confident the Post Office would end the year in profit. But he warned: "There will certainly be no speedy return to the unsustainable profits made in the 1990s, when our ability to invest was restricted and the business was heavily driven by the need to meet huge Treasury cash targets.

"The Post Office is going to have to work much harder for every pound of profit we make in the future."

He said that while domestic mail volumes were still growing, nobody was certain of the impact of the growth of the internet, email and mobile telephones. "We have to accept that mail volumes may one day start to decline," he said.

At the operating level, the Post Office made a £33m first half loss, against a £157m profit for the same period last year. Last year's results were also adversely affected by an exceptional charge of £571m relating to the £1bn Horizon project to computerise the Post Office's network.

So far the Post Office has connected 15,000 post offices to its computer network which is the key to providing services to offset the £400m revenue which the corporation and sub post masters will lose when the government starts making benefit payments directly into bank accounts from 2003.

The Post Office is hoping to use the network for its universal bank, which will provide basic banking facilities for the financially excluded.

However, the banks have been refusing to back the project, claiming that they should not have to finance one of the government's social goals.

A last ditch meeting on the issue is due to take place tomorrow between Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, and the bank bosses.

webTitle: Goulden quits amid Georgica warning

fields.headline: Goulden quits amid Georgica warning
fields.trailText: Allied Leisure's chief executive, Neil Goulden, has quit just ten weeks after the company was taken over for £50m by cash shell Georgica.
fields.body:
Allied Leisure's chief executive, Neil Goulden, has quit just ten weeks after the company was taken over for £50m by cash shell Georgica.

His departure was announced alongside a warning from Georgica that Allied Leisure's performance was not up to scratch. Georgica's shares slumped 9.5p to a low of 80p.

Allied operates Burger King restaurants, snooker clubs and has a chain of bowling allies under a 50-50 joint venture called Megabowl with venture capital firm Duke Street.

Attendances at the firm's ten-pin bowling alleys were said to have been hit by heavy rain. Mr Goulden gets a pay-off of more than £600,000, because he found it difficult to "play a subsidiary role" below Georgica chairman Nick Oppenheim.

Mr Oppenheim said he knew from the start that the market was over-optimistic about Allied Leisure's performance: "Allied has a reputation for missing forecasts."

Georgica wants to change the ownership structure of the firm's bowling allies, either by buying out Duke Street or by exiting the joint venture.

Mr Oppenheim made his name by building nightclub firm Northern Leisure, which merged in a £585m deal with Luminar to create the country's biggest disco group during the summer.

He engineered Georgica's takeover of Allied by approaching the company's shareholders behind the backs of management. This infuriated Allied's chairman Ken Scobie, who said it had thrown the City's takeover rules into "disrepute".

webTitle: Business: Orphan assets plan defended

fields.headline: Orphan assets plan defended
fields.standfirst: Axa denies policyholders short-changed
fields.trailText: Insurance company Axa yesterday invoked the spectre of the Equitable Life crisis as it defended its decision to hand over only a small chunk of its £1.7bn surplus cash pile to its policyholders.
fields.body:
Insurance company Axa yesterday invoked the spectre of the Equitable Life crisis as it defended its decision to hand over only a small chunk of its £1.7bn surplus cash pile to its policyholders.

Axa went to the high court to seek approval for its plans to distribute part of its "orphan assets" - money which has been built up over decades from surpluses and unclaimed policy proceeds.

It is being challenged by a 1,800-strong group of unhappy customers, backed by the Consumers' Association, who claim policyholders are being short-changed and are entitled to a larger slice.

The French insurer is handing its 660,000 policyholders £225m of the total orphan assets money, which they will receive in the form of bonuses that will be added to their policies. It also plans to use £300m of shareholders' funds to give policyholders a cash payment averaging £400 in return for surrendering any future claims to the orphan assets - also known as "inherited estate".

The disgruntled policyholders, led by London chartered accountant Stuart MacWhirter, believe they are entitled to a greater share of the money but Axa argues that it would be imprudent to hand any more of the surplus cash out because this would weaken the strength of the with-profits fund.

The company's barrister, David Richards QC, told the court yesterday that among other things, the surplus cash allows it to meet "unexpected claims," something that he said had become very topical in the light of Equitable's problems.

Earlier this month Equitable warned 1m existing with-profits policyholders that they can expect lower investment returns in future so that it can meet the cost of promises made to some of its pension customers in past decades.

Because it had not set aside enough of the investment profits during good years to protect itself from problems, there was limited surplus cash to draw upon when the House of Lords ruled in July that Equitable must meet the promises, at a cost of at least £1.5bn.

By contrast, said Mr Richards, Axa had been able to meet the costs of similar pension promises it had made because these could be "absorbed" into the inherited estate "without any damage to the interests of the with-profits policyholders". Mr Richards added: "That is not a position that is the same for all life offices, as recent events demonstrate."

Axa also argued that policyholders had no legitimate claim on the £1.7bn, pointing out that the surpluses were built up 30 or 40 years ago. Axa's view was that "the current generation of policyholders have not contributed to the inherited estate," said Mr Richards. The proposed distribution was "fair", he said, adding: "It does not involve any adverse consequences for any policyholder."

The Consumers' Association has claimed that, under Axa's plans, policyholders would be getting £525m, or 31%, of the orphan assets but shareholders would receive as much as 19% or £319m. The evidence of Mr MacWhirter and the Consumers' Association, is to be heard today or tomorrow.If Axa's distribution is approved, policyholders will receive the cash payments by February.

webTitle: Business: TV dinner chefs cook up buyout

fields.headline: TV dinner chefs cook up buyout
fields.trailText: The manufacturer of some of Britain's most popular TV dinners is joining the food industry's dash to go private by agreeing a £185m management buyout.
fields.body:
The manufacturer of some of Britain's most popular TV dinners is joining the food industry's dash to go private by agreeing a £185m management buyout.

Peterborough-based Perkins Foods cooks up own-label dishes for supermarkets including Asda Wal-Mart, Sainsbury and Tesco. The range includes lasagnes, pizzas, meat pies and cheese and onion slices.

Directors have secured backing from ABN Amro Capital for the 124p per share buyout, which is led by chief executive Ian Blackburn.

He said yesterday that the company has felt neglected by the City.

"It's been somewhat frustrating. Even if food companies are performing well and growing their business, they don't seem to be able to get a sensible stockmarket rating."

Perkins' shares touched 140p earlier this year but have since drifted downwards despite a 13% increase in half-year prof its to £9m. An Irish company, Greencore discussed making a 150p-a-share offer in January but the negotiations came to nothing.

A number of small food manufacturers have sought an exit from the stock market this year.

Norfolk turkey magnate Bernard Matthews recently agreed a buyout, tea grower and importer James Finlay was bought by the Swire Group and Sims Food was swallowed by rival Global Group.

Manufacturers have been squeezed by increasingly frantic competition among supermarkets, which have been demanding lower prices from their suppliers.

Perkins hopes that going private will allow it to borrow more money without complaints from shareholders, allowing it to expand in Europe through acquisitions.

Michael Landymore, analyst at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite, said smaller food companies remained firmly out of favour in the City.

webTitle: Chrysler woe deepens as profits slump to 500m euros

fields.headline: Chrysler woe deepens as profits slump to 500m euros
fields.trailText: Jürgen Schrempp, DaimlerChrysler's chief executive, warned shareholders yesterday that losses in America would continue well into next year.
fields.body:
Jürgen Schrempp, DaimlerChrysler's chief executive, warned shareholders yesterday that losses in America would continue well into next year. He said, in a letter, that Chrysler, the US carmaker, would end the year with an operating profit of just €500m, down from €5.1bn the previous year.

Analysts said that this meant that Chrysler was on course to incur a fourth quarter operating loss of about €1.4bn.

Mr Schrempp, who has been criticised for his handling of Chrysler, following its 1998 merger with Daimler-Benz, held out little hope of any immediate recovery at the American end of the business.

He said: "In 2001, we believe that the competitive market environment will continue to intensify and that our underlying financial performance, particularly in the US, will reflect this. We will face a year even more challenging than 2000."

Chrysler has been hit by price cuts in the face of intensive competition in the US market and by the cost of launching new models, including the PT Cruiser, the Dodge Stratus and a new minivan.

Mr Schrempp said Chrysler had been hurt by "the unusually fierce nature of the competition that has occurred in the historically profitable niches in which it has operated - the minivan, the sports utility and the pick-up truck."

He defended the merger, saying that while Chrysler was going through a "challenging period", the merger would result in global growth opportunities and economies of scale.

Analysts criticised the lack of detail about the situation at Chrysler, which will result in an unquantified one-off restructuring charge in the full-year results. "It is hard to tell what they are including in the figures," said Thomas Aney, an analyst with Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.

Mr Schrempp has been attacked by US shareholders for replacing American executives at Chrysler with Germans. The Tracinda Corporation is taking legal action against the company. It is claiming that the merger was not one of equals but a takeover by Daimler. It is seeking payment for loss of a merger premium.

 The European unit of Ford denied that it was planning to cut jobs by about 10%. "There are no plans to cut the workforce, but we do aim to reduce costs by 10%," said a spokesman for Ford Europe.

webTitle: X-Box makes late play for global games market

fields.headline: X-Box makes late play for global games market
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: While Sony launched PlayStation 2 with great fanfare this year, and games rival Nintendo is to release its GameCube next year, Microsoft has been quietly developing its XBox games unit.
fields.body:
In the battle for consumers' wallets, one lucrative patch has been ceded by Microsoft to the competition - the billion-dollar games market.

While Sony launched PlayStation 2 with great fanfare this year - to the frustration of consumers still trying to buy it - and games rival Nintendo is to release its GameCube next year, Microsoft has been quietly developing its XBox games unit.

At stake is a $17bn global "opportunity" - one many feel Microsoft has neglected. "We're getting drawn into these debates with a product that is 12 months away. It's a long way away," says Neil Holloway, managing director of Microsoft UK and Ireland. The X-Box is expected to sell for $299 (£204) and be on the market in north America and Japan first. But what will the XBox offer to challenge Dreamcast and PS2?

"We've managed to improve the performance dramatically with regard to the quality of graphics on the device," he says. But along with DVD, which PS2 includes, the X-Box will offer internet access.

Bill Gates told reporters earlier this year that it would be "the first game console that really takes it into what's going on on the internet, the realism that we can provide, the multi-player gaming, the fact that we've got a disk so you can download game updates."

The Xbox is part of a wider issue about connectivity. Microsoft - which formerly appeared to be aiming to dominate the world, now appears to want to wire it up instead.

"At the consumer end it is clear the home is going to become connected at some point at different stages across the globe. If you go up five, 10 years, there will be homes which are very digitally connected, so you will have a digital TV, digital music box, digital games devices and PCs and those will be connected in a world where the best of these devices are shared."

The games console, Mr Holloway says, will evolve to become a vital component of connected homes.

Sony seems to agree. PS2 will play DVDs and audio CDs. The Japanese company is also set to produce kit that will enable PS2 to connect to a cable modem.

Sony say it will be a "platform for net-based electronic distribution of digital content in 2001", beginning with downloading games via broadband, but ultimately including video on demand.

webTitle: Microsoft co-founders at loggerheads

fields.headline: Samurai versus nerd
fields.standfirst:
Few people will have been more delighted by Microsoft's recent difficulties than Oracle boss Larry Ellison

Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: Few people will have been more delighted by Microsoft's recent difficulties than Oracle boss Larry Ellison
fields.body:
For a brief moment in April, Mr Ellison eclipsed his nemesis, Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates, as the world's richest man. The two have remained neck and neck on wealth terms since, but last week's profits warning from Microsoft catapulted Silicon Valley's self-styled samurai warrior back to the top of the tree by some way.

By mid-afternoon yesterday Mr Ellison's shares in the database software firm were worth $69bn. Mr Gates' Microsoft stake was a relatively miserly $35.7bn, largely due to his selling of stock to fund his philanthropic activities.

The two software tycoons have been at loggerheads, largely at 55-year-old Mr Ellison's instigation, for as long as anyone can remember. They could hardly be more different.

Mr Gates is a geek who likes golf and bridge, and wears sensible sweaters. Mr Ellison flies Russian MiG-29 fighter jets over San Jose, chases women and wears black turtleneck sweaters.

The two share a passion - sailing - but while Mr Gates might take his family for a gentle run around the waters in front of his lakeside home, Mr Ellison prefers crashing through 20ft waves on his super-fast yacht Sayonara.

Associates say the Oracle founder talks about competitors in violent metaphors. The target of his ire is often Mr Gates, largely because his focus is on the "ridiculous device" of the PC rather than the big databases which Oracle believes are far more important.

The relationship hit rock bottom in June when Oracle admitted that it hired private detectives to dig up scandalous information on Microsoft.

webTitle: Populist Hague and his circle keep shadow cabinet in dark

fields.headline: Populist Hague and his circle keep shadow cabinet in dark
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague is not a man to lose much sleep or change his mind.
fields.body:
William Hague is not a man to lose much sleep or change his mind. That much was as evident in yesterday's reaction to protests from Damilola Taylor's parents as it was in last summer's Channel 4 portrait of his happy South Yorkshire childhood.

The youngest member of a close middle class family - the one they nicknamed Tory boy - had to fight his corner against three big sisters at home, and the Labour culture all around him in Rotherham.

It is that resilient sense of certainty that has taken him near to the top of British politics, and may ensure that he goes no further than leader of Her Majesty's loyal opposition.

The question intriguing MPs is "why does William keep going?" Denis Healey's first law of political holes was "when in hole, stop digging". But his fellow Yorkshireman digs on as if he were a frantic face worker in a now-closed Yorkshire pit.

The short answer is that Mr Hague is a surprisingly self-sufficient leader. He does not rely on his shadow cabinet colleagues as previous leaders, John Major or Ted Heath (not Margaret Thatcher), did for collective comfort and advice.

"The shadow cabinet's out on a limb, it doesn't know what's going on," one dissident Tory MP said last night. It is not the first time Mr Hague has left the colleagues in the dark. In public most remain loyal but there is a price: they mutter in Westminster's corners.

"Bad advice," snapped one discarded Hagueite MP as the backlash developed. By that he meant that the leader is surrounded by a small coterie and that they are, mostly, inexperienced and lightweight.

Ex-MP Sebastian Coe, now Lord Seb and the leader's judo partner, usually gets stick. Four years older than Hague he is no threat, the man the leader trusts, can confide in. But Coe was never a policy wonk.

Danny Finkelstein, ex-SDP, is head of policy, while George Osborn writes the leader's speeches. Both have winnable seats to win (Osborn's is Tatton), neither gets put in the frame by bitching colleagues.

More often the whisperers direct their venom at Amanda Platell, ex-Fleet Street editor now director of communications, a woman paid a lot to know what policy lines will work with tabloid readers.

Ms Platell bought the diamond Save the Pound pendant for Ffion Hague (who gets a lot more admiration than flak), an eye-catching present, supposedly from William.

But Ms Platell, not a policy buff either, is not alone in the dock. Her deputy, Nick Wood, ex-Times and Daily Express journalist - central casting's idea of a hard-living Fleet Street face - is credited with a lot of influence over her and the leader.

Hague has the Oxford first and the McKinsey management consultancy on his CV, but Woodsy is the one who knows what will play in the papers and on the Today programme.

Legend has it that he was the only political journalist to belong to the hard right No Turning Back group in the Thatcher era. He may not do judo, but he is a different kind of tough guy.

Michael Portillo has an uneasy relationship with the man many think he will one day replace as Tory leader. Both need each other and know it. But they are not soul mates. The shadow chancellor gets on better with his predeccessor, now shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude. Both feel untrusted and excluded, some MPs say. Maude has been loyal to a fault since Hague's initial claim that the Macpherson report's "politically correct" obsessions have destroyed police morale in London and unleashed a tide of street crime.

Portillo has been more muted, reportedly dismayed by the speech's tone, though he denied it in a carefully drafted statement. Ann Widdecombe has fought the Hagueite fight. It is her kind of issue.

But the wider impression has been one of unease on the Tory benches at the leader's lapse back into the law and order populism that gave him a brief lift last spring and - courtesy of the fuel protesters - in September.

It was embodied by John Redwood's wriggling on Radio 4"s Any Questions. But where has the genial and toffish party chairman, Michael Ancram, been while the predictable likes of Steve Norris and Sir Edward Heath have used their media savvy to snipe at Hague?

MPs believe his colleagues are quietly swimming towards the shore as the SS Hague steams towards the iceberg. Mr Hague thinks he is articulating the fears of ordinary people, black as well as white. Ministers say he is grotesquely wrong, but sound jittery. If he is right he will be even more his own man.

webTitle: 2,500 jobs to flow from North Sea boost

fields.headline: 2,500 jobs to flow from North Sea boost
fields.trailText: Ministers yesterday attempted to show that industry was still creating jobs despite economic conditions which have made thousands of car workers redundant.
fields.body:
Ministers yesterday attempted to show that industry was still creating jobs despite economic conditions which have made thousands of car workers redundant.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers and energy minister Helen Liddell announced North Sea investments that will create more than 2,500 jobs in the oil and engineering industries.

The news comes days after General Motors announced that it was closing the Vauxhall car plant at Luton with the loss of about 2,200 jobs.

The four North Sea projects announced yesterday will bring jobs to the west of Shetland oilfields and to Edinburgh and Tyneside.

The government has given the go-ahead for a £320m BP-led project which will take surplus gas through a new pipeline from the Foinaven and Schiehallion oilfields, west of Shetland, to the Magnus oilfield where it will be used to flush out an extra 50m barrels of oil. The gas, itself the energy equivalent of another 50m barrels of oil, will later be recovered and landed via an existing pipeline.

The project will create 1,000 jobs, including 220 at the pipe finishing company of Bredero Price Coater at Leith, near Edinburgh.

BP and its partners are also investing £210m to access a further 85m barrels of oil in the Foinaven field. This will create about 50 onshore jobs and about 500 during the two years of drilling.

About 900 jobs will be created by the decision to approve the development of the Leadon oilfield off the Shetland Islands. The oilfield was discovered in 1979 but was not developed by its previous owners.

The field, which is licensed to and will be operated by Kerr-McGee North Sea, will be brought onstream through a floating production and storage system to be built at the Swan Hunter yard on Tyneside.

There will be about 800 jobs at the yard in addition to some 100 offshore. The government has also given the go-ahead to Ranger Oil for further development of its Kyle oilfield in the central North Sea, about 110 miles east south east of Aberdeen. This will create about 80 jobs.

Mr Byers said: "This £1bn investment is the biggest the North Sea has seen in years and signals a bright future. These projects show that globalisation and new technologies can be a bringer of opportunities and not a threat."

Greenpeace, the environmental group, attacked the deal. A spokesman said the government should be concentrating on renewable energy schemes rather than "wringing the last drops of oil out of the North Sea".

webTitle: Townsend case thrown out hits back

fields.headline: Townsend case thrown out hits back
fields.standfirst: Stockbroker cleared of insider trading considers legal action against Hoare Govett
fields.trailText: The former vice-chairman of stockbroker Hoare Govett was considering legal action against his former employer last night after an insider-dealing charge against him was thrown out of court.
fields.body:
The former vice-chairman of stockbroker Hoare Govett was considering legal action against his former employer last night after an insider-dealing charge against him was thrown out of court.

His solicitor said Johnny Townsend, a well known City figure who played cricket for Norfolk in his youth, would be "considering the options available" after taking 2 years to clear his name.

"I don't think I would want to work with colleagues like those who pointed the finger at me," he said. "They behaved very badly and jumped to all the wrong conclusions."

Judge Charles Byers told Blackfriars crown court that crucial expert evidence presented by the prosecution contained "considerable shortcomings" and had not persuaded him that Mr Townsend had acted on price-sensitive information when he advised a friend to buy 1m shares in WT Foods in 1998.

The prosecution alleged that Mr Townsend had encouraged Salah Shohet to buy the shares the day after senior executives at WT told Mr Townsend privately, of the company's plans to buy another food firm, the Noon Group. This was said to amount to "flagrant" insider dealing in a closed period.

But Judge Byers said the Department of Trade and Industry's case relied heavily on evidence from expert witness Alastair McKerrell, a Cazenove stockbroker, that had not stood up to interrogation.

Nicholas Purnell, QC, counsel for the defence, had suggested to Mr McKerrell that "you would have to be half daft, if you are a professional, to choose WT Foods as a vehicle for insider share dealing". Mr McKerrell conceded there were reasons why the food company was an unlikely target for insider trading. A second expert witness for the prosecution was not heard after his impartiality was questioned.

Judge Byers said the DTI failed to prove that Mr Townsend had not advised Mr Shohet to buy the shares in his professional capacity as a stockbroker. He directed the jury to acquit Mr Townsend, ending the trial after five days.

Despite holes in the prosecution case, Judge Byers exonerated the DTI investigating officer, Dan Hughes, who conducted the case with "fairness and diligence".

Mr Purnell went further: "Hoare Govett [which had first alerted investigators to Mr Townsend's actions] misled the department over the strength of the case. The expert witness also misled Mr Hughes."

Outside court, Mr Townsend stood near his solicitor who read out a statement: "It is a great pity that a decision was made to proceed [with the case]. This was, at least in part, based on information received from Hoare Govett ... Mr Townsend will now, as a matter of urgency, be considering the options available to him." His legal cost are thought to run well into six figures.

Hoare Govett, a subsidiary of ABN Amro , said: "We notified the securities and futures authority of this matter ... The DTI decided to investigate it and subsequently bring a prosecution. We cooperated fully with the DTI."

A DTI spokeswoman said there had been seven successful prosecutions for insider dealing in the past four years despite about 100 referrals from the Stock Exchange.

Collapses

 December 1996 A judge rules that a former director of Eastern Electricity should not face retrial on charges of insider dealing. The jury had been unable to come to a verdict on Douglas Swinden, alleged by the DTI to have bought shares in another electricity company before the release of a price-sensitive report from the regulator.

 January 1994 Jeffrey Archer is investigated by the DTI for buying 50,000 shares in Anglia TV at a time when his wife was a director of the company. The shares were bought on behalf of a friend and netted £77,000. An investigation finds insufficient evidence.

 June 1991 Two market makers at County NatWest Securities are aquitted after a judge rules evidence inadmissible. Russel Kean and Stephen Floydd had denied insider dealing allegations relating to the trading of 350,000 Grand Metropolitan shares.

The jury had been unable to come to a verdict on Douglas Swinden, alleged by the DTI to have bought shares in another electricity company before the release of a price-sensitive report from the regulator.  January 1994 Jeffrey Archer is investigated by the DTI for buying 50,000 shares in Anglia TV at a time when his wife was a director of the company. The shares were bought on behalf of a friend and netted £77,000. An investigation finds insufficient evidence.  June 1991 Two market makers at County NatWest Securities are aquitted after a judge rules evidence inadmissible. Russel Kean and Stephen Floydd had denied insider dealing allegations relating to the trading of 350,000 Grand Metropolitan shares.

webTitle: Boxing: 'For amateurs it's no more risky than football'

fields.headline: 'For amateurs it's no more risky than football'
fields.trailText: At the St Pancras Amateur Boxing Club in north London yesterday, the under 21s limbered up for the week's first training session beneath the slogan, "Punches in Bunches".
fields.body:
At the St Pancras Amateur Boxing Club in north London yesterday, the under 21s limbered up for the week's first training session beneath the slogan, "Punches in Bunches". Stencilled neatly across the wall in yellow lettering, it was a motto which they had applied to their punchbags at the age of eight, to their trainer's gloves at 11, and at 16 to the heads of their fellow boxers. For this privilege, they travelled to a pebble dash hut in a dark street in Camden five nights a week.

"The worst injury I've ever had was a cut eye," said David Bailey, a mechanic from south London. Last year, the 19-year-old received the cut, just above his eyelid, in an amateur kick boxing championship in Epping Forest, Essex. It was serious enough for officials to call off the fight.

"You see," he said, "you're not on your own in there. You are being looked out for. The risk of getting an injury like Paul Ingle's is tiny."

To the young boxer, his trainer is a repository for the faith that, while the professional circuit might be corrupted by a need to provide good pay-per-view television, at amateur level it is no more dangerous than playing football; if the fight gets heavy, someone will step in.

"I have never been afraid," said Sunkanmi Ogunbiyi, a 20-year-old who after six years of amateur boxing is training for his first professional fight in January. "You don't look at the side effects, because you've been trained in how to avoid them. I am friends with the people I fight, we are not trying to kill each other."

"It's just like having a car accident," said CJ Hussein, the club's trainer. "Young boxers don't think it's going to happen to them." Mr Hussein attributed Paul Ingle's injury to the pressure boxers were under to keep their weight down.

"There are so many weight divisions now - 12 in the amateur league - that it is tempting for a boxer to drop a couple of kilos and move down rather than punching with the big guys.

"You can only lose so much weight by training. Then it's down to dieting and some fighters are dehydrated when they enter the ring. If you get hit in the head in that condition, it's a serious matter." At the St Pancras club, boxers are prohibited from dieting to make their weight.

For many, fighting is not the reason they attend training. Vivianna Sigona, a 21 year old with a black belt in Tae Kwondo who recently converted to boxing, is a dance student at the London School of Musical Theatre and boxes because it is strengthens her system more effectively than aerobics. She has no intention of entering any amateur bouts."The circuit training and sparring picks up your fitness," she said."Unless you take it up professionally, you won't get hurt."

Paul Ingle's brain injury has not deterred Sunkanmi Ogunbiyi from his dream of becoming a professional. "If you're a champ, everybody knows you," he said. "You can go anywhere in the world and people will want to shake your hand."

webTitle: £5.5bn Seagram deal close

fields.headline: £5.5bn Seagram deal close
fields.trailText: Diageo and Pernod-Ricard, the Anglo-French drinks partnership, are expected to win the long-running takeover battle for Seagram today with an offer that values the drinks division at $8.2bn (£5.5bn).
fields.body:
Diageo and Pernod-Ricard, the Anglo-French drinks partnership, are expected to win the long-running takeover battle for Seagram today with an offer that values the drinks division at $8.2bn (£5.5bn).

Talks were continuing in New York yesterday, but the two European companies were expected to trump an offer from a rival consortium of Bacardi, Brown-Forman and Vin & Sprit. Today's announcement will bring an end to negotiations which began in spring when Vivendi, the French media business, bought Seagram, a media and entertainment group, and announced its intention to sell the drinks unit.

Negotiations have been long and complicated. Even if Diageo and Pernod win, they are expected to face several legal and regulatory challenges.

Yesterday's talks were understood to have focused on these issues as well as the price. The transaction, to be 60% funded by the British group, is expected to be paid for largely in cash. One com pany adviser said last night the length of negotiations had been unsurprising . "It's a really messy deal," he added.

One of the regulatory issues arises because Diageo, one of the world's largest alcoholic beverage groups, is dominant in the whisky and vodka markets through Johnnie Walker and Smirnoff. Seagram's whisky brands include Chivas Regal and Glenlivet. Diageo's answer is that Pernod will take over the whiskies.

Traders yesterday welcomed signs that there was some some sort of a conclusion imminent. Diageo shares closed up 16p to 716.5p in London.

webTitle: M&S designer may quit

fields.headline: M&S designer may quit
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer, the troubled retail chain, yesterday confirmed that one of its top designers may quit.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer, the troubled retail chain, yesterday confirmed that one of its top designers may quit.

A spokeswoman said that Sheila Brown, the head of women's wear design, was "considering her position at the company".

She said that Ms Brown had had discussions regarding her future at the company, but stressed they related to a "personal issue" and not to the trading performance of the business.

"Sheila Brown is still head of women's wear design and heads a powerful team which she has built up during her 12 years with the company," she said. "She has recruited some very capable world class designers and the very strong team which she leads is committed to turning round the fortunes of women's wear."

She added that no decision would be taken until after Christmas when Ms Brown returned from holiday.

Brian Godbold, M&S's design director, left more than a year ago and has not been replaced. The design teams are responsible for advising on fabrics, colours, styles and trends.

A number of M&S staff have left recently as the group struggles to reverse a decline.

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: FTC approves drugs merger
fields.body:
FTC approves drugs merger

The US federal trade commission yesterday conditionally approved the merger of SmithKline Beecham and Glaxo Wellcome to create one of the world's largest pharmaceutical manufacturers.

On a 5-0 vote, the FTC required divestitures in six product markets but postponed a decision whether to require the sale of rival anti-smoking products marketed in the US by the two firms.

The firms said they had obtained all regulatory clearances and made all the divestitures needed to complete the long-delayed merger on December 27.

Mining funds back growth

Pension funds representing Britain's mining industry responded to the government's campaign for more investment in fast-growing young businesses by announcing they would invest £560m in private equity and venture capital projects in the US.

The British Coal Staff Superannuation Scheme and the Mine Workers Pension Scheme, which have combined assets of more than £28bn, already have £840m in alternative investment strategies in Europe and the new allocation will bring such commitments to around 5% of the overall funds. British funds in general allocate 0.5-1% to alternative asset classes.

Telia fights on for 3G licence

Swedish telecoms operator Telia is to appeal after failing to win a UMTS mobile phone licence in its home territory.

Telia's share price dropped 17% on Monday after the decision by Sweden's post and telecom authority not to award it a UMTS licence, making the partly privatised group the first leading national carrier not to win a local third-generation licence.

If its appeal succeeded, spectrum would have to be taken from one of the winners.

Fast delays union ballot

A ballot on union recognition among staff at Saudi Arabia's national airline has been delayed because of the fast of Ramadan.

Employees of the airline based in the UK will vote next month on whether they want recognition of the Manufacturing Science and Finance union by the company. It will be the first ballot ordered by the Central Arbitration Committee, set up under new employment law.

Rolls wins airline orders

Rolls Royce said it won contracts related to its AE 3007 engines from South African Airlink and British Regional Air Lines for a total $315m (£210m).

South African Airlink has placed an order worth $235m for up to 70 Embraer RJ135 regional jets fitted with the engine, while British Regional Air Lines awarded Rolls an $80m, 10-year contract to maintain its fleet of Embraer RJ145s.

Belgians buy Peel Hunt

Peel Hunt ysterday became the latest British securities broker to be taken over in an increasingly consolidated sector, as it agreed a £219m cash offer from Belgium's second-biggest financial group, KBC Bank.

KBC is offering 450p per share, valuing the firm's ordinary share capital at £218.5m.

webTitle: Blair visits dome to thank staff

fields.headline: Blair visits dome to thank staff
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Some might consider it a little late in the day to pitch up at the hapless Millennium Dome.
fields.body:
Some might consider it a little late in the day to pitch up at the hapless Millennium Dome. But Tony Blair will put on a brave face today when he pays his first visit to the Greenwich attraction since the new year's eve party which turned into a fiasco.

Downing Street said the prime minister would use the visit to offer his personal thanks to the dome's staff who have soldiered on in the face of dwindling visitor numbers.

Alastair Campbell, Mr Blair's official spokesman, said: "He is going to thank the people who worked there and to acknowledge that, despite the overwhelming cynicism of the media, something over 6m people will have gone through the gates by the end of this year.

"He is also underlining the government's commitment to the regeneration of that area," said Mr Campbell.

The prime minister will be accompanied by Michael Heseltine, the former Tory deputy prime minister, who was the driving force behind the dome in the run up to the last election. Mr Heseltine's continuing support has provided the government with important political cover in the face of the Tories' relentless criticism of the Greenwich attraction.

There was no word last night on whether the prime minister would use his visit to try and drum up another 6m visitors in the final 13 days before the dome closes at the end of the year.

The dome's finances repeatedly collapsed during the year, leading to a series of emergency cash injections, after the original target of 12m visitors proved hopelessly over ambitious.

Admissions to the dome are to be reduced from £20 to £1 on Christmas Eve and £10 on Boxing Day to try and boost attendance.

Although today's visit will be only Mr Blair's second to the dome, members of his family have not stayed away. His son, Euan, has visited the dome but Downing Street refused to say whether the site had passed the famous "Euan test" set by the prime minister.

webTitle: Good day, bad day

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Yesterday
fields.body:
Yesterday

Good day

Speed cameras.
Home secretary Jack Straw praised the "moderating" effect of the ubiquitous speed camera on motorists, citing his own behaviour. "When I was apprehended by a speed camera in 1993, and paid my fine, and got three points on my licence, my driving behaviour improved." He pointed out he had not received any points since.

Bad day

For voyeurs.
The owner of a nude painting of Cherie Blair, the prime minister's wife, by Euan Uglow, said he would not sell the masterpiece. Will Darby, owner of the Cork Street gallery in London, said: "It's an incomplete portrait ... the Blairs know the painting is here but they've never shown any interest in buying it, which I find surprising."

Quote of the day

"The application form for pension credit will be unlike any other form ever issued by the DSS; it'll be short, simple, easily understood and an absolute joy to fill in." - Social security minister Jeff Rooker.

Today

Commons

Scottish questions.
Motion on draft human fertilisation and embryology (research purposes) regulation 2000. Westminster Hall: Backbench debates include financial services authority and the case of Equitable Life.

Lords: Special educational needs and disability bill, second reading.

webTitle: Life for ex-lover caught with murder letter

fields.headline: Life for ex-lover caught with murder letter
fields.trailText: A man who was caught carrying a letter detailing the murder of his ex-lover was jailed for life yesterday.
fields.body:
A man who was caught carrying a letter detailing the murder of his ex-lover was jailed for life yesterday.

Laurie Drummond MacKellar, 28, of Newport, South Wales, admitted murdering Clare Edwards after she tried to end their relationship, Cardiff crown court heard.

MacKellar sparked a nation wide hunt in May after he strangled the 27-year-old divorcee and left her body in their Newport home for her two children to find.

Mr Justice Blofeld told MacKellar he was a cold-blooded murderer who had carried out his threat without remorse.

Earlier, Peter Griffiths QC, prosecuting, told how MacKellar had become jealous when his ex-lover revealed she intended returning to her former husband. He had bombarded her with calls.

He was arrested four days after the murder in Bristol, carrying a letter to the victim detailing his murder plans.

The letter, read out in court by Mr Griffiths, said: "I told you Clare that if I cannot have you, no one else will ... I told you that if you betrayed my love I would kill you."

Throughout the trial MacKellar insisted he killed his ex-lover during an argument when she was as aggressive and violent as he was.

Press Association

webTitle: Tory MP tells of tackling drunken woman intruder

fields.headline: Tory MP tells of tackling drunken woman intruder
fields.trailText: A Tory MP yesterday described how he acted on instinct to protect his wife and two-month-old baby when a drunk, mentally ill intruder forced her way into their home.
fields.body:
A Tory MP yesterday described how he acted on instinct to protect his wife and two-month-old baby when a drunk, mentally ill intruder forced her way into their home.

Andrew Mackay, the shadow Northern Ireland secretary, grappled with the screaming woman, who had fled the nearby Gordon psychiatric hospital, and knocked her to the floor of the Westminster town house he shares with his wife, Julie Kirkbride, the Tory MP for Bromsgove.

"These things are so split second," he said. "My reaction was that this was an unwelcome intruder, who had barged past my wife while my baby and young nanny were downstairs. She was clearly a danger to us - and my first and immediate thought was that I had to control her."

The altercation came at around 9pm on Sunday after the doorbell rang. Because of the security threat of Mr Mackay's job, Ms Kirkbride opened the door and was struck by the force of a stocky woman.

"The door was thrown back on me and I tried to push her but she was on her front foot and I was on my back so she pushed her way in. She screamed that she needed help and ran into the house," Ms Kirkbride recalled yesterday

Mr Mackay, alerted by his wife's screams, rushed to stop the woman, who was in her 30s. "I just caught her and brought her to the ground. I just pushed her and then held her wrists", he said.

The nanny rang the police who arrived within five minutes. The woman, a voluntary psychiatric patient, was not charged but returned to the hospital on the same square in which the MPs live. It emerged she had been involved in a fracas after drinking in Victoria and had fled to the Mackays after being detained by a nurse.

Last night, Ms Kirkbride, 40, who was confronted by a burglar wielding a knife in the house earlier this summer, said: "This was less terrifying than the last time, but only because I wasn't alone: my have-a-go hero husband was there."

Ms Kirkbride added that the latest incident highlighted the problem of falling numbers in the Metropolitan police force. This month, the commissioner Sir John Stevens warned the Met was 3,000 officers short.

Mr Mackay, 51, the MP for Bracknell, said their ordeal illustrated the need for a reform of the Mental Health Act to force potentially dangerous patients to be detained against their will if necessary.

The white paper on mental health, published tomorrow, will include this proposal but patients such as the one who entered the Mackay home would not be included. A spokesman for the Gordon hospital, where she had been a voluntary residential patient for a few years, stressed she had not been sectioned.

webTitle: Electors give Bush key to White House

fields.headline: Electors give Bush key to White House
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The final 538 votes were cast in the presidential election yesterday as electoral college members attended ceremonies around the US in an antiquated ritual which took on new significance after the close-run presidential election.
fields.body:
The final 538 votes were cast in the presidential election yesterday as electoral college members attended ceremonies around the US in an antiquated ritual which took on new significance after the close-run presidential election.

Despite speculation about last-minute defections, the electors were expected to cast their ballots the way their home states had voted, giving Mr Bush a majority of 271 votes against Mr Gore's 267, finally sealing his presidency.

Republican electors, chosen from the ranks of faithful party activists, said they had been inundated with calls from Democrats urging them to switch their votes to reflect the fact that Mr Gore won more votes nationwide, but, as of late yesterday afternoon, no one appeared to have wavered.

Before the election was decided last week by a supreme court ruling against further recounts in Florida, Mr Gore said that he would not accept the votes of renegade "faithless electors" who cast their ballots against the will of the states which had chosen them.

Yesterday, his running mate, Joe Lieberman repeated the pledge, saying: "Al Gore and I don't expect any surprises. We've certainly renounced any effort to change any electoral votes."

Mr Bush is due to meet Mr Gore today for a formal reconciliation, and President Clinton to discuss the transfer of power on inauguration day, January 20.

In a foretaste of what is expected to be an amicable encounter, Laura Bush visited Hillary Clinton in the White House to discuss the role of first lady - the two women held hands for the cameras, doing their bit for what the US press call "national healing".

In more such healing, Democratic congressional leaders met Mr Bush on Capitol Hill and accepted the legitimacy of the election's court-imposed outcome.

Standing beside Mr Bush, Tom Daschle, the senior Democrat in the Senate, said: "Let's put this campaign behind us. Let's find a way with which to begin working together in a constructive way, and the most important thing we can do to recognise the level of urgency with which to do that is to recognise the legitimacy of his presidency and to begin working with him."

Formally speaking, the electorate did not vote directly for Mr Gore or Mr Bush on polling day, November 7, but for slates of electors pledged to support one or the other candidate. In 25 states, those electors were bound by law to honour their mandate yesterday. In others, they were theoretically free to follow their conscience, although there have been very few "faithless electors" in US history and such rogue voters have never decided the outcome of an election.

This year is the first time for more than a century that the electoral college vote has gone against the popular vote, provoking scrutiny of the indirect method of electing presidents laid down in the 18th century. Opinion polls since election day have shown a majority in favour of reform, but changing the constitution would require a bipartisan consensus in Congress which many pundits believe is beyond reach.

Usually the television networks ignore the meeting of electors but yesterday the ceremonies were broadcast live. Republican leaders went out of their way to coddle electors to ensure that none jumped ship.

The vice-president-elect, Dick Cheney, held a conference call with the Republican electors, who were also feted with brunches by party grandees. In North Carolina they were treated as celebrities and accompanied by a school honour guard. In Florida Jeb Bush, the president-elect's brother, had the 25 electors ferried from their Tallahassee hotel for a face-to-face meeting before the noon ceremony.

Websites have appeared in recent days listing the names of Republican electors and encouraging people to email, telephone or write to them, urging them to turn renegade. Cynthia Hadley, an elector from Cocoa Beach, Florida, said she had been fending off scores of Democratic calls for her to break rank.

"I had a house guest at my home. I left her today and she's answering my phone, getting all upset trying to deal with it," Ms Hadley said. "But it's not going to change my mind."

In most cases the electors cast their ballots yesterday in the form of a formal certificate, in public, and in the state legislatures. The only secret ballots took place in Washington, Indiana and Minnesota. All the votes will be sent to the US Senate to to be counted on January 6.

If the Florida dispute had not been resolved, Congress might have had to choose one of two rival slates of electors. This count is expected to pass without incident.

webTitle: Small cut in air noise ordered

fields.headline: Small cut in air noise ordered
fields.trailText: Residents near Britain's booming airports are to be given limited relief from intrusive engine noise after ministers last night agreed modest reductions in sound levels.
fields.body:
Residents near Britain's booming airports are to be given limited relief from intrusive engine noise after ministers last night agreed modest reductions in sound levels.

The announcement ends four years of consultation and a court challenge from the aircraft industry.

The restrictions covering Britain's three major airports will see enforced falls in aircraft noise for all planes leaving the airports during specific night and day time periods.

Noise limits will be reduced by three decibels by day to 94 decibels and by two decibels by night to 87 decibels. The airline industry has warned that older 747s and A340s, which are yet to take to the skies, will be unable to meet the new limits.

The Labour MP for Slough, Fiona MacTaggart, last night said the changes struck a balance between the need to create jobs at Heathrow and allowing residents to sleep.

The lower night noise limits will only apply between 11.30pm and 6am. Higher night time limits will apply between 11pm and 11.30 pm and again between six and seven in the morning. Airlines will also be required to reach 1,000ft at 6.5km from the start of their take-off. The new day noise limits will apply from February next year, a year later than the government originally indicated.

Chris Mullin, the environment minister, defended the modest reductions saying only small numbers now live close to runways. The new restrictions will cover Gatwick, Heathrow and Stansted. Concorde, if it returns to public use, will not be subjectto the limits

The airlines lobbied against the reforms on the grounds that aircraft cannot cut back power until they reach 1,000ft. In addition, largely for safety reasons, airlines usually use the same operating procedures for all routes from a particular airport.

However, Mr Mullin rejected their arguments on the grounds that airlines were overestimating the likely weights of aircraft.

webTitle: Nurses case studies: 'When I quit, it was 60% to do with low pay'

fields.headline: 'When I quit, it was 60% to do with low pay'
fields.trailText: Phillip Huston says he was very idealistic about nursing and the NHS when he began a three-year degree course in 1995. But within 18 months of qualifying, he had quit his job because of poor pay and lack of job satisfaction.
fields.body:
Phillip Huston says he was very idealistic about nursing and the NHS when he began a three-year degree course in 1995. But within 18 months of qualifying, he had quit his job because of poor pay and lack of job satisfaction.

"I was not as badly off as other people on the course, because at least I owned my own house," he said. "When I first qualified at the beginning of 1998, I was earning £12,500 and it eventually was increased to £14,000 after a pay review. It is ridiculous if you think what trainee police officers get."

He said that the 3.7% pay increase for nurses was terrible. "I would have thought it would have been a lot more generous; between 7.5% and 8% would have been a reasonable figure. People will be completely disillusioned by this pay award and this is not the way to retain nurses in the NHS."

Mr Huston, 34, from Hyde, Greater Manchester, decided to go into nursing after he was made redundant in 1994 after 10 years as an army officer. His aunt, two cousins and mother had all been nurses.

"I went from having a very healthy salary to earning £4,000 a year in a bursary. Even though I had some money to fall back on, I did incur some debts while training," he said.

"As soon as I qualified I started work in anaesthetics and recovery at the Countess of Chester hospital in Chester.

"After six months I started to wonder why I had gone into nursing. I found it incredibly frustrating. When I decided to quit, 60% of the reason was because of the pay and the rest was the lack of job satisfaction."

He now works as development manager for Thornbury nursing services, which provides agency nurses and offers professional training.

Alison Brierley had always wanted to be a nurse, but has only been able to realise her ambition in the last few years. She spent the previous 14 years working as a health care assistant in NHS hospitals. Now, with her four children at school, she has been able to realise her ambition.

Alison, 37, who lives in Oldham, Greater Manchester, qualified in October 1999 and now works as a D grade at the Royal Oldham hospital on an acute medical ward.

The 3.7% pay increase will be worth £554.81 a year to her. "At the end of the day, the police do a few months' training and then start off on £19,000 a year," she said. "We do three years at university and then start off on £14,995. It is no wonder that we get despondent.

"We were expecting a little bit more than a 3.7% pay rise. Although we got an increase earlier this year, it is not ideal. It would have been better if we had something nearer 5%.

"Nursing is a very difficult job. Morale is very low and has been for quite some time - it is not just about pay.

"The staff shortages are also having an effect on the wards. It is quite demanding working on an acute medical ward. I didn't realise how much of a strain nursing would be.

"It is not easy when you come home because you can't just switch off from work. When I was training, I didn't realise how demanding a job it would be.

"If I am working a late shift, I don't get home until 10pm and then I can be starting work again the next day at 7.30am. By the time I wind down, it's 12 o'clock before I get to bed and then you are up again and ready to start work."

"At this time of year there are extra pressures with the demands for beds which makes things difficult.

"The people I trained with feel the same way - we are all despondent. I didn't come into nursing because of the pay, it was because I love the job of nursing.
