webTitle: Charge proved: taking the mickey without consent

fields.headline: Charge proved: taking the mickey without consent
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: The subject before the Commons was the Vehicle (Crime) Bill, so naturally they wanted to talk about William Hague. And football.
fields.body:
The subject before the Commons was the Vehicle (Crime) Bill, so naturally they wanted to talk about William Hague. And football. MPs are often accused, as the Tories were yesterday, of turning a tragedy into a "political football". Do footballers do the opposite and say of a defeat that it was "a right Hague on the park"? Or, following a 6-0 hammering, tell John Motson: "We was pants, we was Widdecombe today"?

Jack Straw began to talk about the bill, but was interrupted by Crispin Blunt. The Tory MP for Reigate seemed to be quivering with outrage. Would the home secretary take the opportunity to make it quite clear that he did not believe the leader of the opposition was a racist? Or was guilty of racism?

And, he continued, "if people have taken his remarks to believe that, will he apologise for the effect of his remarks?" - a verbal convolution worthy of the master, John Prescott.

Jack Straw was equal to this throbbing challenge. "No," he said.

He thought the subject was probably out of order, given that the debate was supposed to be about bent scrapyards, but as the Tories had raised it, he thought that Mr Hague had played the race card.

"Disgraceful!" boomed the Tories as if no such thing was conceivable in their party.

Anyhow, Mr Straw went on, amiably enough, the traffic was now the other way. Ann Widdecombe had apologised to Damilola Taylor's family for the distress caused by Mr Hague's remarks.

Miss Widdecombe flopped up to the despatch box like an enraged seal. She had, she insisted, not apologised for any distress caused by her leader. Rather, she had expressed regret for the dis tress felt by the family, a different matter.

This distinction was so subtle that it would take a squad of crack metaphysicians kitted out with Enigma machines years to decipher. Mr Straw didn't even try, and somehow dragged MPs back to vehicle crime.

He told us he had twice had his car stereo nicked outside Preston station, and hadn't even bothered to report it. And once the car had been stolen from outside his house in Blackburn.

"Why didn't you use a Krooklok?" cried Miss Widdecombe in a voice which would have shattered the Amber Room in the summer palace. The home secretary pretended to have misunderstood: "Because the Krooklok has not been invented which anchors a stereo!" he said to merry Labour jeers.

Anyhow, he added, he had offered two tickets to a Blackburn Rovers home game for the return of his car - and got it back. He paused to praise "Rovers' magnificent victory yesterday against Burnley." Nobody wanted to talk about car crime. They were like schoolboys at Christmas desperate to distract their teacher, "Sir, please sir, why does asparagus make your pee smell?"

Michael Fabricant kept trying to ask how many extra policemen would be needed; from dodgy motors to moody barnets, as we say in London.

Then John Bercow replied. He is Misss Widdecombe's Mini-Me, like Dr Evil's tiny sidekick in Austin Powers. He said the Tories would not vote against the bill. So this was the equivalent of learning to drive on an abandoned airstrip; he can't be risked on the roads yet.

For a short while his speech was sane, but that never lasts long. Suddenly he ranted: "The home secretary is a lily-livered liberal! The criminal classes are praying for an election victory!"

He'd forgotten to add the word "Labour" in the sentence. The elected representatives of the criminal classes sniggered happily, and Mini-Me looked very puzzled. Keep those L-plates on for a little longer there!

webTitle: NHS pay deal 'will fuel staff crisis'

fields.headline: NHS pay deal 'will fuel staff crisis'
fields.standfirst: Doctors and nurses say small rise will hinder recruitment
fields.trailText: Nurses' and doctors' leaders warned ministers last night that "disappointing" pay increases promised for next year would not be enough to attract the staff needed to implement the government's ambitious NHS reform plan.
fields.body:
Nurses' and doctors' leaders warned ministers last night that "disappointing" pay increases promised for next year would not be enough to attract the staff needed to implement the government's ambitious NHS reform plan.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said he accepted the pay review body's recommendation of a 3.7% rise for nurses and therapists and 3.9% for doctors and dentists.

The extra will be paid in full from April 1, coinciding with what is widely expected to be the start of the general election campaign.

The settlement included higher increases for about 70,000 senior nurses, giving 5.5% to sisters at the top of the main scale and taking their maximum to £25,420.

There will also be cost of living supplements worth £600 to £1,000 for some nursing staff in London and £400 to £600 in other high-cost areas. That would contribute towards raising their pay by up to 9%.

But most NHS staff will be limited to an increase of less than 1% above the rate of inflation, currently running at 3.2%.

The deal will add 4% to the NHS pay bill in England, costing £673m in a full year. So it will consume less than a quarter of the £2.9bn increase in health authority budgets, already announced for the coming year.

The Department of Health said this should leave room for 5.9% real growth in NHS spending - to recruit more staff, expand facilities and meet the ever-increasing drugs bill.

Mr Milburn said: "We are determined to do right by frontline NHS staff. Year on year we are making steady progress on increasing their numbers and improving pay rates.

"These fair and affordable pay rises will help increase still further the numbers of trained, qualified staff working in the NHS. For the third year in a row, the awards will be paid in full, without staging."

But leaders of the medical professions cast doubt on whether the increases would be enough for the government to make progress towards targets to recruit an extra 20,000 nurses, 2,000 GPs and 7,500 consultants by 2004.

Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, said the pay settlement "is hardly the winter tonic that doctors had been hoping for".

He added: "While it is an above-inflation award, it will do little to motivate frontline staff and even less to tackle the major shortfall of doctors in the UK."

John Chisholm, chairman of the BMA's general practitioners committee, said: "We are disappointed. In our view it fails to address the serious shortfall in current GP numbers. Nor does it recognise the huge workload pressures faced by those in the profession."

Peter Hawker, chairman of the consultants committee, said: "We know there is a crisis of under-capacity and this announcement will do little to resolve that."

John Renshaw, chairman of the British Dental Association executive board, said: "It appears unlikely it will help overcome the shortage of dentists working for the NHS."

Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, said it was a "complex pay award" that would be good news for ward sisters, specialist clinical nurses and community nurses. "Many staff nurses will be disappointed by a basic uplift of 3.7% as alone it won't bring fast progress in encouraging nurses back to the health service."

Karen Jennings, head of nursing at the public sector union, Unison, said: "This is a missed opportunity by the pay review body who should have had the vision to solve tomorrow's problems and not just look at today's."

But Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS Confederation representing health authority managers and trusts, said the deal "could well take us to the edges of affordability".

Health ministers were confident last night that the increases would be enough to continue the trend to recruit and retain more nurses. A spokesman said the workforce grew by 6,000 over the last year and four more years at that rate would achieve the target of 20,000 extra.

The awards range from £335 a year at the bottom of the scale for a nursing assistant aged 18, to £4,835 for a top consultant doctor with maximum distinction awards. According to Department of Health figures, a newly qualified nurse's pay will rise from a minimum of £14,890 to £15,445.

An experienced staff nurse at the top of the scale will rise from £19,220 to £19,935 and a sister at the top of the main scale from £24,090 to £25,420

A hospital consultant's starting salary will go from between £48,905 and £63,640 to between £50,810 and £66,120, with top specialists able to earn up to a maximum £128,935.

Family doctors should see their income rise from £54,220 to £56,335 from next year.

The Department of Health said this should leave room for 5.9% real growth in NHS spending - to recruit more staff, expand facilities and meet the ever-increasing drugs bill. Mr Milburn said: "We are determined to do right by frontline NHS staff. Year on year we are making steady progress on increasing their numbers and improving pay rates. "These fair and affordable pay rises will help increase still further the numbers of trained, qualified staff working in the NHS. For the third year in a row, the awards will be paid in full, without staging." But leaders of the medical professions cast doubt on whether the increases would be enough for the government to make progress towards targets to recruit an extra 20,000 nurses, 2,000 GPs and 7,500 consultants by 2004. Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, said the pay settlement "is hardly the winter tonic that doctors had been hoping for". He added: "While it is an above-inflation award, it will do little to motivate frontline staff and even less to tackle the major shortfall of doctors in the UK." John Chisholm, chairman of the BMA's general practitioners committee, said: "We are disappointed. In our view it fails to address the serious shortfall in current GP numbers. Nor does it recognise the huge workload pressures faced by those in the profession." Peter Hawker, chairman of the consultants committee, said: "We know there is a crisis of under-capacity and this announcement will do little to resolve that." John Renshaw, chairman of the British Dental Association executive board, said: "It appears unlikely it will help overcome the shortage of dentists working for the NHS." Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, said it was a "complex pay award" that would be good news for ward sisters, specialist clinical nurses and community nurses. "Many staff nurses will be disappointed by a basic uplift of 3.7% as alone it won't bring fast progress in encouraging nurses back to the health service." Karen Jennings, head of nursing at the public sector union, Unison, said: "This is a missed opportunity by the pay review body who should have had the vision to solve tomorrow's problems and not just look at today's." But Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS Confederation representing health authority managers and trusts, said the deal "could well take us to the edges of affordability". Health ministers were confident last night that the increases would be enough to continue the trend to recruit and retain more nurses. A spokesman said the workforce grew by 6,000 over the last year and four more years at that rate would achieve the target of 20,000 extra. The awards range from £335 a year at the bottom of the scale for a nursing assistant aged 18, to £4,835 for a top consultant doctor with maximum distinction awards. According to Department of Health figures, a newly qualified nurse's pay will rise from a minimum of £14,890 to £15,445. An experienced staff nurse at the top of the scale will rise from £19,220 to £19,935 and a sister at the top of the main scale from £24,090 to £25,420 A hospital consultant's starting salary will go from between £48,905 and £63,640 to between £50,810 and £66,120, with top specialists able to earn up to a maximum £128,935. Family doctors should see their income rise from £54,220 to £56,335 from next year.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Kings Beyond The Carols | The "Hot Club" Two
fields.body:
The treble soloist who launches the Nine Lessons and Carols from King's College Chapel, Cambridge, gets just one minute's warning that his will be the voice to echo round the globe. Kings Beyond The Carols (1.30pm, Radio 4) discovers how he and other singers train for one of the world's best-known Christian rituals. Most people assume the service began in the Middle Ages: in reality it was only devised in 1928.

In the second part of The "Hot Club" Two (10pm, Radio 2) Martin Taylor recalls the long career of Stephane Grapelli. A pianist before he opted for violin lessons, Grapelli's meeting with the Gypsy guitarist Django Reinhardt (originally a violinist) brought a startling new sound to 1930s jazz. Sadly the two men were separated by the war, which found Grapelli in England and Reinhardt desperately eluding the Nazis all over Europe. After the war the two simply drifted apart and Grapelli began to discover new partners.

webTitle: Boxing: MP calls for inquiry after Ingle left in coma

fields.headline: MP calls for inquiry after boxer left in coma
fields.standfirst: Ingle showing signs of improvement but fears over sport's safety leads to demands for more safeguards and a ban on head punches
fields.trailText: Ingle showing signs of improvement but fears over sport's safety leads to demands for more safeguards and a ban on head punches.
fields.body:
A proposal to hold a full parliamentary inquiry into boxing is to be considered by MPs today as political concern mounts over the sport's safety record.

Derek Wyatt, the Labour MP for Sittingbourne and Sheppey and a member of the select committee on sport which meets today, is to propose that an inquiry be held so that new safeguards can be introduced.

Britain's injured boxer Paul Ingle is meanwhile still in a coma but showing encouraging signs of improvement according to surgeons in Sheffield who are treating him for severe brain and head injuries. Ingle, 28, was knocked down in the 12th round of his defence of the International Boxing Federation featherweight title by Mbulelo Botile of South Africa at the Sheffield Arena on Saturday night.

Mr Wyatt also sent a letter to the home secretary, Jack Straw, urging him to make the wearing of headguards compulsory for professional boxers.

The select committee is also keen to see independent research carried out to assess the impact on boxing. Another proposal is for medical examinations on all professional British boxers who have fought world championship bouts over the past 20 years.

If members of the committee agree to hold an inquiry then evidence will also be taken from former boxers, promoters, trainers and doctors.

Mr Wyatt stressed that the committee did not want to impose a ban on boxing but believed that greater safeguards needed to be introduced.

He said: "A full and proper independent investigation needs to be held into boxing and the long term damage it is causing boxers. I am very concerned at the situation and what happened to Paul Ingle was very shocking."

In a further political development, Paul Flynn, the Labour MP for Newport West, yesterday reiterated his plan to introduce a law that would make punches to the head in boxing illegal.

Mr Flynn said: "Boxing is unique in encouraging blows to the head. A boxer can receive hundreds of blows to the head in a single bout. The new law would outlaw blows to the head in the same way that blows below the waist are banned now.

"At present, if boxers kill or maim opponents in the ring they can't be charged with assault or manslaughter because they have a defence they were acting within the rules."

All amateur boxers have to wear headguards and larger gloves than their professional counterparts to soften the impact of blows.

Demands by some MPs that headguards should be made compulsory for professional boxers were criticised yesterday by the British Boxing Board of Control, the governing body.

The general secretary, Simon Block, said: "The introduction of headgear to professional fights is unlikely to happen and unlikely to make a difference. In fact, all the medical evidence shows that it can make brain injuries worse."

Last night, David Battersby, the consultant neurosurgeon treating Ingle, said the boxer was making good progress.

"Over the course of the day we have lightened his sedation and he is now making movements which are very encouraging," said Mr Battersby. "We are now at the stage of looking after the secondary effects of a head injury."

Ingle will remain in intensive care until the end of the week at least, with his fiancee, Samantha Coulson, and his family, only permitted short spells at his bedside in the Royal Hallamshire hospital.

A statement from Ingle's family was released last night by Ms Coulson who is due to marry the boxer next year. She said: "We have been with him since the accident happened. He is still critical and we are playing a waiting game."

The row over boxing is set to be further fuelled by a court of appeal ruling today on whether the sport's British regulators are liable to pay compensation to the brain-damaged Michael Watson.

Three judges will give judgment on an appeal by the British Boxing Board of Control against a high court decision which awarded Watson £1m after a fight with Chris Eubank in 1991 left him partly paralysed.

In a case of vital importance to other sporting bodies, the BBBC, which went into administrative receivership after the high court ruling, has argued that it owed Watson no duty of care.

webTitle: Netanyahu's comeback flounders

fields.headline: Netanyahu's comeback flounders
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Binyamin Netanyahu's much heralded political comeback was in danger of fizzling out last night, nine days after the former Israeli prime minister announced his return to public life.
fields.body:
Binyamin Netanyahu's much heralded political comeback was in danger of fizzling out last night, nine days after the former Israeli prime minister announced his return to public life.

The clear favourite to defeat Ehud Barak in the prime ministerial election on February 6, Mr Netanyahu suffered a setback when the rabbis of the Shas party said they would not vote for a dissolution of the Israeli parliament, the knesset, to cause a general election.

Their decision blocks one of the two ways by which Mr Netanyahu can circumvent the laws which bar him as a private citizen from contesting the election. Mr Netanyahu gave up his knesset seat and retreated from public life 18 months ago, when he was trounced in the prime ministerial election by Mr Barak.

Although the knesset kept alive the prospects of his other avenue to office, voting 63-46 on the first reading of a "Netanyahu bill" to allow him to stand, he said that was not good enough.

At a news conference he repeated his threat to withdraw from the contest unless a general election is called, arguing that he had no desire to inherit a gridlocked parliament.

"To remove the country from the crisis it is in, perhaps the worst it has ever faced, the nation needs real elections," he said.

"I hope the knesset, or at least the majority of the parties in the knesset, will do the right thing and dissolve parliament."

He may recant overnight if the Netanyahu bill wins two further votes to become law, and if Shas reverses its stand before the vote on dissolution. Mr Netanyahu said he would challenge the hardline Likud leader, Ariel Sharon, for the party leadership today.

Any outcome is possible in a political struggle ruled by self-interest.

Mr Sharon would like nothing better than to see Mr Netanyahu run back to his lucrative public speaking tours in the US. Mr Barak does not want to appear afraid of his old rival, but he want him to run either, which is why he backed the Netanyahu bill yesterday, knowing that it would not draw him into the fray.

If Mr Netanyahu does stand, the opinion polls predict a walkover: he enjoys a double figure lead over Mr Barak. Mr Barak is also trailing Mr Sharon, who is reviled through out the Middle East for his role in the Lebanon war.

Mr Barak could bounce back if there is a peace deal with the Palestinians. Israeli and Palestinian delegates left for Washington yesterday for separate talks with US officials. If there is a breakthrough, this election would be transformed into a referendum on peace.

Netanyahu loyalists accused Shas of betrayal yesterday. Shas, which represents ultra-Orthodox Jews and those of Middle Eastern descent, shrugged off the accusation.

"So what," said Shlomo Ben Izri, a leading member. "Do we have to decide what is good for Netanyahu now? We decide what is good for Shas."

webTitle: EU fails in bid to broker climate deal

fields.headline: EU fails in bid to broker climate deal
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Europe's final chance of clinching an agreement with the United States to cut global warming under a sympathetic Clinton administration ended in abject failure last night after the two sides failed to resolve their gaping differences and cancelled a meeting in Oslo due this week.
fields.body:
Europe's final chance of clinching an agreement with the United States to cut global warming under a sympathetic Clinton administration ended in abject failure last night after the two sides failed to resolve their gaping differences and cancelled a meeting in Oslo due this week.

After the collapse of climate change talks in the Hague last month, yesterday's meeting of EU environment ministers in Brussels had been seen as the best hope of breathing life into stalled negotiations.

However, the US, Japan, Australia and New Zealand flatly rejected an offer of fresh talks from the EU, arguing that a successful outcome was highly unlikely.

It will now be far more difficult for the EU to strike an agreement on how to implement the 1997 UN Kyoto protocol on cutting greenhouse gases with an America led by President Bush who is said not to be particularly interested in environmental issues.

Deputy prime minister, John Prescott, said the EU had missed a unique opportunity but was careful not to pin the blame for the failure on France's sparky environment minister, Dominique Voynet, with whom he has crossed swords in the past.

"I'm rather sad that we've missed this opportunity. It would have been with the old negotiating presidential team of the Clinton presidency but there will now be a new team in place. Anyone else coming in is going to start from scratch. That's inevitable."

Mr Prescott said part of the problem was that the Americans had fallen back on their old entrenched negotiating positions in the course of two transatlantic teleconferences yesterday making an agreement all but impossible.

Massive differences between the two sides persist - principally over whether the US should be allowed to plant controversial "sink forests" in other parts of the world to soak up its own carbon dioxide emissions which are responsible for global warming.

The US also wants a much wider use of so-called emissions trading - the buying and selling of emissions credits from other countries - than the EU is willing to accept.

Mr Prescott went out of his way to play down tensions with Ms Voynet who famously accused him of being a macho man after he claimed she was too tired to understand the detail of an agreement he had brokered at the Hague.

"It's wonderful," he said when asked to sum up his relationship with the French minister during yesterday's meeting.

"She told me today that I'm the darling of the feminist movement. Both of us are professional politicians and both committed to doing something for the environment."

However, his jolly demeanour contrasted sharply with Ms Voynet's take on the issue. When asked earlier whether the two had patched up their differences she frostily replied that she was not interested in the matter.

webTitle: Civil servants blamed in BSE inquiry will not be disciplined

fields.headline: Civil servants blamed in BSE inquiry will not be disciplined
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: The government has decieded no civil servant should be disciplined as a result of the £4bn BSE fiasco, which has blighted agriculture and soured diplomatic relations with France and Germany.
fields.body:
The government has decieded no civil servant should be disciplined as a result of the £4bn BSE fiasco, which has blighted agriculture and soured diplomatic relations with France and Germany.

Fifteen civil servants and five ministers were criticised by Lord Phillips's inquiry into the disaster. Many of the civil servants have subsequently resigned or retired.

Ministers responded to the Phillips report two months ago by setting up a review led by Sheila Forbes, a civil service commissioner. Her recommendations may be published in the next few days to lift the shadow hanging over the civil servants' careers.

In setting up the Forbes inquiry, the agriculture secretary, Nick Brown, hinted strongly he was personally opposed to disciplinary action against civil servants.

He told MPs last month: "Whenever serving public servants are subjected to criticism by a public inquiry, the question arises whether any form of disciplinary action should be taken".

He then quoted from the Phillips report, which said: "If those criticised were misguided, they were nonetheless acting in accordance with what they conceived to be the proper performance of their duties".

Mr Brown also stressed in his Commons statement that some of the individuals criticised receive praise from the inquiry, but there is no corresponding list of individuals who are praised.

The Phillips inquiry criticised the individuals, mainly in the Ministry of Agriculture and Department of Health, on the grounds that they should have acted differently in light of the information that they had available at the time.

The bulk of the criticism cen tered on civil servants failing to do more to bring the potential dangers of BSE to ministers attention.

Amongst civil servants criticised include William Rees, chief veterinary officer between 1980 and 1988, and his successor up to 1997, Keith Meldrum.

The report also highlighted deficiencies by Sir Keith Calman the chief medical officer to 1998.

Phillips also attacked the head of the ministry of agriculture animal health division Robert Lowson.

The chief medical officer for Scotland between 1991-1996, Robert Kendell, was also criticised for misleading statements about the safety of beef.

The report also criticised Thomas Eddy, head of Maff animal health (disease control) division from June 1993 for misleading minutes concerning the possibility that CJD cases in young people might prove to be linked with BSE.

webTitle: The railway children who dice with death

fields.headline: The railway children who dice with death
fields.standfirst:
Vandalism and trespass are biggest threat to rail safety

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Vandalism and trespass are biggest threat to rail safety.
fields.body:
By 4.15pm the control at British Transport police north-east region had logged a long list of incidents.

Three youths were putting objects on the line at Ashington colliery; a large group of youths was abseiling off a viaduct at Baildon, West Yorkshire; some kids were messing about with a signal box at Dewsbury; some were on a bridge in nearby Ravens- thorpe, others in Deighton.

Three youths threw a pram at a train from a bridge in Stockton and a group of youths entered a tunnel, diverting a train because police could not be sure what they had left behind.

This is the reality of vandalism on the railways, another huge problem for the chaotic network. Acts of trespass and vandalism are the biggest threat to the safety of rail passengers; there is one incident every 15 minutes across the network and it gets worse during school holidays. There have been five child fatalities this year already.

In October, just days after the Hatfield derailment, a passenger train hit a concrete block placed on the line by vandals. No one was hurt but the train was held up for more than an hour afterwards. In July, two girls, Kymberley Allcock, eight, and Sophie George, seven, were killed by a Lincoln to Aberystwyth train as they played on a railway bridge.

The health and safety executive annual report shows that 55% of train incidents are due to acts of vandalism and last month the chief inspector of railways warned that incidence of vandalism and trespass was on the increase. It now costs around £260m a year.

PC Tom Lake has been with the transport police in Newcastle for more than 20 years. He and his colleagues are constantly frustrated by persistent vandals and trespassers.

As he drives along the side of a railway track running between Newcastle and Sunderland he spots a youth on a scrambler bike riding up and down the rails. The 18-year-old thinks it is fun and he is oblivious to the danger.

When the police get hold of him the boy is aggressive and cheeky. He says: "It wasn't me. It must have been somebody else on another bike."

Behind him, four woolly-hatted teenagers are full of bravado. As the officers walk away, the boys pick up stones and begin throwing them into the air, just missing the officers. As the car drives off they throw more stones then stick their fingers up in defiance. Vandals can be difficult to catch and difficult to police.

PC Lake says: "In the holidays, they get bored and end up having a go at the trains.

"A lot of them don't realise a train cannot stop, that it's not a car and it cannot overtake. Basically the thing will kill you and there's no discussion about it."

The constable is graphic when he describes the impact a train can have on the human body. Another testament to this is the box in the boot of his car with its torches, search gear, plastic gloves, body bags, exhibit bags and smell masks.

He says: "I would prefer to report somebody than to have to pick their bits up and tell their families. These kids just want to see what putting a stone on the line or something like that can do, not realising what it can do. For years and years the railways were an easy target. They never think of the dangerous side of it or the money involved. They get a thrill out of seeing the concrete or the trolley smashed to bits and they don't realise that the train can be thrown off its tracks."

Further up the line, two kids are running back and forward, throwing stones at nothing in particular. They scarper as they see the bright orange jackets of the transport police.

All along the side of the line you can see what gets dumped at, and sometimes on, the railway. There are fridge freezers, telegraph poles, shopping trolleys, pieces of concrete, a garden chair, a rusty old bike. Padlocks on gates have been jemmied and people nip back and forward by way of a shortcut, making trespass the most prevalent offence. "When children see adults doing it, they think it is OK to do the same," says PC Lake.

In 1999-2000, there were 4,495 reported offences of stone throwing and 6,129 offences of criminal damage and malicious mischief in England, Scotland and Wales. These offences, however, are taken too lightly, according to PC Lake and his colleagues. "Trespass and vandalism is looked at by some people as a tuppence ha'penny offence," he says.

In an attempt to get the figures down and make people realise the real dangers of the railway, the transport police have launched Operation Scarecrow, which is aimed at catching and prosecuting vandals and trespassers.

Various measures are used including patrolling the network by helicopter fitted with thermal-imaging equipment.

webTitle: Karan to lead French tycoon's fashion house

fields.headline: Karan to lead French tycoon's fashion house
fields.trailText: A week after losing Alexander McQueen to his arch rival, the flamboyant French businessman Bernard Arnault yesterday unveiled a surprise transatlantic replacement for the cockney couturier: US designer Donna Karan.
fields.body:
A week after losing Alexander McQueen to his arch rival, the flamboyant French businessman Bernard Arnault yesterday unveiled a surprise transatlantic replacement for the cockney couturier: US designer Donna Karan.

Mr Arnault's luxury goods firm LVMH, which owns Louis Vuitton, Dior, Givenchy, Moet et Chandon, Veuve Cliquot, Guerlain, Christian Lacroix, Hennessy, Kenzo, Fendi, Loewe and Chateau d'Yquem, is to spend some £400m on the US fashion house and its trademarks like DKNY.

"Donna Karan International has excellent potential growth internationally as a global luxury lifestyle brand as part of the LVMH fashion group," LVMH said in an announcement that predictably sent its share price soaring, adding that Karan would remain chief designer.

The move is the latest to shake the high fashion world and comes just days after the elegant Mr Arnault's pugnacious rival, Francois Pinault, lured McQueen away from his post as chief stylist at Givenchy to Gucci, the celebrated Italian brand now owned by Mr Pinault's PPR conglomerate.

Yves Carcelle, president of LVMH's fashion group, said the investment - the largest to date in the US fashion industry - aimed to "capitalise on Ms Karan's creativity and talents as a lifestyle designer".

Founded in 1984, her company sells an upmarket vision of contemporary New York fashion in the form of men's and women's clothing lines, shoes and sportswear. It also lends its name to a range of desirable accessories including sunglasses, perfumes and lingerie. But if DKNY may seem chic to some, City analysts wondered whether the label really fitted the rest of LVMH's luxury brands.

"I don't think it makes sense," said one. "For a company that can't make all the other brands it owns profitable, to go and buy another one doesn't strike me as particularly sensible. It's not as if they bought Tiffany or anything really prestigious."

Possibly reflecting this perceived lack of class, LVMH is paying only £120m for DK itself, roughly a quarter of annual sales.

That compares with two or three times yearly revenue for most such deals in the fashion sector.

Mr Arnault has led his company to a string of acquisitions as it battles with its arch-rival, Mr Pinault's PPR, which owns a 42% stake in Gucci that is being disputed in the Amsterdam courts. The PPR stable also includes Printemps department stores, the La Redoute mail order firm, the Fnac music, electronics and books chain, Chateau Latour, Boucheron luxury jewellers, Christie's auctioneers, Samsonite, a first division French football club and the Vail ski resorts in Colorado.

LVMH insiders say Mr Arnault was relatively unconcerned by the fact that he and Mr Pinault are in competition for the title of France's richest man, an honour currently held the LVMH chief with an estimated personal fortune of £1.2bn.

Mr Arnault, from a comfortable middle class background in the north of France, probably enjoys more of a social advantage than his more humble Breton rival - but that is offset by Mr Pinault's spectacular talent for daring deal-making.

From hips to risk of going bust

Before the disastrous stock market flotation of her company in 1996, Donna Karan was most famous for her hips.

"She is unique among female designers," Vogue magazine once said, "not because she is the only one of them not to have perfect size 10 hips, but because she is the only one who points that out. Constantly."

The 52-year old's label, launched in 1984, became a success on the New York catwalk for selling designer clothes for a more realistic female figure.

Karan was worn by 80s businesswomen, who wanted clothes fit for the boardroom that were neither demeaning or frumpy. Her evening wear became a favourite with her celebrity friends, including Barbra Streisand and Demi Moore, the latter appearing with Bruce Willis in an advertising campaign.

When the flotation came, her company looked poised for financial success. In 1988, Karan had launched DKNY, the cheaper range that started a wave of designer mid-price collections.

Seen as a strong rival to Ralph Lauren and Calvin Klein, the labels appeared famous enough to expand into lucrative areas of jeans, perfume and cosmetics. But after a money-draining attempt to keep the lines in-house, Karan ended up licensing out the brand to other companies.

In the lifestyle-obsessed world of fashion, any problems shatter the illusion of easy luxury that designers like Karan work so hard to cultivate. This has meant that, for the last four years, public attention has shifted away from the quality of her clothes, which continue to impress fashion insiders at the shows.

The fiercely independent New Yorker must be hoping that, with the sale to LVMH, she finds stability and can return to concentrating on her products.

 Charlie Porter, deputy fashion editor

webTitle: Leader: Who is behind the Saudi bomb attacks?

fields.headline: Explosive questions
fields.standfirst:
Who is behind the Saudi bomb attacks?

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Who is behind the Saudi bomb attacks?
fields.body:
Suspicions arising from a spate of mysterious car bomb attacks on British citizens in Saudi Arabia spread outwards like ripples across a pool. The fact that the incidents have been relatively small-scale is no consolation for David Brown, the latest, mutilated victim, or for the relatives of Christopher Rodway who was killed last month. Perhaps eager for political reasons to counter the obvious thought that terrorists are at work, Saudi officials have suggested that personal grudges, bad debts or illegal rackets may be to blame - and they arrested an American after the earlier explosions in Riyadh.

But the most recent device, planted over 200 miles away in Al-Kohbar, shattered hopes that the bombings have been halted. The British nationality of the targets apart, there is no proven connection between the attacks. The Foreign Office has warned the 26,000 Britons in Saudi Arabia to be vigilant; and Scotland Yard has despatched a team of investigators. But no one seems to know why the attacks are happening. And no one admits responsibility.

One possibility is that Mr Brown was randomly targeted as a symbolic representative of western influence in strictly Islamic Saudi Arabia. He works for Coca-Cola; other British victims were connected with Boeing and with the US and British-staffed military hospital in Riyadh. Coca-Cola, with other US firms, is currently facing a consumer boycott prompted by US support of Israel. The Saudi government has taken an unusually tough line in support of the Palestinians during the recent fighting. In broad terms, anti-western feeling in the Arab world is running high. And the continued presence of US and British forces in the kingdom 10 years after the Gulf war is controversial. All or any of this may have incited a handful of fundamentalist radicals to violence. But even if that is so, the question remains: why target the British rather than the 40,000-strong American community?

Casting even further afield for answers, some point to the US and British war of attrition with Iraq; to Osama bin Laden, the Saudi renegade millionaire holed up in Afghanistan who has now been linked to recent attacks on a US warship and the British embassy in Yemen; even to Iranian hardliners critical of the Saudi regime. Whatever the motive, the Saudi authorities must now act swiftly and firmly to stop these outrages and catch the perpetrators.

webTitle: Leader: NHS nursing army needs more pay

fields.headline: Fair and affordable
fields.standfirst: But a key NHS group needs more pay
fields.trailText: But a key NHS group needs more pay.
fields.body:
After Saturday's splash headline on the Times front page - "Nurses win 8% pay rise ahead of election" - there was bound to be disappointment yesterday. Some senior nurses, sisters and charge nurses, in the top four grades will (with the new cost of living supplement and inner-London weighting) get increases of 8% or more starting in April.

At the bottom end of the pay scale, yesterday's report from the pay review body expresses "particular concern" for nurse auxiliaries, calling for the new pay system currently under negotiation to take on board their problems as "a matter or urgency". But the main nursing army - some 430,000 or more - will only receive a 3.7% pay rise.

The special rises for senior nurses - outside London they are getting 5% - is needed. As yesterday's report notes, the structure of the profession has historically been too flat, with differentials that are much too small and which fail to recognise the real differences in skills and responsibility that exist. Under the government's 10-year modernisation plan, the 70,000 nurses in senior grades will have a crucial role in breaking down current demarcation boundaries between the medical professions. They will be expected to assume more responsibility, such as drug prescribing, in Labour's more responsive and flexible health service. It was crucial these more experienced nurses were retained.

But clearly this award is not going to generate "a winter of contentment" among the main army. Health department spin doctors have shot themselves in their own feet. By building up expectations in Saturday's papers, they guaranteed yesterday's disenchantment. Yet one year's award cannot be looked at in isolation. Two years ago, newly qualified nurses had a 12% pay rise and last year staff nurses received 8%. There are limits to such big rises.

To its credit, the Royal College of Nursing acknowledged the good news in this year's award and its complexity. For the third year in a row, the pay review body's recommendations are being being implemented in full.

The NHS will face a serious challenge in meeting its target of 20,000 extra nurses by 2004, but the current 22,000 vacancies is only a 5% shortfall. The professions allied to medicine - occupational therapists, physiotherapists, chiropodists - have a far larger hole to fill. Their salary scale starts a few hundred pounds above nursing, but has a ceiling way below senior nurses. Yet, ironically, it is these professionals who are the key players in ensuring the NHS gets through the winter without a trolley scandal. These are the professionals - along with social workers - who can ensure elderly patients do not block hospital beds, by providing care packages and home adaptations that allow them to be discharged.

The health service is facing a much more competitive market. Gone are the days when women only had two main professions to choose from: teaching or nursing. The life of a nurse has become more stressful in a hospital system which discharges patients much more quickly. Patients are sicker and need more intensive nursing. Pay is going to have to reflect these extra strains, but employment conditions are almost as important.

The NHS has been notoriously slow in introducing more flexible working hours and childcare facilities. That is a major reason why 70,000 former nurses declined to return and why thousands more joined nursing agencies, where they could demand more flexible arrangements. That cost the NHS £340m last year. Time for change is long overdue.

webTitle: Bomb found on Milan Cathedral roof

fields.headline: Terrorists strike
fields.standfirst: Bomb found on Milan Cathedral roof
fields.trailText: Italian police officers defused a bomb placed on the roof of the Duomo cathedral in Milan yesterday which was was timed to go off early this morning.
fields.body:
Italian police officers defused a bomb placed on the roof of the Duomo cathedral in Milan yesterday which was was timed to go off early this morning.

A cathedral worker raised the alarm at midday after spotting an abandoned sack leaning against a gargoyle on the northern end of the roof terrace.

A clock was set to detonate the 1kg (2.2lb) of explosive powder at 3am, avoiding casualties but damaging the 15th-century masterpiece of hundreds of spires and statues.

Around 130 tourists on the roof were evacuated while a bomb disposal team moved in to make safe what it described as a crude device.

Terrorists are suspected, but the police thought it was unlikely to be the work of the Red Brigade, whose shootings and bombings terrorised Italy in the 1970s and 80s.

Last June a knapsack with a crude bomb was discovered in the basilica of Sant'Ambrogio. A previously unknown anarchist group called International Solidarity claimed responsibility and demanded the release of jailed comrades.

Yesterday's bomb could have exploded prematurely but the blast would have been too small to cause serious injury, an investigator said.

An interior ministry undersecretary, Massimo Brutti, told the senate in Rome that the investigation, to be led by Stefano Dambruoso, would explore all avenues. Mr Dambruoso is a specialist in terrorism and intimidation.

Some politicians speculated that the bomb was intended to disrupt campaigning for the the elections in the spring

The Duomo, so huge it can be seen from the Alps, was begun in 1386 and made with the finest marble. Its mix of gothic, renaissance and baroque styles lures thousands of sightseers every day.

"A grave and irresponsible act," the archbishop of Milan, Cardinal Carlo Maria Martini, said.

"It ... offends all those who search for peace and love the city."

The bomb was in plain sight near the terrace's lifts, at a spot where tourists would have been likely to walk past, Italian news services said.

webTitle: K-For Germans 'using under-age prostitutes'

fields.headline: K-For Germans 'using under-age prostitutes'
fields.trailText: The German army was embarrassed yesterday by allegations that members of its K-For contingent in Macedonia regularly visit under-age prostitutes.
fields.body:
The German army was embarrassed yesterday by allegations that members of its K-For contingent in Macedonia regularly visit under-age prostitutes.

The claim, made in a documentary shown by ARD television on Sunday, was abruptly dismissed by the defence ministry in Berlin as "unconfirmed".

In the film a Bundeswehr soldier alleged that colleagues visited brothels in the Maceonian city of Tetovo where they slept with prostitutes aged 16 and under. He said their superior officers were aware of the visits.

The documentary included an interview with a brothel owner from Tetovo who said that since the arrival of K-For troops in the region two years ago the number of brothels had spiralled.

The soldier admitted sleeping with a 16-year-old Bulgarian prostitute, who was also interviewed.

She said she had had hundreds of German soldiers as clients.

The defence ministry spokesman pointed out that prostitution was illegal in Macedonia, adding: "We have no means of responding to possible illegal activities in civilian areas or of launching an inquiry into the allegations. This is purely a matter for the local authorities."

This is purely a matter for the local authorities."

webTitle: Poll dates put French in a spin

fields.headline: Poll dates put French in a spin
fields.trailText: The first real shots in France's 2002 presidential election campaign will be fired today as the divided national assembly debates an issue as complex as it is crucial: the date on which the French should go to the polls.
fields.body:
The first real shots in France's 2002 presidential election campaign will be fired today as the divided national assembly debates an issue as complex as it is crucial: the date on which the French should go to the polls.

Six motions in favour of changing the timetable have been tabled because President Jacques Chirac's early dissolution of parliament in 1997 means that for the first time in modern French history general elections should be held two months before the presidential election.

Those seeking a change, mainly leftwingers, say that is putting the cart before the horse: how can voters be expected to accept or reject a government programme before deciding which political direction they prefer?

"The interests of democracy and of the republic are at stake," the Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, said. "What we propose is to re-establish a situation that is normal, logical, and coherent with the principles of the way our republic is supposed to function."

The unspoken political point behind that argument is that Mr Chirac hopes the conservative parties will win the parliamentary elections, due in March, thus discrediting Mr Jospin's campaign for the presidency in May.

But rightwingers opposed to delaying the parliamentary elections by two months have denounced the motions as a political manoeuvre by Mr Jospin to boost his chance of beating Mr Chirac in the presidential election without damaging the left's prospects in the general election.

"This is a measure of circumstance, of convenience, which does not seem to me very suitable given that it does not respect the principle according to which one cannot suddenly change the rules in a democracy so close to the date," Mr Chirac said last week.

Constitutional experts predict mayhem if the electoral calendar is not reversed. The candidates for the presidency, they point out, must be approved by a total of 500 MPs - who may not even be elected in time if the dates are not changed.

The debate has divided deputes along unaccustomed lines, the opposition RPR drawing strong support from two key players in Mr Jospin's leftwing coalition: the Greens and the Communists. Both fear that voters will see a change of dates as underhand.

"I am very concerned that any such change could be interpreted first as a sleight-of-hand and secondly as greatly increasing the status of the president vis-a-vis parliament," the Communist transport minister, Jean-Claude Gayssot, said yesterday.

But the prime minister is assured of help from an equally unexpected source: the centre-right UDF led by former president Valéry Giscard-d'Estaing. Observers say that as many as 35 UDF deputies are determined to resist pressure from their opposition partners, Mr Chirac's RPR, and side with the Socialists.

Mr Giscard, the former UDF prime minister Raymond Barre, and the party's current leader, François Bayrou, all back change.

"The choice of president is the choice that gives France its direction, and it should naturally come first," Mr Giscard wrote in Le Monde.

So political has the essentially constitutional debate become that Jean-Louis Debré, leader of the RPR in parliament, called it "a trap designed to implode the opposition" - a view shared by the radical Green Danny Cohn-Bendit, who said all on the left should recognise it as such and applaud Mr Jospin for so successfully torpedoing the right.

The question, which Mr Jospin hopes will be settled by a vote before February, arises because the constitution of the Fifth Republic does not adequately foresee the possibility of a president and a government of opposing political hue.

The electoral code stipulates that "the national assembly's powers end on the first Tuesday in the April of the fifth year following its election", while the constitution states that the presidential mandate expires precisely seven years - now reduced to five for the next president - after his accession.

webTitle: Paddington crash driver could not see signal

fields.headline: Paddington crash driver could not see signal
fields.standfirst:
Report finds multiple causes for 31-death accident

Special report: transport in Britain
www.lgri.org.uk
Ladbroke Grove inquiry
www.hse.gov.uk/hsehome.htm
Health and Safety Executive
fields.trailText: Signals in the area of the Paddington rail crash were "exceptionally difficult" for train drivers to read and did not comply with industry standards, the health and safety executive said yesterday.
fields.body:
Signals in the area of the Paddington rail crash were "exceptionally difficult" for train drivers to read and did not comply with industry standards, the health and safety executive said yesterday.

In its report into the October 1999 disaster the HSE said that the 31 people killed in the crash would not have died had automatic train protection been fitted to the Thames train which passed signal 109 at red.

The findings back up earlier conclusions that a combination of dazzling sunshine, an inexperienced driver and a "fundamentally flawed" track layout caused the tragedy. It is thought that Michael Hodder, the driver of the Thames train, was deceived by a "phantom aspect" - a red light which appeared to be amber - before he crashed into the oncoming Great Western express.

Experts who had looked at signals in the Paddington area, in particular signal 109, had concluded that "the complexity of the layout and signal gantries, the range of approaches and the obscuration of the signal aspects by overhead line equipment present an exceptionally difficult signal reading task", yesterday's HSE report concluded.

It added that while the height of the signals on the gantry that carried signal 109 broadly met requirements "many of the other signals in the Paddington area on the approach to signal 109 are at a height in excess of that permitted by Railway Group Standards - although when the signals were designed and installed, no maximum height was specified."

Signals needed to be aligned to maximise their readability. This was particularly important on east-west lines such as those around Paddington where a low sun can come into play, the report added.

The crash on October 5, 1999, left 31 people dead, including Mr Hodder, 31, who went through signal 109.

His train, heading for Bedwyn in Wiltshire, travelled another 700 metres before colliding almost head-on at Ladbroke Grove with the Great Western train which had started out from Cheltenham Spa station in Gloucestershire.

The HSE report said there were "no indications that Mr Hodder deliberately set out to pass signal 109 at red", adding "that any acts or omissions by him were just one group of contributory factors".

"No faults were found," says the report. "Had ATP been fitted and operational on the 165 [Mr Hodder's train] there would not have been a collision."

The public inquiry had heard how Thames Trains management had refused to spend £5.26 million on safety measures, including ATP, which would link a train's brakes automatically with the signals - even though its trains were designed and built for such use.

Signal 109 had been passed at danger seven other times over five years and was among the 22 signals most passed at danger. Mr Hodder was not an experienced driver, having only qualified 13 days before the accident. His competency certificate was issued following assessment of his route knowledge. This assessment did not involve questions about the Paddington-Ladbroke Grove section.

The HSE report described how staff at the signal control centre in Slough, Berkshire, tried to prevent the crash once they realised a collision was imminent. An emergency stop message would have had to have been sent within 15 seconds and points would have had to be changed within about 12 seconds of the train going through the red signal.

Even changing to danger the signal ahead of the Great Western train was "ineffective" as the GW train was going too fast to stop in time.

The report criticised the lack of opportunities for signalling staff to practise their responses to signals passed at danger, for example by simulator training.

Steve Walker, the HSE's assistant chief inspector of railways, later told a news conference that the HSE would make a decision early in the new year whether or not to instigate any legal proceedings under the Health and Safety at Work Act. He said signal 109 was still not in use and that Railtrack was looking at significant signalling changes in the area.

Mick Rix, general secretary of the train drivers' union, Aslef, welcomed the HSE findings about the lack of proper train protection systems and poor signalling in the area.

"The industry should turn its attention to proper train protection and upgrade the infrastructure, rather than seeking to blame driver error for this terrible tragedy," he said.

Yesterday's HSE report follows its three interim reports into the accident.

It contained no recommendations. They will come when Lord Cullen produces his report after the public inquiry into the crash.

webTitle: 'It girl' Tara to make her debut as solo pianist

fields.headline: 'It girl' Tara to make her debut as solo pianist
fields.trailText: In one of the more unlikely virtuoso performances of the year Tara Palmer-Tomkinson, the It girl more famous for her fast living, high spending excesses, will make her debut as a solo pianist with the National Symphony Orchestra on Thursday night.
fields.body:
In one of the more unlikely virtuoso performances of the year Tara Palmer-Tomkinson, the It girl more famous for her fast living, high spending excesses, will make her debut as a solo pianist with the National Symphony Orchestra on Thursday night.

Ms Palmer-Tomkinson will perform four classical "lollypops" when she takes to the stage at Queen Elizabeth Hall in London in aid of the Chemical Dependency Centre.

According to Anne Colis, the joint artistic director of the National Symphony Orchestra, Ms Palmer-Tomkinson, who fought a well documented battle against cocaine addiction, is excited about her first live solo performance.

"We had the first rehearsal on Sunday night and Tara was just so excited and the orchestra loved her as well. She really is a very good amateur player and is not going to disgrace herself at all.

"She told me that playing with an orchestra was a better buzz than any drug, and that the feeling you get when they reach a crescendo is like nothing else."

Ms Palmer-Tomkinson has been playing the piano since the age of six, but has returned to it with renewed gusto since her rehabilitation.

"Since she got out of therapy I think it is something she finds very soothing," said Ms Colis, who has been planning the concert for more than a year.

"The aim is very much to try to breathe some life back into the live concert scene. I had the idea after seeing Woody Allen playing the clarinet and thought to myself there must be a lot of celebrities out there who must dream of playing with an orchestra. I saw Tara playing on TV and decided she would be perfect. When I phoned her she said yes immediately."

Bach's Ave Maria and one of Chopin's preludes will be among the vignettes she will perform.

The orchestra, made up of freelance musicians from London, is aiming a little higher for its next star turn.

"We were talking in the pub and decided that now Bill Clinton, who plays the saxophone, has got a bit more time on his hands, he would be perfect," said Ms Colis.

webTitle: Holiday travel outlook is grim

fields.headline: Holiday travel outlook is grim
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: People travelling home for Christmas are being warned they face a festive season of misery, overcrowding and delays on the roads and railways.
fields.body:
People travelling home for Christmas are being warned they face a festive season of misery, overcrowding and delays on the roads and railways.

Motoring and rail organisations are advising travellers to plan ahead as much as possible.

Last night rail watchdog groups warned that speed restrictions meant far fewer trains would be running this Christmas, particularly on cross-country routes.

"Most of the speed restrictions are still in force and GNER has had to reduce the number of trains it runs," said Rail Passenger Council spokesman Scott Richmond.

"This means they are running 40% of their Christmas timetable. There is going to be massive overcrowding and the same applies to other high speed train operators such as Virgin and First Great Western. It will be standing room only for many on long-distance journeys."

The British Airports Authority said it expected this holiday season to be far busier than last year. An extra 200,000 domestic passengers took to the air last month to beat the crisis on the railways, the authority said yesterday.

Train passenger numbers fell following the Hatfield crash on October 5. Subsequent introduction of speed limits saw many more people use alternative transport.

But George Muir, director general of the Association of Train Operating Companies, said the train services were doing their best within the limitations set by Railtrack.

Railtrack was continuing its programme of track replacement and upgrading over the holiday period and passengers should notice an improvement from the new year, he added.

webTitle: Farming job losses on increase

fields.headline: Farming job losses on increase
fields.standfirst: Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: The farming industry was yesterday reeling from figures which showed 24,000 workers had left in the past year.
fields.body:
The farming industry was yesterday reeling from figures which showed 24,000 workers had left in the past year.

The statistics from the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food showed an increase of 7,000 job losses over the previous year.

The National Farmers' Union said the industry had been left "punch drunk" by the losses and called for urgent government support for financially crippled farmers.

The losses were revealed in the agricultural and horticultural census for June this year.

The total number of cattle fell by 2.9%, the dairy breeding herd fell by 5.1%, the beef breeding herd dropped by 6.4%, the number of pigs was reduced by 11.7% and the number of sheep and lambs declined by 5.5%.

NFU president, Ben Gill, said: "These figures are a dire reflection of the continuing desperate situation in British agriculture. They illustrate that the crisis has cut so deeply into the heart of farming that in spite of the survival instincts of our farmers many simply cannot carry on.

"They are doing all they can to hang on to their businesses."

Mr Gill said that an NFU audit last year showed 62% of farmers were working more than 61 hours a week.

He added: "It is a small wonder that the ethos of working longer for less is crippling the industry.

"The industry is punch drunk from the constant bombardment of paperwork, regulation and red tape.

"What we need is for the government and the public to demonstrate that they value and support British agriculture and the protection of their countryside."

Press Association

webTitle: Comment: Dave Hill on yob culture

fields.headline: Turn the yobs back into boys
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Dave Hill: I cannot live with, tolerate or bear the abject failure of the top boys of New Labour to face up to where the core of the yob culture really lies.
fields.body:
Some things I can live with. I can live with this nervy government throwing a few bones to the fickle dogs of Middle England, whose votes will be needed next May. I can live - at least, at three o'clock on too many mornings - with the thought of a carload of cops descending on the swaggering, guffawing young men who roam past my east London home, waking my children and putting fear in the hearts of elderly folk down the street. I can even live with the prospect of Blair, Straw and company boasting about how big and hard they are for banging up a few more lads for acting big and hard.

But as the parent of three sons, two of them around the same age as poor, dead Damilola Taylor, I really cannot live with, tolerate or bear the abject failure of the top boys of New Labour to face up to where the core of the yob culture really lies.

"Yob" may be "boy" spelt backwards, but the ministers most responsible for the welfare of all the young are too smug, stupid, or maybe just too scared to face up to the deepest implications of destructive aggression among schoolboys and young men. Far easier to take refuge in the soft option rhetoric of law and order than to address, or even ask, the really tough questions thrown up by knifings in back alleys or boozing in the streets: questions about where the irresponsibility, amorality and sometimes chilling cruelty of young males actually comes from, what the factors are that help foster it, and how these aspects of our society can most effectively be challenged and changed. And behind these lies the hardest question of all: what do we want our young men to be for?

New Labour's failure to look this issue in the eye lies behind its inability to come to anything like terms with all the other dimensions of "the great boy problem" that currently so preoccupies society. We live in a world where the old models of manhood are increasingly redundant and look ever more absurd, yet the government seems almost as eager as the opposition to resurrect the notion that boys must be drilled, urged and cajoled back into masculine clothes which might have fitted their forefathers.

Look more closely at the yob culture and what we see are young men not behaving simply badly, but in precisely the sorts of ways they hope will win them manhood's spurs. Just like the politicians they strut and they pose, frantically competing to be the most bellicose -who's got the most bottle, who will be the first to chuck a chair at the police? Look at boys in general, including those who are not yobs, and the same psychological dynamics dominate. As the shrewdest gender researchers have shown time and again, boys grow up policing themselves and one another with neurotic dedication, deriding and marginalising any human quality or perception within their own ranks that might be seen as - oh horror! - "feminine" and therefore "gay".

The parallel with politicians holds damningly here too. Whether by design or habit, Hague has done his utmost to position himself as more of a man than Blair: the military haircut, the judo, the 14 pints of beer, the gritty "commonsense" revolt against the effete equivocations of the wine bar wimp. He's made himself look daft, of course, but Blair's edgy anyway. The distinctly mixed reception to his brief paternity leave showed what a risky business loosening the male straitjacket can be. The rules don't allow a man to be both nurturing and aggressive, caring and competitive, "masculine" and "feminine" at the same time. You can get hammered for it, mate: just look at the hatred that is heaped on David Beckham.

Yet the hostile reactions triggered by such transgressions vividly expose the issues that must be raised if boys and young men are to be happier, and communities are to be spared their worst behaviour. We have to ask why there is such fierce resistance to a boy or man demonstrating a whole range of human qualities and aptitudes. We have to ask out loud why learning how to be "masculine" seems to mean almost nothing except being seen to triumph over "feminine" contamination.

The answers to such questions do not lie with those plying tired, traditional answers. Nor do they lie in fatuous debates about the pros and cons of "feminising" men, the better to prepare them for the needs of modern industry. Rather, it's a case of acknowledging potential - the potential of any boy to be a rich and varied human being and granting him permission to explore it to the full.

Look at boys in general, including those who are not yobs, and the same psychological dynamics dominate. As the shrewdest gender researchers have shown time and again, boys grow up policing themselves and one another with neurotic dedication, deriding and marginalising any human quality or perception within their own ranks that might be seen as - oh horror! - "feminine" and therefore "gay". The parallel with politicians holds damningly here too. Whether by design or habit, Hague has done his utmost to position himself as more of a man than Blair: the military haircut, the judo, the 14 pints of beer, the gritty "commonsense" revolt against the effete equivocations of the wine bar wimp. He's made himself look daft, of course, but Blair's edgy anyway. The distinctly mixed reception to his brief paternity leave showed what a risky business loosening the male straitjacket can be. The rules don't allow a man to be both nurturing and aggressive, caring and competitive, "masculine" and "feminine" at the same time. You can get hammered for it, mate: just look at the hatred that is heaped on David Beckham. Yet the hostile reactions triggered by such transgressions vividly expose the issues that must be raised if boys and young men are to be happier, and communities are to be spared their worst behaviour. We have to ask why there is such fierce resistance to a boy or man demonstrating a whole range of human qualities and aptitudes. We have to ask out loud why learning how to be "masculine" seems to mean almost nothing except being seen to triumph over "feminine" contamination. The answers to such questions do not lie with those plying tired, traditional answers. Nor do they lie in fatuous debates about the pros and cons of "feminising" men, the better to prepare them for the needs of modern industry. Rather, it's a case of acknowledging potential - the potential of any boy to be a rich and varied human being and granting him permission to explore it to the full. comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Analysis: The NHS and public satisfaction

fields.headline: Can't get no satisfaction
fields.standfirst: Polls that purport to show how satisfied people are with the NHS may simply be telling us instead which party the respondents prefer
fields.trailText: "Labour gambles on modest rise for nurses", said the Guardian yesterday - and so it turned out when the pay review recommendations were published. But was it a gamble? What if people's satisfaction, or lack of it, with the NHS has little to do with how much money is spent on doctors, nurses and hospitals but is much more a "political" judgment related to feelings about the party in power?
fields.body:
"Labour gambles on modest rise for nurses", said the Guardian yesterday - and so it turned out when the pay review recommendations were published. But was it a gamble? What if people's satisfaction, or lack of it, with the NHS has little to do with how much money is spent on doctors, nurses and hospitals but is much more a "political" judgment related to feelings about the party in power?

Apart from questions about voting intentions, the most commonly asked opinion poll question is about (dis)satisfaction with the NHS. Both, of course, are about politics. The entanglement goes further: politics is about the NHS and vice-versa.

A typical "satisfaction" question was posed in a survey carried out by Mori on behalf of the British Medical Association at the end of November. Of those asked the question "Overall, how satisfied or dissatisfied are you with the NHS?", 28% said fairly or very dissatisfied. The BMA made much of the fact that these figures were 11 percentage points higher than in a poll carried out in 1998.

Naturally, the Department of Health chose to emphasise the 58% who expressed satisfaction. However, other polls carried out this year have suggested that two-thirds of the population believe that the NHS had not improved since Tony Blair became prime minister.

The BMA poll also revealed something about the link between politics and the NHS. Unprompted, three-quarters of those polled thought either the current or the last government was responsible for the current state of the NHS. The BMA's interpretation of their opinion poll results was, unsurprisingly, that the NHS needs more doctors and more money (and also by implication that doctors need more money).

But we know that opinion poll results are very sensitive to the exact wording of questions, the order in which they are posed and whether interviews are carried out face to face or over the telephone. We know it is important to be able to tie in respondents' personal characteristics (age, party allegiance) in order to interpret satisfaction results. It is also necessary to track trends in opinions over time rather than to construct over-elaborate interpretations of one-off polls.

The best trend data on NHS satisfaction is produced by the British Social Attitudes survey, with data going back to 1983. The graph displays the results - the survey was not done every year, which explains the gaps. Latest results - for 1999 - show that dissatisfaction with the way the NHS is run fell from an all time high of 50% in 1996 to 33% in 1999, its lowest level for more than a decade. But this happened after the notorious 1998-99 winter of NHS discontent. What is going on?

One interpretation is that these results reflected a honeymoon period for the Labour government. When the figures are broken down by political allegiance, it is Labour supporters who account for the greatest decrease in dissatisfaction - from 60% in 1996 to 31% in 1999. The fall in dissatisfaction among Tory supporters over the same period was just two percentage points.

So, as the BMA poll showed, asking people how they feel about the running of the NHS turns out to be as much a question about the performance of the government of the day as it is about the performance of the health service. So the chart does mirror the changing economic and political fortunes of both the NHS and those charged with its stewardship.

Dissatisfaction rose sub stantially during the 1980s, coinciding with historically very low real-terms increases in NHS funding between 1983 and 1989. Then, following the unusually large injection of cash for three years in succession from 1990, dissatisfaction fell. The cycle shifts during the mid 1990s, when the Major government entered the 1997 general elec tion following one of the lowest real increases in NHS funding for many years. Dissatisfaction with the NHS had rocketed and Labour was subsequently elected.

However, the fall in dissatisfaction last year does not fit easily with this interpretation based on NHS funding. NHS spending in 1998 and 1999 effectively continued the previous government's parsimony, and yet dissatisfaction fell in both years.

Whatever the reason for the ebbs and flows in dissatisfaction, it is by no means certain that the mere knowledge of money being spent on the health service - without visible signs of improvement - will be enough to convince the public that the service is being turned around. The BMA poll certainly suggests otherwise. And, significantly, British Social Attitudes shows that dissatisfaction towards specific components of the NHS (GPs, inpatient, outpatient care, and so on) has remained more or less the same throughout the past few years.

More generally, questions about satisfaction are easy to ask; perhaps too easy. The media and the prevailing political climate play a role in shaping and influencing overall perceptions. If we really want to get close to what people feel about the health service, it is much better to ask questions about their personal experience of it: "how long did you wait to see your GP?", rather than "are you satisfied with your GP?"

In the meantime, if you are stopped on the street by pollsters and asked to rate your satisfaction with the health service, try cutting through to the heart of the matter by telling them how you plan to vote in the general election.

 Jo-Ann Mulligan and John Appleby are at the King's Fund.

j.mulligan@kehf.org.uk

webTitle: Police fear hits from Seoul's suicide web

fields.headline: Police fear hits from Seoul's suicide web
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The South Korean police are investigating a spate of web-assisted suicides which has raised disturbing questions about the internet in one of the most wired countries in the world.
fields.body:
The South Korean police are investigating a spate of web-assisted suicides which has raised disturbing questions about the internet in one of the most wired countries in the world.

Yesterday they arrested a man of 26 for his alleged part in a double suicide at a motel in Kangnung, on the east coast.

The suspect, named only as Mr Kim, is reported to have met the two victims through a website which offers advice on how to commit suicide. The police say he may have provided the poison they used.

Detectives said the man also used the internet to take out a contract on himself and a suicidal woman friend. Their would-be killer, a Mr Yoon, was unable to fulfil the contract because he was arrested on Friday for a separate and "successful" contract suicide arranged over the net.

For about £560, it is alleged, Mr Yoon stabbed his victim in the stomach in a Seoul station car park on December 12. He told the police that he thought he was helping the victim.

The revelation that people are using the internet to help themselves - and others - to commit suicide has shocked many in South Korea, where about one in three people in a population of 47m are on line.

Local reports say there are about 30 South Korean websites on suicide. The one used by Mr Kim and Mr Yoon, which contains adverts for "suicide partners", is reported to have had more than 50,000 hits.

Since the police began investigating the suicides, most of them have been closed down, although the authorities are unsure whether the law is on their side.

"It's unclear whether the operation of such sites is illegal," a prosecution official said. "So we're examining related laws and scrutinising suicide sites, as well as collecting information on similar cases overseas."

Similar sites have been operating in Japan for some time. In October last year a man and a woman killed themselves after making a suicide pact over the web. The previous year the operator of a website selling cyanide killed himself after the police questioned him about a customer's suicide.
