webTitle: Scores killed in Algerian violence

fields.headline: Scores killed in Algerian violence
fields.trailText: The killing of nearly 40 people at the weekend has brought to 200 the death toll in the holy month of Ramadan and reminded Algerians that the end of the nine years of Islamist insurgency is nowhere in sight.
fields.body:
The killing of nearly 40 people at the weekend has brought to 200 the death toll in the holy month of Ramadan and reminded Algerians that the end of the nine years of Islamist insurgency is nowhere in sight.

On Saturday night rebels wearing military uniforms burst into a boys' dormitory at a technical college and opened fire, killing 15 students and a teacher, according to hospital staff.

Guerrillas fighting for the creation of an Islamic state traditionally see the fasting month of Ramadan as the sacred period for their jihad (holy war), making it a tense and bloody time.

Since Ramadan began three weeks ago about 200 rebels, government troops and civilians have been killed, according to media reports.

The daily newspaper el Watan said a group of "terrorists" machine-gunned a bus carrying civilians, killing 15 and wounding several others, at a fake roadblock on Sunday night near the city of Tenes, 125 miles west of Algiers.

An hour later five civilians, three of them women, were shot dead by rebels in Khemis Miliana, 75 miles west of Algiers.

Breaking its customary silence on rebel violence, the official APS news agency reported the raid on the school in Medea, 55 miles south of Algiers, ending nearly two years of blackouts on security-related news in the state-controlled media.

More than 100,000 people have been killed since early 1992 in the uprising, which began after the military-backed government cancelled a general election which Islamists were poised to win.

Killings are reported almost daily, despite government peace efforts. Promising peace and reconciliation when he took office 18 months ago, President Abdelaziz Bouteflika offered an amnesty to militants not guilty of murder, bombings or rape.

About 6,000 rebels took up the offer, but the more radical Islamic Armed Group (GIA) and Daawa al Djihad (Appeal and Struggle) vowed to continue fighting.

About 4,000 armed rebels are active in small groups throughout the country, according to official estimates.

"The real danger lies in the fact that we see no concrete political or military strategy to fight terrorism," said Salima Tlemcani , an expert on security issues at el Watan.

"Where do the Algerian leaders want to lead this country?" an editorial in the newspaper asked.

"Nobody seems moved by anything anymore, nobody reacts. Algerians get killed in total indifference."

webTitle: 'Collaborators' keep quiet on apartheid

fields.headline: 'Collaborators' keep quiet on apartheid
fields.trailText: Stella Sigcau does not like to be reminded of it, but she was Africa's first female prime minister. She lasted just 86 days in office before a military coup overthrew her government in the South African "independent" black homeland of Transkei.
fields.body:
Stella Sigcau does not like to be reminded of it, but she was Africa's first female prime minister. She lasted just 86 days in office before a military coup overthrew her government in the South African "independent" black homeland of Transkei.

That was 13 years ago. Today Mrs Sigcau, who serves as minister of public works in President Thabo Mbeki's cabinet, is unusually quiet on the issue gripping South Africa: should whites apologise for apartheid?

The question is more than academic to Mrs Sigcau, because some of those who oppose a new campaign to persuade whites to admit they benefited from racial oppression ask why only one group is being asked to sign the "guilt list". They argue that the system would not have proved as durable but for the collaboration of large numbers of black people.

Many black South Africans worked for the apartheid police, army and civil service. Others served on the township councils, which were denounced and attacked by the African National Congress when it was underground.

Poorer people often faced a nearly impossible choice between collaboration and destitution, and the point at which they contributed to their own oppression was not always clear.

But there is no doubt that people such as Mrs Sigcau - who was once denounced in parliament as an "apartheid spy" - and other black people who served as homeland leaders, police chiefs and judges benefited from the oppression of their compatriots. Yet none of those who once served apartheid and now work for the ANC have seen fit to say sorry.

They include the ANC premier of the corruption-plagued Mpumalanga province, Ndaweni Mahlangu, who previously served as deputy chief minister in the Kwa-Ndebele homeland.

Among the ANC's members of parliament are mixed-race people who joined the racially segregated parliament under PW Botha, and former military officers from the black homelands.

The ANC argues that there is no need for such people to apologise because its white opponents are using the issue to justify their own refusal to admit that they benefited from an evil system.

Mrs Sigcau is a Pondo princess whose father, the late paramount chief Botha Sigcau, was the first president of Transkei after it was carved out as a corral for Xhosas by the white government. It was hardly a free country, being dependent on Pretoria for its entire budget as "foreign aid" and for the only recognition of its sovereignty other than by the other three "independent" homelands.

Transkei's citizens scraped a living as best they could from the overpopulated and overworked land, but Mrs Sigcau did not suffer. She lasted less than three months as prime minister but, by her own admission, that was long enough for her to accept a hefty bribe from the hotel and casino magnate Sol Kerzner in return for gambling concessions.

Mr Mbeki is said to keep Mrs Sigcau in his cabinet because her heritage gives her sway over Transkei's rural vote.

The ANC's spokesman, Smuts Ngonyama, makes the previously unheard-of claim that Mrs Sigcau was really an ANC underground operative, even though she has been denounced in parliament as exactly the opposite. Her office says she has no comment.

Mrs Sigcau was overthrown in 1987 by a bloodless coup by another apartheid servant who went on to prominence in the ANC.

General Bantu Holomisa was five years as Transkei's military ruler for five years then, after joining the ANC, became a deputy minister in Nelson Mandela's government.

He fell out with the party after publicly spilling the beans on Mrs Sigcau's bribe-taking. Gen Holomisa says he has nothing to apologise for.

Others in Mr Mbeki's government have also refused to say sorry.

The minister of home affairs and leader of Inkatha, Mangosuthu Buthelezi, ran the KwaZulu semi-autonomous homeland through the bloodiest years of his party's war with the ANC.

He took secret money from the apartheid government to fund the conflict, and Inkatha collaborated with the security forces in murderous attacks on unarmed township residents in the ANC's heartlands.

But he has repeatedly said that he has nothing to apologise for, and these days the ANC does not ask him to do so.

webTitle: Ecstasy honeymoon 'over for Britons'

fields.headline: Ecstasy honeymoon 'over for Britons'
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: The ecstasy honeymoon may be over for British users who have become disenchanted with the mood-changing drug that became a staple for night-club goers and ravers, researchers will suggest today.
fields.body:
The ecstasy honeymoon may be over for British users who have become disenchanted with the mood-changing drug that became a staple for night-club goers and ravers, researchers will suggest today.

British ecstasy users report fewer benefits and more drawbacks than their American counterparts. They are more likely to have criminal convictions, are typically older and have taken the drug for longer.

Yet they are also far less likely to take precautions, such as drinking plenty of non-alcoholic liquids, to reduce potential problems, according to researchers at Edgehill college of higher education, Ormskirk, Lancashire, and Liverpool John Moores University.

"British users appear to be more complacent," they will say in a paper to be presented at a conference of the British Psychological Society in London today.

The authors, Michelle Wareing, Philip Murphy and John Fisk suggest the fact that Britain set the pace for use of ecstasy as a mainstream drug may be an explanation for the differences with the US. "British users seem to have already gone through their honeymoon period and are now perhaps entering a period of disenchantment."

More than nine in 10 American users told researchers they liked to dance under the influence, compared with 73% of Britons. Britons were also more likely to report problems such as short term memory loss, lack of motivation and tiredness.

Other papers to today's conference will reveal that psychiatric problems linked to the use of recreational drugs are more prevalent among heavy ecstasy users .

webTitle: So you want to be a... Yoga teacher

fields.headline: So you want to be a...
fields.standfirst: Yoga teacher
fields.trailText: Yoga teacher
fields.body:
Excuse me Good evening

When do we start fighting? Pardon? I don't follow.

Well, we've been stretching and warming up for ages. Yes.

So when do we get down to kicking? Kicking?

Yeah. You know. Flying kicks, strangleholds and so on. <There's none of that.

What? You can't have an eastern martial art without kicking. But yoga isn't a martial art.

Whadyamean? Precisely what I say.

You mean not even chopping bricks in half? I'm afraid not.

So what is it? Yoga is an ancient discipline concerned with developing a holistic, healthy and harmonious lifestyle. It is a combination of physical and mental exercises which promote flexibility, reduce stress and increase stamina and strength.

I paid £2.50! I'm sure we can refund you.

I dunno. What else does yoga do? The word is generally translated as 'union' and the practice is intended to lead to a better balance of the body, mind and spirit. It can offer benefits that make your body stronger and healthier, and calm your mind, helping towards self-realisation.

So there's no combat yoga? Absolutely not. The most widely practised form of yoga in the west is Hatha yoga.

Hatha! Hatha! Quite. All classes should offer students a balanced programme to stretch and flex the body. Some classes may be low impact, whilst others can be very demanding. Hatha yoga includes asana (physical postures), pranayama (breath control), and deep relaxation.

How do you get to teach all that? In order to become a yoga instructor it is important to be a member of the British School of Yoga. webTitle: The teachers who are reuniting Rwanda through education

fields.headline: Learning, united
fields.standfirst: Will Woodward meets the teachers who are reuniting Rwanda through education
fields.trailText: Will Woodward meets the teachers who are reuniting Rwanda through education
fields.body:
The national exam results are just out and Stephen Rwamurangwa, headteacher of Kayonza modern secondary school, is pleased. His school, about two hours' drive east from the Rwandan capital, Kigali, has the best results of all the predominantly English-speaking schools in the country and is the 12th best overall. "Generally I would say it's down to total teacher commitment," Rwamurangwa says. Across a table in his dark, cloakroom-sized office, he adds: "I have tried to change the objectives of the school and its performance. I am proud that the school is small but it is among the best schools time and again. The students always feel they can perform better, they have confidence, they feel they can become successful."

Many of Rwamurangwa's preoccupations are recognisably those of headteachers across the world: exam results, inspection, trying to meet the demands of the curriculum. The school motto is haranira kijijuka - "struggle to achieve literacy". Emmanuel Mudidi, the education minister, who knows the head, says he is doing well in an averagely resourced school. The government has given education a central role in its reconstruction. By 2020, ministers hope, everybody should be completing six years of primary school and three years of secondary school, following a modern curriculum taught by Rwandan-trained teachers.

From classroom to state president to the international community - the UK is putting £73m into Rwanda over three years, of which £21m is earmarked for education - there is a remarkable degree of agreement about their goals. And it's good that there is, for right now the main thing, almost the only thing, Rwanda has going for it is ambition.

This is the Rwanda where at least 800,000 and perhaps as many as 1m people, one-eighth of its population, were killed in the space of a few weeks in 1994; which ranks 164th of 174 countries on the UN human development index; where 50% of the population is illiterate; where only about two-thirds of children experience any time at all at primary school; where only one in five has any experience of secondary school.

When the Hutu army and interahamwe militia began its slaughter of the minority Tutsi population and moderate Hutus, teachers - because they were community leaders, because they were educated - were often the first to die. Many Hutu teachers participated in the genocide, too. Illiteracy increased the potency of radio, the strongest media in the country, when inciters of the killings controlled the airwaves.

The new government blames a lot on the old education system, which Mudidi says suffered from a "colonial hangover", separating a small percentage of the population, who were educated to run the country, from the masses. "The consequence of such an education was the genocide of 1994," the government's education policy statement says baldly. And after the war, as long as the schools were closed, people refused to believe the war was over. "We didn't have teachers, we didn't have schools. We went into prefectures and said, who can be the headmaster, who can be an inspector?" says Narcisse Musabeyewo, the government's director of primary education. The way he tells it, as the schools resurfaced, so some kind of normality began to return.

The genocide is a memory now, invisible and everywhere. It might be possible for a particularly ignorant tourist to visit Rwanda, a beautiful country crowded with subsistence farmers plundering postage stamp-sized fields, and not know there had been a genocide. But there are 125,000 people in prison on genocide charges; outside, there are people living side by side with men who killed their families.

And in the schools, the government's policy of providing secondary education to all those whose parents died in the war means that in some, three-quarters of the students are genocide orphans; at Kayonza it's about half.

Rwamurangwa's school has a rectangle of one-storey classrooms looking on to a grass yard with a Rwandan flag. He says, with a smile and a shrug: "The problems are so many. The major one is simply that as a boarding school, we don't have electricity." And more: "We don't have enough textbooks for the students. We don't have adequate laboratory equipment ... with the few books we have, sometimes an item is on the curriculum but we don't have the books to follow it." Of the 28 teachers at the school, just eight are trained. Most of the students in Kayonza board, either on site or in UN-built returnee huts. They are supposed to pay 7,000 Rwandan francs a term - about £12 - and day pupils 5,766 per term. But only about 160 actually do. Those who can't pay stay on for as long as the school can cope.

Genocide orphans are supposed to have their fees paid by a government fund. This fund has been badly managed - or, some say, exploited - and in several private schools, teachers who rely on money from the fund for their salaries have not been paid since the spring. Rwamurangwa earns 57,000 Rwandan francs a month, a bit more than £90. Most primary teachers earn 23,000. At Kayonza, the school fees for orphans were not paid last term.

This year, under pressure from the World Bank, which said there were too many - 30,000 - teachers on the government's books, the ministry of education has moved to prevent teachers working in more than one school. This got rid of some "ghosts"; but now many teachers do 30 hours of classroom teaching in the same place for half the money.

Kayonza's 620 students divide roughly into one-third French-speaking, mostly Hutus; and two-thirds Anglophone, mostly Tutsis. But the government has abolished identification by tribe and has spent six years telling its population that they are Rwandan, and only Rwandan. All Rwandans speak the native language, Kinyarwanda, but the lessons at secondary level are mostly in either French or English. The new curriculum is a spliced-together version of the old Rwandan system and that taught in Anglophone east Africa, with the Francophone influence - chalk and talk - most pervasive. The government is trying to reform it, make it more skills-based, but for the moment it is still vast, complicated, traditional, outdated.

Rwamurangwa takes me to watch Caleb Asiimwe teach a history class; they're studying 19th-century Prussian diplomacy. From a battered textbook, he gives dictation on the Schleswig-Holstein question. The students like this history, says Asiimwe later, they like the charac ters, the great men; outside the classroom, they call each other Bismarck and Metternich.

But African history, especially Rwandan history, is mostly submerged. Partly this is practical - the teachers complain there are no up-to-date, reliable textbooks about Rwanda, and the government is still working out what to do about it. Partly it is emotional. "They are telling us not to go deep," says John Mugisha, a history teacher at Fawe, a new, elite all-girls school in Gisozi.

His headteacher, Emerithe Nzaramba, says: "These children are still young. We try to talk about general subjects in our country but we don't go into details. We think we have to get some kind of counselling system before we go into talking about it. It's a bit artificial but we have to help them to live in the country."

Next I take part in an English class run by Ryan O'Neill, 25, a Glaswegian working at Kayonza through Voluntary Service Overseas. Today his students practise asking questions, by asking me. The first question, from David Byabagamba, is: "What will you tell people about what happened to our country in 1994?" I ask them what I should tell people about Rwanda now. "That we are united, one nation," says Irene Iribagiza, firmly and quietly.

The teachers and students at Kayonza love Ryan. There's no literature at all in the English syllabus and if I'd not been there, he would have spent the lesson on gerunds. He is one of 54 VSO teachers in Rwanda. The organisation has been here now since 1999; a couple of volunteers have fled quickly, lonely and freaked out, but most have stayed, fallen for the country.

"I thought Kayonza was a dump when I first arrived," says Ryan, who shares a house with no running water with another VSO teacher, Denise Rawlinson. "But I've grown to love the place."

So does Christine Heap, 60, an RE teacher from Darlington now working in Byumba, one of the few volunteers with extensive experience. "They want to learn: this is why I came into teaching. Anything you do is appreciated. That's such a big difference - a complete contrast to teaching at home."

At Heap's school, I speak to a group of Francophone students learning to be primary teachers. They share a recognisable ambivalence about the prospect of a teaching career. "I prefer to teach our children in Rwanda in order to make them intelligent, so they participate in the development of our country," says Jean Habakurama, 21. But he plans to apply for university, to study something else - he doesn't think teaching will pay enough. Likewise Evalde Nsengimana, 23: "For me, as with my friends, I would prefer to teach two years and then go to university to improve my knowledge. We are not happy to be teachers only."

Rwamurangwa is content to carry on in his school in Kayonza. "If there is the ministerial suggestion for me to change to another school I cannot reject it, but I would rather stay here to see the school progressing," he says.

Education in Rwanda, like living, is a continuing battle between hope and experience. The potential of people who have known the very worst confronts the realisation that so much has to be done to make things better. But there is something remarkable, perhaps deceptive, about the teachers and their students, so that in bare classrooms, as hardly trained staff teach excruciatingly old-fashioned syllabuses to classes of 60-plus, it is possible to believe that hope is winning.

webTitle: Cut in home-building plans for south-east fails to satisfy critics

fields.headline: Cut in home-building plans for south-east fails to satisfy critics
fields.trailText: The government has scaled back plans for construction of thousands of homes in the south-east, following claims that the planned pace of development would eat into acres of valuable countryside.
fields.body:
The government has scaled back plans for construction of thousands of homes in the south-east, following claims that the planned pace of development would eat into acres of valuable countryside.

The planning minister, Nick Raynsford, yesterday confirmed the decision to cut the number of new homes to be built each year from the original plan of 43,000 to 39,000 for the next five years.

But he admitted that ministers had been unable to accept proposal by the South East Regional Planning Authority (Serplan) for a further reduction of 6,000, as this failed to take proper account of the region's future housing needs.

He said that by concentrating on high-density housing developments, it would be possible to meet the new target without using any more land than Serplan had envisaged would be needed for 33,000 new homes per year.

The announcement was given a cool reception by environmental groups and the opposition, who argued that the new target figure was an inadequate response to the threat development poses to the region's green spaces.

The shadow environment secretary, Archie Norman, accused ministers of arrogantly assuming that they knew better than Serplan what the region needed.

"This is a slap in the face for local people. This will inevitably mean the loss of more of our precious green fields. This shows how the centralised national planning system is flawed with Whitehall diktats overriding local wishes," he said.

"The rise in the number of single-person households is the factor fuelling household growth, but single people mainly want to live in towns and cities. Labour are building the wrong houses in the wrong places."

Tory leader William Hague is also expected to criticise the move today, accusing the government of putting the green belt in jeopardy.

Tony Burton, assistant director of the Council for the Protection of Rural England, urged the government to do more to ease building pressures on the already overcrowded south-east by encouraging the regeneration of other regions.

"This is an inadequate response to building pressures on the south-east's countryside, which leaves 100 square kilometres of rural land under threat from the bulldozer," he said.

"The south-east's environment is at breaking point. The harm caused by excessive housebuilding cannot be masked by commitments to improve the density and design of new development.

"Policies to focus on urban regeneration will be undermined by the vast area of rural land already earmarked for development."

webTitle: Fraudster takes his medicine lying down as court convenes in bedroom

fields.headline: Fraudster takes his medicine lying down as court convenes in bedroom
fields.trailText: A double bedroom in Hertfordshire became the setting for a crown court hearing yesterday because the man being sentenced for fraud was so ill that the judge had to go to him.
fields.body:
A double bedroom in Hertfordshire became the setting for a crown court hearing yesterday because the man being sentenced for fraud was so ill that the judge had to go to him.

Anthony Tobias, 36, who is paralysed from the neck down, lay under his duvet as the judge, his barrister, the prose cution lawyer, the court clerk, a stenographer and the policeman who had arrested him congregated around his bed.

During the 1990s, with the aid of a telephone, a computer and a pen clenched between his teeth, Mr Tobias embarked on a catalogue of fraud and deception, which enabled him to have built a detached £250,000 home in Stevenage.

Judge Ronald Moss, who sits at Luton crown court, where the case should have been heard, was told that the condition of Mr Tobias who was paralysed in a swimming accident nearly 20 years ago, had deteriorated recently, leaving him bedridden and on life support equipment.

Mr Tobias, who is married with a young daughter, lay barely visible under the duvet as the clerk read out the charges of fraudulent trading, false accounting, two offences of evading a liability and forgery. He pleaded guilty to all five charges.

Judge Moss who, like the barristers, did not wear a wig or gown, occasionally asked the defendent if he was all right and, in a weak voice, Tobias, who was linked by a tube to medical equipment, replied that he was.

Sentencing him to 12 months' probation, Judge Moss said: "Clearly, although he could be taken to prison, it would be almost an inhuman regime for him because they can't cater for someone with his depth of disability".

It would mean Tobias lying on a bed in a prison cell. "Community service", said the judge, "was not an option and a conditional discharge didn't mark the gravity of the offences".

Judge Moss had considered taking away Tobias's computer, but he went on: "To take it away might be regarded as cruel.

"I just want to bring this proceeding to a civilised end as quickly as possible. I can only hope, in moments of reflection, he feels remorse." The judge said many small firms had been affected by Tobias's dishonesty.

A spokesman for the lord chancellor's office said yesterday it was the first time anyone could remember a crown court case being heard in the bedroom of a private house.

webTitle: Comment: Rail privatisation

fields.headline: Time to backtrack
fields.standfirst:
If the government can think the unthinkable on the tube, next it should return Railtrack to public control

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: If the government can think the unthinkable on the tube, next it should return Railtrack to public control, says Ros Coward.
fields.body:
What would be the public response if an electricity supplier declared they had let their pylons rot, so electricity would now only be available sporadically? Would we passively accept this because "not everyone depends on electricity"? Would the government give the supplier until Easter to sort itself out? Would the newspapers relegate the story to back pages? Not likely. A private company failing to deliver a public utility, especially over Christmas, would be a national scandal.

So why treat the railways differently? The crisis is damaging business, driving travellers to distraction, and now preventing people from reaching families and friends for Christmas. So far, all the government has done publicly is give Railtrack a "dressing down" and initiate a forum to make the companies coordinate responses. The media have merely given the public space to complain. It appears we've all accepted railways are no longer a public utility but one transport option among others, standing and failing by their own business acumen.

If you listen to those complaints, however, it's clear the public never abandoned the belief that railways are a public utility. The public has protested about every aspect of the whole dysfunctional privatised structure - about fares, about ticketing, about safety. Most people were disappointed that New Labour never planned to take back control of Railtrack (at £3bn it would have been a snip) and outraged that it took three years to produce a transport plan.

In fact, the industry and politicians are also ambivalent about the status of the railways. The industry's overreaction to Hatfield is precisely because it understands the railways' symbolic importance for the public: we expect it to be run in our interests, meeting health and safety standards that truly private activities don't. No one protests about annual car fatalities, which run to thousands. Driving is seen as a private activity where we assess our own risks.

Implicitly, the government also acknowledges the railways as a public utility. The 10-year transport plan promised £60bn for the railways, of which £30bn is to come from public taxes. Until now, it has insisted this is a "subsidy" to passengers - nothing that would entitle it to take control. Politically, renationalisation was seen as too much of a poisoned chalice.

But there's growing evi dence the unthinkable is now being thought. A compromise on the tube looks possible. The select committee on transport pulled no punches about Railtrack's dismal failures. An early day motion on renationalising Railtrack already has more than 70 Labour supporters. Rumours indicate that Tony Blair himself has finally recognised the extent of the railways' problems.

What's needed urgently is a public campaign to exploit this political vulnerability. Unfortunately, the admirable Save Our Railways was wound down when renation alisation no longer looked viable and when rail unions withdrew their funding. webTitle: UN quits key area of Kosovo

fields.headline: UN quits key area of Kosovo
fields.standfirst:
Local Serbs assume control of law and order after days of unrest

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: The United Nations appears to have lost control of a key part of northern Kosovo after a weekend of violence in which a Serb man was shot dead by Belgian peacekeeping troops.
fields.body:
The United Nations appears to have lost control of a key part of northern Kosovo after a weekend of violence in which a Serb man was shot dead by Belgian peacekeeping troops.

The UN Mission in Kosovo has ordered its international and locally recruited police service and all UN personnel to withdraw from the town of Leposavic.

Late yesterday afternoon the town and surrounding villages had no international presence - troops from the Nato-led peacekeeping force, K-For, had been confined to barracks.

An improvised roadblock of logs had been erected by locals outside the town's UN police station.

Responsibility for the enforcement of law and order appeared to have been assumed by local Serbs.

Serbian parliamentary elections are due throughout Serbia - including Kosovo - on Saturday.

The UN staff were pulled out after Milan Jokovic, 20, was shot outside the police station late on Saturday as a crowd of 200 people surrounded the building. Soldiers used teargas and fired warning shots in attempt to disperse the crowd.

A Belgian officer admitted on Sunday that Jokovic had been struck by a bullet which ricocheted off a wall. K-For officials now say they do not know who fired shot.

Earlier on Saturday six Belgian soldiers and a civilian had been seized by the crowd and held hostage. Two guns and 150 rounds of ammunition were stolen in the process. The hostages were released three hours later, after negotiations with a senior Belgian officer.

UN officials say the violence was sparked off by the arrest of a Serb man for reckless driving.

Jokovic's funeral, on a hilltop three miles to the south of Leposavic, was attended by more than 500 people. A trailer towed by a mechanised plough carried his coffin between the trees and funeral plots marked by Orthodox crosses and the Serbian flags.

The presence of four foreign journalists attracted the attention of a stout man, dressed in a black leather jacket. As we moved away from the cemetery he demanded to see identity cards. An American photographer working for the Liaison photo agency saw the man move a pistol to his pocket. He then produced what appeared to be a police badge.

"This is a people's revolution," he explained as he demanded the right to see our papers. "This is Serbia, not Kosovo. Kosovo is part of Serbia."

For 20 minutes he walked alongside us back to our car, with one hand placed in his pocket. He said the victim of the shooting was the son of a fellow policemen. "If it happened to him it could happen to my son". He eventually let us go after two of us produced out-of-date Serbian press accreditation.

A senior British UN official based in nearby Mitrovice said later that dozens of policemen were believed to be employed in the region, paid by Serbian government officials north of the border. The official, who refused to be named, admitted that the policemen had considerable control over the local population.

A UN spokesman, Frank Benjaminson, denied that the UN had lost control of the area.

"We will return them [the UN police and staff] as soon as possible. We still have K-For in the area, even though you can't see them," he said.

South of Leposavic, on the road to Mitrovice, a check point previously manned by Belgian soldiers was guarded by Greek troops, who are seen by the Serb community as more sympathetic.

In the south of the province K-For was coming under increased pressure after an attack on a joint Russian and American patrol on the boundary with Serbia.

The shooting followed the destruction by the troops of a road believed to have been used by Albanian guerrillas for smuggling arms and men into Serbia.

The troops returned fire and then retreated. There were no casualties.

It is not clear who fired the shots, though K-For officials suspect the rebel group of ethnic Albanians fighting for the independence of three Albanian municipalities in Serbia and their attachment to Kosovo.

webTitle: Women: The end of the womens' unit?

fields.headline: The end
fields.standfirst:
... or is it? Yvonne Roberts sees red at reports of the death of the women's unit

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: ... or is it? Yvonne Roberts sees red at reports of the death of the women's unit.
fields.body:
They think it's all over? Well, it is now. Or so they would have us believe. In 1997, following a victory sealed by the female vote, Labour looked as if it were investing in fair play for women. It wasn't just the appointment of a women's minister or the creation of a women's unit. It was the belief - daft, as it's turned out - that politicians such as the present women's ministers, Baroness ("I'm not a feminist") Jay and Tessa Jowell, had a basic understanding of the way the female world turned.

Instead, three years on, a dangerously ignorant process is under way. In its second term, Labour proposes to replace the women's unit with an organisation that represents both males and females discriminated against because of their sex. Among the titles suggested are Citizens' Unit or Equal Opportunities Unit. It will widen its remit to consider, for instance, issues such as why boys perform less well in exams.

"The debate has moved on," a senior government source says, while Tessa Jowell argues that, under the "new feminism" (whatever that might be), we should be worried about inequalities affecting either sex.

If reports about the death of the unit are correct, the subliminal message is both guilt-inducing and, paradoxically, complimentary. It reads: the battle is over. Equality has arrived. All that remains is to tidy up a few human rights blips for both sexes. Women have done well to catch up - but this far and no further. Female gains in future may be achieved only at great cost to men.

Is this true? No. Has the debate moved on? No. Is women's equality established? No. Is the discrimination practised against men and women on a par? Definitely not.

Women continue to live in a world in which the vocabulary, vision and criteria for achievement, success and excellence are mainly moulded by the male experience and the assumption that the family is invisible. A world in which a stereotypical attitude to women is institutionalised and systematic.

In the summer, education minister David Blunkett warned girls against "aggressive assertiveness" because, for the first time, they had dared to do 0.06% better than boys in A level results. Take a look further down the line, however, and what do we find in our newly landscaped, allegedly woman-friendly Garden of Eden?

A childless woman who competes "equally" with men will still earn £100,000 less over a lifetime. Women at the top with influence? Still a minority tribe. Women at the bottom? Often impoverished. Single parent families under a Labour government disgracefully live on 20% of the average wage. Equal pay for the "ordinary" woman? In your dreams, pal.

Discrimination against women is woven into the clapped-out infrastructure that "supports" Britain today. Why? For one thing, because the value of caring is ridiculously low - in the home and outside it. It is seen in the inflexibility of employers who, for instance, as long as four out of five part-timers are females, refuse a career structure.

It is seen in the blindness of male politicians who blithely discuss "citizenship" as if it carries the same meaning for women as it does for men. And who ignore lobbyists such as Donna St Hill of the Women's Budget Group who argue for a gendered political economy which includes in the gross domestic product the value of reproduction.

At the risk of generalisation, women's "problem" is not other women or definitions of femininity. In contrast, men's "problem", the crisis in masculinity, as academic Lynne Segal has argued, is other men and the narrow definition of what it is to be "manly". Blunkett's criticism of girls reveals how desperately some men cling to the idea that unless they are "winning", there ain't no justice in this world.

Since the 50s, women's aspirations (and financial necessity) have cracked the mould that said the "good" woman was a full-time wife and mother. Now some men, under similar pressures, are similarly trying to widen the definition of what it is to be a "real" man. They need all the help they can get, for all our sakes. And, of course, men's rights should be defended. But that requires a different engine of change.

A women's unit, properly supported, is vital since, practically and symbolically, it helps to make the case that female discrimination is profoundly different in its historical origin, in its impact on the individual and in the solutions it demands from a society that has still to exorcise the ghosts of the male breadwinner and men's "right" to power. They think it's all over? It's barely begun.

webTitle: 'Improper relations' halt trial

fields.headline: 'Improper relations' halt trial
fields.trailText: A 10-week trial at the Old Bailey collapsed yesterday after it emerged a police protection officer at the court was having an "improper relationship" with a juror he was supposed to be supervising.
fields.body:
A 10-week trial at the Old Bailey collapsed yesterday after it emerged a police protection officer at the court was having an "improper relationship" with a juror he was supposed to be supervising.

The prosecution was forced to accept calls for a retrial after other members of the panel told court staff the male officer and the juror had been sending text messages to each other during court breaks.

Police began investigating allegations of impropriety two weeks ago, and after discussions the prosecution agreed with defence barristers, who argued that the trial, estimated to have cost taxpayers £1.5m, should be stopped.

The officer, who has not been named, has been suspended, while the juror could face contempt of court charges.

John Bevan QC, for the prosecution, told the court: "It has become apparent in the last 10 days or so, as a result of information received, that an improper relationship of several weeks duration has existed between a female juror and a male officer of the jury protection squad."

Mr Bevan revealed it was the second time the case had been halted because of jury "misbehaviour". It is understood that on the previous occasion the jury were caught playing cards when they were supposed to be deliberating.

Judge Crawford Lindsay QC, agreed there was no alternative but for the remaining five women and six men to be discharged and for the trial to start for a third time.

webTitle: Bush urges US central banker to back tax cuts

fields.headline: Banker urged to back tax cuts
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush sought to enlist the support of the financial world's most powerful individual yesterday when he met the US central banker Alan Greenspan, in Washington.
fields.body:
George W Bush sought to enlist the support of the financial world's most powerful individual yesterday when he met the US central banker Alan Greenspan, in Washington.

Political analysts believe that a nod from Mr Greenspan, the respected chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, would help Mr Bush to find support for his unloved $1,300bn (£800m) tax-cutting package.

Mr Bush said after the hour-long breakfast meeting: "I talked with a good man right here. We had a very strong discussion about my confidence in his abilities."

A taciturn Mr Greenspan was guided by the president-elect's hand on his shoulder in a public appearance designed to draw a veil over the rancour that existed between the banker and George Bush Sr's administration.

Mr Bush made it clear that he wanted to convince Mr Greenspan that he needed to cut taxes to head off a recession. But he faces an uphill struggle to win acceptance of the plan in Washington, where even senior Republicans have voiced concern about its impact on the economy.

Democrats have criticised it for favouring the wealthy.

Yesterday George W Bush said: "There's going to be a lot of discussion, a lot of head-knocking ... and arm twisting."

He may also find it difficult to get Mr Greenspan on his side. Before the election, the Fed chairman made it clear that tax cuts were a lowly second choice to paying back the US government debt.

But if the economy continues to slow down, the Federal Reserve could start to soften its anti-inflationary stance as soon as today.

If that happens, some economists believe Mr Greenspan could make a U-turn on taxes early next year.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Kohl's Turkish coalition sealed | Austrian judges reject pressure | Brazil jail riot leaves 5 dead | Bilbao police defuse bomb
fields.body:
Kohl's Turkish coalition sealed

Ex-German chancellor Helmut Kohl went to Istanbul at the weekend to seek parental consent for Elif Sozen, 32, to marry his son Peter, possibly in April. Her parents said yes.
AP Istanbul

Austrian judges reject pressure

Two-thirds of Austria's judges and prosecutors have signed an open letter defending the independence of the judiciary against Freedom party attacks on the investigation of the the party's guiding spirit, Jörg Haider, and other leaders for allegedly using secret police files against rivals.
AP, Vienna

Brazil jail riot leaves 5 dead

More than 300 Brazilian prisoners are holding 22 hostages, mostly prisoners' relatives and children, after killing at least five fellow prisoners in a riot on Sunday.
Reuters, Sao Paulo

Bilbao police defuse bomb

Spanish police defused a suspected Eta bomb yesterday in a lift in the Basque University, near Bilbao.
Reuters, Bilbao

webTitle: Stephen Moss: To ban boxing and hunting would impoverish our lives

fields.headline: To ban boxing and hunting would impoverish our lives
fields.standfirst:
As a boxer lies fighting for his life, Stephen Moss argues for keeping blood sports

Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: As a boxer lies fighting for his life, Stephen Moss argues for keeping blood sports
fields.body:
There is no rational argument for permitting boxing. Allowing two men (or, increasingly, women) to stand toe to toe punching the living daylights out of each other for the enjoyment of others is insane and barbaric. Similarly, with hunting: it is monstrous that several hundred people and a pack of hounds should get an afternoon's enjoyment out of pursuing a terrified fox for several hours before tearing the exhausted animal apart.

In the case of boxing, the British Medical Association's arguments cannot be resisted. Boxers' brains are reduced to mush by the constant pounding: even if they manage to escape the sort of catastrophic blood clot on the brain that overwhelmed Paul Ingle as he defended his world featherweight title on Saturday, they may face a lifetime of slurred speech and slowed movement.

Most boxers don't even get rich out of it: the game is littered with great champions, notably Joe Louis, who ended up penniless and propping up bars, grizzled relics of great careers. Promoters and TV companies cream off most of the money, and every champion has his retinue of hangers-on looking to cash in on his courage. As for the journeymen, many are being paid to act as punchbags for young hopefuls who want a 20-0 record to get a crack at a title.

Forget all the nonsense about the noble art. It's a nobbled art. Many fights are, in effect, fixed: nine times out of ten, the winner will be known in advance because the matching is so precise. Bright prospect versus gnarled veteran looking for one last pay day is the classic match: the latter will put up a good show and go down in the seventh, boosting the ranking and TV drawing-power of the former. It stinks.

As for the titles these young hopefuls are gunning for, they stink too. An alphabet soup of self-interested governing bodies offering tacky belts that they will take away from champions who refuse to play ball with their match-making. Boxing has always been corrupt and driven by money, but the proliferation of governing bodies in the past 20 years has raised it to a new level.

The route-out-of-the-gutter argument is largely bogus. Few boxers make a packet; some of those who do lose it all anyway; many of those who don't end up punchy. The latter are often found hanging around in boxing gyms - warm, supportive places that provide a surrogate family for the old pro. But why couldn't an amateur-based system provide the same support? Professional boxing appears to exist largely for promoters, pay-per-view TV companies and overweight punters in bow-ties.

Similarly, with hunting: there are no rational grounds to retain it. The conservation argument is tenuous: as Matthew Engel pointed out in these pages last week, hunts can't be allowed to get away with claiming that they both eliminate vermin and sustain the fox population. Hunting is a ludicrously inefficient way of controlling foxes. Hunts exist for hunters, not for farmers whose land they cross, and certainly not for the welfare of the hunted.

Some argue in favour of boxing and hunting on libertarian grounds: that those who engage in them do so freely and without affecting the rights of others. The argument is unconvincing. A fox is a living thing with the right to a humane death: if hunting is acceptable, why not badger baiting and cock fighting? And if boxers are free to maim and kill each other, why not permit so-called total fighting, in which there are no restraints, or bring back gladiators? There would certainly be an audience.

I have hunted and boxed, and feel ambiguous about both. They are fascinating, inward-looking worlds full of courageous individuals with a deep love of what they do. They have rich, superbly documented traditions; to lose either would be like losing a language - an accumulation of meanings that offer an insight into human behaviour. I think of the old master of foxhounds I rode with who had no interest in being up with the thrusters to witness the kill, but wanted to watch the hounds working and listen to them calling to each other as they trawled through a copse. I think, too, of the former boxer damaged by too many hard fights but still anxious to box because only in the ring could he truly express himself.

The only argument for boxing, as for hunting, is aesthetic (jarring though the word is, as a boxer lies fighting for his life in a Sheffield hospital). Not in the sense of beauty, though many would claim that boxing - the "sweet science" - is beautiful when a Muhammad Ali or a Sugar Ray Leonard is performing; and some would even make the same claim for hunting when the hunt gathers in the frosty light of a crisp December day.

Boxing and hunting are worlds entire unto themselves: ban them and you eliminate a way of being. That is why hunting, feeling itself hunted, has responded so ferociously: it is not a sport under attack but a way of life. Boxing would feel the same way; boxers have nothing else.

Boxing and hunting are insupportable on rational grounds, yet both offer rooted, cherished narratives of how people choose to live. Both are long established and are the preserve of self-contained social groups. The social self-sufficiency - with its unique codes and language - has produced a way of seeing, a portrait of a world.

Boxing has the greatest literature of any sport. William Hazlitt, Paul Gallico, George Plimpton, Norman Mailer, Hugh McIlvanney, Joyce Carol Oates and David Remnick have all written brilliantly, and by no means blindly, about the sport: its heroism and its hellishness. Hunting, too, has attracted good writers: it dominated the sporting magazines of the Victorian age, RS Surtees wrote entertaining novels based around the hunting field, and Siegfried Sassoon's Memoirs of a Fox-Hunting Man offers a wonderful depiction of a youth devoted to the sport. The fact that boxing and hunting have inspired great writing does not mean either is great, but should make us aware that in banning them we would be losing something profound.

Boxing and hunting have no place in a rational world, but do we live in a rational world? In a rational world, half its people wouldn't starve while the other half eat in fancy restaurants; palaces would be pulled down so that Peckham could be revitalised; there would be no conflict between religions because we know that every faith is founded on sand; the world's self-proclaimed greatest democracy would bother to count the votes cast in elections; the lion would lie down with the lamb, and both would oppose genetic modification. Boxing and hunting are crazy, but so are we.

 Stephen Moss is writing a cultural history of sport.

webTitle: Board game to beat the bored

fields.headline: Board game to beat the bored
fields.standfirst:
Monopoly goes provincial - even northern cities are hip these days

Special report: north-south divide
fields.trailText: Monopoly goes provincial - even northern cities are hip these days
fields.body:
It being Christmas, I am going to say something nice about the ludicrous dolts who control Britain's railways. For in the past few years - and the past few weeks especially - they have achieved something that has eluded successive governments for generations: they have addressed Britain's most intractable structural problem: its metrocentricity.

London has been sucking the life out of provincial cities ever since the railways were invented, and probably since Saxon times. The problem grew so bad that earlier this year one of the country's most compelling and influential columnists suggested moving the political capital somewhere else: to York, Chester, Crewe or to the geographical centre of Britain, Hawes in Wensleydale. Thus began an intense national debate ... well, a late-night phone-in on Radio Stoke, anyway; the moment passed quietly in Hawes because both Guardian readers were away.

The idea, however, was predicated on the existence of reasonable transport links, which seems very far-fetched in a Christmas week when travel is more difficult than in any year since the 1940s, if not the 1840s. The other cities of Britain have been bedevilled because it has always seemed so simple to go to London. All that's gone.

To some extent this fits in with a trend that was noticeable through the 1990s: provincial chic. The great regional centres are much more highly regarded than they were in the Thatcher years. This is partly because of the growth in student numbers and the attendant youth culture and clubbing, which have created a sense of life on the streets. It's partly to do with the fashion for football, in which London is second-best. It's partly political: local councils have become much more adept at marketing their cities and buffing up their image. Newcastle now is widely perceived as cool rather than cold; Leeds is meant to be Dallas; Birmingham is definitely one of the most exciting and hippest places in the whole West Midlands (sorry, couldn't resist it); even Bolton talks of being a 24-hour metropolis.

And in the toyshops this Christmas there is a plastic-and-cardboard manifestation of this rediscovered self confidence: provincial variants of Monopoly. There are now a dozen versions of British regions and cities apart from London. The makers claim demand is "phenomenal".

Now Monopoly is a prince among board games, being both complex and divisive - responsible, I would guess, for more broken marriages than adultery and only slightly fewer than contract bridge. Originally, of course, it was American and based on the streets of Atlantic City.

But the London version has seared itself into our consciousness because it has the added British ingredient: class. It is understood that the brown properties are cheap because they are working-class, and that the purples are expensive because they are aspirational (even if, in reality, Park Lane is clogged with traffic and Mayfair full of tarts).

This is much harder to achieve outside London. Part of the metrocentricity problem is that the averagely well educated person in, say, Newcastle, could easily name dozens of London streets but not one in Bristol or Birmingham. Unfortunately, the new Monopolies will not address this: Bristol Monopoly is not on sale in Newcastle and vice versa. Also, the designers have backed away from replicating the intricate gradations of status inherent in the traditional version. The squares are sponsored, and the colours represent different business groupings rather than geography: the pinky set is sporting, for instance, and the browns represent "service industries". Far from being inherently undesirable, sponsors are said to be doubly keen on getting brown because the design of the box-top gives them an extra mention. In Mancunian Monopoly, St Peter's Square is brown and St Ann's Square purple, but these certainly do not represent the extremes of local class consciousness.

Some of the streets are less than catchy and some are not even streets. Can you really imagine building a hotel (Welsh version, orange set) on Vale Road, Llandudno Junction? Or (Ulster version, purple) on Giant's Causeway? Wouldn't that lead to problems with planning? And what about (Edinburgh version, green) the Scottish parliament, priced at £320 in the place usually allocated to Bond Street? To be realistic, that figure should double about every fortnight.

All of this seems very commendable since, for most Britons, London is so distant this Christmas. These games are even educational: I can reveal that Cist y gymun is the Welsh for Community Chest. Whether they will catch on is another matter: I suspect, deep in our psyche, we need something that has the spice of class distinction. It's part of being British. Have a sweet-tempered Christmas, especially if playing Monopoly - or travelling by train.

webTitle: G2: A country diary

fields.headline: Poetry in motion
fields.standfirst: Cheshire
fields.trailText: Cheshire
fields.body:
"What is this life if, full of care, we have no time to stand and stare" - the opening line by WH Davis to one of the few poems I recall learning by heart at school - and now, some three miles out of the village, a colleague and I followed the poet's advice. We had walked through damp lanes, and across sodden fields, all at a naturalist's pace, and eventually stopped to take stock of the morning so far.

The brand new five-barred gate we had chosen provided comfortable support for the elbows as we stared across the wide pasture field in front of us, where an all-too-familiar "new lake" covered one corner, and the neat lines of clipped thorn-bush hedgerows led the eye to the horizon and the grey outline of the Derbyshire hills. At one point the distant calls of wild geese could be heard high above us as a skein of some 75 Pink Feet, in an untidy V-formation, slowly moved eastwards, no doubt heading for the coastal estuary around the Wash.

Back on the ground, a brown hare, which had been sitting upright with ears pricked in a nearby field, suddenly loped away out of sight behind the hedge, as a fox, now looking its best in a new winter coat, came out of a small covert. After a quick look round, it moved back into the wood, but this brief appearance was enough to alarm the redwings, fieldfares and blackbirds who all flew up into a tall oak off to our right.

Behind us, a smaller pasture had been cropped by the sheep and was now proving a rich feeding ground for a number of flighty pied wagtails and a small flock of very intent starlings, busy burying their beaks into the soft earth. WH Davis was right.

webTitle: Wolverhampton raises a ragged cheer as recognition helps keep Birmingham at bay

fields.headline: Wolverhampton raises a ragged cheer as recognition helps keep Birmingham at bay
fields.trailText: The good news was proclaimed yesterday by the town (now city) crier near the statue of Prince Albert which Queen Victoria unveiled in 1866.
fields.body:
The good news was proclaimed yesterday by the town (now city) crier near the statue of Prince Albert which Queen Victoria unveiled in 1866.

"O yea, O yea," bellowed the gent in the scarlet cloak, tricorn hat, white socks and pigtail. "Wolverhampton now holds itself in city status!"

Bookies groaned when they made sense of this bizarre syntax (they had given Wolverhampton derisory odds of 33-1) but the locals raised a ragged cheer when they got the crier's drift.

It was 11.35am; within seconds a nearby news vendor was pasting up Express and Star bills proclaiming "Yes, we're a city". To celebrate the great day, he handed out with his paper stickers ("I'm a city slicker") and packets of sticky sweets (made in Germany).

Wolverhampton based its campaign on its 1,000 years of history - Ethelred the Unready granted a charter to Lady Wulfruna in 985 - and its reputation as a vibrant multi-racial community. "City status would be a recognition of the civic pride, harmony, ambition and loyalty [of Wolverhampton's people]," said the bid document published in August.

The real question now is what benefits city status will bring. They are not sure yet whether the mayor will become a lord mayor but they are hoping for a big economic spin-off: only last week Chubb, the long-established safe maker, announced that its factory is to close with the loss of 170 jobs.

"This is a great opportunity for us to squeeze all the value we can out of the new status to bring jobs to Wolverhampton and prosperity to its people," said Ken Purchase, MP for Wolverhampton North-east. "It will cheer us up a bit and give us new opportunities. But it's not going to turn the world upside down."

Back in the council offices, one of the security staff pronounced himself "chuffed to bits" before preparing to hoist the union and civic flags from nearby poles. He explained that the civic flag carried an image of a bale of wool to mark the trade that brought the city wealth long before the first blast furnace arrived down the road in Bilston.

It is said that the lord chancellor sits on some of that wool in the House of Lords, which suggests that Wolverhampton had influence in high places denied to the 36 losers.

The new city has had two previous goes at boosting its status and lost to Sunderland in 1992, the last time a city name was up for grabs. Its motive was to secure a clear identity, to keep Birmingham at bay and fend off the inexorable advances of Telford up the M54.

"Third time lucky," said council leader Norman Davies, first elected in 1973. "We kept our cool and had confidence that we would win through at the end of the day.

"We are now citizens rather than townsfolk. It's a coming of age. We have moved from hamlet to village, from village to town, and now from town to city. People have a different feeling about cities and this will be a boost to local confidence, business confidence in particular."

Not everyone was as excited as Councillor Davies. In the Mander shopping centre, two teenage girls were literally speechless with apathy but Kirtee Patel, 24, was unstoppable.

"I'd like to know what makes a city for a start," she said. "Wolverhampton isn't a city - it's a town. It's too small to be a city. This won't make any difference."

David Bridgewater, examining Hornby trains in a shop window, thought it would but was not quite sure how. "It will make all-round improvements," he said vaguely.

Were he still with us, one of Wolverhampton's more famous sons might have raised a hearty cheer. But Button Gwinnett left town/city for the new world more than 200 years ago, became governor of Georgia and signed the American Declaration of Independence.

David Bridgewater, examining Hornby trains in a shop window, thought it would but was not quite sure how. "It will make all-round improvements," he said vaguely. Were he still with us, one of Wolverhampton's more famous sons might have raised a hearty cheer. But Button Gwinnett left town/city for the new world more than 200 years ago, became governor of Georgia and signed the American Declaration of Independence.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • An edge of tension creeps into relations with two of our Turncoat of Turncoats candidates. First up, a warm Diary hello to that relentlessly ambitious Foreign Office minister Peter Hain. What a paradox he is. The effects of his sanctions policy on the sick, dying and starving of Iraq he takes in his stride, and yet at a hint of personal criticism the poor lamb goes into shock. His latest bleatings appear in Tribune, where he rebukes George Galloway, John Pilger and myself for doubting his motives in propagating the policy that led two heads of the UN humanitarian aid programme in Iraq to resign in disgust.

 An edge of tension creeps into relations with two of our Turncoat of Turncoats candidates. First up, a warm Diary hello to that relentlessly ambitious Foreign Office minister Peter Hain. What a paradox he is. The effects of his sanctions policy on the sick, dying and starving of Iraq he takes in his stride, and yet at a hint of personal criticism the poor lamb goes into shock. His latest bleatings appear in Tribune, where he rebukes George Galloway, John Pilger and myself for doubting his motives in propagating the policy that led two heads of the UN humanitarian aid programme in Iraq to resign in disgust.

Ah well, no doubt people have done worse on the long crawl towards cabinet before. And when Peter talks of opponents as people who "cannot stand a serious argument so they resort to cheap smears" ... high praise from one who routinely dismisses sanctions critics as "Saddam apologists". As for the section about serious argument, should we take this as formal acceptance, after so many timid rejections, of George Galloway's continual offer of a public debate? Perhaps Peter's diary secretary would care to call with a time and date?

 It was Peter who responded to a recent item over a delayed humanitarian flight from Morocco to Baghdad by drawing a distinction between "blocked the flight" (my words) and "placed the flight on hold" (his). It now seems that fellow Turncoat contender Barbara Roche is another semantic stickler. She is irritated by Friday's item in which we mentioned her reference to the "vile" behaviour of asylum seekers. What in fact she said earlier this year was this: "These people have come here with the intention of exploiting the system and exploiting their children. It's a vile thing to do." Somewhere in all that is another absolutely crucial semantic distinction, and I trust that this clarifies the matter.

 Meanwhile, the mystery over whether Barbara took some lemon pies in the chops, slapstick-style, from people angry about those asylum-seeker comments is solved. Barbara does not comment on "silly stories", of course, but P Sullivan does and rings to report seeing the incident at 12.15pm two Saturdays ago. Barbara rounded the corner from Wood Green library and was walking up the ramp to Safeway's when she was the victim of a two-person assault, he reveals, although the flurry of curd and cream made it difficult to be certain exactly how many pies were involved.

 Telegraph cricket hack Lord Michael Henderson, who drew attention here recently to my capacious arse, enjoyed a triumph of his own in Pakistan. Showing off his profound knowledge of the game, Hendo dismissed England as useless, and lashed Michael Atherton and Graeme Hick particularly, before and during the Third Test in Karachi. Atherton's century and Hick's 40 won a sensational victory, and the front page of Saturday's sports section was devoted to readers' letters along with an interminable self-apologia that climaxed: "journalists are not afraid of scorn". There's a bit of luck. To adapt from Hendo's own letter to my colleague Gary Younge, "you want to learn something about your country's cricket, my lad ..."

 Let's hope that no one from boxer Paul Ingle's family was listening at 8.30am yesterday when supercilious Today sports presenter Garry Richardson got the giggles. What set him off was Frank Bruno, after regretting Mr Ingle's injury as "a sad little thing", signing off with a cheery "wicked". We all know that corpsing on air establishes one as a character (Hendo's cricketing chum Jonathan Agnew built a career on it), but it might be worth being a bit choosy about the context.

 A Book of the Month contender arrives. It is The Seat Belt, Rune Andreasson and Claes-Goran Backstrom's compelling account of "Swedish research and development for global automotive safety".

webTitle: Distinct towns win city status

fields.headline: Distinct towns win city status
fields.standfirst: Brighton and Hove, Wolverhampton and Inverness are triple victors and Wales is main loser at end of bitter two-year contest
fields.trailText: Three towns quite distinct in character and geography were expecting an economic boom yesterday after beating 36 others to become millennium cities.
fields.body:
Three towns quite distinct in character and geography were expecting an economic boom yesterday after beating 36 others to become millennium cities.

In a long-overdue announcement, the Home Office said the Queen had decided to honour Brighton and Hove, Wolverhampton and Inverness at the end of a bitter contest which began two years ago and which brings the number of cities in Britain to 49.

In Wolverhampton, the council leader, Norman Davies, said it was the "best Christmas present ever". He said: "Our New Year's Eve celebrations will be even more special now that we are one of the cities of the millennium."

The director of the Inverness chamber of commerce, Simon Cole-Hamilton, said: "City status will bring a lot of kudos and further strengthen Inverness's profile."

Simon Fanshawe, the writer and broadcaster who spearheaded Brighton and Hove's campaign, said: "We're fantastically excited, not just about being a city but about what we've done. We got it because we put in a different kind of bid, reflecting the fact we're a different kind of city."

All three new cities are hoping for the kind of economic benefits experienced by Sunderland, given city status in 1992. The bookies' favourite, Luton, missed out, and other losers included Reading, Milton Keynes, Warrington, and Bolton and Stockport, two towns within Greater Manchester.

The tipsters had appeared to have little confidence in the bids from both Wolverhampton, power house of the Black Country, and Inverness, capital of the Highlands.

No Welsh town has been honoured although six originally applied. Bids by Newport and Wrexham were endorsed by the Welsh secretary, Paul Murphy, who was said to be very unhappy that none had been successful.

The Plaid Cymru president, Ieuan Wyn Jones, called it "very disappointing news". Nick Bourne, the Conservative leader on the Welsh assembly, said: "This is a giant snub to Wales."

The Home Office minister, Mike O'Brien, announced that Wales would be given another chance in 2002, when four towns - one each in England, Northern Ireland, Scotland and the principality - will be chosen in honour of the Queen's golden jubilee.

webTitle: Arts: How do pop groups survive?

fields.headline: And the brand played on...
fields.standfirst: Lead singers die, songwriters quit - and still pop groups survive. It is down to hidden talent, or smart marketing?  Dave Simpson  investigates
fields.trailText: Lead singers die, songwriters quit - and still pop groups survive. It is down to hidden talent, or smart marketing? Dave Simpson investigates.
fields.body:
Rock legends Thin Lizzy are still packing out venues across Europe. That's Thin Lizzy, whose leather-trousered lead singer Phil Lynott, the unmistakable face of the band, passed away nearly 15 years ago. Thin Lizzy without Lynott might seem unthinkable, but this is just one in a surprisingly long line of bands that have survived - and even prospered - without their most influential member.

Van Halen's career was scarcely troubled when "face of Van Halen" David Lee Roth was replaced by the less pretty phizog of Sammy Hagar. The same applies to the Spice Girls after they lost Geri Halliwell in 1998. Then there's the Manic Street Preachers since the disappearance of lyricist Richey Edwards; Fleetwood Mac without genius founder Peter Green; and AC/DC after the death of singer Bon Scott. Even the Beatles recorded a number one (Real Love) minus John's physical presence.

The few bands that have flopped disastrously after a key member upped and left (Ultravox minus Midge Ure, the Stone Roses after John Squire) don't seem to disprove the trend. It's not the band that people want - it's the brand name.

The classic example of this phenomenon is Pink Floyd. They have survived the departure of not one but two principal members, Roger Waters and Syd Barratt, which their original manager, Peter Jenner, describes as "like the Rolling Stones losing Mick Jagger, twice".

Up to and including 1967's debut album The Piper at the Gates of Dawn, Pink Floyd were fronted by Barratt. He was the good-looking one with the curly hair who nowadays lives as a recluse with his mum in Cambridge. Back then, his behaviour was unbecoming even for a rock star. He took lots of LSD. He greeted a live TV interviewer with a blank stare. Most famously, he freaked out onstage, thinking that his head was melting (it was in fact a combination of hairwax and Mandrax tablets he'd concocted as a pomade, which dissolved under the lights).

Unsurprisingly, the Floyd decided that continuing to work with Barratt was impossible - a particular problem given that he wrote and sang all their songs. But David Gilmour came in on guitar, the rejigged line-up came up with Dark Side of the Moon, and the rest is history. In 1983, when main singer-songwriter Roger Waters left the band, they simply carried on without him. Waters, who had penned most of their 1970s classics, including The Wall, expected Pink Floyd to flounder in his absence. Instead, they played his songs to millions and watched as the solo Waters sank into the Where Are They Now? files.

It undoubtedly helped that Pink Floyd have always been a fairly anonymous, mysterious proposition, playing in the dark or beneath huge lightshows. But, crucially, neither Barratt nor Waters proved bigger than the band - or the brand.

Jenner recalls a meeting the band had with their booking agent. "I think that was one of their great moves," he says. "It was explained to them that they had a very valuable brand name already. They'd established a presence in the market. But at the time, those concepts weren't in mine or the band's vocabulary." Indeed, Jenner quit, convinced that Pink Floyd couldn't continue without Barratt.

Today a band become a brand as soon as it enters the marketplace, and even something as apparently disastrous as the loss of a lead singer can be turned into a marketing opportunity. When Geri left the Spice Girls, a clever spin operation whirred into action. Crucially, Geri had not informed the others that she was leaving. "It looked like she'd let the other four down," explains a source in the Spice Girls camp who prefers not to be named. "That's why they got such support, even when the media thought they were finished and the knives were out for them."

The Spice brand proved bigger than Geri, with Sporty, Baby, Scary and Posh strong enough characters in their own right to front it out. Of course, it helped that the music wasn't affected: the Spice Girls scarcely wrote their own hits, and though Geri had been the PR face of the band, her singing role was minor. "It would've been much worse if Mel C had left," says our source. The publicity over Geri's exit didn't hurt, either. Spice album sales rose by 20%.

A band member, no matter how talented he or she is, underestimates the importance of brand name at their peril. In fact, industry figures maintain that the average consumer has no idea who is actually in their favourite combo.

"When I tell people 'I managed the Floyd when Syd was in them', they go 'Oh, what was that? Dark Side of the Moon?' "Jenner says with a laugh. "And these are people who are massively interested in the Floyd in a 'my favourite band' sort of way."

Similarly, very few of the AC/DC fans who packed their recent UK arena tour probably know or even care that Bon Scott, rather than post-1980 incumbent Brian Johnson, sang on their pivotal early albums.

This explains the failure of many solo projects. Albums by Dave Gilmour, Richard Ashcroft and even Mick Jagger (1985's disastrous She's the Boss) shifted a fraction of the units generated by their bands. These artists could have made the same record, stuck the name the Verve or the Stones on it, and sold truckloads.

In the end, though, a pop brand name works in the same way as any other. If Heinz were suddenly to start making awful baked beans, people would stop buying them. Likewise, a pop band still has to deliver the goods. As a group gathers its own history, the "legendary" name becomes even more significant.

Take the sudden collapse of Genesis. In 1975 they pulled off the coup of replacing the theatrical Peter Gabriel with Phil Collins - hardly a flamboyant figure. The fans accepted the change (it helped that Collins was promoted from within) and, to their credit, Genesis were able to forge a new musical identity. However, when Collins himself left 22 years later, he was replaced as frontman by Ray Wilson, of one-hit jeans advert wonders Stiltskin. One solitary album with this line-up, and the band folded - after 30 years.

The live set may have included old songs, but fans were unable to accept that this was still Genesis. Still, at least they didn't descend into the chicken-in-a-basket circuit hell of, say, the Drifters, in their various reincarnations, or the Wilson-less karaoke horror that now masquerades as the Beach Boys.

"The art is satisfying people's conception of the band," says Peter Jenner. "You mustn't deny what the old band has done - that is really bad news. But you've got to develop it rather than rewrite it." Massive Attack reinvent themselves periodically and astonishingly. Destiny's Child have survived multiple upheavals. Perhaps even the vaguely Floyd-ish Radiohead could survive without Thom Yorke, who - let's face it - is barely audible on their latest album.

In the meantime, the once great name of Thin Lizzy seems finally to be falling into disrepute. Some fans think the Lynott-less line-up offers a "great show", but scores are up in arms. "By the third song, I couldn't take it," declares Lizzy fan Phil Osbourne on the Starting Point website. "I could feel tears; I'd seen enough." Over at the Northern Lights Lizzy fan site, Nick is even more damning: "This is proof that Lizzy died with Phil."

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Rasta loses drug battle
fields.body:
Rasta loses drug battle

A Rastafarian yesterday lost his court battle to make it legal for followers of his religion to sell and smoke marijuana under the Human Rights Act.

Judge Charles Gibson told Rasta Brown, 39, at Inner London crown court that there were "substantial difficulties" in using the act as protection for commercial dealing, but said the Rastafarian community could take the matter to the high court.

Hunger for health

Food lovers are rejecting traditional British fare, such as fry-ups and Sunday roasts in favour of healthier fare like muesli and fruit, according to the 1999 national food survey by the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food.

Firm fined over child deaths

A construction company was yesterday fined £75,000 for breaking health and safety regulations over the deaths of a girl, aged five, and her six-year-old brother, who were hit by a waste lorry in Edinburgh. Boland Construction (Scotland) Limited was convicted of the offences at Edinburgh sheriff court.

Steel man's full house

John Kinsey, a 42-year-old steel worker, has scooped almost £418,000 in Britain's biggest bingo win at the Mecca Club in Wednesbury, West Midlands.

Ambulance staff fight back

Women staff employed by the London Ambulance Service are to receive self-defence training to counter the increasing violence they face when answering calls.

Man charged with murder

A man was yesterday charged with the murder of teenager Victoria Hall whose body was discovered in a stream near Creeting St Peter, Suffolk, more than a year ago. Adrian Bradshaw, 26, of Felixstowe, will appear at Ipswich magistrates court today.

Trials for sex vaccine

A vaccine to prevent HPV, a common sexually transmitted infection that can lead to cervical cancer, will be given trials . Juilian Peto, professor of epidemiology at the Institute of Cancer Research, London, believes its development could lead to national immunisation programmes for teenagers before their first intercourse.

Welsh speak for parliament

Welsh speakers should be allowed to use their first language when giving evidence to parliamentary committees, the Commons procedure committee recommended yesterday. It stopped short of suggesting that Welsh MPs should be allowed to speak the language in the chamber.

UDA blamed for man's death

Security sources have linked the loyalist Ulster Defence Association to the murder of a man found shot in the back of the head in north Belfast yesterday with £2,000 in cash stuffed in his pockets. The killing is thought to be have been some sort of internal "execution" rather than any rekindling of the feud with the Ulster Volunteer Force.
