Second BSE case found in Germany
Ivory Coast exile 'hiring troops'
Schröder condition on EU entry
fields.body:
US rejects climate talks in Oslo

The United States has turned down an invitation to meet the European Union later this week to reopen talks on curbing global warming, a French government spokeswoman said yesterday.

Norway had offered to host the meeting to enable the two sides to patch up the differences which sank the UN Hague conference on cutting greenhouse gases last month.

The US said it would not go to Norway if a successful outcome was unlikely.

There is a wide gap between the EU and the US-led "umbrella group" on how to implement the 1997 UN agreement on cutting the pollution blamed for global warming.

The big stumbling blocks are the US wish to count the carbon stored in its forests and farmlands against its emissions-reduction target and the EU's insistence on limiting the use of "flexible mechanisms" such as buying emissions credits from other countries.

Since the failure in the Hague, the two parties have been trying desperately to patch up an agreement. Both wanted to reach a deal before George Bush's Republican administration, which is considered hostile to the agreement, is sworn in at the end of January.

The French spokeswoman said the lack of a meeting in Oslo did not mean there was no chance of a deal in the medium term as the parties would meet at a UN environment programme summit in Nairobi in January.
Reuters, Brussels

Second BSE case found in Germany

Germany has announced plans to destroy a herd of 82 cattle today, after its second case of BSE was confirmed in a cow recently slaughtered in southern Bavaria.

Two other suspected cases were found in northern Bavaria at the weekend.

The federal institute for virus research in Tübingen said the herd on a farm near Sulzberg in southern Bavaria was tested last week under the government's decision, after the first case, to enforce mandatory testing for all cattle aged over 30 months.

"We believe that the animal was infected three years ago after being fed contaminated fodder," a state agricultural spokesman said.

Further tests are needed on the two suspect carcasses found in northern Bavaria at the weekend.

In November the BSE virus was found in a dead cow in northern Schleswig-Holstein.
Tony Paterson, Berlin

Ivory Coast exile 'hiring troops'

The Ivory Coast president, Laurent Gbagbo, says the former junta ruler General Robert Guei, who fled in the face of street protests after trying to rig the presidential election in October, was recruiting mercenaries in Liberia.

In an interview published yesterday in the French newspaper Libération, Mr Gbagbo said: "We're on his trail, we've taken precautions."

He said he wanted to talk to the general. "I've asked his friends to persuade him to return to Abidjan [Ivory Coast's capital] and I'll give him the status of former head of state."

The two men met on November 13, causing anger in the country, where memories of Gen Guei's presidential guards killing demonstrators in the days after the election remain fresh.

In the interview Mr Gbagbo also rejected what he called "blackmail" by France and the US, which wanted him to press the supreme court to reverse a ruling barring the former prime minister Alassane Ouattara from standing in parliamentary elections.
Reuters, Abidjan

Schröder condition on EU entry

Chancellor Gerhard Schröder proposed yesterday that eastern European workers should be denied free movement in member states for up to seven years after their countries join the EU.

The German leader was speaking in northern Bavaria, attempting to allay fears of an influx of cheap labour from Poland and the Czech Republic when the EU is expanded.

"If we were to allow complete and immediate freedom of movement for workers after enlargement we would be confronted with a strong influx into Germany," he said. "Sections of our employment market would not be able to cope with this."

He said his proposal would be put to member states and the commissioner for enlargement, Günter Verheugen, next year.

At the Nice summit a week ago the EU's 15 member states agreed reforms aimed at allowing up to 12 states to join from 2003. Germany and France remain at loggerheads on the key issue of Polish agricultural subsidies, which could delay Poland's entry.

Mr Schröder's proposal is a marked departure from his recent promise in Warsaw to ensure that Poland is among the first new EU members.
Tony Paterson, Berlin

webTitle: Gary Younge on how Britain hit the bottle

fields.headline: A few too many
fields.standfirst:
In the past 35 years our alcohol intake has shot up. More than 9m of us are now drinking at dangerous levels and our European neighbours regard us as drunks. In fact the only people who don't think Britain has a drink problem are the British. Gary Younge on a nation in denial

Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: In the past 35 years our alcohol intake has shot up. More than 9m of us are now drinking at dangerous levels and our European neighbours regard us as drunks. In fact the only people who don't think Britain has a drink problem are the British. Gary Younge on a nation in denial.
fields.body:
From the Tannoy of Finsbury Park station comes a familiar message. The 8.33pm to Hertford North has been cancelled. The three middle-aged men, accompanied by one young boy, have an hour to kill and there is only one thing for it. "Let's go to the pub," says one. "These bloody trains will drive you to drink." They will also drive you with drink.

The majority of those who board the next train are carrying bottles of beer. About a quarter of the carriage is drunk. When we arrive at Stevenage the walkway between the town centre and the leisure park, a thoroughfare between town and clubland, teenage boys clutch pints of lager as though they were tickets to manhood.

It's Saturday night and you can almost hear the drum beats of a primal British ritual pounding. It's time for the smallest market town and the largest urban centre to bury their differences in a sea of beer and Bacardi Breezers. By the end of the night, young women with glazed eyes will link arms and sing anything from Frank Sinatra to The Wizard of Oz; young men will support themselves against the nearest immovable object and then urinate on it. It's Saturday night: time to "get hammered", "blasted" and "go mad for it". It's time, in short, for alcohol to take over.

"British social culture is built around drink," says Eric Appleby of Alcohol Concern. "If you're going to meet people after work you meet them in a pub. If you're going out for a chat you'll go to a pub and in the pub there is a macho thing about how many drinks you've had. Drinking alcohol then becomes the primary social activity."

So while the social scenes of most American sitcoms, such as Seinfeld, Friends or Frasier, take place in coffee bars and diners, all English soap characters like to mull over their problems at the Woolpack, the Rovers Return or the Queen Vic. If Jim Davidson, the comedian and Tory MC, wants to impress his colleague and co-star, the TV presenter Suzi Perry, he falls off the wagon and drinks himself silly. "As soon as I saw her I fell in love with her," he said. "I decided I'd try everything I could to pull her. I started cracking open the champagne, fell into a bottle and stayed there. I was absolutely smashed. I woke up the next morning with my first hangover since 1994."

And, being a dominant factor in our social culture, alcohol is increasingly becoming a major issue in our political culture. When the leader of the opposition wants to look like a man of the people, he recalls his days drinking 14 pints as a teenager and the 32 rum and blacks he claims he downed on his 18th birthday.

When the prime minister is looking for the central theme of what will almost certainly be the final parliamentary session, he reaches for the bottle and declares war on "yob culture". When his son, Euan, was found inebriated in Leicester Square it was not just a blow to him as a father but a political embarrassment to the head of a government that had just proposed spot fines for those found drunk in public.

Back in Stevenage a young woman, in a short skirt despite the bitter cold, stands outside the Pulse nightclub with her head in a bin. While one friend puts a coat over her back so that no one can see her knickers, the other holds her hair out of her face as she retches. A sight so common that no one is watching.

Inside the Vogue nightclub next door, Peter and Dave have been drinking since lunchtime. Peter, 35, has custody of his two children every other weekend. On his weekends off he "goes out and gets smashed". Dave runs out of fingers and moves on to his toes as he counts how many drinks he has had that day and then laughs a cheery, leery, glazed laugh, while expressing amazement that they're still standing.

By the time the night is over the car park will be spattered with vomit. A young man staggers dangerously and aimlessly down a main road shouting: "I'm a he man." Another, perched precariously against a burger van, yells: "You're a cunt."

Britain has a drink problem. We drink almost two-thirds more alcohol per person today than we did in 1965. More than 9m adults drink at levels that endanger their long-term health, and more than one in 25 of us is alcohol-dependent. While it is an issue affecting the whole country, some places and people are in more trouble than others. The proportion of women drinking over the limit rose by 55% between 1984 to 1996. Glasgow is facing the worst incidence of alcohol abuse for 80 years. Most vulnerable are the young - a third of young men live on "beer and fast food"; a quarter of 16- to 19-year-olds in greater Glasgow get drunk at least once a week.

It has cast a serious pall over the way other countries see us. According to a British Council report recently, those aged between 24 and 40 around the world regard Britons as "violent, xenophobic and frequently drunk".

And it is costing us dearly. Not just in human terms - 28,000 deaths a year are alcohol-related - but economically. Every year alcohol costs the NHS around £150m, industry an estimated £2bn and the government roughly £150m, according to Alcohol Concern.

But, curiously, it is not the amount we drink that marks us out as a nation. Even though we drink considerably more than we used to, we still drink a lot less than most other European Union countries. That is particularly true of France and Germany, where Chancellor Gerhard Schröder recently made it to number two in the music charts when a DJ put music to a recording of him saying: "Get me a bottle of beer or I'm going to go on strike here." With the exception of Finland and Sweden - where, like here, they binge drink - no other EU country drinks less than Britain.

This is borne out in other areas. Britons are far less likely to die from cirrhosis of the liver than citizens of any other EU country with the exception of the Irish and the Dutch. The incidence of road traffic accidents involving alcohol is also substantially lower than the EU average.

Our drinking habits have also changed quite radically. Europe has traditionally been split up into drinking cultures determined principally by climate. Colder, northern countries (the UK, Germany, Austria) are beer-drinking cultures, while warmer, southern nations (Italy, France, Spain) drink wine. Now those habits are converging. The proportion of beer in our national alcohol intake has dropped by a quarter, while wine has more than doubled.

So if we drink less than most other European countries and are increasingly drinking the same kind of things, why does a Saturday night out in Lisbon, Barcelona or Lyon never have quite the same chaotic, threatening feel as London, Birmingham or Liverpool?

The problem, say experts, is the way that we drink. "In most other countries they drink with food or as part of some other social activity," says Appleby. "Here we mainly drink to drink and quite often to get drunk. The particular thing about British drinking culture is that it is associated with aggression."

"The problems in Europe relating to alcohol are largely medical whereas in Britain they are about disorder," says professor Nick Heather, who is the director of the centre of alcohol and drug studies in Newcastle. "They may drink more on the continent but they drink consistently and regularly whereas we drink in short bursts."

The reason for this cannot be found in the British psyche but in the history of our licensing laws and cultural make-up, argues Dr Paul Davis, a consultant clinical psychologist who specialises in addictive behaviour. "Until the very end of the 20th century, the law squashed the hours when we could drink into a relatively small space of time so we learned to drink quickly and in quite a focused way," says Davis, who believes bingeing has been a key element in British drinking culture since before the Victorian era.

"And because we drink as a separate activity, away not just from food but from children, our drinking habits are not regulated by other social norms, which makes deviant behaviour far more likely." The situation in Scotland, which has enjoyed more relaxed laws for far longer but has more acute problems than the rest of the UK, is underpinned by different historical and cultural factors, he says.

Whatever the reasons, the consequences are there for all to see every weekend on almost every high street in Britain. As such, it marks an ideal point for Blairite intervention - a place where individual rights meet societal responsibilities without the encumbrance of ideology. A populist issue where the boundaries between private and public are necessarily blurred. A problem that appears to demand New Labour's increasingly familiar strain of social authoritarianism in the name of common sense and decency.

By maintaining the distinction between the nation's most popular drug and other drugs, from cannabis to heroin and crack, the government has left alcohol out of the broader picture. It does not feature in the high-profile, cross-cabinet assault on drugs; there is no alcohol tsar. By concentrating on "yob culture", says Heather, "They are responding to a real and growing problem in this country. But the sheer quantity and severity of problems created by alcohol abuse are many times greater than all those caused by illicit drugs put together."

And even though alcohol abuse has a serious effect in every area that the government has made a priority, from homelessness to health, from crime to education (one in four school exclusions is related to alcohol) there has been no coordinated approach to the issue. The response has emanated from Downing Street and the Home Office and has been framed strictly in terms of crime and punishment.

Launching its action plan to tackle alcohol-related crime in August, the Home Office called for greater use of existing laws to confiscate alcohol from young people and to prevent the sale of alcohol to them as well as new powers for the police to close premises associated with violent and disorderly behaviour.

The approach is useful as far as it goes, say alcohol experts. The problem is that it doesn't nearly go far enough. "It's a start," says Appleby. "But we need a national alcohol strategy that deals with issues across the board rather than just the behavioural end of it. They are relatively safe while they're just dealing with yob culture. But for any lasting effect they also have to tackle the drinking habits of the average man in the pub."

webTitle: Home Office unveils new 'independent' police complaints system

fields.headline: Home Office unveils new 'independent' police complaints system
fields.trailText: A new system for investigating complaints against the police was announced today by the government.
fields.body:
A new system for investigating complaints against the police was announced today by the government.

An independent police complaints commission will take over from the existing police complaints authority, with powers to bring in civilian investigators.

Under the new system, the most grave incidents, such as deaths in police custody, would be investigated by a mixed team of civilians and police officers, led by a civilian. Pressure groups like Inquest have called repeatedly for independent inquiries into deaths in custody.

The new framework for police complaints is part of the government's response to the Macpherson report into the murder of Stephen Lawrence.

Other significant changes include allowing people other than victims of alleged misconduct to make a complaint. Greater openness will be encouraged with investigating authorities required to provide a full account of the inquiry and action taken as a result.

Dissatisfied complainants will be allowed to complain to the IPCC, which will have powers to reinvestigate.

The framework for the IPCC, published yesterday by home office minister, Charles Clarke, was drawn up after consultation with the human rights pressure group, Liberty, and the consultants KPMG.

Mr Clarke said: "While the number of complaints against the police remains low and a credit to the professionalism of the service as a whole, the government has long supported the idea of a more independent system for dealing with serious complaints.

"Our resolve was affirmed with the recommendations of the Lawrence inquiry report and the home secretary's subsequent action plan."

It is hoped the IPCC will be operating by 2003.

The current system of dealing with police complaints is based on independent supervision rather than independent investigation. The PCA supervised 950 of the most serious complaints against the police in 1999-00.

The chairman of the commission for racial equality, Gurbux Singh, welcomed the document.

He said: "Getting the handling of complaints against the police right will be an important part of the work of building a new and effective relationship of mutual support and understanding between our police services and Britain's ethnic minorities."

Press Association

webTitle: Britain signs up to protect antiquities

fields.headline: Britain signs up to protect antiquities
fields.standfirst: After 30 years of stonewalling, stolen treasure trade to be banned
fields.trailText: After 30 years of stonewalling, the government is finally considering following the lead of 91 other countries and signing the Unesco convention banning the international trade in stolen art and antiquities. The trade is estimated to be worth more than £150m a year in insured losses in Britain alone.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
After 30 years of stonewalling, the government is finally considering following the lead of 91 other countries and signing the Unesco convention banning the international trade in stolen art and antiquities. The trade is estimated to be worth more than £150m a year in insured losses in Britain alone.

Successive British governments have cited legal difficulties connected with British property law and have refused to adopt the convention, which commits states to outlaw the import and export of stolen cultural objects and allows for the recovery of stolen objects in certain circumstances.

The arts minister, Alan Howarth, accepted the problem was one of political will, not legal barriers, and promised the government would "apply ourselves urgently to the recommendation" made by an advisory panel to department of culture, media and science to adopt the Unesco convention.

Mr Howarth welcomed yesterday's report of the advisory panel which he appointed to study the illicit trade for which London is an important clearing house. Some experts have estimated the UK end of the trade at £500m a year.

The market ranges from scraps of bronze coin and glass mummy beads from unidentified archaeological sites, selling for a few pounds in antiquity and curio shops, to superb Khmer temple carvings hacked off to order at Ankor Wat and other Cambodian temple sites, smuggled out of the country and sold for up to £1m.

The visible market is the tip of the iceberg. Most of the objects are uninsured, including many thefts from museums, such as the Cezanne stolen from the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford in the small hours of the new millennium.

The worldwide trade is worth billions, and Interpol and other police agencies believe drug barons and other criminals are laundering profits through untraceable stolen antiquities.

The booming market in illegally excavated archaeological objects is fed by gangs of thieves using metal detectors. A Suffolk farmer, John Browning, from whose land one of the most notable hoards was stolen, said yesterday he had driven off nine attempted raids since September.

Mr Browning, who has spent years trying to recover the superb hoard of Roman bronze taken from his land, gave a cautious welcome to the other main recommendation from the committee, the creation of a new criminal offence of importing, dealing in or possessing illicit cultural goods.

However, the chairman of the committee, Norman Palmer, professor of commercial law at University College London, said the law could only apply to those knowingly handling stolen antiquities, and would not be retrospective.

The committee also proposes enhanced training and powers for specialist police art squads and customs and excise, and a data base which would tell both dealers and museums of the status of objects.

Nothing in the proposals would affect the bitter international rows over disputed museum collections such as the Parthenon marbles or the Benin bronzes.

 In 1995 police in the west country followed a tip and found three lorry loads of Chinese artefacts including bronze horses, ceramics and large carved headstones, laid out in a private garage, ready for an auction the following day. There was no prosecution, because of the difficulty of proving the offence of handling stolen goods, but most objects have been returned to China.

 The Sevso Treasure, of late Roman silver, valued at £40m, was to be auctioned at Sotheby's in 1990 by the Marquess of Northampton. The original export license from the Lebanon with which his family acquired the silver, proved to be false. While the collection was on promotional viewing in New York, Lebanon, Croatia and Hungary all claimed it, but none could prove ownership. The auction was cancelled, and the collection, still owned by the marquess, is unsaleable.

 At the end of the Gulf war about 3,000 objects were looted from museums in Iraq and have turned up in sales over the world, including the UK.

 The Getty Museum offered $600,000 for the Icklingham Leopard, just one among dozens of Roman bronzes illegally excavated from a site in Suffolk in the 1980s. The Getty abandoned the purchase on advice from the British Museum. Other pieces from the hoard were bought by two wealthy American private collectors from a New York gallery. After years of legal actions by the Suffolk landowner, an agreement was reached that on the death of the American owners, the pieces will be donated to the British Museum.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Love and Death | All The President's Men | Existenz | Andrei Rublev
fields.body:
Love And Death
(Woody Allen, 1975)
8pm, FilmFour

Bergmanic ruminations and quickfire gags on life and everything in a War-And-Peace Russia, where Allen plays an accidental hero out to kill Napoleon. Diane Keaton is his reluctant bride joining him on the mission, which is finally aborted by a discussion on the morality of murder. All this, and Eisensteinian battle scenes too.

All The President's Men
(Alan J Pakula, 1976)
9.30pm, Sky Cinema

How Washington Post reporters Woodward and Bernstein traced the Watergate break-in back to President Nixon's office. William Goldman's masterly, Oscar-winning screenplay extracts all the suspense of the investigation and its riveting detail, without getting bogged down in the complexity. And Pakula is in his element, showing reporters Redford and Hoffman - and Jason Robards as editor Ben Bradlee - delving into many shades of mucky dealing from their gleaming, bright-lit newspaper office.

Existenz
(David Cronenberg, 1999)
10pm, FilmFour

Probably Cronenberg's best yet, linking the Videodrome theme - addictive players hooking into weird, mind-bending techno-games - with the fetishistic sexuality of Crash: just watch 'em insert those gadgets into their spines! In some sort of real world, games inventor Jennifer Jason Leigh is on the run with security man Jude Law, but with bone guns that spit human teeth, it's a weird, thrilling trip where reality is a moot point.

Andrei Rublev
(Andrei Tarkowsky, 1966)
11.55pm, FilmFour

Rublev (played by Anatoli Solonitsyn) was a minor icon painter of medieval Russia, and Tarkowsky's historical epic traces his life through eight episodes. It's a long, compelling, at times obtuse study of faith and cruelty in barbarous times - Russia was suffering at the hands of the Tartars - that had added depths in the cold war-era Soviet Union. Among many stunning images, the final glorious montage of Rublev's work stands out.

webTitle: TV and Radio: 'Five steps to tyranny' documentary

fields.headline: The blame game
fields.standfirst: We may think we know right from wrong. But tonight, the BBC's Five Steps To Tyranny demonstrates how the most ordinary people are capable of the most monstrous acts. By  Tim Radford
fields.trailText: We may think we know right from wrong. But tonight, the BBC's Five Steps To Tyranny demonstrates how the most ordinary people are capable of the most monstrous acts. By Tim Radford.
fields.body:
Adolf Hitler did not invent the idea of Nordic supremacy: the German Society for Racial Hygiene dates from 1895, and was not - originally - intended as an anti-Semitic force. It was concerned with maintaining the vigour of a racial group. Its founder ranked the Jews along with the Aryans as two of the world's premier civilising forces. The implication, however, was that the Jews were separate. Forget about people ever being separate but equal. When people become separate, they become "them". When they become "them", they tend to become unacceptable. Once they become unacceptable, any bad things that happen to them do not matter.

Bad things have happened, since 1900, between Turk and Armenian, Russian and Jew, German and Jew, German and Slav, Hindu and Muslim, Boer and Bantu, Chinese and Tibetan, Iraqi and Kurd, Hutu and Tutsi, Serb and Bosnian, Serb and Kosovan. In each case the willingness of ordinary humans to debase and murder their neighbours has left a smear on the outgoing century. There is a lesson in how such things could come about in Five Steps To Tyranny.

Five Steps is a politics lesson, conducted by Sheena McDonald and based on a series of academic experiments, some of them so shocking they have never been repeated. In one of the most notorious, a psychologist asked volunteer interrogators to administer increasing electric shocks to a victim - an actor, of course - shrieking and begging for mercy in another room. "Do I have to do this? It hurts him", they would say, and the experimenter would answer "Do it. I will take responsibility." And most of them did it, apparently because a man with a white coat and a calm voice told them to do so. They were, after all, only obeying orders.

In 1968, after the assassination of Martin Luther King, an Iowa school teacher suggested a game for her third-year white, middle-class infants. Imagine, she said, that they were really two groups, one blue-eyed, one brown-eyed. The blue-eyed kids were good, smart and privileged, and the brown-eyed ones were stupid and naughty and would never get anywhere. Within a day or so, she had effectively recreated apartheid in the playground; one group was cock of the walk and one group was cowed and weeping. "He called me names," said one tearful child. "What did he call you?" "He called me brown-eyed."

In the most shocking example of all, in the 1970s, an American experimenter randomly divided his student volunteers into two groups, gave one epaulettes, clubs and reflector sunglasses and the other prison uniforms, and told the first group to guard the second. Each set of students proceeded to adopt their entirely fictitious personae with such terrible conviction that the three-week experiment had to be ended after five days.

There have been more limited experiments which underline a preparedness to divide into "us" and "them" and outlaw "them". In one recent demonstration, a psychologist films unwary adult, responsible Manchester United supporters as a jogger collapses nearby. When the jogger wears a Manchester United fan club shirt, the passer-by rushes to help him. When he wears a Liverpool shirt, he is left to fend for himself. There is also a somewhat less convincing experiment on what looks like a Connex South East train, in which a polite but slightly menacing male asks passengers to surrender their seats to him, for no reason other than that he asks. Many of them do. When he is accompanied by a silent figure in uniform, all of them do. This could be evidence of the kind of social compliance that led ultimately to some of the century's most terrible crimes. On the other hand, it may be a desire not to upset the sort of slightly menacing nutter to be found on Connex South East...

But there is no doubt about the programme's bottom line: tyrannies happen because ordinary people are surprisingly willing to do tyranny's dirty work.

Programmes like this can show such things with great vividness - and there is news footage from Bosnia, or from Rwanda, or from Burma to back it up with terrible clarity. It isn't clear why the majority is so often compliant, but the implication is that democracy should always be grateful to the protesters, the members of the awkward squad, the people who challenge authority.

But don't take it for granted that the awkward squad must be a force for good: in Germany, in the 1920s, Hitler was an outsider, a protester, a member of the awkward squad. When he came to power in 1932, he found that German medical professors and biologists had already installed a racial ideology for him, one which had already theorised about the elimination of sick or disabled German children, and the rejection of Jewish professionals as agents of pollution.

People had theorised in similar ways in Sweden, and the United States. But Hitler turned ideas into action, and ordinary people were soon directing the trains to Dachau, and Auschwitz. The lesson, driven home by eight decades of movie newsreel and television reportage, is that appalling things can happen anywhere. The only comfort is that it remains possible for other people to be appalled.

 Five Steps to Tyranny, 9pm, BBC2.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Last night's TV

fields.headline: Christmas moaning
fields.trailText: Kilroy | Trisha | Cutting Edge
fields.body:
Under the banner "We can't afford Christmas" on Kilroy (BBC1), Robert The Silk was at his most sympathetic and sincere. Surrounded by children whose parents couldn't splash out on designer clothes or cool trainers, he oozed heartfelt concern, asking such delicate questions as "Do you feel deprived?" and "Are you poor?" Without once stroking his expensive suit, curling his lip or wrinkling his nose in disdain, Bob nodded meaningfully when a young lad replied in an awkward whisper, "I don't feel poor. I just feel less fortunate than other people." As well you might if you had Robert Kilroy-Silk sitting next to you.

Ever the tender professional, Bob moved on to speak to a wee Scottish boy who confessed he only got a selection box from Santa last year and - wait for it - was happy with it. Bob's face was a (ragged) mask of implacability without a hint of incredulity. He didn't even finger his lapels lovingly while contemplating a Christmas with only a Crunchie for company. Not even an orange in his stocking.

As the assembled children demonstrated a stoicism lacking in many of their elders, they assured Bob they didn't really care about material possessions since they had love in their lives. Bob didn't look convinced.

Trisha (ITV) meanwhile resorted to stunt Christmas trees in order to reunite a family. "There are balls all over the stage", she sighed like some unwilling MC at a Castrators Anonymous meeting. All this to reunite a family who probably had good reason for disuniting in the first place. It was difficult not to be happy for them, however, as they looked positively normal compared to Trisha's usual guests. There wasn't a sovereign ring or hint of inbreeding among them.

With lots of colds and flus going about at the moment, it's nice to see daytime television imparting to its enlarged audience traditional Christmas messages like "Look at the poor children", and "What a dysfunctional family." Bless.

Similarly, Cutting Edge (Channel 4) sought to uncover A Very British Christmas. This meant asking children - who weren't poor - about it, along with Druids ("Dear Santa, Can I have a new cloak and a jumbo mortar and pestle for Christmas? Yours, Echeb The Darkling") and mad Christians. Some of the latter pointed to the absence of Santa from the Bible to vindicate their dreariness; on Raasay - an island whose inhabitants should perhaps have been asking Santa for an extra consonant - they weren't for having a cool Yule at all.

Under the watchful eye of Reverend James R Tallach, the Wee Free flock tutted at the festive overindulgence in food and drink. Never mind sodomy, it would seem, too many walnut whips is a one-way ticket to damnation. (Which means that that wee boy with only a selection box on Kilroy is Pandemonium-bound for sure. Poor soul. He'll get sent to the ring of Hell where they laugh at you for having cheap trainers.)

Hamley's: A Real Toy Story (Channel 4) would have had the poor children pushing their faces up against the screens of their (probably portable, perhaps black-and-white) televisions, such were the delights displayed from what might be the world's most famous toy shop. Ostensibly a report on the company's new chief executive and his task of reviving the store's reputation ("Come here! Buy stuff!), this documentary was toy pornography. Tasteful, it wasn't, though the thought of islanders on Raasay, who probably watch Countdown with envy ("Hamish! She's asking for another consonant!"), convulsing with horror was quite smirksome.

It was pomegranates at dusk when Nasty - or perhaps Hammy - Nick was confronted by Mark Fowla - comin' atcha! - in EastEnders (BBC1). After supplying Little Big Martin with some dodgy paracetamol last week, it was Nick's turn to be in need of painkillers as Mark lost his temper in a vicious stylee. One could barely bring oneself to watch, though that's more to do with the mere presence of Nick than anything else. Perhaps he should ask for a Hooded Claw outfit for Christmas and be done with it.

In Coronation Street (ITV), the sinews in poor Deirdre's neck must be at breaking point, so annoying is Ken's son, Peter. The fact he is Ken's son is frightful enough, but that he is chasing Liz McDonald too is positively perverted. The man needs help, or it's Hell for him too.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Answer me

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with... EastEnders' Lucy Benjamin
fields.trailText: Getting personal with... EastEnders' Lucy Benjamin.
fields.body:
Full name: Lucy Jane Benjamin

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why?
No.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why?
Yes, but to gee myself up so I can get into nightclubs and pubs!

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad?
Small busty blonde, fun-loving with great sense of humour.

What was the last illegal thing you did?
Fare evasion on the train when I was 21 years old.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?
I bought my mum a car for Christmas.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?
Angharad Rees, who played my mum in the 90s sitcom Close To Home.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with?
Far too many to mention, but I'd really like to work in TV again!

Has a critic ever made you cry?
Not a review, I never cry at them, but one TV journalist called me the "anorak girl" which I didn't take too kindly. I thought my character was a lot more glamourous.

What would you advertise without a fee?
An Aston Martin.

What would you never advertise?
Chicken Tonight, because of the crap song they have to sing.

What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning?
Hearing burglars downstairs, which has happened to me before.

What takes you to a "happy place"?
Love and food.

 Lucy Benjamin plays Lisa Shaw in EastEnders.

fields.headline: It's magic!
fields.trailText: Although we've grown accustomed to such scientific phenomena as morphing and virtual reality, there's still a tangible mystique about a real-life magician doing inexplicable tricks with only a top hat and a pack of cards.
fields.body:
Although we've grown accustomed to such scientific phenomena as morphing and virtual reality, there's still a tangible mystique about a real-life magician doing inexplicable tricks with only a top hat and a pack of cards. Heroes Of Magic (C4, Christmas Eve) trawls amusingly through a century of magicians, packing in crumbly old film clips of historic performers such as Cardini, Slydini and Richiardi alongside present-day candidates David Copperfield and Paul Daniels.

While the film wouldn't dream of spilling the beans about how Copperfield is able to fly around the stage or how the 1930s magician Horace Goldin fired a canary from a gun so it ended up inside a light bulb, it makes you ponder the primitive fascination of magic.

One aspect of the conjuror's art guaranteed to lure in the punters is the way you know you're being conned but you just can't work out how. Magic has always had the disreputable aura of travelling fairs and seaside fleapits about it, and it's easy to imagine that many of these magicians could have ended up as pickpockets or fraudsters if they hadn't found a niche as entertainers.

With his trimmed grey moustache, shiny blue jacket and string tie - not to mention his missing arm - Argentinian magician Rene Lavand could surely have plied a lucrative trade bamboozling wealthy widows on the Côte d'Azur. The contemporary American magician David Blaine has a hustling, lapel-grabbing style. And, as Geoffrey Durham says about the charmingly suave David Nixon, "he could have sold you anything".

Yet magic would never have survived without the baffling gifts of its finest practitioners, from the seemingly suicidal escape stunts of Harry Houdini to Maurice Fogel's daredevil "Russian Roulette" trick, in which he faces a six-man firing squad, only one of whom has an empty rifle. The British magician David Devant used to say it was "all done by kindness", plus some smoke, mirrors and sleight of hand, of course.

webTitle: Arts: Profil of photographer Erwin Wurm

fields.headline: No, I'm not saying cheese
fields.standfirst: Erwin Wurm photographs people interacting with everyday objects in the strangest ways. By  Adrian Searle
fields.trailText: Erwin Wurm photographs people interacting with everyday objects in the strangest ways. By Adrian Searle.
fields.body:
The things people do alone in a hotel room. Do a handstand against the wall with your head in the wastepaper basket. Lay on the bed, rest your head on the bedside table and balance the bedside light on your ear. Use a bagel as a door-stop. Shove pens up your nostrils and in your ears, wedge plastic film canisters over your eyes, hold a stapler between your teeth. You look ridiculous, but no one can see you. Except the camera can: the above are but a few of Austrian artist Erwin Wurm's One Minute Sculptures, performed, enacted and recorded on video one desultory afternoon at the Adelphi Hotel, Liverpool.

Wurm's photographs and videos currently fill the Photographers' Gallery in London. His art reminds me of writers' delaying tactics, when the deadline looms and the words won't flow. Stand at the window for a very long time. Have a scratch, have a biscuit. Make tea, even though you've just had coffee. Fiddle with the stapler, and accidentally hurt yourself. Staunch bleeding, then make more tea - or possibly Bovril this time. Patrol flat, work yet another shift at the window. Your eyes are unseeing, your mind empty, dangerously receptive to the more extreme and eccentric options that now begin to present themselves. How adults play, left to their own devices with everyday household objects.

Wurm's sculptures nearly always involve the conjunction of the human body and an object, or a person and a place. Sculpture always has a relationship to the body - even if it is the spectator's own. Wurm's sculptures also exist in time: not the slowed-down time of objects in galleries or the almost geological time-scale of monuments and statues, but pocket-cartoon time, the moments, seconds, minutes it takes to perform the act and to get the gag. Wurm's One Minute Sculptures raise predictable, rhetorical questions about the relationship between performance, sculpture and photography. This is less interesting than the strangeness of the images, the peculiarity of the conjunctions of people and things.

Although Wurm's work can be likened to the body sculptures of Rebecca Horn, or to Lygia Clark's manipulable objects, or to any number of Fluxus artworks and conceptual instructions, they are closer, to my mind, to the ad hoc works of Richard Tuttle, say, or the sculptures of fellow Austrian Franz West. The objects Wurm uses are never merely props. Wurm's own sculptures - or should we call them photographs? - have sometimes been appropriated and restaged by others: a One Minute Sculpture makes a fleeting appearance in a Macy Gray pop video and other works were re-staged, without consent or credit, by Ridge Forester for fashion shoots commissioned for Self Service magazine.

The spontaneity and humour of Wurm's work borders on stupidity. What he investigates, surely, is play. His images are arresting and he makes us laugh - though were you to rely on Michael Newman's catalogue essay on Wurm for the Photographers' Gallery show, you'd be hard put to find much to laugh about. But I guess Newman's academic theorising (which tries not just to put the genie back in the bottle, but to seal the bottle in a vault, and to bury the vault under a ton of bombproof concrete) is a considered foil to Wurm's light touch.

When I look at Wurm's photos of actions with bananas - two young men in suits standing close together, sharing the same banana, still in its skin - I think of the business with the banana in Krapp's Last Tape. You can't really say that Wurm's work is Beckettian, because Beckett's gags with stones, bananas, bits of string, pencil stubs, bicycles and so on are invariably painful plays on the relationship between people and the world of things. The clownishness is fraught with the recalcitrance and morbidity of objects, their farcical, unavoidable symbolism. Wurm's gags are relatively depleted, almost purely physical, even if they have a certain absurd poetry, especially when he gets other people to follow his instructions.

One series of photos, taken on a rainy day in the streets of Taipei, have an uncanny atmosphere. A girl sits in a car, a mushroom up each nostril. A man sits on the roof of a car stalled in traffic, as though he were a piece of luggage. A young woman lies face down on the wet pavement outside a household goods store, her face in a plastic bowl. A man kneels in the middle of the road, amidst the rainy reflections of neon and traffic lights. These are the sort of things that might show up, unannounced and unexplained, in a Jim Jarmusch movie.

Another series of Outdoor Sculptures are taken in Cahors, France. A man standing at a wall, as though beheaded, his head disappeared in a hole in the wall. A graveyard, with an ankle and foot emerging from another hole in a wall (this looks so like a Robert Gober sculpture it is hard to consider on its own terms). A man lying on the cobbles, a sofa lain across him, as though it had just fallen from the sky above the Rue Maréchal Foch. Somehow, this image seems to refer to the famous trick photograph of Yves Klein flying from a window.

These conjunctions are more staged incidents than sculptures. Other photographs undermine the status and dignity of the person depicted: The Bank Manager In Front of His Bank has the middle-aged banker looking utterly unconcerned, although thick white stalks of asparagus dangle from his nose, like monstrous fangs or vegetal tusks. Poor Fabio, in the video Fabio Getting Dressed, has been instructed to put on his entire wardrobe, item by item, till he is so ridiculously encumbered he can barely move. Play up the daftness of the situation and it ceases to be funny or poignant. Wurm, I am sure, wants us to dwell on the implications of these acts and images.

So stay home alone. Use a gherkin to prop your mouth open. Stand still with a whole apple in your mouth and think Magritte. Shun imaginative uses for clingfilm and a bicycle pump and it will go fine. You might even get some work done - you might be doing sculpture.

 Erwin Wurm is at the Photographers' Gallery, London WC2 (020-7831 1772), until January 21.

webTitle: Women: Young mothers and sleep deprivation

fields.headline: Tired and emotional
fields.standfirst: You share the housework and the mortgage, but who gets up when the baby cries in the night? A study of the sleep patterns of young mothers has confirmed what most already know.  Natasha Joffe reports
fields.trailText: You share the housework and the mortgage, but who gets up when the baby cries in the night? A study of the sleep patterns of young mothers has confirmed what most already know. Natasha Joffe reports.
fields.body:
My favourite new mother sleep deprivation story is about Kate. Kate found she was temporarily unable to read due to exhaustion but became adept at what she called "mindless domestic tasks". She did a lot of cooking. One day she was looking at a recipe that said: "Place the washed and scrubbed potatoes in boiling water" and she read: "Place the unsuspecting potatoes in boiling water." She became quite upset.

I like this story because it says a lot about your state of mind when you are a new mother and have had no sleep (intermittently crazed, alive to the vulnerability of small living things), and a little bit about potatoes (their defencelessness and infantile curves).

That's the funny side of the whole sleep deprivation thing. A grimmer aspect is highlighted now in the Johnson & Johnson Night and Day study of sleep patterns of new mothers which, among other sad statistics, suggests that 16 weeks after the birth, around a third of women are still suffering lack of sleep and 11% are severely sleep deprived. For 39% of those getting less than three hours' sleep in a given night, the result was something between "unhappiness" and "extreme unhappiness". These mothers feel disoriented, out of control, unable to complete simple tasks.

The other interesting finding (but are we surprised?) was that 85% of women were doing most of the night care of the baby, only 11% were sharing it equally with their partners and a mere 4% were leaving most of it to the fathers. Remember Tony Blair doing his cuddly new man thing and claiming, in answer to a reader's question in the Independent, that "it's impossible to wake Cherie once she's asleep, so the night-time tends to be my shift"? Luckily for him most new mothers didn't have the time or mental energy to buy, let alone read, the newspaper or I suspect there would have been hordes of us outside Downing Street, joining in the chorus of "Liar, liar, pants on fire".

What's happened to us all? We've got everything else sussed - we're earning as well as our male partners, the flat is jointly owned, the men are sharing the housework. We've come a long way, baby, as those spooky ads for women's cigarettes used to say when equal access to lung cancer was something to aspire to. Then suddenly the real baby's here and we are reduced to tired, tearful madwomen, ambushed by gender stereotypes.

But how much should the man be doing? Most of the women in my antenatal group took the view that when the woman is away from her job and the man is at work, it's fair that the woman undertake all the night care during the week. Other women I have spoken to agree. Marie, for example, thinks it is fair enough for her husband to sleep in the spare room: "I see no point in both of us being tired and the fact that he is relatively well rested means that when he comes in from work, I can rest for a bit and likewise at weekends." Again and again, that seems to be all many women are looking for: a chance to catch up on sleep.

Is this because, 30-odd years after Millett, Friedan et al taught us otherwise, we still fail to see childcare as real work? Psychotherapist Susie Orbach thinks so. The perception, she says, is that the woman is at home doing nothing. "This terrible deal gets struck where the person at work gets to sleep through because the other person is doing 'nothing' all day."

Looking after a new baby "is so fantastically fatiguing and emotionally overwhelming, the person at work could do with less sleep because they are doing something they know how to do, whereas the new mother is learning something new every second".

The danger is that once the pattern is set during maternity leave, it never really changes. Although the Night and Day study did not include any women who had returned to work, all the recent research shows that in families in which women and men both work full-time, the majority of women do a great deal more domestic work than their partners. That is likely to include the night-time care of children, which goes on for years. As Susan Maushart says in her book The Mask of Motherhood: "I have no doubt sleep deprivation is the greatest single contributing factor to women's precarious mental state during the active years of early mothering. It is also the least researched."

So why aren't we insisting on men doing more? It seems sometimes women themselves have a hard time moving away from a perception that work involves the accomplishment of particular tasks, towards an acceptance that the chaos involved in looking after a new baby is also work. Dr Harriet Gross, the psychologist who conducted the Night and Day study, says that what stresses out many sleep-deprived new mothers is the feeling that they haven't accomplished anything because they have not completed various finite tasks they may have set for themselves in a day instead of being absorbed by the endless round of dressing, changing, feeding, holding and jiggling that is babycare.

For some women, too, the reason they don't insist the man does more at night is the enjoyment they derive from caring for the baby. As Gross says: "Looking after children is a tiring activity which is not perceived to be work because of the other benefits." In other words, because of the pleasure you get when she smiles at you from her bath, you would feel guilty if you treated looking after your baby as work.

Other women practise what psychologists have called "gatekeeping" behaviour: they don't let the man take on many of the burdens of looking after the new baby because they value the intensity of the one-on-one relationship with it and don't really want the dad intruding (or they worry about his competence).

For every mother jealously guarding her turf, however, I suspect there must be several like Claire, who says ruefully: "My husband tried to do the Friday and Saturday night feeds but it never worked well. I would have to wake him as he never heard the baby crying and I found it difficult to sleep until the baby went back to sleep."

Many couples are just mucking along, the men feeling their way as much as the women. Julian, father of six-week-old Noah, says: "You start off with the best intentions. For the first couple of weeks, I was changing him and Ally was feeding him at night. People at work cut you some slack for some time. Now I'm working harder, I would be completely destroyed if I didn't get sleep."

Although he's now doing less at night, Julian is clear that being a full-time mother is "just like a job". He tries to do as much as he can during evenings and at weekends, and unlike many men, he hasn't moved to the spare room. "We're both absolutely exhausted all the time," he says, "but I'm quite happy to feel like death warmed up to feel like a family."

Probably the only way to make a radical change to that position would be to institute universal, substantial paternity leave, so that both parents could concentrate on childcare for the first few months and patterns could be set that didn't leave working mothers exhausted for years.

In our real world, in which men cannot on the whole take months off work after the birth of a child, the solution probably has to be tailored to the individual case. It doesn't seem sensible that a father who is working as a brain surgeon or a bus driver should do so on three hours' sleep. The mother at home may put the laundry in the fridge and cry a lot, but she (probably) isn't going to kill anybody. On the other hand, in many jobs, much of the time, the sky isn't going to fall if a new father is knackered. After all, isn't being with baby what it's all about?

webTitle: G2: Sidelines

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: Ah, Christmas. Logs on the fire, gifts under the tree, ill-advised dancing following accelerated alcohol consumption. But if you're female, at least you'll be giving your liver a break on December 25, if not your varicose veins.
fields.body:
 Ah, Christmas. Logs on the fire, gifts under the tree, ill-advised dancing following accelerated alcohol consumption. But if you're female, at least you'll be giving your liver a break on December 25, if not your varicose veins. Research for Dixons reveals that the average British woman spends seven hours confined to the kitchen on Christmas Day. No wonder we don't believe in Santa Claus any more. Pass the cooking sherry.

 Poor Chris Evans, labouring as he is under the double curse of being ginger and being allowed to enjoy the company of youthful popstrels only during the week their next single is due for release (step forward, Ms Halliwell and now Billie Piper, spotted in "an embrace" with Evans last weekend). Now then, girls - stop using Chris! He has feelings, too, even if he often gives the impression of having mislaid them some time ago and forgotten to pick them up from lost property.

 More importantly, we deplore the use of red hair as a synonym for lack of sex appeal. Perhaps someone ought to mention this to Tony Parsons, who yesterday succinctly described green goddess Charlie Dimmock as "a woman with a body like a sack of organic fertiliser and a face to match". But at least organic isn't poisonous, Tone.

Pass the cooking sherry.  Poor Chris Evans, labouring as he is under the double curse of being ginger and being allowed to enjoy the company of youthful popstrels only during the week their next single is due for release (step forward, Ms Halliwell and now Billie Piper, spotted in "an embrace" with Evans last weekend). Now then, girls - stop using Chris! He has feelings, too, even if he often gives the impression of having mislaid them some time ago and forgotten to pick them up from lost property.  More importantly, we deplore the use of red hair as a synonym for lack of sex appeal. Perhaps someone ought to mention this to Tony Parsons, who yesterday succinctly described green goddess Charlie Dimmock as "a woman with a body like a sack of organic fertiliser and a face to match". But at least organic isn't poisonous, Tone.

webTitle: Obituary: Bengt Hambraeus

fields.headline: Bengt Hambraeus
fields.standfirst: Prolific composer of the Swedish avant-garde
fields.trailText: Prolific composer of the Swedish avant-garde.
fields.body:
Bengt Hambraeus, who has died aged 72, was one of the most significant figures of postwar Swedish music. A prolific composer of almost 200 works, he was best known for his pioneering organ music, for instance, Constellations I (1958) - later acknowledged by György Ligeti as a primary influence on his own ground-breaking Volumina (1961) - and Interferences (1962).

Hambraeus was the first Swedish composer to write an electro-acoustic score, Doppelrohr II, in 1955, and in his classic Constellations II (1959), taped sections from Constellations I were mixed with electronically created sounds. These placed Hambraeus at the forefront of the Nordic avant-garde, a position he maintained with an uncommon integrity of purpose, never needing to court sensation or deliberately provoke audiences, as did Ligeti.

Born in Stockholm, Hambraeus began studying the organ in 1944, concentrating on the great German tradition of JS Bach and Reger, to whose memory his early Organ Sonata in E minor (1946) and Toccata Monumentum per Max Reger (1973) were dedicated. In 1947, he enrolled at Uppsala University for a degree in musicology, art history and religious studies.

He retained an interest in the music of the past all his life, contributing several articles to the Scandinavian Medieval Dictionary. From 1951-56 he worked towards a PhD on Renaissance music, while regularly attending the new music summer schools at Darmstadt, where he encountered Messiaen, Adorno, Cage, Boulez and Stockhausen.

In his own music, the two interests often come energetically into contact, as in the central panel of his choral-and-orchestral Symphonia Sacra in Tempore Passionis (1985-86), or the melodic profiles of many items in the four volumes of his Livre d'Orgue (1981). As early as 1948, he had written Music for Ancient Strings for an ensemble of five violas da gamba and harpsichord, and in 1963 composed a Notturno for an ensemble featuring crumhorn, viola da gamba and claviorganum.

From the outset, Hambraeus's music covered a much wider expressive landscape than the majority of organist-composers. In style, it ranged from Hindemithian neo-classicism (the 1948 Concerto for organ and strings) to the cerebral serialism of Spectrogramm (1953). His output embraced most major musical forms, with four operas - including the church opera Se Människan (Ecce Homo, 1970) and, specially for radio, Sagan (1979) - plus the ballet Klassiskt Spel (1965) for pre-recorded tape.

He composed a second organ concerto, Continuo a partire da Pachelbel (1975), and one for piano (1992), a major utterance, though as yet unrecorded, as well as the important orchestral scores Transfiguration (1963), Rencontres (1971) and Ricordanza (1975-76). In the field of chamber music, he produced three string quartets (1948-1967), sonatas and other works for an enormous variety of unusual instrumental combinations.

Hambraeus's output for his own instrument was also extensive, with many works now established in the repertoire. Often his organ works were the vehicle for more privately motivated music, as with the Missa pro Organo in memoriam Messiaen (1992), or the Triptyque for Organ, with MIDI (1994), composed in memory of his son Michael, who had died that year, aged 33.

His magnum opus, however, will remain his huge choral trilogy comprising the fifth and last of his Constellations series (1983, with organ and two amplified sopranos), Symphonia Sacra in Tempore Passionis, and Apocalipsis cum Figuris secundum Dürer (1987, with bass and organ). These massive, at times unrelenting, scores also point to Hambraeus's lifelong interest in world music.

Hambraeus was a noted teacher and administrator, and worked for Swedish Radio from 1957-72. During this time he wrote the incidental scores to several stage, radio and television plays, including Euripides's Bacchae (1959), Strindberg's Ghost Sonata (1962) and Othello (1964).

In 1972, he accepted a post as visiting professor at McGill University in Canada; made associate professor the following year and full professor in 1975, he remained on the staff until 1995, having settled permanently there to take advantage of the technological opportunities. He continued to compose actively; his last piece with tape, Canvas with Mirrors, was completed in 1990.

Hambraeus was also an accomplished scholar and writer, producing several major articles and books on topics from Stokowski's Bach transcriptions and Buxtehude to reminiscences of the Darmstadt summer schools and, most recently, 20th Century Performance Practice (1997).

In 1960, he married Enid Odenaes, who survives him, along with a daughter.

webTitle: Obituary: Sir Florizel Glasspole

fields.headline: Sir Florizel Glasspole
fields.standfirst: Trade union founder and Jamaica's first black governor-general
fields.trailText: Trade union founder and Jamaica's first black governor-general.
fields.body:
Sir Florizel Augustus Glasspole, who has died aged 91, played an integral part in the three most important stages of the development of modern Jamaica - the foundation of a modern trade union movement, the transition through internal self-government to independence, and in negotiating the sometimes difficult waters of international politics. He was also his country's governor-general from 1973 to 1991, at a time of heightened domestic confrontation and the regional Grenada crisis of 1983.

One of five children of a Methodist minister, Glasspole was educated at Wolmer's high school for boys, a college more generally known for producing five West Indies wicketkeepers. Glasspole himself took part in athletics, cricket and football, and excelled academically. He considered a career in law, but his parents could not afford to send him overseas to study, so he became an accountant.

Working in this capacity in the sugar estates of rural St Thomas, he was appalled by the conditions of agricultural workers. Consequently, he took part in the stirring of trade union and political activity in the island throughout the 1930s. He was co-founder of the Jamaica United Clerks' Association - launched, famously, at a meeting under a tamarind tree in 1937 - and, following widespread unrest and a sugar workers' strike in 1938, joined the Trade Union Advisory Council, of which he became general secretary, and the newly-formed People's National party (PNP), led by Norman Manley. Glasspole was thus in at the beginning of Jamaican politics.

Numerous trade union appointments followed, and in 1944 he was elected as representative for East Kingston and Port Royal, one of only a handful of PNP successes in a landslide victory for the more conservative Jamaica Labour party. In 1952, the Marxist sector of the PNP was expelled and the party and the trade union movement restructured - the Marxists took the TUC with them. Glasspole, however, who was on the conservative wing of the PNP, became general secretary of the new National Workers' Union.

When Manley led the PNP to victory in 1955, Glasspole was appointed minister of labour and later minister of education. He showed such vigour in settling disputes that Manley referred to him as the "dean of the labour movement in Jamaica".

That government shattered on the 1961 referendum - on whether Jamaica should remain in the embryonic Federation of the West Indies - and, the following year, Sir Alexander Bustamante led the JLP to victory, and his country out of the federation and into independence.

After a decade in opposition, the PNP returned to power under Michael Manley, the son of the former premier. Glasspole was appointed governor-general, his country's third, in 1973. He was knighted in 1981.

When Richard Hart, who was one of the four Marxists expelled from the PNP, called on the governor-general at King's House, his official residence in Kingston, he was invited to view the new uniform which Manley had allowed Glasspole to design for himself; Hart regarded the costume as being slightly "pompous".

Although he believed that Glasspole's most valuable contribution was in trade union work, Hart nonetheless acknowledged that Sir Florizel obtained greater satisfaction in the post of governor-general, and in the achievement of "a black man replacing an Englishman, with plumes and all". By coming from the more conservative wing of the more radical of Jamaica's two main parties, as well as by his hard work and efficiency, he brough together all strands of the nation.

His wife, Inga, whom he married in 1934, died in 1999. They had one daughter, Sara Lou.

 Sir Florizel Augustus Glasspole, trade unionist and politician, born September 25 1909; died November 25 2000

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on Billie Piper

fields.headline: No: 1784
fields.standfirst: Billie Piper
fields.trailText: Billie Piper
fields.body:
Status: Home-grown, youthful pop sensation of the Britney Spears ilk.

Appearance: Smooth body, great contours. An exhibition of radically innovative features such as significant weight reduction and a higher level of equipment - all available in a range of different colours.

You what? Sorry, was I saying that out loud? I was dreaming of the new Ferrari Modena 360 with it's aluminium frame, body shell and chassis components.

Thank you, but pass notes is no place for blatant product placements. Besides, aren't we supposed to be talking about Billie? Ah yes. Her new single, Walk of Life, is out now (available at all good record shops).

That's it? That's all you've got to tell us? What kind of a backhander is she giving you? The Modena 360, if all goes according to plan.

How so? This weekend Billie found herself with an unexpected Christmas present from that bastion of romance, DJ Chris Evans. Overcome by love/goodwill/hunger for publicity (delete as applicable) he bought her the £110,000 Modena filled with roses.

But isn't she going out with Ritchie Neville from Five? An on-off relationship in which Evans obviously felt there was room for manoeuvre.

You mean reversing round corners and three-point turns? No, I mean muscling in on someone else's lady.

So Chris is going at it full throttle. What does Billie have to say about this love interest? "I'm puzzled. It's like something out of a film."

A bad film. Why?

She can't drive. Shame. Oh well. I'm ready, waiting and willing to take it off her hands.

How charitable of you. But first remind me: "Pop star with new single is rumoured to be romanced by DJ Chris." Haven't I heard this somewhere before? Geri was a long time ago now. And besides, she only got a Ford Mondeo.

Do say: "I'm sure the theory test can't be that hard."

Don't say: "You're going at 70mph. What's your stopping distance?"

webTitle: Obituary: Sir William Henderson

fields.headline: Sir William Henderson
fields.standfirst: His researches checked the scourge of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: His researches checked the scourge of foot and mouth disease.
fields.body:
Sir William Henderson, who has died aged 87, was a Scottish veterinary surgeon and research scientist who became, in retirement, director of the London Zoo. But he began his distinguished professional career as a world expert on foot and mouth disease (FMD).

When he started his research in 1939, foot and mouth was a major cause of economic loss in much of Europe, South America, Asia and Africa. Henderson rose rapidly to become deputy director of the FMD Research Institute at Pirbright, Surrey, and subsequently (1957-66) director of the foot and mouth disease centre at the Pan American Health Organisation in Rio de Janeiro.

On return to the United Kingdom he became, successively, director of the Agricultural Health Council's Institute of Animal Health (1967-72), secretary to the Agricultural Research Council (ARC, 1972-78) and president of the Zoological Society of London, 1984-89.

The only son of a company manager, Henderson was educated at George Watson's College in Edinburgh, and took a veterinary qualification at the Royal Veterinary College and Edinburgh University. As a young researcher at the Animal Virus Research Institute, Pirbright, he developed an accurate and sensitive method for measuring the amount of FMD in infectious materials, by multiple inoculations into the tongue of anaesthetised cattle. Later, he used the same technique with vesicular stomatitis viruses in cattle. This work earned him an Edinburgh DSc.

In Rio, Henderson was responsible for diagnosis and vaccine control in most of Latin America. He learned Spanish and Portuguese, and fostered an improvement in international collaboration that earned him wide influence and many awards from professional associations and governments. He advised the US and UK governments on safe importation of ruminant meat, especially from Argentina.

At the Institute of Animal Health, he carried through a major programme of modernisation of laboratory buildings. Then, in 1972, he was invited by the then minister of agriculture, James Prior, to take on the job of ARC secretary, at the same time as another top scientific administrator, Sir Charles Periera, became chief scientist at the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (Maff).

Fortunately, the two men had similar backgrounds and viewpoints, for they were called on to apply the customer-contractor relationship that had been implicit in the Rothschild Report (1972) on the organisation of government research and development. By agreeing to moderate the impact of a potential transfer of more than 50% of the ARC funds to Maff, they ensured a smooth transition to the new regime.

In retirement, Henderson became a lively chairman of the veterinary advisory committee of the Horserace Betting Levy Board and initiated moves by Lord Carnavon to establish the Equine Virology Research Foundation. He was appointed chairman, from 1979-81, of the new Genetic Manipulation Advisory Group, a consultant to the Wellcome Foundation and a board member of Celltech and Wellcome Biotechnology.

When Sir William, at the age of 70, succeeded Lord Zuckerman as chairman of the Zoological Society of London, its direction and finances were uncertain. With Lord Peyton of Yeovil as treasurer, Henderson obtained a government grant of £10m to give the zoo time to recover its self-supporting status and attain wider scientific integration.

He was knighted in 1976 and elected to a fellowship of the Royal Society of London. He received numerous other honours and honorary doctorates. Throughout his extraordinarily diverse and active life "Gregor" Henderson, as he was known, remained a genial and approachable man, an efficient chairman skilled in obtaining a consensus near to his own convictions, and a great memoriser of people and their personal qualities.

He is survived by Beryl, his wife of almost 60 years, and four sons.

 Sir William 'Gregor' MacGregor Henderson, veterinary surgeon, research scientist and administrator, born July 17 1913; died November 29 2000

webTitle: Corrections and clarifications

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Highlighting a BBC television programme called Mythical Journeys, the current edition of the Guide, page 63, said that the show would follow the travails of the legendary Thracian poet Orpheus in the wake of him "losing his wife, Eurydice, in the underground". Even in the realm of Greek mythology this is unlikely. Underworld, rather.
fields.body:
Highlighting a BBC television programme called Mythical Journeys, the current edition of the Guide, page 63, said that the show would follow the travails of the legendary Thracian poet Orpheus in the wake of him "losing his wife, Eurydice, in the underground". Even in the realm of Greek mythology this is unlikely. Underworld, rather.

A leading article yesterday, page 19, argued that Muhammad Ali's condition testified to the dangers of boxing: "He has been reduced to virtual immobility, his once-fast tongue slowed and slurred - all because he took punches for three decades." In fact, Ali's condition stems from Parkinson's disease. The Parkinson's Disease Society in London says that research has so far found no link between blows to the head and this illness.

In an article entitled Snooker braced for a big split, page 8, Sport, December 16, we wrongly said the 10 events in the TSN snooker tour would be worth £6m each. They are worth £6m in total.

New Media's review of the year on page 26, Media Guardian, yesterday, slipped in abbreviating digital terrestrial television as DDT, a pesticide.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number.

webTitle: Letters: The real arguments against monarchy

fields.headline: The real arguments against monarchy
fields.trailText: The case for abolishing the monarchy is not helped by the kind of Orwellian rewriting of English/British history evident in Hywel Williams' article (Nursery nation, December 16). To say the Hanoverian Anglican establishment was as "obscurantist" as continental Roman Catholic ones is nonsense.

The case for abolishing the monarchy is not helped by the kind of Orwellian rewriting of English/British history evident in Hywel Williams' article (Nursery nation, December 16). To say the Hanoverian Anglican establishment was as "obscurantist" as continental Roman Catholic ones is nonsense. Catholic monarchy equated with suppression of intellectual enquiry, lack of free civil association, absence of a free press or religious liberty - and no parliamentary limits on royal power. Hanoverian England and Presbyterian Scotland, though, produced the industrial and agrarian revolutions, the Scottish enlightenment and a civil society that was the envy of Europe.

Despotic Catholic France, Spain and Italy had no room for nonconformist churches, dissenting academies, freethinking Unitarian scientists or a nascent City of London.

In the circumstances of the time, the Protestant settlement served Britain remarkably well. Our 18th-century forebears rightly saw the integral connection between authoritarian Catholic religion and authoritarian government (an earlier generation of Guardian readers would never have forgotten this). As for "1789 and the collapse of dynasticism" turning European states into model governments, actually it was Europe's Catholic ex-monarchies (Italy, Spain, Portugal, Hungary) that started the fashion for fascism across most of 1930s Europe, while Protestant constitutional monarchies in Scandinavia, Holland and Britain stood firm for democracy.

The case against Britain's monarchy is not that it involves anti-Catholic discrimination, but that it is hideously expensive and enables the executive to abuse the royal prerogative.
Rev BG Cooper
Edinburgh

 God help us if the monarchy were all that stood between us and the electoral practices of Florida (Letters, December 16). Fortunately, we also have a local government service that does not depend on patronage and returning officers who would not dream of declaring a result until every vote was counted and every doubtful vote scrutinised and agreed on by all the candidates involved.
Lynne Armstrong
Portsmouth
LynneRA@aol.com

webTitle: Letters: Unions in the internet age

fields.headline: Unions in the internet age
fields.trailText: I thought that with such a headline (Unions.dot.com, December 18), Jane Martinson might have mentioned some of the remarkable ways unions are using new technology.
fields.body:
I thought that with such a headline (Unions.dot.com, December 18), Jane Martinson might have mentioned some of the remarkable ways unions are using new technology. Growth in US unions is attributed to low unemployment, instability in the hi-tech sector, the new leadership of the AFL-CIO.

But another reason is the increasing embrace of the internet by unions, allowing greater efficiency but also such things as online recruitment and solidarity campaigns. US unions recruiting in the hi-tech sector allow potential members to sign up online. But even modest efforts by UK unions have had some success, with one reporting nearly 1,000 new members joining through website inquiries in the last year.

All union campaigns these days, be they the organising drive at Amazon.com or the effort to save jobs at Vauxhall, have an online di mension and these are comprehensively reported upon on the LabourStart website (www.labourstart.org).
Eric Lee
London

 There has been self-congratulation in the media over the £100,000 won for the Indian stonemasons building the temple in Wembley who were being paid below the minimum wage (They came to Britain to earn 30p an hour, December 12). But it was only pressure by Ucatt, the building workers' union, that secured the gains. And there is still a long way to go. We want the site owners, Shrico, to pay the rate for the job; to house workers in decent accommodation; and to undertake not to sack workers for complaining. The government should tighten the rules so that work permits cannot be revoked at will.
Ben Rickman
Brent Trades Union Council

webTitle: Letters: Quaker oast

fields.headline: Quaker oast
fields.trailText: David McKie finds it odd that a pub should be named after Benjamin Beale "since he was a Quaker" (A marvel for Margate, December 14). Brought up in a teetotal Quaker family, I, too, would once have found it strange.
fields.body:
David McKie finds it odd that a pub should be named after Benjamin Beale "since he was a Quaker" (A marvel for Margate, December 14). Brought up in a teetotal Quaker family, I, too, would once have found it strange. But research into family history has shown that my maternal grandmother's family, the Crowleys of Alton and Croydon, like many other Quakers, were brewers. My great-great-grandfather, Abraham Crowley, insisted workmen be served bread and cheese with their pints. This arguably makes him the inventor of the pub lunch.

In the 1880s, my great-grandmother was persuaded to sell her shares in the family brewery and embrace teetotalism. Thereafter the family divided - some stayed Quaker and turned teetotal, others joined the Church of England and continued to brew.
Carolyn Shaw
London
