webTitle: Letters: Choices on the clone bill

fields.headline: Choices on the clone bill
fields.trailText: MPs vote today on the government's proposals allowing limited research into disease using early human embryos (MPs agonise over matters of life and death, December 16).
fields.body:
MPs vote today on the government's proposals allowing limited research into disease using early human embryos (MPs agonise over matters of life and death, December 16). Embryo stem-cell research is not about sacrificing embryonic lives or cannibalising minuscule people, as some would have it. It is about extracting stem cells from the pre-implantation embryo, at a stage when there is not even the trace of a central nervous system. Many people would find it hard to identify the 100 or so unspecialised cells that make up the early human embryo as an individual human life.

The ethical and moral dilemmas have proved difficult to resolve, but for those who find their lives devastated cruelly by disorders that might one day be cured by therapies arising, the issue is stunningly simple. Which do we value the most, the 100-odd cells of the six-day old embryo that was never to be, or the lives of men, women and children who presently must endure the miseries of disease each day? The answer is quite clear to me.
Dr Maureen McHugh
Special Parkinson's Research Interest Group (Spring)

 Your excellent report needs some clarification regarding therapeutic cloning. Licences might be obtainable under existing UK law to use cloning technology for purposes such as research into infertility, but they cannot at present be granted for investigations into stem-cell therapies for degenerative diseases. The restricted supply of human eggs means the widespread use of cloning technology for therapies is a remote prospect. The primary value of research on this technique would be to advance understanding of how healthy cells from patients might be converted directly into whatever type of tissue is required for treatment. The proposed regulations would ensure that the use of cloning technology is strictly regulated, while continuing the ban on reproductive cloning.
Prof Richard Gardner
Royal Society working group on therapeutic cloning

webTitle: Leader: The three Millennium cities

fields.headline: A tale of three cities
fields.standfirst: But what a silly way to choose
fields.trailText: But what a silly way to choose.
fields.body:
Inverness will have no complaints. Nor will Wolverhampton; nor Brighton and Hove - though those two may chafe against each other even more than usual, now that they have been formally conjoined. All three (or is it four?) will be celebrating this morning, since they have just been "officially" declared cities. The complaints will be left to those denied: Luton, Newport and Wrexham among the 36 places that will have to soldier on as mere towns. What is more, the rejection of all six Welsh aspirants and both of Northern Ireland's has aggravated national sensibilities as well as local ones.

But there is a greater cause for ambivalence about yesterday's news than the disappointment of those left out. Archie Norman, for the Tories, got close to it when he objected to the whole process which arrived at yesterday's decision. He suspected political calculation, noting that all three of the winners include constituencies narrowly held by Labour. With an election near, a dose of civic PR certainly will not hurt. (Still, if that was the criterion, Luton, reeling from Vauxhall, would surely have won.)

What Mr Norman complained about was the process by which city status is granted by personal command of the Queen, on ministerial advice. In other words, our old friend crown prerogative. That is why parliament had no role in yesterday's choice and why the candidate cities could do no more than wait to hear the whim of Her Majesty's ministers.

The same point was neatly highlighted by yesterday's claim that Tony Blair had pencilled March 29 2001 as the date of the general election. Such stories will proliferate between now and the spring. Why? Because dissolving parliament is one more power that rests exclusively in the hands of the executive, in the form of the prime minister. Whether it is naming cities or naming dates, the PM has too much power. It is not just a few of our towns which need to become cities; our constitution needs to grow up.

webTitle: Film: The best Ethan Hawke scene

fields.headline: The best Ethan Hawke scene
fields.standfirst: Hamlet
fields.trailText: Hamlet
fields.body:
A sumptuous apartment on the Upper West Side of New York, overlooking Central Park. Hamlet (Ethan Hawke) is sitting brooding by the window, as his sometime lover Ophelia (Julia Stiles) sits at a table in the centre of the room. He turns to her.

"Are you honest?"

She looks up quizzically.

"My Lord?"

"Are you fair?"

"What means your Lordship?"

Hamlet gazes at her.

"I did love you once."

"Indeed, you made me believe so."

"You should not have believed me. I loved you not."

He stands and walks over to where she is sitting. Tenderly, he begins to rub her shoulders.

"Get thee to a nunnery. Why wouldst thou be a breeder of sinners?"

He sits beside her, his face mere inches from hers.

"I am myself indifferent honest, and yet I could accuse me of more things that it were better my mother had not borne me."

They kiss.

See also: Gattaca, Alive, Search And Destroy, Dead Poets Society, Reality Bites

Don't see also: Before Sunrise

Pointless trivia: Ethan Hawke directed the video for bespectacled singer-songwriter Lisa Loeb's Stay, in which he cast his own cat.

More pointless trivia: Ethan Hawke recently joined forces with (among others) Michael Douglas and Naomi Campbell to campaign against America's gun laws.

webTitle: UK concession over art treasures

fields.headline: UK concession over art treasures
fields.standfirst: Trade in stolen artefacts faces clampdown after years of inaction
fields.trailText: Trade in stolen artefacts faces clampdown after years of inaction
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
After 30 years of stonewalling, the government is finally considering following the lead of 91 other countries and signing the Unesco convention banning the international trade in stolen art and antiquities. The trade is estimated to be worth more than £150m a year in insured losses in Britain alone.

Successive British governments have cited legal difficulties connected with British property law and have refused to adopt the convention, which commits states to outlaw the import and export of stolen cultural objects and allows for the recovery of stolen objects in certain circumstances.

The arts minister, Alan Howarth, accepted the problem was one of political will, not legal barriers, and promised the government would "apply ourselves urgently to the recommendation" made by an advisory panel to the department of culture, media and sport to adopt the Unesco convention.

Mr Howarth welcomed yesterday's report of the advisory panel which he appointed to study the illicit trade for which London is an important clearing house. Some experts have estimated the UK end of the trade at £500m a year.

The market ranges from scraps of bronze coin and glass mummy beads from unidentified archaeological sites, selling for a few pounds in antiquity and curio shops, to superb Khmer temple carvings hacked off to order at Ankor Wat and other Cambodian temple sites, smuggled out of the country and sold for up to £1m.

The visible market is the tip of the iceberg. Most of the objects are uninsured, including many thefts from museums, such as the Cezanne stolen from the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford in the small hours of the new millennium.

The worldwide trade is worth billions, and Interpol and other police agencies believe drug barons and other criminals are laundering profits through untraceable stolen antiquities.

The booming market in illegally excavated archaeological objects is fed by gangs of thieves using metal detectors. A Suffolk farmer, John Browning, from whose land one of the most notable hoards was stolen, said yesterday he had driven off nine attempted raids since September.

Mr Browning, who has spent years trying to recover the superb hoard of Roman bronze taken from his land, gave a cautious welcome to the other main recommendation from the committee, the creation of a new criminal offence of importing, dealing in or possessing illicit cultural goods.

However, the chairman of the committee, Norman Palmer, professor of commercial law at University College London, said the law could only apply to those knowingly handling stolen antiquities, and would not be retrospective.

The committee also proposes enhanced training and powers for specialist police art squads and customs and excise, and a data base which would tell both dealers and museums of the status of objects.

Nothing in the proposals would affect the bitter international rows over disputed museum collections such as the Parthenon marbles or the Benin bronzes.

webTitle: Charity maintains Queen's private picture collection

fields.headline: Charity maintains Queen's private picture collection
fields.trailText: The Royal Collection Trust, a charity set up to mainitan the Queen's private picture collection, has recieved £14m of funds which were intended for repair work on Windsor Castle.
fields.body:
The Royal Collection Trust, a charity set up to mainitan the Queen's private picture collection, has recieved £14m of funds which were intended for repair work on Windsor Castle.

The sums raised from the visitors' fees to Windsor Castle and Buckingham Palace had been earmarked for fire repair work at the castle, Alan Williams, Labour MP for Swansea West, told the Commons public accounts committee.

Of the £6.8m raised from the castle entrance fees in 1997, just a third was used for fire repairs.

Mr Williams argued that, since the palace had originally justified charging for entry in 1993 by arguning £26m was needed to repair the castle, it was wrong that the money should be spent elsewhere without it being accountable to the taxpayer.

In defence of the move, the keeper of the privy purse, Sir Michael Peat, told MPs that the Queen's collection was larger than the National Gallery, the Tate and the National Portrait Gallery put together yet received just a fraction of government funding.

webTitle: Psychiatrist put on sex offenders register after attacking patient

fields.headline: Psychiatrist put on sex offenders register after attacking patient
fields.trailText: A retired consultant was yesterday put on the sex offenders register for indecently assaulting a highly vulnerable psychiatric patient 14 years ago.
fields.body:
A retired consultant was yesterday put on the sex offenders register for indecently assaulting a highly vulnerable psychiatric patient 14 years ago.

William Kerr, 75, will remain on the list for five years for the offence but the jury failed to reach a verdict on 12 other charges including two of rape.

The court heard that the woman was referred to him by her GP after experiencing an overdose, the death of her husband and behavioural problems with her young daughter. Kerr told her that all her problems were sexual and then assaulted her. He also exposed himself to the woman on a later visit.

Judge Arthur Myerson, at Leeds crown court, also gave the crown prosecution service a week to decide whether to seek a retrial of the undecided charges.

A jury at a previous hearing had decided that Kerr was too ill to plead, but the seriousness of the charges led to the unusual "hearing of fact" trial, held without Kerr having to give evidence from the dock.

The three-week case heard claims of systematic abuse over a 30-year career. Patients from Harrogate, Ripon and York said that their complaints were disregarded by their GPs as hysterical over-reactions by unstable women.

Kerr was accused of abusing his power as the area's principal psychiatric consultant, and telling vulnerable women that their complaints would not be believed.

At yesterday's hearing he was cleared of two charges of indecent assault. He was also cleared last week of two rape charges and two of indecent assault. Many of the alleged offences date back two decades before Kerr retired in 1988.

After the verdict, the judge said that he had extremely limited sentencing powers in a "hearing of fact" case.

He gave an absolute discharge to Kerr, who was not at the trial, saying that the "very difficult" case and the absence of a plea meant that the retired consultant was not formally guilty of a criminal offence.

"The verdict recognises, however, that Dr Kerr has taken advantage of one of his patients for his own sexual gratification," he said, adding that because the former consultant was in "precarious" physical and mental health, he was not a danger to the public.

"I have little doubt that there are those in this court who believe that this is not an adequate order," he said. "That is not for them to decide, that is for me. No other sentence is practical in the circum-stances."

Kerr was arrested in 1997 after a former patient made a complaint to the police.

Ensuing media publicity led to 13 other women coming forward with allegations of rape and indecent assault.
fields.bodyText: A retired consultant was yesterday put on the sex offenders register for indecently assaulting a highly vulnerable psychiatric patient 14 years ago. William Kerr, 75, will remain on the list for five years for the offence but the jury failed to reach a verdict on 12 other charges including two of rape. The court heard that the woman was referred to him by her GP after experiencing an overdose, the death of her husband and behavioural problems with her young daughter. Kerr told her that all her problems were sexual and then assaulted her. He also exposed himself to the woman on a later visit. Judge Arthur Myerson, at Leeds crown court, also gave the crown prosecution service a week to decide whether to seek a retrial of the undecided charges. A jury at a previous hearing had decided that Kerr was too ill to plead, but the seriousness of the charges led to the unusual "hearing of fact" trial, held without Kerr having to give evidence from the dock. The three-week case heard claims of systematic abuse over a 30-year career. Patients from Harrogate, Ripon and York said that their complaints were disregarded by their GPs as hysterical over-reactions by unstable women. Kerr was accused of abusing his power as the area's principal psychiatric consultant, and telling vulnerable women that their complaints would not be believed. At yesterday's hearing he was cleared of two charges of indecent assault. He was also cleared last week of two rape charges and two of indecent assault. Many of the alleged offences date back two decades before Kerr retired in 1988. After the verdict, the judge said that he had extremely limited sentencing powers in a "hearing of fact" case. He gave an absolute discharge to Kerr, who was not at the trial, saying that the "very difficult" case and the absence of a plea meant that the retired consultant was not formally guilty of a criminal offence. "The verdict recognises, however, that Dr Kerr has taken advantage of one of his patients for his own sexual gratification," he said, adding that because the former consultant was in "precarious" physical and mental health, he was not a danger to the public. "I have little doubt that there are those in this court who believe that this is not an adequate order," he said. "That is not for them to decide, that is for me. No other sentence is practical in the circum-stances." Kerr was arrested in 1997 after a former patient made a complaint to the police. Ensuing media publicity led to 13 other women coming forward with allegations of rape and indecent assault.

webTitle: Civil servants blamed in BSE inquiry will not be disciplined

fields.headline: Civil servants blamed in BSE inquiry will not be disciplined
fields.trailText: December 19 2000: Billion pound BSE fiasco results in no action.
fields.body:
The government has decided no civil servant should be disciplined as a result of the £4bn BSE fiasco, which has blighted agriculture and soured diplomatic relations with France and Germany.

Fifteen civil servants and five ministers were criticised by Lord Phillips's inquiry into the disaster. Many of the civil servants have subsequently resigned or retired.

Ministers responded to the Phillips report two months ago by setting up a review led by Sheila Forbes, a civil service commissioner. Her recommendations may be published in the next few days to lift the shadow hanging over the civil servants' careers.

In setting up the Forbes inquiry, the agriculture secretary, Nick Brown, hinted strongly he was personally opposed to disciplinary action against civil servants.

He told MPs last month: "Whenever serving public servants are subjected to criticism by a public inquiry, the question arises whether any form of disciplinary action should be taken".

He then quoted from the Phillips report, which said: "If those criticised were misguided, they were nonetheless acting in accordance with what they conceived to be the proper performance of their duties".

Mr Brown also stressed in his Commons statement that some of the individuals criticised receive praise from the inquiry, but there is no corresponding list of individuals who are praised.

The Phillips inquiry criticised the individuals, mainly in the Ministry of Agriculture and Department of Health, on the grounds that they should have acted differently in light of the information that they had available at the time.

The bulk of the criticism cen tered on civil servants failing to do more to bring the potential dangers of BSE to ministers attention.

Civil servants criticised include William Rees, chief veterinary officer between 1980 and 1988, and his successor up to 1997, Keith Meldrum.

The report also highlighted deficiencies by Sir Keith Calman the chief medical officer to 1998.

Phillips also attacked the head of the ministry of agriculture animal health division Robert Lowson.

The chief medical officer for Scotland between 1991-1996, Robert Kendell, was also criticised for making misleading statements about the safety of beef.

The report also criticised Thomas Eddy, head of Maff animal health (disease control) division from June 1993 for misleading minutes concerning the possibility that CJD cases in young people might prove to be linked with BSE.

webTitle: Credit card frenzy leads to debt society

fields.headline: Credit card frenzy leads to debt society
fields.standfirst:
Consumer credit of £159bn a year partly fuelled by competitive rates which encourage users

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: When the creditors began phoning and knocking at their door, Angela Adams and her husband, Roy, ignored them at first.
fields.body:
When the creditors began phoning and knocking at their door, Angela Adams and her husband, Roy, ignored them at first.

They told their friends and family to ring a few times, hang up, then phone back so that the call would be answered. "It was like a password," Angela said. But then the phone was cut off.

Angela and Roy, from Ward End, Birmingham, owed around £60,000 in unsecured loans - a huge sum for them, but nationwide just a tiny part of a mountain of consumer debt which has grown by more than 60% in four years as credit cards proliferate and attitudes to debt change.

Their problems began five years ago when Roy lost his job with TNT only three weeks before Christmas. "We were living beyond our means," Angela said.

"My husband had quite a good job and so we bought lots of things on credit. When he lost the job, we couldn't afford to pay back the loans, we just buried our head in the sand and dug ourselves in deeper and deeper.

"We wrote letters to the creditors asking if they would accept lower payments, but they wouldn't accept that."

The couple were not alone in their difficulties. According to David Cairns, managing director of Debtcall, which operates a free telephone advice line, we are now living in a debt driven society.

He said last month broke all records when people borrowed more than £1bn on their credit cards. Part of the reason is the advent of more competitive rates which encourages people to use their cards more.

"They have also developed some neat little tricks such as encouraging long term clients to pay a low rate as long as they keep using their credit cards every month. Lenders have become involved in a feeding frenzy because there are so many credit cards and loans available."

The office of fair trading says that the total amount of consumer credit, including loans, has increased by more than 60% in four years and is now running at £159bn a year. The average debt per person on unsecured loans (those excluding mortgages) is £2,500. There has been a 37% increase in queries about debt at Citizens Advice Bureaux in the last two years.

By December 1999, the average debt per credit card was £717, a rise of 50% in four years. It is estimated that 31% of people have more than £250 owing on their credit cards.

Earlier this year the Department of Trade and Industry set up a debt task force in an attempt to combat the rising tide of credit card debt. Kim Howells, the minister for consumer affairs, said the problem had been building up for five years.

"This is partly caused by a fundamental cultural change," he said. "People seem to have evolved a different attitude and they are not as worried about being in debt.

"There has also been a change in the way that banks and other lenders market their products. People seem to be inundated with offers of credit cards now. The upside of this marketing is that it offers lots of financial products to people, but the downside is if they do not get it right then it can lead to trouble."

Malcolm Hurlston, chairman of the Consumer Credit Counselling Service, said there was a lot of social pressures on people around Christmas. "Credit cards are the most convenient way of spending and borrowing money in the short term because there is no arrangement fee. But because they are so convenient, it can leads to problems.

"The people most at risk are those on regular, but low, incomes who had generally been pillars of the community in terms of repayment. But because of the increasing social pressures, they are at risk of getting into debt."

The office of fair trading advises people to work out their monthly budget, to shop around for the best deal and not to buy on impulse. Customers should check the annual percentage rate on loans, to read the small print and always open post as credit card statements do not go away.

Angela and Roy Adams were lucky in that their family helped them out. Their credit rating remains in tatters and they face a string of county court judgments, but they are slowly paying off their debts.

"It is far too easy to go into a place and get money," Mrs Adams said. "Just the other day I got an offer of a credit card with a £1,000 limit. I just tore up the leaflet and put it in the bin.

"I am much more sensible with money now. If any of my friends get into debt, then I can advise them what to do."

webTitle: Review: Stockhausen/AcoustICA

fields.headline: Stockhausen/AcoustICA
fields.standfirst:
ICA, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Karlheinz Stockhausen took his place as one of the greats of contemporary music thanks to the seismic impact of his works of the 1950s and 1960s. AcoustICA, the organisers of the ICA's Stockhausen Day, focused on pieces written during this period, as well as later works by other composers that revealed the consequences of Stockhausen's work.

The final work in the day's two concerts was the oldest: the 1953 Kontra-Punkte, performed by the Contemporary Arts Ensemble under Zsolt Nagy. It synthesises the wizardry of Stockhausen's complex compositional procedures with profound musical expression. In 1953 the piece was shockingly acerbic; in 2000, Stockhausen's integration of structure with drama is stunningly complete. Nagy and his players performed Kontra-Punkte with delicacy, as the texture gradually thinned from the full ensemble of 10 instruments to solo piano.

Benjamin Kobler's virtuosity at the piano was crucial to the success of Kontra-Punkte. In the earlier concert, he demonstrated the range of his gifts in four of the 11 Klavierstücke Stockhausen composed in the 1950s. Klavierstück V was a series of self-contained, fantastical gestures. In contrast, No VII focused on the resonances of repeated notes. Individual pitches were surrounded by brilliant fluorescences of harmonic and rhythmic colour. The compact pyrotechnics of VIII were followed by Klavierstück XI, one of the first pieces in which the performer, not the composer, chooses the order of the musical events. Kobler had prepared his own score of the work, rather than leaving those decisions to be made spontaneously during the performance. Even if this robbed the piece of its theatrical element, there was no doubting the quality of Kobler's playing.

At the start of the day, percussionist Laszlo Hudacsek gave a scintillating account of Zyklus, a piece that extends the bold violence of many of the Klavierstücke. But there is another side to Stockhausen's music, revealed by a performance of Refrain. Written in 1959 and scored for piano, percussion and celeste, it turns its players into an ensemble of glittering music-boxes. Responding to each other with vocal clicks and percussive bells and gongs, Kobler, Hudacsek and Nagy brought a beguiling theatricality to their performance.

There was more theatre in the second concert in Claude Vivier's piece Bouchara, performed by the Contemporary Arts Ensemble with soprano Sarah Leonard. Setting Vivier's own, invented language, Bouchara contained music that was both sensual and primeval. Enhancing the work's air of mysterious ritual, the piece culminated in elemental tape sounds. Sinan Savaskan's Unique Strands, Circular Functions and Portofino, a world premiere, grew impressively from a luminous wash of colour to a striking climax. And Stefan Wolpe's Piece for Two Instrumental Units returned to the structuralism of the 1960s, with music of glorious modernist abandon.

But the real revelation was a performance of Stockhausen's groundbreaking 1960 piece Kontakte. This work was among the first written for both live musicians and tape; everything that the composer had achieved before seems to be distilled in it. The richness of the relationships between the live and electronic sounds, and between the players, made for a brilliantly poised performance.

webTitle: Review: The Messiah

fields.headline: Slippery satire in Brent's Messiah
fields.standfirst:
The Messiah
Bush Theatre, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
The Messiah
Bush Theatre, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The National Theatre of Brent, which has brought its 17-year-old Messiah back for Christmas, pulls off a cunning double bluff. On the one hand, it satirises theatre's epic pretensions and earnest solemnity; on the other, it suggests that two hapless actors accompanied by a Handelian singer can, in some strange way, evoke the magic of the nativity. In that sense, the Brent duo become the modern equivalent of the rude mechanicals in A Midsummer Night's Dream.

But the basic joke is at the expense of theatre itself. As Desmond Olivier Dingle (Patrick Barlow) and his sidekick Raymond Box (John Ramm) attempt to transport us back to the Holy Land, we are reminded both of theatre's hierarchical structure and its frequent vanity. Desmond is bossy, smug, self-important and deeply sceptical about poor Raymond's weekly acting class with Mrs Cotes in Staines. But, as we watch two actors attempting to encompass the Roman census or the jostling Nazarene populace, I thought of those self-deluding occasions when theatre optimistically imagines it can easily evoke epic experience: a recent War and Peace, for instance, when the Battle of Borodino was fought out with kitchen cutlery.

Very old jokes also mix with a microcosmic study of theatre practice. We get the unstoppable singer, the over-insistent recorded brass and even subtle wordplay, reminiscent of Benny Hill, on Uranus. But the reminder that in the interval we can buy wise men flip-flops, or Herod tea towels, echoes theatre's current dependence on marketing. And, so slippery is the satire, I'm not even sure whether its confusion of the virgin birth with the immaculate conception is an authentic mistake or simply a reflection on Desmond's theological vagueness.

Neatly directed by Loveday Ingram, the show both sends up modern theatre and offers a very funny study of an archetypal bully-and-stooge relationship. The best moment comes when the overweening Desmond, voted a cardboard actor on an audience show-of-hands, flounces out into the Goldhawk Road threatening never to return. But although Barlow, Ramm and Kate Flowers as a pushy soprano keep their tongues mainly in their cheeks, the climactic moment when a twinkling model Bethlehem is trucked on to suitably jubilant chords goes beyond satire. The trick of the National Theatre of Brent, having demolished all our expectations, is to show that theatre can, after all, evoke the momentous.

 Until February 3. Box office: 020-7610 4224.

webTitle: Review: El Nino

fields.headline: El Nino gives forceful voice to the nativity
fields.standfirst:
El Nino
Chatelet, Paris
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
El Nino
Chatelet, Paris
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Is it an opera or is it an oratorio? John Adams ducks the question of categorising his latest large-scale choral work, El Nino, by refusing to give it any kind of description. The Paris premiere was staged by Peter Sellars, and the music critics who turned up in droves to witness it no doubt expected a grand spectacle, a successor to Adams's acclaimed large-scale operas Nixon in China and The Death of Klinghoffer. This retelling of the nativity story is certainly not that, but what we did see and hear was much harder to pin down.

Adams has said he wrote the piece as a way of trying to understand what is meant in biblical terms by a miracle (his working title was How Could This Happen?). So his beautifully varied libretto draws on the Old and New Testaments, as well asalternative sources such as the Gnostic Infancy Gospels, and intersperses the sequence with texts by later Hispanic writers. Though the biblical narrative, from the annunciation to the flight into Egypt, is preserved, it is only one element in a much more elaborate literary tapestry.

Though the title brings with it associations of natural disasters and, by extension, what Adams calls the "alarming force" that is part and parcel of miracles, the total effect of El Nino is more like a meditation on these events than a theatrical presentation of them, while the music itself, often quiet and reflective, only rarely barnstorming or dramatic, and never celebratory, does not drive the story forward so much as enhance it in other, more subtle ways. In its mood and purpose the result seems far closer to Berlioz's l'Enfance du Christ, say, than it is to Handel's Messiah, let alone a genuinely operatic work.

For that reason especially, it would have been much easier to appreciate the special qualities of the score for the first time in a concert performance rather than in the theatrical framework that Sellars has devised. A specially shot film is projected throughout the almost two hours of music, reinterpreting the events of the nativity in present-day West Coast terms as a drama involving a group of Hispanics: Mary and Joseph are a young, homeless couple, the Three Kings are reincarnated as LA cops, and so on. Mean while, some rather ineffectual choreography for a trio of dancers (who also appear in the film) is woven around the movements of the three soloists and the chorus.

Following this parallel narrative, with its rather over-familiar Sellars landscape of metaphors, only distracts from the music and the rich detail of the texts. The unfamiliar pyschological glosses from the gospel of James, the fairy tale-like anecdotes of dragons and magical palm trees from Pseudo-Matthew, the mysticism of Sor Juana Ines de la Cruz, and the wonderful rawness of the poems by Rosario Castellanos and Gabriela Mistral sometimes fail to register because there is too much information to absorb.

The performance, though, is remarkable. The playing of the Deutsches Symphonie under Kent Nagano, a long-time Adams champion, is wonderfully assured. All the details of the instrumentation, with its brittle edges provided by pairs of guitars and synthesisers, are in place, and the pacing of a score that often carries on where the seamless melodic flows of his last orchestral work, Naive and Sentimental Music, left off, seems utterly natural.

The soprano numbers are sung by Dawn Upshaw, whose tendency to make everything sound like Oklahoma! is cunningly exploited by Adams in numbers that recall the more introverted music of Nixon in China. The mezzo is allotted the majority of the Spanish-language settings in lyrical writing of the greatest beauty and intensity, and it is hard to imagine anyone delivering it more exquisitely than Lorraine Hunt Lieberson. Willard White is the baritone, making every word count, and vividly depicting both the alarm of Joseph when he discovers that Mary is pregnant, and the narration of Herod's anger.

A trio of countertenors from the Theatre of Voices support and echo the principals, though the chorus, the London Voices, do struggle to get their words across. More clarity will surely come with more performances, when it will also be possible to get to grips more completely with Adams's musical and literary achievement. The bad news is that El Nino will not reach London (the Barbican) until 2003.

 Performances until Saturday (box office: 00 33 1 40 28 28 40) and televised on BBC Knowledge next Saturday.

Mean while, some rather ineffectual choreography for a trio of dancers (who also appear in the film) is woven around the movements of the three soloists and the chorus. Following this parallel narrative, with its rather over-familiar Sellars landscape of metaphors, only distracts from the music and the rich detail of the texts. The unfamiliar pyschological glosses from the gospel of James, the fairy tale-like anecdotes of dragons and magical palm trees from Pseudo-Matthew, the mysticism of Sor Juana Ines de la Cruz, and the wonderful rawness of the poems by Rosario Castellanos and Gabriela Mistral sometimes fail to register because there is too much information to absorb. The performance, though, is remarkable. The playing of the Deutsches Symphonie under Kent Nagano, a long-time Adams champion, is wonderfully assured. All the details of the instrumentation, with its brittle edges provided by pairs of guitars and synthesisers, are in place, and the pacing of a score that often carries on where the seamless melodic flows of his last orchestral work, Naive and Sentimental Music, left off, seems utterly natural. The soprano numbers are sung by Dawn Upshaw, whose tendency to make everything sound like Oklahoma! is cunningly exploited by Adams in numbers that recall the more introverted music of Nixon in China. The mezzo is allotted the majority of the Spanish-language settings in lyrical writing of the greatest beauty and intensity, and it is hard to imagine anyone delivering it more exquisitely than Lorraine Hunt Lieberson. Willard White is the baritone, making every word count, and vividly depicting both the alarm of Joseph when he discovers that Mary is pregnant, and the narration of Herod's anger. A trio of countertenors from the Theatre of Voices support and echo the principals, though the chorus, the London Voices, do struggle to get their words across. More clarity will surely come with more performances, when it will also be possible to get to grips more completely with Adams's musical and literary achievement. The bad news is that El Nino will not reach London (the Barbican) until 2003.  Performances until Saturday (box office: 00 33 1 40 28 28 40) and televised on BBC Knowledge next Saturday.

webTitle: Review: Vampire with a Nazi bite

fields.headline: Vampire with a Nazi bite
fields.standfirst:
Nosferatu the Visitor
Contact, Manchester
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Nosferatu the Visitor
Contact, Manchester
Rating: **
fields.body:
Written and directed by Jonathan Holloway for his own theatre company, Red Shift, this is a curious reworking of Bram Stoker's Dracula. Holloway obviously has a keen appreciation of the vampire genre and the classic Nosferatu films, for this stylish production has an atmosphere of low-budget horror meets film noir, but can you take the vampire from the story, the teeth-marks from the neck, and retain the terrible foreboding?

Updating the story to a post-war London of dapper suits and trilbys, Holloway attempts to transpose the sexual tensions of the original, while giving the physician, Van Helsing, an unspeakable past. Dutch in Stoker's novel, Van Helsing is here a German haunted by Nazi atrocities, and this allows Holloway to use the blood motif as symbolic of the quest for racial purity. No need then for Count Dracula and his blood-suckers - this is Nosferatu as the spectre of German war-guilt. Richard Heap's Van Helsing is a commanding hybrid of intellectual arrogance and fevered remorse, but the Nazi undercurrent doesn't quite cohere.

Holloway's script feels as if it began as a straight adaptation of Stoker's novel and then tried to turn elsewhere. With a cast of only four, doubling-up is required; but even so, important characters in the novel - not least Mina and Jonathan Harker - are introduced far too late.

Confusingly, Harker's journal is either narrated by Van Helsing or recited by a voice-over. And in the scene where Renfield drinks Dr Seward's blood, the drama is curtailed when the doctor steps to the front of the stage to tell us what happened next.

Still, there are strong performances, particularly from Matthew Lloyd Davies, who measures every step to good effect as the timid but tenacious Jack Seward, doctor at the asylum and the foil to Van Helsing's inscrutable gravity. Keith Lancaster as the fly-eating madman Renfield, meanwhile, does not quite compare to Tom Waits's brilliantly tongue-curling performance in the 1992 Francis Ford Coppola film of Dracula. And what's more, he sounds worryingly like William Hague.

Lucy Burden has more success as Lucy Westenra, affording her a tortured girlishness with a squeaky voice and some wonderfully concerned expressions.

As befits the genre, there are elements of self-parody - how else can you get away with all that howling wind and screaming? - and the production is big on melodramatic music, dry ice, fake blood and a rotating minimalist set designed to screen every shift of shadow and light. Yet the play lacks the sensuality of the original, the self-indulgent lushness that made it both sexy and scary.

You can rest assured, though, that the Count will come again.
